name: VilVite Bergen Science Center

photo.caption: Experience the pull of gravity in our G-Force bike. The only one of its kind in Europe!

ranking_subcategory: #8 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #8 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #8 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: Come to VilVite - Bergen Science Center - to explore and enjoy science!

reviews.title: My kids love it!
reviews.text:
We bought the Bergen pass and entry fee was covered by the pass (understand that entry fees may not be covered by the Bergen pass all year round. Ie period of exclusion exist). Walking distance from light rail station. 
The acitivities and exhibits are engaging, even for my Wife and I, the moment we entered the centre. My older kids particularly liked the Sentrifugal-skapen which is a 360 deg “roller coaster” on the bicycle. The other was making bubbles that are as tall as us. Also a huge interactive physical model that allows kids to play with and understand the concept of hydro power generation. The list goes on.

reviews.title: Hands on heaven
reviews.text: We loved every minute of the 3 hours we spent here. The grandchildren (5 and 3) would have happily stayed for longer, and the grown ups loved it too.

reviews.title: Great fun
reviews.text: Very interactive place for kids and adults, loads of fun, hands on things and explanations how things work. Great day out in this rainy weather.

reviews.title: Worth the trip
reviews.text: My husband and are in our 60's and we enjoyed "playing" in the science center.  It is small but still fun and was free in October with the Bergen card.  Our only tip is to skip the g force bike if you are prone to motion sickness.  Neither one of us noticed it until shortly after we got off.  It was fun but five hours later, we both feel somewhat nauseous.

reviews.title: Kids loved it
reviews.text: We visited VilVite Centeret to times now. My children (4,8,12) loved it. Lots of things to try and do. It is kind of expensive but worthy once in a while. You need at least 3-4 hours to enjoy everything they have.

reviews.title: This is the best kids under 100 years old
reviews.text:
If you had kids under 100 years old, you must go here. The pictures I took here showed everyone from my youngest, through teenagers to in laws happy, smiling and laughing.

You better arrive early as there is so much to do and nobody will want to leave. At closing time the staff have to persuade people to leave!

reviews.title: Reserve One Whole Day if you have Kids
reviews.text:
Although Bergen Science Centre (VilVite) isn't listed under "Children's Highlights" in the Lonely Planet guidebook, it should be. 

There are plenty of interactive games for us to spend a full day with two eight-year-old kids. Of course, remember that you can pop in and pop out for one whole day, as long as you have paid for the entrance ticket. 

An additional (unexpected) activity for us is finding an open area just outside Bergen Science Centre and, hurray, free time in the playground. My daughter quickly came to see the opportunities to play tag (which, I strongly believe, is itself an inherently good thing to do, besides learning science).

reviews.title: A Hidden Gem in Bergen
reviews.text: If you are traveling with Young Children go to Vilvite you will not regret it. it's a place where the children have a lot of option to experiment their science knowledge hand on .. very helpful staff and a lot of science experiments

name: Vidden Trail between Mt. Floyen and Mt. Ulriken

photo.caption: The cabel care taht brings you to Mt. ulriken 643m

ranking_subcategory: #4 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #4 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #4 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: Bergen Classic. Hiking from Mount Ulriken to Mt Floyen. Vidden trail.
Panoramic Hike Across Vidden: From Ulriken to Floyen
Hike and cabin experience at Vidden, Bergen

reviews.title: This activity is not safe enough to be in the top 10 for Bergen
reviews.text:
I did the Vidden Trail, and thoroughly enjoyed the 4 or so hours, and 17 km, it took me to complete, including walking off Mt Floyen into town. The views were stunning and the remoteness so close a big city quite breath-taking.

But this is a serious hike. You need the right clothes, the right footwear for rock scrambling and mud, you need water and sustenance. There is no clear "trail" to speak of, rather a set of spread out markers and you get to pick your own way through the rocks to get to them. The markers are in the form of rock cairns, or simple bare metal poles sticking out of the earth. They are not signposted. I almost took a wrong turn in the first kilometer, starting from the Mt Ulriken end. There were times when I realized I had passed other people going the other way without even noticing them until they were well past me. Possibly other people were on the trail I never saw. It actually feels quite remote at its furthest from the city. At one point I was literally scrabbling up and down the rocks with my hands, all by myself.

If you go the other way, starting from Mt Floyen, closer to the city center, then everything is deceptively clear and easy to start with. This hike gets tough after descending the other side of Floyen though. I saw a triplet of naive American tourists in skimpy outfits and equally skimpy footwear, saying they could throw their shoes away, just after hitting the first of 10km of mud and rocks and before the first real climb. I have to wonder how much further they got.

So please take heed: this trail is not for everyone, it is not a gentle Sunday stroll through a park, there are no facilities between the beginning and end except for a few rescue huts. It's not safe for anyone that's not confident with a bit of off-trail walking.

reviews.title: Recommended when the weather is fine
reviews.text: We decided to hike the trail from Floyen to Ulriken and were pretty happy about that as it looks not so easy to find the start from Ulriken. We didn`t use funicular or cable car as when walking you can catch a number of nice views. The trail itself changes from a nice gravel path to stony terrain marked with cairns that make navigation pretty easy.

reviews.title: very nice walk
reviews.text: we were there as a family and it is a very nice easy walk to do. No need for poles for those who use them

reviews.title: Challenging but oh so worth it
reviews.text: I wouldn’t say it’s an easy hike at all mainly because you have to scramble over rocks and pick your own paths for for at least 8km. It was very much an up and down hike but certainly easier going from Mt Ulriken. If you are not sure footed and not happy to scramble over big rocks then I’d advise against walking there. We saw kids there but yet again unless they are like mountain goats you’d better walk elsewhere. The views were to die for and we loved the ever changing vistas. The reservoirs contain drinking water so we filled our water bottles up there (following the locals). Talking to locals they put the hike in the same category as Trolltunga and that is classified as extreme.

reviews.title: Not difficult but slow
reviews.text: This hike took us 5 hrs but mostly because the terrain is rocky and muddy and requires careful placement of steps. Going from Ulriken to Floyen is mostly downhill so the hike is not physically challenging for the sure footed. You will want shoes with good traction. I should mention that it has been raining which makes conditions more slick. Also be sure to allow time for queue at the gondola. The line for us started at the entrance doorway and took about an hour. It is a beautiful hike even on a rainy day.

reviews.title: Spectacular hike!
reviews.text: Very picturesque hike and very common for Bergeners. Rather demanding one, so you should be prepared for a mountain trail which is worth every step! Waterproof shoes/boots and a wind stopper should be on your packing list if you are planning to walk that trail.

reviews.title: A really nice 5 hour hike
reviews.text: I hiked from Ulriken to Floyen a beautiful Friday with sun and approximate 20 degrees and I really enjoyed it. However, I would not recommend the hike to less experienced persons who might have issues with rocky paths, slippery clay and steep descends. It took me a bit more than 4.5 hours to hike the 13 kilometers and the best part of it was the views. However, be aware that you should bring food and drinks for the hike and that there is few, if any trash bins along the route.

reviews.title: Beautiful Hike but not for everyone
reviews.text: Great hike with wonderful views. We really enjoyed this hike between Mt. Ulriken and Mt. Floyen but this hike isn't for everyone. It took us about 6.5 hrs to complete the full hike, we stopped along the way to take pictures and enjoy the views, if we didn't stop as much we probably would have finished in 4.5 hrs. I would recommend starting at the top of Mt. Ulriken and finishing at Mt. Floyen. We took the cable car to the top of Mt. Ulriken, if you're feeling really ambitious you can hike to the top. The last 5th of the hike or so was on a gravel path or was paved, our legs thanked us for finishing with an easier walk at the end. We took the funicular back into the Bergen city center but one could walk down if they wanted to. This hike was difficult and one should be in good shape to do it. There were several parts where we had to climb up and down rocks like mountain goats carefully picking our path. We wore waterproof hiking shoes and dressed in layers. By the end of the trek we were a bit muddy and tired. For reference we are in our mid-20s and in moderate to decent shape. We have done a lot of hiking in the U.S. Rocky Mountain National Park and had somewhat of an idea of what to expect on the Vidden Trail. The path was well marked and while it wasn't very busy we did see other people on the trail.

reviews.title: So scenic
reviews.text: I loved this trail! It was easy to follow, long, but not too hard. The views from this trail are absolutely breathtaking!

reviews.title: Bus then cable car stunning views
reviews.text: A wonderful place. You can walk down but it takes a few hours. The views were stunning. Very windy but a great place to have coffee at the top.

reviews.title: Stunning, but challenging!
reviews.text:
We hiked up Floyen, then across to Ulriken on a bit of a whim. We should have been slightly better prepared but that's completely our own fault. We got by absolutely fine - total of 4 hrs 30 (including lots of pics and exploring) - but could of done with having some water with us - oops! The restaurant at Ulriken was amazing - incredible burger and a decent traditional meat broth!
If you're doing the hike - just go better prepared than we were 🙈 otherwise, it was amazing!

reviews.title: windy walk
reviews.text: A great trip with amazing views,  all be it a little windy on the day we done this .. Ild say you need a reasonable fitness level but if you don't just take your time and it will be fine .

reviews.title: Wonderful hike in and out of trees.
reviews.text: It's a good workout with great views toward the top of the mountain and thick woods below, around the tram base.  The trail is rocky in many places and washed out in others, so hiking poles were a big help.  The views are wonderful.

reviews.title: Nice rates nice place
reviews.text:
I went there, the staff are nice the food was good, and there are places to relax 
I will recommend that place

reviews.title: Vidden In Early July
reviews.text:
My husband & I (30 y/o) with intermediate hiking experience and his two sisters (mid 20s) hiked this trail starting around 1030 am in early July. Weather was gorgeous; started with a light jacket and shorts but didnt need the jacket after the first hour. We took the My Ulriken cable car up; hiked the trail to Floyen and hiked down Floyen to our AirBNB which was so wonderfully situated right above the Floibanen station in Bergen. The main Vidden trail from the top of Ulriken to Summit of Foyen took us about 5 hours. We werent going particularly fast or slow; moderately paced taking lots of pictures. The weather was wonderful and the trail was great. It was a weekday but the trail was well traveled. Although we certainly didn't have it to ourselves,everyone on the trail was pleasant and respectful. There was plenty of space between hikers (most of the time people were just small dots ahead and behind). It was certainly NOT something that should keep you from doing the trail. Make sure to bring plenty of water & snacks (there is no where to get any along the way obviously). Bring layers for changes of weather as you are pretty exposed atop the fjord plateau if the weather takes a turn (luckily we had perfect weather the whole day through). Sunscreen is a must as the sun is intense up there. And bring your wallet for a drink at Floyen upon completion!
Recs:
- Definately start from Ulriken to Floyen; otherwise you have a lot of uphill
- Use the restrooms at the top of Ulriken before you go -- again its exposed most of the hike so it can be difficult to find a private space.
- Take the Ulriken up; we took a taxi from the Bryggen harbor to the loading site 
- Bring your camera it is absolutely stunning

reviews.title: A great walk, can be done in both directions
reviews.text: Very beautiful, not very difficult but quite long 6 to 7 hours, between to the two summits, longer if you skip the lifts and walk up and down.Tough walking the 650m up or down Ulriken. Well worth the effort. The weather can change quickly, be prepared!

reviews.title: A challeging little walk.
reviews.text: Started on the moutain train to Floyen. Took about 2 minutes to get to the top at circa £5 each way. At the top there are stunning views of Bergen below. We wete lucky as it was a clear sunny day. The trail itself is easy to follow and well marked. There are a couple of rocky climbs so I would give this a moderate to grading. The hike with a number of nreaks to enjoy the scenes, took around 6 hours. It could probably be done on around 4.5 hours. At Ulriken yhe gondala down is about £28 each going down. The main trail down was closed but takes around 45 minutes. We had to take diversion, which for a couple of 50+ year olds was difficult and not recommended. The climbs were very rocky and steep. On a wet day this would be quite dangerous. Overall We really enjoyed it.

reviews.title: Ulriken Zip line for thrillseekers.
reviews.text: If you want a real rush, that is both a bit scary and at the same time a ultimate rush, i recomend Ulriken Zip line. The start is right behind the restaurant at the top of the mountain, and has 300 meters down to base. (end of the line). You can order your ticket online by looking up: Ulriken Zip line. This is known as the fastest Zip line in Norway. And the price of 300 NOK it`s a must to try. Breathtaking view, if you manage to concentrate on that. During your ride. Have fun.

reviews.title: Wonderful Fjellhike right abvove the cirty of Bergen
reviews.text: You not not have a huge backpack an five deays of time to experience the wolrd of Norwegioan Fjells. Just take thy cable car Ulriken and hike to Flyer (this directionrecommended. You just need good shoes, a certain fitness, something to drink and around 5 hours of time. Not recommended in fog and really bad weather.

name: Stoltzekleiven

photo.caption: View from the top of Stoltzekleiven (Sandvikspilen)

ranking_subcategory: #2 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #2 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #2 of 110 things to do in Bergen

reviews.title: Few Days in Bergen
reviews.text: I recommend this place especially for active people. Amazing views of the port, city and the islands of Askøy and Sotra. You must be there if you are in Bergen.

reviews.title: Wonderful View
reviews.text:
I prefer categorizing here as Scandic Dubrovnik, however it owns additional attraction than Dubrovnik.
It’s more friendly touching including hiking and other outing activities.
Wondering how it looks like in winter period? The thing is sure that summer visit is amazing! 
If your visiting time is allowed, suggest do hiking activity. Of course, just stay there and enjoy the view moment is also interesting.
There’re many nationality visitors coming over here. Everyone is exciting once he/she   climbs on top of hill. 
If time limited without budget concerned, suggest taking tour package. There’re several hills around Bergen. This is highly recommended. 
Well prepared, then you will definitely love it.

禦寒衣物要穿上、避免受寒。有高像素攝影機也是必須。
總之、來了就不會後悔。從這到另一個景點Floyen 大約13Km 路程。若登頂，再步行下山也是不錯選擇。

reviews.title: Tough workout with an awesome view for a rewarad
reviews.text: This is a more-or-less vertical hike up to the arrow at the top of Sandviken. It takes me 45 minutes or so, as a well-aged hiker. I recommend it to those who want a challenge! Then walk back via Floyen.

reviews.title: Stoltzekleiven
reviews.text: This hiking tour was little bit difficult for us. Many steep places. We managed to come to the top of the mountain in 50min approximately. View on the North Sea is amazing.

reviews.title: A must for the fit tourist
reviews.text: Stoltzekleieven is a local tradition and often used as a rite of passage. People from Bergn may take you to Stoltzekleiven rather than a local gym. It is tough and steep, but what a reward when you are at the top. I highly recommend you make the trip.

reviews.title: 900 steps
reviews.text: These 900 steep steps will take you to the local mountains. If you are very fit, you can do them in 15 minutes, if not, you will need 30. And then you must get back down, which will take you an hour or so, as noone uses the stairs to get down.

reviews.title: Great walk up the mountainside
reviews.text: Stoltzekleiven is a steep rocky path and stairs in Bergen up towards Sandviksfjellet.  The stairs have about 908 steps.  According to measurements made by Norconsult in 2018, reproduced in Bergens Tidende 12.7.2018, the increase is 301.44 height meters, length 834 meters and average increase 36 percent

reviews.title: Workout for locals
reviews.text:
This is mainly stairs of rocks leading up to a part of the Floien mountain. It is steep, with each step so high that it needs a force to mount. It is also quite narrow, with no rail support. One will mainly meet locals making the stairs for exercise. 
An average tourist will have a better experience walking the ordinary Floyen pathway or going by funicular. The view from here is as good, and on the main top one may continue on an easy forest/ mountain walk.

reviews.title: Got the Blood Pumping
reviews.text: Hiked with Jana Morozova with Jandis AS tours.  She helped us pace ourselves so that we could make the top and at the top we were rewarded with a gorgeous view of Bergen harbor.  Jana provided us with crampons the last few hundred feet because it was icy, then took us down via a very scenic route.  What a day!!!!! Loved it.

reviews.title: The most challenging climb in Bergen
reviews.text: Stoltzekleiven is one of the most challenging climbs in Bergen. Not because of its difficulty, being as it is a stairway carved in stone. But the uneven terrain, the angle and distance between steps, makes it a very good training that shouldn't last more than 35 to 40 minutes. It makes your heart pump, for sure!

reviews.title: Quick workout
reviews.text: If you want to get a workout, but have little time. The stairs are a great way to get the sweat going right away. The view is an incredible reward on the top. You can continue to Fløien and go down from there, or you can go down Skredderdalen. It’s steep.

reviews.title: Sports/adventure
reviews.text:
Excellent placebo to push yourself up the steap stonestairs.
At the top the view' is breathtaking,just like gjetting up is 😂😉👍

reviews.title: Challenge
reviews.text: This is a steep challenge, but very satisfactory when reaching the top. You feel you've achieved something different. It's definitely not a walk in the park :-)

reviews.title: Perfect uphill exercize
reviews.text: If you enjoy walking or running uphill this is the perfect place. With an average gradient above 35 % and 300 metres climb you are sure to get a good exercize. At the top you can choose between different paths down or head towards Fløyen or toher mountains.

reviews.title: Not an ordinary mountain hike
reviews.text: A quiet difficult hike for beginners, but absolutely worth it when you get up there and experience the spectacular view over Bergen.

reviews.title: Beautiful view to Bergen
reviews.text:
It was wet morning when we climbed but rocks were not slippery. Steep but not too hard climb. 
Make sure you have a sturdy shoes and water. A beautiful lake on the top of mountain.  We went to floyen funicular from there. Good signage. Easy walk, beautiful forest and we really enjoyed hiking there. Well worth doing it if you like hiking.

reviews.title: Beautiful View All Around!
reviews.text: We loved Bergen, Norway. It's challenging to pick an item that we loved most, however, this view is just incredible. We really enjoyed the time here; the park, walking trails, the goats....

reviews.title: Strenuous but worthwhile
reviews.text: Get a taxi or bus to the beginning; then start the hike up, across many, many, stone stairs, but be aware it is very uneven, and steep. Have good walking shoes with good grip, also (it's Bergen) be prepared for rain and slippery. The view at the top is great. The (unwritten) rule is to hike up on the path, but take the "backroad" back to go down.

reviews.title: Exquisite.
reviews.text: Heaven on earth. Beautiful is a poor substitute for words. Go there, close your eyes take a deep breathe and enjoy the mountain air. Fill your lungs. Our major metropolis do not offer clear air. Open your eyes to enjoy ......!!

reviews.title: Very nice view
reviews.text:
It is a stunning view yes, but actually the other one the Ulrikken is better (above the hospital and the cable car up). You buy the tickets near the Bryggen and then hike the swindling alleys up halfway the mountain. But actually as you come as far up as taking the "train" ride up you have almost same view over the city as on top.
Yes take the hike up and enjoy the older very beautiful buildings but I suggest to save money and go to the Ulrikken instead. Bergen is beautiful !

reviews.title: Fitness Test
reviews.text: Test your fitness on the +-700 stone steps. And, at the end get rewarded by the immense view at the top! Also, the journey is through some stunning forestry. Definitely worth it for any adventure.

reviews.title: Hell and heaven
reviews.text: Stolzekleiven is a really hard up hill run. Will make your heart beat and your bloodstream singing in your ear. On the top you will find a fantastic view over Bergen. Advisable to go in daylight.

reviews.title: Nice walk stright up the mountain side
reviews.text: We were four friends that did this walk. Iam not the moust fit guy, but it was not so hard anyway. Gues it was about 40 minutes up, and a smal round trip. And another trail down. Best to do it when its not raining.

reviews.title: Need an exercise? Do this
reviews.text: Approx 100 steps up to the fantastic view of Bergen. Cross over to Fløien for the Return downtown. ENjoy a lunch at the Fløien before moving Down.

reviews.title: Only one with an umbrella.
reviews.text: We walked along the coast nutildags we found a pedestrian bridge. We crossed the bridge and went towards town on a path that led us to the begining of the path. Lots of local well trained either ran or walked briskly up and Down the path. We walked and took a lot of breaks partly to enjoy the wiev but more important to get our breath back. It started to rain. The locals didnot notice. They continued. I unfolded my umbrella, passed the halfway mark. It stated that I still had 509 steps to go. We reached the top. The rain stopped. We took some nice photos of Bergen before we continued our walk. We walked another route that took us back to the center of town. A lovely walk. We are 66 and 69 and not overly sporty.

reviews.title: Spectacular view of the whole city
reviews.text:
"The path is really really difficult to walk," said a local. Though we thought parking is more difficult. You need a parking license to park on street. There're also several street parking that only take coins(22kr/hr). Finally we found a machine in front of NLA University College that takes credit card. You can get a parking ticket here that allows you to park on street like residents.

The view is definitely worth to go. Just be sure to wear sport shoe and not carry too much. The path is not easy to walk.

reviews.title: Amazing view
reviews.text: Remember to wear good walking shoes or sneakers here. You will need the traction over the cobblestones which can be hard on the feet. But the view, but the view! It is beautiful. You can see all of Bergen which itself is beautiful. There are variations in terrain and hills and when it's over 90 degrees in July and humid it is not so easy. There is shade a tree coverage so its not that bad.

name: Gamle Bergen Museum - Bymuseet i Bergen

photo.caption: Familien promenerer i Gamle Bergen, foto Tove Breistein

ranking_subcategory: #10 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #10 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #10 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: In the 1800s Bergen was Europe’s biggest wooden city, a distinctive city environment with closely spaced wooden buildings, busy streets, markets and alleys. At old Bergen open air Museum you can experience some of this atmosphere, with houses from the eighteenth, nineteenth and twentieth centuries. What did it look like? What did people talk about? In beautiful natural surroundings you can meet both masters and servants from the past. Lunch at Gamle Bergen Tracteursted which is open June-August (closed mondays). Both the park and the restaurant can be visited without a ticket. Museumshop/small cafe. Open 2. may - 12 may from 10-15, 13. May (closed 17. May) - 9. september daily 9-16. 7 minutes with bus from the center or 30 minutes walk.

offer_list.title: Biking and Hiking in Bergen

reviews.title: Good but not a must see.
reviews.text: Gamle Bergen Museum is a little outside town. Take busses nr. 4, 5, 6 or 83 to get there. Takes about 10 mins by bus. Easy to find, just follow the signs and walk under the main road and you’re there. You pay a little further in the museum which is strange, because at that point you’ve seen most of it. It isn’t big and not fantastic. But what there is, is okay. It costs 120Nkr entrance, which is a lot for what it is. We had the Bergen Card, somitnwas free:))

reviews.title: Living history of Bergen
reviews.text: Restored old buildings to visit, several with living history interpreters to inform about life in 19th century Bergen.

reviews.title: Charming, But Not a Must-See
reviews.text: The Old Bergen Museum is an open air museum where wooden buildings from the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries have been set up as a village.  The landscaping and views of the sea from the hilltop are very nice.  However, for us, it was a case of “been there, done that”.  The buildings are similar to the ones in Bergen’s city center and other Scandinavian cities.  The houses were open for viewing, but we only walked into three of them.  We had read that there were performances and people dressed in period costumes, but we never saw any.  Perhaps we would’ve enjoyed the museum more if it had not been raining.  We just wanted to get out of the rain and cold.  The museum is not for people with mobility issues as this place requires walking uphill on cobblestones.

reviews.title: Interesting and entertaining
reviews.text: Nice assemblage of old Bergen buildings with appropriate equipage for each.  There was a complete old printshop, dentists office, bakery, photo studio and more.

reviews.title: Live actors in an old environment
reviews.text: We loved touring the old businesses and homes, and talking with the actors in them. They had performances out in the streets, too.

reviews.title: Bergen in miniature
reviews.text: Very interesting place with typical in 18th and 19th Norwegian houses. We saw there staff in clothes popular many centuries ago. Sea captain house, Bakery house, craftsman house, and many others. History in architecture

reviews.title: Museum was closed but great tour
reviews.text:
We took a 90 minute tour with Dane, a young man from Oslo who is a student at Bergen University. He led us around Bryggen sharing facts and stories about the history of Bergen. It was only his third time leading the tour and he did a great job entertaining us and keeping us engaged!
I recommend the tour!

reviews.title: Bergen in miniature
reviews.text: The most of buildings in this museum were not erected on the territory of the museum. They were relocated from various districts of Bergen. Today this is the showcase of Norwegian society in 18th century in architecture.

reviews.title: Closed outside the summer season but still able to visit
reviews.text: Outside the summer season the site is available to visit as it isn't fenced off, although there is noone present and the interior can only be viewed through the window. However, that means there's no entry price, and the buildings are in a nice location, with quite a lot visible through the windows.

reviews.title: Collection of old houses
reviews.text: Location of this museum is very close to Bergen center. 5 min by bus and you are there. Very interesting to walk there. Only wooden houses built 200 / 300 years ago

reviews.title: Visit with relatives
reviews.text: We enjoyed this visit as it was included in the Bergen pass. I would recommend visiting on a quiet day as the houses are small and you want to enjoy a peaceful crowd. Lots of history. The acting as guides were very good!

reviews.title: interesting and nice
reviews.text: fine atmosphere at nice place, houses are not so old but definetelly charming, liked local ducks and dogs, landscape form the view point is aslo beautiful

reviews.title: Try to visit it
reviews.text: It remained unclear from many articles on internet, could you visit it out of the season or not. The answer is yes, youcan come and walk among the houses from different eras (still, they look very much the same) but none will be open out of the season. You can take buses 3, 4, 5 and 6 and I think also some with higher numbers and get of at Gamle Bergen stop, cross the bridge over the road, go down the stairs on the left, go down the road towards the sea, and once the wall on the other side of the street ends (and that is the wall of Gamle Bergen or Old Bergen) turn to the left and you will see the gate. During the season they also have restaurant working. Watch out for the swing on the hill above the small lake, it is not fixed on the rope, so you can easily fell down.

reviews.title: Life in old Bergen, with lots of real, antique furnishings.
reviews.text:
Very casual museum with many old, original tools in actual old, wooden houses that were moved to this site, creating a small village.

Doctor and Dentist offices with old “tools of the trade”.  We visited after the normal tourist season, so we did not see the people in traditional dress.

Worth a bit for a couple hours.

reviews.title: An interesting walk in the past
reviews.text: A very interesting and well organised collection with roch collection of  excellent artifacts. Surprised by a small theatrical scene and the presence of actors who played very well their roles. Beautiful surrounding.

reviews.title: Worth the bus trip
reviews.text: This was totally worth it. It is a group of about 30 houses or shops and most were open. Very authentic and interesting.  Even a live drama

reviews.title: Lovely visit
reviews.text: The houses are meticulously reassembled and looked after. The actors are good at their job. The performance was lively and gives you quite a vivid image of what 18th century life was like in Bergen.

reviews.title: A step back in time
reviews.text: Strolling among these old buildings is like walking back in time. You hear the creaking wood under your feet, as you explore the buildings. Several actors and actresses, of all ages, enhance your interactive experience. Your journey will take at least one hour at a fast and crazy pace, but you can also spend over three hours and have plenty to do. I highly recommend this place for those who want more out of their museum experience!

reviews.title: A quirky way to learn about Bergen history
reviews.text: It is an eclectic collection of houses from 1700s, 1800s, and early 1900s.  The town provides a view of Bergen's history through viewing the  various types of middle class houses and interiors.  There is a short play depicting how the various economic strata interacted.  It provides an insight I didn't expect.

name: Lysoen and Ole Bull's Villa

photo.caption: Lysøen - Lysoen - and Ole Bull's Villa in Os

ranking_subcategory: #12 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #12 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #12 of 110 things to do in Bergen

reviews.title: Culture and hiking
reviews.text:
A beautiful island home of Ole Bull. Has plenty if hiking trails where the easy one suites families with small children (and trolleys). Amazing view from the top. For the less active one, there's the museum and cafeteria with free wifi!

Boat goes from Buena Quay (and back) once every hour and last ferry is 16:30. Cost 80 NOK per person and 30 per child (round trip).

reviews.title: Great walks on the island
reviews.text:
The sun came out as we were on the ferry so we decided to walk rather than go around the house. It is worth noting that if you do the same, you only pay for the ferry. Stunning views - do try and get to the high spots with amazing views of the fjord.
Loved the woods, the views and the tranquillity.

reviews.title: Worth the hassle to get there
reviews.text: It's a bit of a hassle to get to, but Ole Bull's Villa is just gorgeous. The home is small, but fantastic. We had an English tour that told us all about Ole Bull, his music, his nationalism. In the summer, there are concerts on Sundays, as well as a bus  from Bergen.

reviews.title: A lovely island and relaxing ride to get there
reviews.text: We went by bybanen and bus, followed by ferry, on a nice sunny day. Hiked up to the tower before touring the villa. Stopped for lunch on a sunny deck while waiting an hour for the bus back on the mainland (Sunday schedule in effect). A beautiful experience!

reviews.title: Wonderful slice of history, beautiful house and grounds reached by boat
reviews.text: The boat ride to and from this beautiful island gets you in the mood for a special experience. Ole Bull's house is charming, and the central concert hall one of the most beautiful spaces you can imagine. The extensive grounds are spectacular. Very highly recommended!

reviews.title: Home of my great great grandfather
reviews.text: This is an island of around 150 acres.  You can do a lot of walking and hiking.  A small cafe that has great waffles. Can also see small concerts in the music hall.

reviews.title: Opened our eyes to history we did not know about.
reviews.text: Went on a whim because we could see some of the countryside around Bergen.  Learned about Ole Bull's life and travels.  His home certainly reflects his favorite places he went and the love he felt for his homeland.  Great boat ride over and back to island.  Cafe was closed but we were the 1st boat of the day.  Staff was knowledgable and engaging in english as well.

reviews.title: Very interesting place to see
reviews.text: I would recommend this trip out to see Ole Bull's house. He was a famous musician in Bergen and built an interesting house out on the island. There is a short boat trip over from the dock where one can park. It was a lovely trip. And nearby there is also an old monastery where we visited and went for a nice walk.

reviews.title: Nice place outside Bergen, in lovely nature
reviews.text: This is a very nice island, where you can walk around on nice small roads, with beautiful nature and view.

reviews.title: Beautiful tour---beautiful island
reviews.text: Ole Bull is a Norwegian musical hero. His estate on Lysoen Island is architecturally very interesting...the scenery is magestic. The boat ride to the island is pleasant, giving a flavor of past times. The island is private, no person lives there, but it is a very nice place to spend time, to reflect and take in the beauty of this country. Learning about Ole Bull was interesting also.

reviews.title: Interesting Home
reviews.text: We traveled from Bergen on a rainy day to visit Lysoen and Ole Bull's summer home.  After a short boat ride we arrived at the villa which is a really unique building.  Bull designed it himself and included so many different types of architecture.  We first gathered for a very informative and interesting discussion of his life.  He really was a man ahead of his time!  I was surprised to learn of his connections to the US and the amount of time he spent here, as well as his "rock star" type of popularity in his home country.  A trip here is certainly worth the time!

reviews.title: Light on a gloomy day
reviews.text:
I visited the villa on a very rainy, foggy and gloomy day. I took the public bus to the pier and I was the only passenger on the boat to the island. Yeah, sensible people would stay indoors on a day like that :), but that offered me the privilege to enjoy the boat driver's kindness and conversation. With Bergen Card the bus rides and the boat ride to the island are free and so is the visit to the villa.
Few minutes into the trip, the villa revealed itself and it was nothing short of a fairy tale. Beautiful architecture, beautiful setting and breathtaking views. 
The walking paths on the island, paved with crushed shells, radiate from the house. You can have long walks (unfortunately I couldn't, because of the rain and the late time), but you cannot get lost, as Ole Bull's thought was that his guests should always find their way back to the house, from each and every spot on the island.
I was fortunate to have amazing Jelena as my "private" guide, me being the only English speaking visitor at that particular time. The tour was great, very informative, Jelena told me all the stories and anecdotes of the house, of Ole Bull and his family and of some of the objects and furniture pieces in the house.
But what stayed with me above all was the energy of the island (The Island of Light), the energy of the house and Jelena's smile and conversation. It was one of those fate-arranged encounters that leave an ever lasting mark on your soul.

reviews.title: Ole Bull Lyseon museum
reviews.text: Was amazing and I recommend taking the tour offered through the visitor center in city center. I made it for the last of their concert series and it moved me. The tour bus that gets you there will make it clear why you wanted to take the tour bus. Ole Bull influence shows up in many ways throughout Bergen so you will want to see the museum first if you can.

reviews.title: beautiful day and great boat ride to Lysoen
reviews.text: This was a wonderful excursion out to the island of Lysoen and the home of Ole Bull's Villa. The guide was very knowledgeable and the house is totally fascinating to visit. It is very accessible and the grounds are specular to say nothing of the boat ride to the island .

reviews.title: Amazing Summer Home ....
reviews.text: This is the eclectic summer home of a violin virtuoso who was a Norwegian revolutionary while simultaneously a friend both of the King of Sweden (which then 'owned' Norway) and the Tsar of Russia.  See it if you can.

name: Fantoft Stavkirke
ranking_subcategory: #18 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #18 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #18 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: Biking Tour and Grieg Concert in Bergen

reviews.title: Fantoft Stavkirke
reviews.text:
The original church, or rather whatever was left of it, was moved to Bergen from a small village some 200 miles away at the end of the 19th century. Since nobody knew how it really looked they modeled it on the Borgund Stavkirke decorating it with a steeple, dragon heads, etc. In 1992 the church burnt to the ground. They reconstructed it without even trying to recreate its medieval appearance while using modern materials and building techniques. So now it looks like it belongs to Disneyland. It's surrounded by a wire fence and if you want to simply get closer to this brand new Disney church, just behind the fence, you must pay 60 NOK right at the gate. Nice. 
 
If you drive there, there's a small parking lot for buses on the right, but I don't think cars are allowed there. If you drive past it there's a parking lot of some company on the left where I saw some visitors park their cars. You can also try to find a spot on the street leading to the bus parking. From there it's a 5 minute walk thru a nice wooden area.

reviews.title: Beautiful!
reviews.text: If you are interested to see stave churches, this one is one of the most beautiful. The site around the church is also beautiful. It's kind of a forest. It was a shame I didn't have more time to spend there because I would have love to walk and wander around. Definitely recommend it.

reviews.title: Cool lil wooden church
reviews.text:
This place is a bit out of the way, definitely not walkable. Had to take the light rail for quite a number of stops to get there. And the sign to walk up the hill wasn’t super clear, I initially walked towards someone’s garage lol 
An interesting place to visit, smells good inside from all the wood haha

reviews.title: Norway Medieval Wooden Church
reviews.text: This is an accurate recreation of the original hundreds year old church which burned down. From where our tour bus parked we walked uphill thru the woods and saw the church in a clearing. It is beautiful and fascinating with complex architectural detail. There are very few of the Stave churches left so do see this if you have the opportunity.

reviews.title: Fascinating Stave church on top of a hill
reviews.text: Fantoft Stave Church is fully restored, after being burned down some years ago. Tiny, but gorgeous. Worth the bus ride and climb to get there.

reviews.title: Both simple and complex, it is a lovely church
reviews.text: From Bergen, we took a train to visit.  It was a short hike to the church.  It was a very interesting church. The wood construction was both simple and complex.  It is very interesting to those interested in churches or architecture.  They had a person who could provide a lot of information about the church and its history.  Children would be bored though.

reviews.title: Be prepared to walk!
reviews.text: It's a long walk uphill from the light rail but worth it in the end. Signage is poor and google did a bad job of routing us. The church is remarkable with a setting in the forest. The interior is definitely modern but still with breath taking artistry and the exterior is like nothing I have ever seen before.

reviews.title: Reconstructed
reviews.text: Lovely carvings in this small chapel, but really not a lot to see for your 500metre detour. Reconstructed.

reviews.title: Beautiful reconstruction of a stave church
reviews.text: It's interesting to look at, but there are no tours or information packets. The ticket takers can answer questions.

reviews.title: Lovely reconstruction of iconic stave church
reviews.text: It was well worth the cost of a cruise excursion to have an in-person visit to a Norwegian stave church. The Fantoft Church is a modern reconstruction using all the traditional techniques and materials, i. e., nothing but wood. I was surprised at how tiny it is. The pervasive smell of wood shavings was really evocative. Highly recommend.

reviews.title: Great Example of a Stave Church
reviews.text: It is only a 5 minute walk through the woods to this church and it is a perfect way to approach this historic building. Yes, it is true that the church has been moved here and, yes, large parts have been replaced over the centuries. Nevertheless, it is a wonderful example of the blend of Chrian and Viking pagan symbols and well worth a visit. Be warned, the church is small and try to avoid the crowds of tourists by visiting early or late.

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: Took the tram from central Bergen to Fantoff, turn first left and carry on up the hill for about 10-12mins. Luckily it was open on my morning visit and entry was free using the Bergen Card. Very small inside and upon leaving the attendant was advising a party of people to stay at the gate while the current visitors toured around.

reviews.title: Old church
reviews.text: As I know there are only a few similar old churches remained in the world. At the roof there are placed dragon heads. our guide told us about the history of dragons in Norway

reviews.title: Just an outside visit
reviews.text: I had to see that place when I was already in the region. Nice walk in the forest to get there from the park. Church itself was closed but it did looked fantastic from the outside. Careful with open fire-sorry, I had to do it  ;-)

reviews.title: Interesting, Old church
reviews.text: By walking in, I did not know what to expect. It is impressive.. A church built so long ago entirely of wood and it is still standing there today intact. Worth the visit. After that, visit the eatery. They have some interesting home cooked food and it is tasty. You gotta hurry if it is lunch hour. It gets sold out fast.

reviews.title: Stave Church in Mossy Forest
reviews.text:
Stave church in Fantoft located in Fana borough of Bergen and quite close to railway station Fantoft.

Stave church in Fantoft is located on a hill and surrounded by old trees with mossy roots and rocks covered with lichen. First and original stave church was moved from Fortun to Fantoft in 1883. Unfortunately in 1992 was burnt by arson connected with early Norwegian black metal scene. The current form of a stave church in Fantoft we owe to 20th-century architect Egil O. Laastad who designed it and two architects J. L. Andersen and K. H. Irgens who conducted construction works. Its plan, interior and roofs topped with beautifully sculptured dragon-heads were based on decorations of various late Viking Age stave churches from Norway.

In my opinion, stave church in Fantoft is worth visiting not only due to its architecture, history but also because of its beautiful location.

reviews.title: Unique Blend of Christian and Viking
reviews.text: Well worth seeing, if you're in Bergen.  It's a short walk through a lovely wooded path to Fantoft Stavkirke, which offers onlookers a unique blend of Viking and Christian iconography.  The wooden edifice itself is slathered with tar (as a preservative) several times a year, so be sure not to touch or you'll wear some of it home!  Dragons are perched along the roofline, and other Viking icons are carved onto the ends of the pews inside.  It also has a wonderful "woody" smell -- like freshly hewn wood -- inside.  Take a peek at the pics to see what I'm referencing, but go for yourself because it's a lovely walk to reach the building itself.

reviews.title: Amazing building...
reviews.text: But sadly not the original and it wasn't open for viewing when we were first there. On our return, when we did get to go inside it was very beautiful to see but that is kind of it... It is surprisingly small on the inside.

reviews.title: Stave Church Replica - good stop off on way to airport
reviews.text: This dramatic wooden church hidden in the woods is worth a visit.  I didn't go inside just walked around the outside.  If you don't have too much luggage you can stop off at Fantoft on the light rail on the way to the airport then hop back on again to get to the airport.  It's about 15 mins walk from the Fantoft stop.   The fence is a bit annoying for photos but it still looks amazing so I'm glad I went.

reviews.title: A beautiful replica of a traditional Stave Church.
reviews.text: This is located in a beautiful park setting in the hills above Bergen. It is a replica, but done authentically so you will have a true view of the architecture and building techniques.

reviews.title: Something old worthy seeing
reviews.text: This old, typical church is a really good place to see and to remind us of the old "viking" times in Norway. Located still in Bergen, the best way to get close is by car. There used to be many of these churches however only a few have been left all over the country and this is one of them. For me a nice thing to see.

reviews.title: Church in a dragon style
reviews.text: Wooden church is decorated with dragon heads at the roof. Our guide said that there are traces of viking journeys to China that happened after Rome empire crashed. Original building. The church was closed. We explored it from outside

reviews.title: Beautiful walk up the hill
reviews.text: It was a little sad that the church is closed in winter but it’s still beautiful to see. There’s a platform so you can take a pic above the fence. And if you go during sunset, the lighting is gorgeous!

reviews.title: amazing even from the outside
reviews.text: I don't know if you are able to go inside, but when we wandered past it was locked. Still, it is amazing to be in the presence of all this represents of norrønt history and culture.

reviews.title: Amazing!
reviews.text: So amazing to see and the nature around is also pretty incredible. The wood carvings inside are really cool and though the church is not so big it is still very nice. Keep your hands to yourself and don't touch anything. So much history in Norway, I'm glad I got to see it! Not hard to get there from central Bergen, definitely worth it! Took about 20 or 30 minutes metro ride.

reviews.title: Nice sidetrip off the beaten path
reviews.text:
This site got circled when researching things to do in Bergen. Exactly my kind of place. The burning down of the place in the 90’s added to the intrigue and I did this the first day in town. 
There was a nice, steep but short hike to the stave church from the parking lot. The staff was helping with our questions and took US$! We spend a half hour in the church zone surrounded by security and a fence. We walked around the property that surrounded it and saw so much that added to the experience. It’s so beautiful to be there, with the church as the backdrop. Like everything in Norway, it is expensive but I think this is one of those places that most people would appreciate. 
Added is a picture of my brother standing in front of the 11 century cross. Absolutely amazing! (Zoom in to see what i mean) Maybe the Norse gods are smiling down from Valhalla!!

reviews.title: A must visit for metalheads
reviews.text: This s a medieval church that has a quite special story for metalheads since it was burnt by a group of black metal musicians as an act of anti-catholic active militantism in the early nineties and was featured in the first EP for Norwegian Black Metal one man band Burzum

reviews.title: A faithful reconstruction.
reviews.text: This is how I remember the Stavkirke, although this is a reconstruction of the one I saw in 1969. It is also more built up nearby but the church still stands in its own wooded clearing. Easy to access from the Bergen Light Rail, alight at Fantoft. Beautiful building with a simple interior, wooden craftsmanship at its best.

reviews.title: Definitely worth seeing
reviews.text: This is a remarkable wooden church a little hard to find but its worth the effort.  If you put in your gps it will get you there its just that they don't have any obvious signs directing you to its location but just follow the crowd.

reviews.title: A Disappointment
reviews.text: After seeing the Stave church in Oslo this one was a let down. It is not an original Stave church but a reconstruction that still smells new. It is the replacement for the original that some idiot burned down. It is beautiful but isn't what I thought I was going to see but if it's your only choice it's better than nothing. Also, I didn't like all the chain link fencing around the church but I understand the need for it after the fire.

reviews.title: OK but don't go out of your way
reviews.text: This is an interesting replica construction of the original which was destroyed by fire. It's a lovely building outside, but fairly small and plain inside. There's a short walk to access it and it gets very busy. I visited as part of a tour and would say 20 minutes is enough here to take a few photos and move on.

reviews.title: Even for those sick of seeing churches...
reviews.text: Even for those tourists sick of seeing churches...this one is worth a visit. Cool wood architecture and style. Peaceful setting. It's small and can get crowded.

reviews.title: Wood church
reviews.text:
Very small and beautiful. You will see ornaments coming from the viking times. Nice to walk around.
If you go by car, make sure you do not park in the bus parking which is the closest to the walking path to the church. You might get a heavy fine and your vehicle can get towed away. The only parking available for visitors is on the street. Avoid private streets.

reviews.title: Worth seeing as part of a larger tour
reviews.text:
I saw this church as part of a larger tour. This is a stunning replica of the original church that was burned down. It is made of wood and covered in sap or resin. Regardless of which, don't lean up against the walls or you are coming away with it on your clothes. Although it is huge on the outside, it is quite small inside. Not too many people can get in at once, but it wasn't particularly busy when we got there.

I wouldn't recommend making this church a sole destination. It simply doesn't take that much time to take the entire thing in. However, it is a great stop on the way to something else.

reviews.title: Nice - when you find it !
reviews.text:
I it actually one of the oldest churches in Norway, only Urnes is older.
This one was moved to location 1880 (bought as it was probably going to be scrapped in the all church boom building during that time.
The fire 1992 was such a disaster but rebuilding to an exact replica seems really to have been a success.
Such a pity it is so difficult to find even if you have some general idea that it should be there in front somewhere.
I think it is under rated, should be bigger novice about it and better signs - go there is history is of interet.

reviews.title: Expensive and Disappointing
reviews.text: This place was like a tourist trap. We came here to see the Viking’s heritage church but we only saw a new built weird looking Christine church instead. There’s 2 people sit in front of the door to sell tickets. It was 60/p for a 30 seconds visit. Some people even just walked through without paying which made the feeling, of getting ripped off, worse. Best view and photos are taken from the outside, it’s not worth to get in there by all means.

reviews.title: Worth while walk to see
reviews.text: One needs to take the train out and then walk another 20 minutes to find this place.  There is admission to go inside, but if you're after photographs, there's plenty of space to walk around the outside without going in (paying admission) to take some great photos.

reviews.title: Worth the hike!
reviews.text:
Got off the tram and didn't know which was to turn. After we ask a passerby and found our way, it was all uphill and about a 12-15 minute walk.  But, it was so well worth it!  This church is nestled in the woods with trolls living all around it!  Was disappointed it was fenced in but understand why.  One arson was enough.

Paid the price to go inside and was glad we did!  All the wood carvings were amazing!  Ask about all the dragons.  Legend has it back in the day, dragons were good luck.

The construction of no nails or screws makes it so unique!

reviews.title: Authentic reproduction of a Stave church.
reviews.text: Only after we were on our tour for ten minutes did our guide tell us this was an authentic rebuild of a Stave church that was destroyed by an arsonist about 20 years ago.  That DID NOT take away from the enjoyment of the site as there are only a handful of these churches left in the world.  We enjoyed it thoroughly.  When in Norway you should see how the Norwegians worshipped years ago.  We felt the trip was very worthwhile.

name: Mount Ulriken
ranking_subcategory: #7 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #7 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #7 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: Ulriken643 Panorama Tour will take you to the top of the mountain by cable car. The breathtaking scenery on the top of the mountain will give you a full view of beautiful Bergen surrounded by sea, fjords and hills with all its glory.

offer_list.title: Bergen Classic. Hiking from Mount Ulriken to Mt Floyen. Vidden trail.
Zipline at Mt Ulriken in Bergen
3-Hour Mt Ulriken Scenic and Cultural Hike
Biking and Hiking in Bergen

reviews.title: Brilliant but very busy.
reviews.text: Do it. Just go up for the view and you’ll find yourself walking all over. We were early which was great but it really became crowded after a few hours.

reviews.title: Gourmet Dinner
reviews.text: My husband and I enjoyed a 5-course gourmet dinner at the restaurant on top of Mount Ulriken.  It was superb and something totally off the beaten path.  Service was great and the food was delicious!   Riding up in the cable car with a view over the city was exciting. This gourmet dinner will be an event we will never forget.

reviews.title: Cabel card as slow as it get
reviews.text:
It wes by par the worst cabel card ride ever! Small q but very more then one hour in line. The view is ok but dont worh the time. Bergen in general is boring city. Dont spent your time here. Norway is big & intresting.
Avoid bergen if looking for fun & site seen.

reviews.title: Fantastic Views of the City and Coastal Region
reviews.text: This is a great way to see a great view of the City of Bergen and the surrounding coastal mountain and fjord region. You can get tickets at the Tourist Information Center near the fish market; they include a bus trip up to the cable car and back, so you also get a good close up look at the city.The views at the top are very nice. There is a cafe up there so you can grab a light bite and  cocktail and enjoy the view. There are also opportunities to hike into the mountains from easy children's hike to challenging trek, if you are so inclined. If visiting Bergen, this is a must see stop.

reviews.title: Do not buy your ticket online!
reviews.text: Buying tickets online is completely useless and a waste of time because you still need to wait in line behind people who did not buy tickets to show your online tickets on your phone to the person at the counter because they have to print out a barcode ticket for you to scan in the machine to get in the cable car. So, you waste less time if you buy directly with that person or if you buy at the self-serve machine below the stairs. Don’t forget to pay parking at the other machine outside the building. I read online there were some sort of “telescopes” on top, but when I went (June 23, 2019) they were not there. The views from the top are magnificent. Cable car ride is not long and you never have to wait long for the next one. Definitely recommend the cable car ride to the top.

reviews.title: Depends on the Weather
reviews.text: This is certainly a must do.  Be prepared for both rain and fog.  Remember that Bergenis the rainiest city in Europe!  Even though our time at the top was really a waste, couldn't see three feet in front of my nose, the ride up and back down was worth the cost.  Suggest watching the hourly weather forecast.

reviews.title: Awesome view of Bergen!
reviews.text:
Mount Ulriken is a must visit place in Bergen.it gives wonderful view of the whole city .The mountain is famous among youngsters and the people who like to do hiking.There are trails and steps to climb the hill. We chose to take cable car ride. Up the mountain very less place to hangout only few restaurants where you can sit and enjoy view. youngsters enjoy the most by hiking different mountains.
We went to tourist information center near fish market .They provide bus service to and fro mountain Ulriken cable car station ,and cable car both the ways.The ticket was Nok270 for this.
Bus service is shuttle ,running every half an hour.
If you reach cable car station by yourself,Tickets are Nok 125 oneways and Nok185 bothways.

reviews.title: One day in Bergen
reviews.text: If you are in Bergen this is a first place when you have to go. The best view on all city and bergens areas, islands, fjords and mountains. I recommended this place obligatory!!!

reviews.title: Go early- wear competent footwear
reviews.text:
Went early today to visit Mt Ulriken. Caught #2 bus from city to Ulriksdan, then followed the signs up. We got there at 10.45 only to find high winds had closed the cable car until 11. Luckily not long to wait.
At the top we got a coffee and waited for the clouds to clear. When they did fantastic! You can see for miles and miles in all directions. Super high and super clear.
My son and I went right to the top of Ulriken, but this was wet and slippery, so grippy foot wear is a must.
On our way down the cable car it was queuing out the door.

reviews.title: Wonderful view of a wonderful city
reviews.text: This is where you go in order to get the absolutely best view of Bergen.  On a clear day you can see "forever".  You have the options of hiking to the top, or using the cable car.  On nice days there most probably will be a wait to use the cable car, but they are good at expediting the lines.

reviews.title: Info not provided with other reviews
reviews.text: My husband and I wanted to do the walk across the Vidden starting from Mt. Ulriken. None of the reviews mention that you may have to wait in a long queue to get on the gondola. We left from Bergen center on a bus at 11 and did not get to the start of the hike until 12:30. The hike took us 5 hrs. Be sure to allow enough time.

reviews.title: Fabulous
reviews.text: You must go on adventures to find out where you truly belong. This is one of my best places ever.  Nature lover

reviews.title: Top of the world
reviews.text:
Great view from the top of Ulriken, we took the cable car up and back down. Stayed on top for almost two hours enjoying the view. We bought hot chocolate with cream and some cookies at the restaurant.
All together this was a great experience but a bit on the expensive side.

reviews.title: Ulriken the great visit
reviews.text: We went by Bus and Train. I did Zip lining too. Walking on the top of the hill in a cool weather is a great experience. One loves the nature should not miss this tour.

reviews.title: Dinner with a View
reviews.text: We booked the Dinner with a View package and it did not disappoint.  The cable car itself was a bit crowded, but was so beautiful that you barely had time to notice.  I loved that the top of this mountain was not completely paved, it was still rough, rocky ground in many areas, but still had safe, easy walkways to get to the restaurant and viewing platform.  The dinner was fabulous, a 4 course meal, with a menu that challenged our boring palates but was thoroughly enjoyable.  Plus the mountain goats gave us a bit of a show while we were waiting for the next course.  It was a bit slow, perhaps because there was a large group at the same time, but everyone was very pleasant and professional and watching the view change as the light changed was amazing.  The only thing that was missing was that there is no shuttle service from the cable-car station back down to the city.  You have to walk down to the main road to catch a city bus.  It was a several minute walk down a somewhat steep hill, so if you are not up to the walk, be prepared to call a taxi.

reviews.title: Mandatory
reviews.text:
You can't come to Bergen and don't go on the top of ulriken.
I love this place, good place for hiking and let the steam go.
2 roads one of 2.4km wild and one 800 m of rock stairs... Yes 800 m of pure stairs up to 600m.
I choose the 2.4km path great spots to admire the city.

You have to try it and in case there is a funicular to go on top too in case you can't climb.

reviews.title: Massive queues
reviews.text:
Would only walk up in future
1.5hour queue. Had to abhort our ride as we would have run out of time
Did speak to lots of nice folk while waiting
One 10 person capacity,slow gondola
Don’t get these guys to run a Ski resort!!
No advice on wait time

reviews.title: Worth a trip
reviews.text: We got the shuttle bus from the centre of Bergen to the cable car and were able to but a ticked which covered the bus and return on the cable car.  Fortunately it was a dry sunny day which makes the views over Bergen stunning.  We went about 9.30am so it was not too busy.  Worth a visit.

reviews.title: Hike / cable car up to Mt Ulrikken overlooking Bergen
reviews.text: Well worth it .... you can choose to “hike it” (including a long rock staircase), scramble up the mountain side (with the sheep), or cable car it — spectacular view from the top.

reviews.title: Great hike if you don’t have time to go to the Fjords
reviews.text: If you’re able and into hiking I definitely recommend this one. I was in Bergen for 3 days and did a solid hike situation. Floyen first day which is easyish but pretty, ulriken Is much harder but also easily accessible from the city and then the last day I took the train to stanghelle, took like 30 min, and hikes storafjellet which was an incredible experience which I recommend. the path is like 10 min walk from the station. As good of a view as trolltunga or priekestolen and NO PEOPLE.

reviews.title: Great climb and possibility to hike onwards
reviews.text: I hiked from the city-center up the mountain to the top. The climb was amazing with lots of beautiful views and the new stair path built by the Sherpas were great and offered a lot of spots to rest on. The best part compared to the cableway was that it is free of charge. Just bring some water and some energy snack like a Kvikk Lunsj and hike to the top. If you can't get enough you can always continue onwards to Floien.

reviews.title: If it's raining,don't waste your time and money going up
reviews.text:
I've expected the beautiful view of the city, but ended up covered in the total fog. I don't see ANYTHING.
I've waited for 1 hour til the last bus comes, no gain.
Even though it's small rain, the mountain is so high and easily covered by the fog.
Don't waste your time and money going up, if it's raining.

reviews.title: Hike up or take tram
reviews.text: Beautiful part of Bergen.  Hike up the stairs or take the tram up.  There are many areas to hike once up at the top.  We actually paraglide off of this mountain and it was amazing!  They have a local paragliding club that will take you a flight - around $175.00 for a 20 minute flight.

reviews.title: Ulriken
reviews.text: Ulriken is the highest city mountain with perfect view-point and restaurant at the top. I think that hikers from Bergen prefer to start their hiking tours from Ulriken.

reviews.title: Great view
reviews.text: Take the cablecar up to the top of the mountain. There you will find a nice restaurant, with great food and drinks, as well as a great view over Bergen City

reviews.title: Amazing view and nice hike top the top if you want
reviews.text: You might chose between the cable car or walk the newly built steps. If you want to walk, good shoes and hiking clothes are needed, because it's a hike. It's a restaurant at the top, not a place to chose because of the food, however the view will compensate. Definitely recommended, however you will use some hours and Fløien is easier accessible if you have limited time available.

reviews.title: Amazing view
reviews.text: The cablecar was closed due the windy weather. So we decided (not prepared) to hike up to the restaurant. It's suitable for people who go regulary to the gym, at least twice a week. It's a really nice walk, a lot of steps (1400) and very steep rocky roads. But it is really worth the view (when the fog was gone)!

reviews.title: Awesome
reviews.text: We took Ulriken express bus to and from cable car, very convenient, had beautiful weather which made the views spectacular. A must if visiting Bergen.

reviews.title: Fantastic views
reviews.text: We took the bus from the centre of Bergen which was handy. Bus step quite high and a little difficult for my elderly Mum. Trip in the cable car was great and. Even though it was really windy, the view was worth it. Lovely hot chocolate in the cafe at the top.

reviews.title: Fabulous views from the top!
reviews.text: You pick up the bus near the Fish Market, which will take you to the cable car. A quick and efficient service, and the views at the top are stunning. Plenty of walks at the top, depending on how demanding you want the walk to be!

reviews.title: Big mountain, big highlight of holiday!
reviews.text:
We got a return ticket for the bus from the centre of Bergen to the cable car which worked out easiest. 

My amazing other half loved it as did I. “Such a beautiful sight” she exclaimed. I thought she was looking at me but it was actually the amazing view from the top she was referring to.

reviews.title: Stunning
reviews.text: We hiked across from Floyen to Ulriken - very tired and hungry by the time we arrived so we decided to stop off at the restaurant. Incredible panoramic views and the Mountain Burger absolutely hit the spot 👌🏻

reviews.title: beautiful place
reviews.text: great place to get out of the city with amazing views. there are a lot of tourists, but thats Bergen for you

reviews.title: Spectacular views.
reviews.text: Ulriken Cable Car takes you to the top of Mount Ulriken, one of the seven mountains surrounding the city of Bergen. Enjoy the view better by walking up (hard) - walk down after taking the cable car up (fairly easy) or just take the cable car up and down (no brainer..!!) And also the Ulriken Restaurant Sky:Skraper next to the cable car upper station is unique. Taste some smoked Norwegian salmon here. Recommended.

reviews.title: Escape to the nature
reviews.text: We chose to take the gondola ride to the top of Mount Ulriken, although if younger / fitter we would have walked via the 'Sherpa Steps'. The views of Bergen and the wider area from the top are simply superb. We walked one of the (shorter) mountain trails, amazed at how quickly we had gone from a cityscape to true wilderness. The pure air and the smell of heather and fir was so invigorating. Would recommend this trip as a 'must do' for anyone visiting Bergen.

reviews.title: Not to miss
reviews.text: Great nature park with majestic views and convenient access through a gondola lift. Once up the summit there's several trails and mountain walks. For the most adventurous it is possible to reach the peak by foot.

reviews.title: Great experience with breath taking views
reviews.text: Ulriken is the highest of the Seven Mountains which surround Bergen, Norway. It has an altitude of 2110 feet above sea level. Within a few minute cable car ride you could reach the top or about an hour by foot. Hike up is the best as it surely is an experience. Every 10 steps I take I had to stop and look back as the view is breathtaking. Steps make it so much easier thanks to the Amazing hard work of the ‘Sherpa’ team 🙏🏽🙏🏽

reviews.title: Easter hiking
reviews.text: Nice hiking to the highest mountain in Bergen. Hiking starts near the Haukeland hospital. It's very easy to reach the top by walk.  Nice way and in half you start hiking by stone steps up to top.  Recommend for everyone who visit Bergen.

reviews.title: Great - the hike accross Vidden, too.
reviews.text: The cable car took us to the top of the mountain with a fantastic view over Bergen and the coast line. From here we started our hike over what's called Vidden to Mount Fløien - another famous tourist destination. Beautiful weather and fantastic scenery gave us a few enjoyable hours before reaching our destination.

reviews.title: Easy and fun!
reviews.text: We took the bus from city center.  Cost included bus ride and the cable car.  It came to roughly $33US.  Definitely worth it.  Beautiful views.  Wear hiking or sturdy athletic shoes, very rocky terrain if you decided to hike.

reviews.title: A bit weird to review a mountain
reviews.text: But as mountains go it's one of my favourites! Lots of paths and trails to explore, there's a cable car, a zip line, a restaurant, and of course: fantastic views of Bergen.

reviews.title: nice view, but expencive resturant
reviews.text: take the steps to the mountain, nice excersize and you get the fantastic view at the top. resturant have nice food to top price :-)

reviews.title: Take the stairs
reviews.text: I live here and this is one of my favorite excersise routes. There are now stone stairs all the way up. BUT: if You are visiting: dress outdoorsy, You NEED proper  shoes (jogging or hiking) and windbreaker jacket. Weather conditions can change fast... Happy hiking!

reviews.title: We walked the stairs
reviews.text:
~1500 steps, or 800 meters of stone stairs, laid by Sherpas during 3 summer seasons. It was magnificent and breathtaking :-)
We took the longer way (2,3 km) back down. Also a beautiful walk. Definitely something to do when visiting Bergen.

reviews.title: Standard mountain
reviews.text: Took bus 2 from city central. Get off at Haukeland Hospital N (before the tunnel) & follow the sign up the road “Haukelandsbakken” to Ulriken. It is a 5-10 minutes walk uphill. With Bergen card, there is a 20 percent discount on Cable car price. The view wasn’t as great as Mt Floyen but we still enjoyed.

reviews.title: Breathtaking
reviews.text:
We took a little bus shuttle that drove us at the base of the funicular going to Mount Ulriken (approximately 15min by bus).
Then took the funicular (very cute) and landed on top of Mount Ulriken. 
The view on top is just beautiful and vast, you can have a drink at the little cafe if you want. Up there you can follow different trekking paths, each one will take you somewhere beautiful. It's nice even for begginers!!

reviews.title: Views to Die For
reviews.text: Once you get on the tram car and are spirited up the Mountain the view is stunning.  There are places to eat and gift shops.  You can also walk the trails up and back if you so desire.  It is one place that you cannot miss when visiting Bergen.

reviews.title: Steep slopes
reviews.text: The highest Bergen mountain. To get to the mountain you have to use cable car line. Very comfortable restaurant at the top!

reviews.title: Great experience...
reviews.text: Too get to the Ulriken cable car it's a 10 minute ride on the 2 or 3 bus plus another 15 minute (uphill) walk to the cable car.  Really enjoyed the ride plus great views.  At the top the views are stunning and there is a coffee shop and gift shop.  There is also a restaurant but this is only open in high season.  Loved it, highly recommend.

reviews.title: Recommended!
reviews.text: Lovely for both locals and tourists. Been here tons of times, lovely view over Bergen and food and drinks are avalable at the top.

reviews.title: Absolutely way better than the Funicular
reviews.text: We where advised by our guides to do this godola trip to mount Ulric and it was way better as a experience than the Floibana the day before. Also the Skyskraper restaurant had some amazing tastes With a view that was breathtaking

reviews.title: Amazing view
reviews.text:
The top of the mount ulrikken is amazing with a fantastic view in clear weather... You can see all of Bergen and everything around.
You can choose to walk up on a hiking trip among goats climbing the sides of the mountain. Or you can take the cabelcar up and down. 
If you live in midttown you can take a speciel bus from the streets of city center and they drive you to the entrance of the cabelcar with half and hour rides... So they drive you back again when your finished. You just time it with one of their rides.you can by a returnticket from them and it includes a trip to mount ulrikken with the cabelcar.

reviews.title: Hike here
reviews.text: The tour books all talk about the hiking around Floyen, but this is where you want to be. This is lovely hiking above the tree line. The ups and downs are mild on top of the mountain, but the trails are rocky so be prepared. The views are just lovely, fjords and mountains, but also including over Bergen. There is a shuttle from downtown Bergen, and the cable car is easy. On weekends, though, it can be very busy with locals up there hiking around. There is a restaurant and store at the top of the cable car.

reviews.title: A beautiful view. A "must" if you visit Bergen.
reviews.text: It is also possible to walk up to the top. A recommended trip, if you are in good shape! Sherpaer has built a nice stone staircase to the top.

reviews.title: A must do, if you are in town for more than 3 days
reviews.text: One of the most beautiful hikes in Bergen, especially after they have built the new staircase in 2018. Very beautiful view over Bergen when you get up there. Also a nice restaurant with good coffee, cakes and sandwiches. But remember nothing in Norway comes cheap. ;)

reviews.title: Wild wild Ulriken
reviews.text: We got the cable car to the top, there's a small gift shop and a resturant and lots of stunning views, you can see for miles up there! We decided to walk down but could find no obvious way so just made our way down. We climbed down boulders and rocks, skidded down muddy slopes, swung off tree branches and just made it up as we headed for the bottom! What an adventure but our legs paid for it the next day, I think I jarred more than a few muscles thinking I was Tarzan! I'd do it again in a heartbeat though!

reviews.title: Breathtaking views
reviews.text: Whilst the queue for the cable car took some time as only 12 people can leave every 10-15 mins, once we were at the top, the views of Bergen were incredible. Would highly recommend!

reviews.title: Stunning view from the top
reviews.text: Really worth to go to the top because the view to the city is incredible. We were there in wintertime, the snow-covered mountain was amazing - but the wind was really heavy. With Bergen card you can get discount from the price of the cable car.

reviews.title: The highest Bergen mountain
reviews.text: Cable car line will bring you fast to the top of ulriken. We were in September. Rather short waiting time. The gandola capacity is around 15 pax. Nice wiev from the top

reviews.title: A 7 minute cable car ride to the top
reviews.text: This was an excellent experience as it was my birthday and I have not been in a cable car for years. The views from the top are amazing and there is a lovely café. Outside was  very windy but sunshine and you could see for miles, It seemed a little shabby and he paths weren't the best so flat shoes are highly recommended along with a jacket. you can sit inside and enjoy a coffee and the views or outside walk around with your camera

reviews.title: Best views of Bergen
reviews.text: If you want the best view of the city and onwards to Sotra and the coast line, Ulriken is the place to go. Nice cafe / restaurant at the summit.

reviews.title: Tiring hike
