reviews.text: Ulriken was a worthy hike. don't think twice. Just do it. Choose your route/path wisely. There are a few for you to choose.

reviews.title: Great view
reviews.text: Our friends went hiking under the rain, we just took the cable up to the cafe. It was nice ride up with a good view. The cafe has glass all around, a great place to chat and enjoy the scenery.

reviews.title: Starting point for a splendid hike
reviews.text: I recommend the 4 hours hike over the fjells to Floyen, hat second vciewpoint of Bergen! The path needs good shoe, and is marked - not recommended in fog or heavy rain.

reviews.title: Great view and getaway from city activities.
reviews.text: You can ride the Ulriken gondola or hike, which we did, to the top and when you arrive you will be greeted with amazing views of Bergen and the surrounding coast.   Dining and a gift shop is available and the top of the gondola is the beginning of many trails that you can take.   We had done a city walk with local friends the day before and it was fun to spot out all of the places we had visited from one vantage point.  The hike is not for the weak of heart so you will want to take the gondola.

reviews.title: Anbefales!
reviews.text:
Ulriken is a must. In clear wether gou can see "everywhere"! I think this is better than Fløyen. 
Have a lunch there, so nice! We took the bus from citycenter and than e everything was so easy. Try it!

reviews.title: Fascinating views, nice hiking trails
reviews.text: There are a couple of options, but we decided to buy a combined pass (meaning that it includes retour bus from city center to the cable car + retour pass for the cable car), price was 275 NOK per person and could be bought online and in the tourist information centre. The shuttle bus left from Bryggen area and took us comfortably to the cable car. There was a short line of people waiting for the cable car, which runs in about every 8-10 minutes. Unfortunately while we were going up it started to rain and basically it was raining during the whole time. Up in the mountain there are very good spots to take pictures + a restaurant (we did not try that). We wanted do to a big hike, however unfortunately after about 30-40 minutes snowy rain started to fall and a cloud totally wrapped the mountain, so we had to come down quite quickly. Nevertheless what we saw was absolutely breathtaking and I am sure that in clearer weather you can easily spend there 2-3 hours.

reviews.title: Expensive, good view but limited options
reviews.text:
You can get tickets for the bus + cable car just near the Tourist Information Center or in the center itself. It's pricey though, about 3 times the price of the Floyen funicular. 

The view itself is pretty good, though I don't recommend going in the rain.

For hiking, the only real thing I could find from here was the Vidden Trail and that's quite a slog if you're just looking for a short hike with some nice views.  However when doing the Vidden trail I found this is the best place to start, and end at Floyen.

reviews.title: Pleasant, but not really unusual
reviews.text:
On a clear day or even a semi-clear day which is more likely in Bergen, the trip up Mt. Ulriken by cable car is a pleasant way to spend a few hours. The views of the city and harbor are nice, but similar to lots of other such places. If you are a hiker and not just a tourist, the ride would be more rewarding since there are trails leading all over the place. When we were there on a Saturday, we enjoyed seeing the hikers below, often with their dogs and even small children. Norwegians are really into physical fitness and hiking is like a national pastime.
Let me give you a warning about one thing and that is unless you are absolutely famished and in danger of collapsing, do not buy anything at the little restaurant at the summit. In an expensive country, this was the most ridiculous clip joint of all we encountered. One cup of ordinary coffee was the equivalent of $6.00 and a tiny apple muffin to go with it was another $3.00. Even Norwegians to whom we spoke later were amazed at that bit of thievery.

reviews.title: Amazing views (when it is not raining)
reviews.text:
We booked an excursion from our cruise ship to go to the top of Mt. Ulriken.   When we left the ship, we could easily see the top of the mountain, but the excursion bus took us for a tour of Bergen before we drove to the gondola base.    Perhaps they had an appointment time for our ascent?

By the time we arrived at the gondola base, the clouds and rain had moved in so we had decent views of the city below as we as rode  up the cable - until we entered the clouds.

At the top station, we were mostly above the clouds so could see sky above and clouds below.    Luckily the clouds moved quickly and we had intermittent times that we could see the city below, and we took advantage of those seconds to take some great pictures.

Naturally as we boarded the gondola to head back down to the base station, the clouds parted for several minutes of clear skies.  Oh well.

The gondola ride is comfortable and smooth.    The scenery is good during the ascent and descent. The facilities at the top include a nice cafe, restrooms, a gift shop and several viewing platforms.

There were some wooly sheep grazing at the top of the mountain that were being filmed by a television crew while we were at the top.   The sheep were interesting but be careful where you step - smile.

We traveled up with a hiker who was riding to the top to hike the trail back down to the town.   That would be a scenic hike but time and weather did not allow.

A great attraction but do a “do not rain” dance before you drive to the gondola station.

reviews.title: Montain walking in Bergen from Ulriken to Fløien via Vidden
reviews.text: If you have some hours to spare in Bergen, and fancy a hard walk, take cableway up to mount Ulriken and walk the route back to Fløien, by the locals calles "Vidden" (mountain plateau). This is an amazing trip, walking in a u-shaped turn ending up in the middle of down town at Fløien where you could either walk or take take the cable way back down again. The trip takes from 3-5 hours depending on your fitness.

reviews.title: Beautiful hike with a great View of Bergen!
reviews.text: If you’re up for a nice hike up the mountain this is a must do while in Bergen. There are many ways to get to the base of the hike from town. Take bus 12 from the city centre and get off at stop ‘Montana’ and the directions from there are easy to find. A fairly straightforward hike up, but not recommended if you’re not up for a 4km climb. Great restaurant at the top and we took the cable car down! Great for kids and there is a trail at the top over to Floyen and they had zip lining up there too!!

reviews.title: Best views of Bergen and beyond and more
reviews.text: If you are in Bergen, it is easy to find a shuttle bus directly to Mr. Ulriken, it is a block to the left (facing the water) of the Fish Market. It is only an extra $5 each way payable by credit card along with the cable car ticket, for a total of 27.  It runs every half hour.  The cable cars was a pleasant journey to the top, for which you are rewarded with spectacular views.  I felt like I was at the top of the world.  There is a restaurant at the top, we sat outside for lunch; you usually expect substandard fare but the food we chose was delicious.  There were a number of rocky trails to hike once at the top; if you are inclined to do so, wear the right shoes and travel lightly to have 2 hands free for the rocky terrain.  Bring  you phone or camera as you will want to take lots of photos.

reviews.title: Stunning views, great cinnamon buns!
reviews.text: We were lazy and went up this simply stunning mountain in the cable cars. The views on the way up were good, once up their they were not good, they were amazing. Then to top it off we were treated to lovely cinnamon buns in the restaurant at the top of the mountain. Our guide advised us that Bergen often gets rain (over 250 days of rain a year!)and we were very lucky to get no rain and pretty warm clear skies, especially in September, so it may be worth considering that before going up, but its definitely worth it if you can.

reviews.title: Spectacular view
reviews.text: We took the bus up to the gondola up to the top of the mountain where there were amazing views over the city

reviews.title: A panoramic view of Bergen
reviews.text: The saying goes " No pain .. No gain" .. this is something you get to experience trekking mount Ulriken. It is challenging  to trek to the summit, but as soon as u get there you get a great reward : a breathtaking panoramic view and fresh air that makes you feel the purity of nature

reviews.title: Superb view!
reviews.text:
I love that Ulriken has a cable car, because I'm pretty lazy. But if you wanna avoid queuing for an hour, you should get there early. We went up the mountain just before 10am, and when we got down an hour earlier the line reached out the building!!

The view is gorgeous, and there are hiking paths of varying difficulty along the mountain. There's also a pricey cafè and a souvenir shop.

reviews.title: Best Views in Bergen
reviews.text: There is a express tourist bus leaving from the fish market / tourist office to Mount Ulriken, with a short cable car ride up. From the top, you have a wonderful view over Bergen, the surrounding mountains and the fjords. You can hike down (it's all stears!!) in about one hour. Alternatively, there are more easy hikes on the top of the mountain (round trips). Good restaurant.

reviews.title: Gorgeous views!!
reviews.text: As others have said, do note that there are often very long (hour or more) lines to get on the cable car.  We waited about an hour on a beautiful, sunny August day when there were 4 cruise ships in town.  Plan accordingly!  The wait to come down was significantly shorter.  Lines aside, the view from the top was absolutely stunning.  There is a nice little cafe with outdoor patio at the top as well as a minimal gift shop.  There's also a little playground of sorts with balance beams, monkey bars, and few other stations to entertain the little ones.  We were on a bus tour so had relatively limited time but would have loved to venture out on some of the trails and do some exploring.  Nevertheless, there is plenty of room to walk around and enjoy the views in all directions.  Don't forget the camera on this outing!  :)

reviews.title: Cool mountain scenes, bring hiking gear
reviews.text: Locals come to hike all the time, lots of rocky areas, boulders to climb, etc. We didn't climb down but it's possible. Only 1 tram in each direction, so at least a 30 minute wait to ride up, heard it was a 1.5 hour hike up. Mountain top restaurant is decent.

reviews.title: Hike up Ulriken and cable car down
reviews.text: We caught the 12 bus from Festplassen K which took about 20 mins. Ask the driver to drop you for Ulriken and follow the signs to the left opposite the bus stop. Past the grocery store where you can buy water and food then turn right up to the fire trail. Then turn right and start walking! Half way up the trail you get a fork. The steps have just been made by Nepalese sherpas flown over to create expert steps from local rocks. The other option is to take the path Which is longer and apparently less difficult. We took the steps and figured you have to go up no matter what. It was not too bad. We took it easy and the whole thing took under 90 mins including photo stops etc. Take pics as you go because the weather closes in and you might lose the view for a while. The last bit is a bit of a push. There is a railing to hang onto and help pull yourself up the last few steps. Locals take their dogs up this trail every weekend so don't get too freaked out about the level of difficulty. I'm 47 and hauling extra weight and bad knees and it was no problem for me. You earn the hot chocolate and pancakes at the top! Showers available too if you want to take a towel and soap. Cable car every 30 mins down and then walk to get any number of buses back into town. All in all this was the highlight of my trip to Bergen.

reviews.title: Hike from Ulriken to Fløyen
reviews.text: My son and I were travelling through Bergen this summer. It was recommended that we do the hike from Ulriken to Fløyen. It was the highlight of our trip! We were lucky with the weather the day of our hike. There were intermittent showers and times where the sun tried to shine through. The weather can change quickly in the mountains so I would recommend checking the weather before heading up. We took public transit to the base of Mount Ulriken. We decided to hike up to the top instead of taking the tram. We took a trail that lead us straight to the top. It was definitely challenging! At the top we found the trail markers for Fløyen. The hike was well marked in most places. After a while the signs were replaced with stone piles to mark the way. The hike from one mountain to the other is 13 km so make sure you have plenty of food and water. Rain gear and hiking boots are a must! This was the most beautiful, scenic hike! Lots of photo opportunities! Well worth the trek!  Once you get to Fløyen you can take the funicular back down to the town centre.

reviews.title: Amazing view!
reviews.text: Mount Ulriken is is worth a visit. The view from the hilltop  is really amazing.Bergen is a beautifull city!!  If you do not want to hike up, you can take the funicular. The restaurant on top offers local tasty food.

reviews.title: Really worth while
reviews.text:
This is absolutely a very good idea, much better than the other one.
Yes you have to hike up some stairs through the hospital area, and yes the queuing is during rush hours in peak season slow. (why not make a bigger capacity or double line up ?)
But once up there you have a wonderful view over the fantastic city of Bergen, if you have hiking shoes and stamina you can wonder off on the mountains around and hike down (or up) and just take one way ticket - is an option.
The restaurant on top is really quite ok and has some local good food, just fine.

reviews.title: Fabulous views
reviews.text:
Visited Ulriken on Sunday 12th August. Caught the number 12 bus from Bergen and got off at the Haukeland hospital. It costs about £9 for a 24hr bus ticket or you can buy a single on the bus for about £3.50. I don’t know if we went the right way but we walked through the hospital grounds up to the Ulriken 643 cable car. We paid for a one way ticket as we planned to walk back down. We arrived at about 1.15pm which was later than we planned and so the queues were taking a while to go down - we queued for an hour to go up.
Once up we queued to buy a sandwich and got to the front of the queue the cafe ran out of bread! We had a bun instead (sandwiches were £11 each but did look good and prices in Norway are much more than in the UK).
We decided to do a walk around the lakes at the top of Ulriken - the green walks are easy and up to about 4.3km in length. We soon lost the route and were making our own walk up with no real idea of where we were going. It was busy though and we never went so far that we were actually lost. It did take us 2 hours to do what we planned as a one hour walk. There were no maps available for us to take on the walk with us and all we had was a photo on my phone that we took of a map on a display board. The signposting was inadequate if you actually want to follow a route. The ground is wet and rocky in places and very uneven and rocky in others - you need water proof shoes really.
The walk down is much longer and much more strenuous than expected. The walk up would have been more than we could have done and we are both averagely fit adults with no health problems. I would have paid for the return cable car trip if I had known what to expect. Some people coming up had small children with them - I really don’t know if these children would have found the walk all the way up enjoyable. At the top the stairs virtually disappear and there is a rail to hold onto to help pull yourself up over the remaining rocks.
We did not get back to the bottom of Ulriken until almost 7pm, 6 hours after we arrived so much longer than we had planned. We were really tired at the end of the day but the views were worth it and if we had allowed more time we could have done everything at a more leisurely pace!

reviews.title: red walking path does not excist
reviews.text: We walked the red walking path that should be 3,5 hours (ulriken - trolldalen - isdalen - svartkredit - brakedalen - ulrikseggen - ulriken) following the map as given at ulriken643. But after Isdalen this route is a dead end and brought us in a very dangerous place. This path does not excist anymore  So we walked all around the lake 8 hours later. Be aware the map they give is old!

reviews.title: Fabulous
reviews.text: We got our tickets from the street kiosk. Very friendly and knowledgeable. Everything we were told was exact. Glad we were there early. Weather was crystal clear and views spectacular.

reviews.title: Challenging but wonderful
reviews.text:
I went there in August. I started at 9 am because i wanted to avoid big groups of people. The way up was more challenging than some people were telling me. You absolutely need outdoor shoes, because the way contains wet parts and there are a lot of stones. I think having outdoor shoes is also more important if you’re planing to go the shorter way down again. The legs may be wobbly because of the way up and the loose stones on the way make it not even better. I’ve went the shorter way up (it’s about 1 1/2 hour, 2-2 1/2 if you want to enjoy the landscape and take some pictures) and the shorter way down. I’ve met some people telling me about the longer way, it’s about 2 -3 hours up but it sounds easier. I think everyone has to decide which way is the best, I saw children going the harder way so easily but I also saw fit men huffing and puffing in the middle of the way. No matter which way you go up, it’s absolutely worth it! The view is incredible. On the top is a bistro and a kiosk where you can buy you some food or sit on a platform with a coffee before the way down. Inside the bistro are toilets were you also have the opportunity to fill your water bottle. 
Of course you have the opportunity to skip the way up and down and just take the Ulrikenban. A ticket for the way up and down was about 175nok (adult) and 125nok (children)! A important information may be that your only able to pay by visa or 
MasterCard at the ticket machine. Someone told me it’s also possible to get a ticket at the gondola, but I’m not sure, if it really works. 
If you want to avoid a long waiting period and you’re planing to take the gondola, start your trip early in the morning. 

If you want to go by public transport from Bergen you have to take the bus number 2 to Birkelundstoppen at the Strandkaiterminalen (it’s the destination next to the tourist information) and leave the bus at Haukeland sjukehus before the tunnel. It’s about a 10 Minute walk to the starting point of Ulriken.

reviews.title: Lovely visit to the mountains
reviews.text: So easy to get there by the bus, then the very fun cable ride! We loved hiking in the mountains, discovering beautiful landscapes! Rewarding hot chocolate after the walk at the restaurant! ;-) Highly recomended!

reviews.title: LONG LINE - beware - 80 minutes!
reviews.text: At height of summer (August) at 11am the line is out the door and the wait is almost an hour and a half. Not worth it!! Make a backup plan like walking to the top or coming early.

reviews.title: A Must In Bergen
reviews.text: If you are going to Bergen, do take a trip to Ulriken, you can hike (643 Meters) or you can take the funicular. the view from the top is breathtaking and a lot of activity including paragliding etc...

reviews.title: All the views
reviews.text:
Mount Ulriken was beautiful! I opted to take the cable care up and the long hike down (the stairs looked a little scary). The hike was a bit more challenging than I was expecting, but I’m also out of shape and don’t hike regularly. I still managed to make it down and it was worth it. 

The views from the top and all the way down are breathtaking. Defiantly worth the time to visit!

name: Det Hanseatiske Museum og Schoetstuene

photo.caption: The Hanseatic Museum -first building at Bryggen

ranking_subcategory: #11 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #11 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #11 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: This wooden building is furnished in 16th-century style and gives visitors a feel of what Bergen was like in its medieval trading days.

reviews.title: Excellent Walking Tour of Hanseatic Wharf
reviews.text: While visiting Bergen, this is a must do tour. The city was one of many ports for the German Hanseatic League  of trading merchants from the 1300s to the 1700s. Many of the scenic waterfront structures are from this era. We took the walking tours with a student guide and he did an excellent job of painting a picture of the lives of the merchants, who were primarily young apprentices. The tour gave us a great understanding of an important time in the history of Northern Europe. Much of Bergen has gone "tourist" with more focus on shopping, dining and entertainment, and many historical sites are closed, but this museum is a bright beacon of city history not to be missed.

reviews.title: How the Hanseatic Merchants Lived
reviews.text: The  Hanseatic German Merchants had a strong trade influence for many centuries. The museum reflects how they lived in Norway.

reviews.title: A trip back in time
reviews.text: This little museum showcases some real history of the town, check out the old oven and building it's quite interesting.

reviews.title: this is for people who history...and Norway
reviews.text: this museum goes back 400 years in how merchants lived and worked.  You can see a 400 year old home. its right near a lot of restaurants.

reviews.title: Beware the museum is closed 2019 and beyond
reviews.text: The experience for now is different while restoration of the house of the museum is underway. You will get a guided tour + entry to the Schotstuene.. This is dear if you don’t want the free bus and entry to the Fishing museum. We have happy memories of how the museum was 10 years ago and it will be good when the original experience is restored.

reviews.title: While they're renovating, you can still tour, from Bryggen
reviews.text: The actual museum is closed for renovation, but the tour leaves from the back of Bryggen and takes you around there, and into Schotstuene. You learn so much about both the Hanseatic league, and how to do major restoration.

reviews.title: Closed due to sinking
reviews.text: In October 2018 they discovered the museum was sinking.  It will be closed for two years.  However, they have moved exhibits to different venues around Bryggen.  The Museum Shop is also open.

reviews.title: Open, Friendly and Interesting
reviews.text:
The Hanseatic Museum in Bergen is not a large museum, nor (except for a few parts) made up of original structures.  However, it provides an excellent background on the life of members of the Hanseatic League in Bergen and an interesting description of a lifestyle not often shown in other places.  The displays clearly identify the origins and authenticity of any items or re-creations with scrupulous attention to the distinction between what is certain, probable, possible and speculative.  The well-educated best guess recreation of a room as it appeared during the time was especially interesting.
Feel free to ask questions.  The staff was knowledgeable, friendly and happy to provide explanations and additional information.
Tickets to this museum include the fishing museum, so you will want to give yourself time to visit both.

reviews.title: Museum closed
reviews.text: The museum is closed for renovations until 2026.  Some of the collection has been moved to the Schoetstuene museum, but not all is yet on display.  The Schoetstuene museum is worth a visit.

reviews.title: Museum closed at the moment!
reviews.text: Wew were disappointed to find that this museum was closed, and as far as we could tell there is nowhere else in Bergen where you can see any of the exhibits inside. It's being refurbished.

reviews.title: Old Fish Was Never So Interesting!
reviews.text: Come for the King Cod, stay for the King Cod. And also the detailed look at the life of hardworking Germanic merchants and their apprentices. This place has everything. Kings. Cods. Tiny beds with doors.

reviews.title: Amazing Hanseatic Museum
reviews.text: You won't want to miss this museum. It's as if you've actually stepped out of 'now' and back into that time period. You truly feel as if you are there. A must-see for adults as well as children. A true learning experience. You'll be transported back to another time.

reviews.title: Bergen Must-See – Regional History
reviews.text:
We did a walking tour of Bergen that included a stop at the Hanseatic Museum. This is one of the must-see stops in Bergen as it gives a great feel for the history of the town and region as well as the Hanseatic League. 

The museum takes roughly thirty minutes to see. Everything about the building is interesting including the floors.

reviews.title: Great set of museums
reviews.text: When you buy your ticket make sure it includes the fisherman's museum and other annex. The museum on the Hanseatic wharf is interesting in itself with details of the Hanseatic trading history but coupled with the two annexes really does tell the story of Bergen, with a minibus linking the three buildings. Young children might not appreciate the exhibits and the history.

reviews.title: Terrific summary of the history of Bergen
reviews.text:
The building is furnished as the home of a Hanseatic merchant that it actually was. That does not mean luxury, but living and working space for the merchant, his journeyman and his apprentices. The rooms have extensive information (in English) about fishing, the processes of trading, the shipping to and from the other Hanseatic cities, etc. A history buff can spend a couple of hours. However, you do have to be able to climb three flights of narrow stairs.
 A few blocks away is the other part of the museum--the building shared by several guilds where cooking and socializing was done. One ticket covers both and it is worthwhile to see both.

reviews.title: NOW I know what the Handeatic League was!
reviews.text: Really old building, faithfuly preserved.  An excellent view into the business trading life of the 13th-15th centuries.  The building is that old and the scale and design of the living quarters was a revelation to us.  This is NOT handicap accessible and there are a fair amount of steps.  If you are travelling with someone for whom this is a challenge, they can wait for you across the street in Starbucks.  Also, the shuttle to the Norwegian Fisheries Museum a couple of miles away leaves every half hour from just outside. It was a great morning--neither museum takes a long time, maybe an hour each.

reviews.title: An excellent view into the origins of Bergen
reviews.text: The Hanseatic Museum provides an excellent way to understand the economic and trading base that underpinned the location, establishment and role of Bergen as part of the Hanseatic network.

reviews.title: Skip this site, it is closed for renovation
reviews.text: We really would have liked to have seen this site, after walking there in the rain we found out it will be closed for years for renovation. Bergen card needs to revise their information.

reviews.title: A unique look into the history of Bergen.
reviews.text:
Norway is neat in that unlike the US, people can be trusted to act like adults. That's one of the reasons why the Hanseatic Museum is so neat - you're walking through a time capsule from the Hanseatic settlement of Bergen, that captures the sights, feel, and smells of the era of trade. Walking through the uneven floors, rooms and chambers you see exactly how people lived, traded, and worked during this interesting period in Bergen.

Highly recommended for the history nerd, but might be a bit much for children or anyone with mobility issues.

reviews.title: Expensive
reviews.text: It was interesting at best - there is not much to it, not much furniture.  You're mostly just wandering around relatively empty rooms.  For what you get, I thought the price of about US $20 per person was very steep.  We only spent about 30 minutes inside, then walked to the second location, which is just big rooms with tables in it.  There are stairs at both locations.

reviews.title: What an amazing old building!
reviews.text: Our patience in the queue for this small museum was worth it (and we discovered the reason for the queue - free entry on their last day before closing for a long renovation period). I love small museums and old architecture and this museum was perfect! While there are issues with access, this is often the case with such old buildings. The rooms and floors gave such a wonderful atmosphere, even the darkly lit ones! Many photos were taken and a great experience was had!

reviews.title: Learn about the Hanseatic League - but not for people with mobility issues
reviews.text:
I found this museum very interesting and authentic. I did not know a deal about the Hanseatic League, so was interested in the explanations.  

The building has lot of narrow stairs, so would be challenging for people with mobility issues, but I found the authenticity of the place well worth the climb.  The rooms were furnished in the original style - box beds etc so overall I found the place to be excellent.

Unfortunately, my husband was not impressed - very worried about the safety aspects of a narrow wooden building - so I have reduced my score to 'very good'.

reviews.title: Unique buildings
reviews.text: The building is sinking and the museum is being closed for a few years while it is taken down piece by piece and reassembled so we were pleased to have the chance to see inside.  It’s a fascinating building to walk around with interesting displays on Hanseatic history on the ground floor.  It’s very dark upstairs which makes it difficult to see the map.  More information boards would be good up there.  The entrance fee, 16NOK, also gives entry to the Schoetstuene building, 5 mins walks away, where the apprentices and others used to gather for warmth and food.  [No fires were allowed in the museum building so it was freezing.] It’s also an interesting and well preserved building.  If you’ve time, which sadly we didn’t, entry to the Fisheries Museum is also included so, for Bergen especially, the ticket is great value.

reviews.title: Exhibition in two parts
reviews.text:
It's a museum/exhibition in two parts.  The first is right by the Starbucks. The second is further up and westwards near St Mary's church.  Get a ticket in either and it'll allow you into the other.  They also give you a ticket to the Fisheries museum.  

The museum itself gives you a good insight into the historical background of Bergen, the Hanseatic Guild which had set themselves up in an enclave and the importance of the fish trade as well as some of the important aspects/tools that were relevant back then.  

It does rain a lot in Bergen so I'd save this for a rainy day.

reviews.title: Very interesting museum
reviews.text: This museum in Bryggen is an interesting insight into the history of Bergen across the centuries. The most interesting part is the first floor which details history of the city as a Hanseatic trading port.

reviews.title: Like going back in time
reviews.text: Beautiful building that really gives you a feel of the history of Bergen. The ground floor offers interesting reading and information and the upper floors are preserved as they were in the 1700's. Brings you back in time!

reviews.title: A Marvellous Experience
reviews.text: A dampish day led us to visit the Hanseatic Museum and how glad we were that we did.   We stepped back in time walking through an authentic house of the time and getting a real feel for the way the merchants lived.   Information is very interesting and well laid out.  Rooms are dimly lit to preserve the wood and stairs a bit uneven but this all added to the character of this wonderful museum.  Well worth of visit!

reviews.title: Very interesting Hanseatic Museum
reviews.text: This museum is right on Bryggen Wharf and very historic and interesting. Their artifacts are old and authentic and there is much to read about the history the Hanseatic trade in multiple languages including English. We were entertained for at least an hour. Nice gift shop with different items and a cafe.

reviews.title: On our list of must see!
reviews.text: This was high on the list of our 12 year old grandson, who travelled with us, and loves European history.   It was a great introduction for him as our trip began in Bergen and ended in another Hanseatic city, Tallinn.   Excellent presentations.

reviews.title: Small but very interesting
reviews.text: Museums are expensive in Norway, but so is everything. Get a Bergen card or take advantage of the three museums that a single ticket will get you entry into. All are fairly close by to walk to. This one gives you a real feel for the trade network and the times they lived in. It was literally like stepping back in time.

reviews.title: Glad it was free entry (due to ticket machine malfunction on day) for this v small museum
reviews.text: We were surprised by how expensive the museums in Bergen are including this one.  It might be worth buying a “Bergen card” if you plan on visiting a few although I noted that some reviews say that this museum isn’t included??  Anyway, our impressions (in 30 min or so) were that this museum is reasonably interesting for anyone keen on history;  a few boards in English + various exhibits (mostly reconstructions) although there were some original ruins from 1280 + boards explaining how they work out how old these ruins are etc.  The cookhouse, with an explanation of how they used wooden shoes to prevent the spread of fire, was presented quite well too (see photos).  Don’t expect too much...all presented in an old fashioned/static way hence the average rating.

reviews.title: Excellent Museum on the Hanse trade association
reviews.text: Excellent museum (will close for longer renovation!!) showing how the Hanse & their trade network worked. The museum is in a historic house. Schoetstune is a short walk away.

reviews.title: Best way to start your visit is this museum.
reviews.text: You will get a complete picture of Bergen's history here.  We had guided tour and she was very informative.  Be sure to visit the 2nd site a few blocks away and tell them you paid at the main museum.

reviews.title: Very interesting
reviews.text: You really should educate yourself about the history of this famous area of Bergen and the museum is a perfect place to do that. Bergen was an important seat of the Hanseatic League and this museum is a fine example of how they lived. (It reminds me of the Tenement Museum in NYC in that is authentic living space). It is very small and cramped inside with uneven surfaces and small staircases. It isn't for the physically impaired and you have to watch your step and may feel confined. Having said that only as a caution, I found it to be fascinating. A worthy stop in Bergen. Well preserved.

reviews.title: Small but interesting
reviews.text:
This museum is in two buildings several hundred yards apart.

The main part is a reconstruction of a Hanseatic house. It is interesting and informative though in the interests of authenticity the rooms are small and dimly lit. There was a tour group during our visit and things got very crowded.

Because of the buildings wooden construction fires were not allowed either for heating or cooking and therefore merchants tended to congregate in assembly rooms. These rooms and associated kitchens are in the second part of the museum which is more spacious and (in my opinion) more enjoyable.

reviews.title: A lesser known part of history
reviews.text: We visited the Hanseatic Museum during a stop in Bergen on a recent cruise. Prior to this trip, I didn't know much about the Hanseatic League and how it shaped Europe, but this museum took care of that. It preserves a League merchant's home. I found it fairly interesting. The information on the first floor was the most instructive. It could have benefited from having a little more detail about what each room was used for spread throughout the house, but you get the general gist. History buffs should enjoy this quite a bit.

reviews.title: Travel to 1704
reviews.text: Great place to see first hand what life was like working and living in a wooden building with the Hanseatiske merchants. Your truly feel transported to the past .  I think the guide with you makes the difference in your experience.  The stories of the way of life, the work and the hardships brought life to a very old building.  It is a quick visit and shouldn't be missed.

reviews.title: A must-see museum
reviews.text:
If you want to understand Bergen and its past, you should not miss this museum.
The ticket, 160 NOK, includes the access to Schotstuene merchants rooms and also to the Norwegian Fisheries.
Basically, the Hanseatic museum consists in the visit of a very old wooden merchant house, dating back from 1702, where the German merchants stored stockfish and cod liver oil received by boat from Northern Norway and in return sold grain and flour. 
You can visit:
-the room where stockfish was weighed, sorted and pressed into barrels
-the Merchant office with original furniture and his bed in...a wardrobe
-several rooms where workers and apprentices lived and worked
-storehouses where flour and other goods were kept
All is authentic and very old and smelling wood.

reviews.title: This is old
reviews.text: Everything is old the furniture, floors, walls, and artifacts.  So authentic it is creepy.  Get a guided tour or you will rush through and miss things.  The stairs are challenging.  Nice gift shop; staff is great and they sell beverages. I learned many things and am constantly surprised by early Norwegians stamina.

name: Leprosy Museum

photo.caption: Lepramuseet og st. Jørgen kirke, gsfoto

ranking_subcategory: #13 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #13 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #13 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: etween 1850 and 1900 Bergen had three hospitals for leprosy patients and the largest concentration of patients in Europe. The city’s oldest leprosy hospital, St. George’s Hospital, is now not only a monument to thousands of personal tragedies, it is also an important arena for the dissemination of Norwegian work and research on leprosy. In many parts of the world leprosy is commonly known as Hansen’s disease, after the Norwegian physician Gerhard Armauer Hansen who discovered the leprosy bacillus in Bergen in 1873. The herb garden we meet today is from the 1990s. It is open to the Public during museum opening hours. Open mid may - end august daily from 11 until 15
address: St. George's Hospital Kong Oscarsgate 59, Bergen 5017 Norway

reviews.title: Very interesting
reviews.text: This is a small museum but it's very interesting. They have translations of the text in many languages. I recommend it.

reviews.title: Disappointed
reviews.text:
I found it difficult to find, some signs would help
They have tried to help the English visitor with a leaflet in English with reference to room numbers!
I could not find the numbers in the room so I was lost. Later I was told the tiny numbers on the corner of the display is the reference i needed, but boy was it difficult to find. Bigger or brighter numbers please
It has potential but I believe if needs a new look at how to explain this period
Kids would be bored, not sure worth a stop.

reviews.title: Worth the visit
reviews.text: A fascinating look into the lives and care of leprosy patients in Norway, which had the largest number of cases in Europe.

reviews.title: Subject is interesting, explanation insufficient
reviews.text: First is it difficult to understand how it is working. A small hall with the cashier but no information about price, entrance by your own or with a guide. With languages are spoken, audiotour possible? After 15 minutes we don't have the answer on our questions and we left the houses.

reviews.title: Interesting but poorly arranged museum
reviews.text: I guess I'm very critical since my life's work was as a curator. Posters in rooms do not make a museum. Way too much reading and not artfully presented. Subject matter of course does not lend itself to much, but I think this museum could do a much better job. Having said that, it was still worth visiting. Children will be very bored however. Seeing the church was the best part of the tour.

reviews.title: Interesting Museum of Leprosy
reviews.text: Located in a building that was once a leprosarium, the museum shows the living quarters and the laboratory facilities associated with finding the lepra bacillus.  There is even a wax model of leprosy.

reviews.title: Hanson's Disease, or leprosy, lasted a long time in Norway
reviews.text: The hospital and church have been turned into a museum. There are informational handouts in English and other languages. Fascinating story of the disease, the discovery that it is caused by a bacteria, and the social stigma changes over the centuries.

reviews.title: You didn't know you wanted to learn about leprosy - but trust me, you do!
reviews.text: This is a fascinating place; a former habitation for people suffering with the disease of leprosy, which struck Norway hard and lasted there longer than elsewhere in Europe. The historic buildings are fascinating and well-explained without feeling overdone. Our guide was excellent - she had only been working there for a month but was full of knowledge and gave us an absorbing and insightful tour. This is one of those off-beat places that gives you deep perspective into history that enriches your knowledge of the realities and challenges of the past.

reviews.title: Full of history.
reviews.text: This is quite a small museum but well worth a visit. It tells a marvellous story about Leprosy in Norway and how Hansen developed new ideas on the treatment of this terrible disease. You can have a guided tour if you wish but we were quite happy walking around on our own and reading the information provided.

reviews.title: very informative
reviews.text: Although the museum is very small, it does present a lot of information about the disease and treatment of it.  The original rooms where patients lived are there, and you get a real sense of how terrible the disease was.

reviews.title: Historical must see
reviews.text: A small building which housed those with leprosy.  The historical research and developments are incredible over the many years of the facilities existence.  The pictures of patients with their stories was neat.  Recommend you go.  The only reason for a 4 rating is the guide given to read as you go seemed really out of sequence.

reviews.title: Medical history
reviews.text: Great insight to the history of the research, the physicians, as well as the ailments and life of people afflicted with leprosy.

reviews.title: Surprisingly interesting!
reviews.text: I really didn't know what to expect but the place has a fascinating history and played a unique role in global medicine. 'Museum' is maybe the wrong word as this really is the old Leprosy hospital and church - both are equally fascinating.

reviews.title: One out of the 3 hosptals for leprosy in Bergen
reviews.text: Again, we tried to visit it but it was closed as season was gone... Still, you can see the central court and imagine how it looked like. being the port town, story goes that Bergen had 3 hospitals for leprosy.

reviews.title: Quirky museum
reviews.text: I like to visiting museums a little away from the mainstream and this certainly fitted the bill. The story of leprosy in Norway was something I had no clue about and it was interesting to find out more. Sons aged 12 and 10 were fine with tbe pictures. I was left with quite a few outstanding questions though which might suggest it is a good idea to take the guided tour.

reviews.title: Good medical history of Leprosy
reviews.text: An interesting museum with a comprehensive history of how the causative microorganism of leprosy was identified.  The exhibits were a bit dated and only in Norwegian.  The museum has prepared some English leaflets for visitors.

reviews.title: Scary
reviews.text: It is an interesting museum but a bit spooky. It tells you the misery life of leorosy patient in the past. Norwegian physician contributed a lot in the research of leprosy. Maybe it is not very suitable for teenagers. My son is frightened by the look of leprosy patients.

reviews.title: Great way to spend an hour
reviews.text:
This is a great place to spend an hour or so! If you need English then you are given a card to read so that you can follow everything.
For some reason this region seems to have suffered with a huge amount of leprosy....I actually know a bit more about the disease now.
Also they open the church every few hours, it’s a lovely building with a wooden interior.

reviews.title: Do not miss this museum
reviews.text: I read a bit about this place and decided that we must include it on our visit to Bergen, and was definitely not disappointed.  If you have the slightest interest in history, medicine, science or even social history, you would be interested in this place.  It's well laid out, not large with good written booklet in English and plenty of gory drawings to illustrate the leprosy victims.  The hospital church was opened for about 10 minutes while we were there (it opens every hour for about 10 minutes) and a short commentary in English was given - really interesting.  It won't take you more than an hour and they will organise an English tour guide to take you around if you ask - an extra fee is payable for this of course!

reviews.title: Chilling
reviews.text: Some elements of a house of horrors only because it was true.  But the museum is lovingly restored and maintained.  Slightly off the beaten path with a welcome absence of most of the tourists.  The buildings were a testament to the country and staffs care for all their citizens even the downtrodden.  You do not think of a population of Former Viking ancestors having such heart and caring.

reviews.title: Who knew?
reviews.text: When I think of leprosy, I never thought of Norway. But it turns out that in the 18th and 19th century, Norway had one of the world's highest incidences of the disease and western Norway was particularly hard hit. This museum is located in an old hospital for patients with the disease. Dr Hansen, for whom the disease is now named, worked in this hospital. Take the tour because your guide will provide much more detail than you'll get from reading the signage on the exhibits.

reviews.title: VEry interesting museum
reviews.text: Very interesting museum on Leprosy and how it evolved over the time. At the entrance you can have the translations of the texts in many languages. Each room has some documentation about the evolution of the sickness and how it's been treated in different times.

reviews.title: Informative and interesting
reviews.text: Learnt a lot about leprosy especially in Norway. The guide was informative, friendly and interesting. The museum itself was quite basic  but worth the 9 pounds entry on a rainy day. Didn't take long to look round and I feel more could've been made of it, with regards artefacts and displays. Worth going to as long as you don't expect too much.

reviews.title: Fascinating place
reviews.text:
I hadn't heard of the Leprosy Museum at St George's Church and Hospital before we were taken their by our guide, who explained this history of the place.

Leprosy was documented from the 1400s and the hospital was run by nuns who treated sufferers in the hospital. Unfortunately we didn't have time to go inside, but I would have loved to have taken a tour of the hospital with a guide to get more information even though our guide for the city gave us a appetising amount of information.

reviews.title: A little-known problem for long-ago Norway ...
reviews.text: We learned so much on our visit! Our young guide was enthusiastic and so knowledgeable. Such a crippling disease, this hospital was a major player in finding a cure for Leprosy. It was mind losing to learn statistics and to see how the townsfolk responded so well to those afflicted with Leprosy

reviews.title: A Very Important Story Here-Don't Miss it
reviews.text:
This hospital has a very interesting history. At one time 3% of Norway's population was infected. Dr. Hansen, who discovered that it was caused by a bacterium, worked at St. George's, hence the name Hansen's Disease. The hospital complex is as was decades ago. 

I strongly recommend a tour, our guide Monica, was top notch. Answering all questions and very welcoming. Thanks, Monica! I don't know how many tours they do a day, but ours started at 12 noon.

Admission was free with our Bergen card. The tour costs NOK20.

With the tour which ended with viewing the inside of the wooden church, a real gem, took about 1:15 hours. The church was opened for 10 minutes at 12:50. You probably didn't come to Bergen to go to a Leprosy Museum-but you really should put it on your itinerary.

name: Hardanger Fjord
ranking_subcategory: #3 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #3 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #3 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: Private Tour: Full-Day Round Trip to Hardangerfjord from Bergen
Private Tour: Bergen to Hardangerfjord Golden Circle
Bride's Veil and Steinsdalsfossen waterfalls with sceneries of Hardanger Fjord
DRIVE PORSCHE FROM BERGEN TO HARDANGERFJORD AND VØRINGSFOSS - NORWEGIAN GUIDE

reviews.title: Great Boat ride with lovely views
reviews.text: There were so many great views and mountains and fjord as we navigated through the freezing water. I was frozen from sitting outside but it was worth the many pictures I took,  windy but clear skies, and boat filled with people was unforgettable and I would do it again.

reviews.title: Enormous
reviews.text: Hardanger Fjord seemed to go on forever.  Few towns, but very scenic.  Drive along side or get out on the water and enjoy it.

reviews.title: Each fiord has something special
reviews.text: opening the time going through this fiord makes me want to go back and do many others...which I intend to do.

reviews.title: Good boat trip.
reviews.text: Despite the occasional squall, our boat trip from Eisfjord to Nordheimsund, zig zagging across Hardanger was wonderful. Mountains with snow, waterfalls etc..

reviews.title: See it from the water.
reviews.text: I live in Southeast Alaska and wanted to see how Norway compares.  It was disorienting because the scenery looked familiar but there were no landmarks I could recognize.  What I enjoyed was seeing the small towns along the shore and the mountain farm high up.  The suspension bridge across the fjord is striking.  This gives you a real feel for the country.  At the very end is Eidsfjord a delightful little town.

reviews.title: Great activity on a nice weather day
reviews.text:
We booked a tour of the Hardanger Fjord with Go Fjords round trip from Bergen. It was a seamless transfer via 75 minute coach bus ride from Bergen bus station to the town of Nordheimsund for the ferry/cruise portion to the town of Eidfjord and back (with several other stops along the way). We had several hours to explore Eidfjord and surrounding area on foot before returning to the boat, otherwise there was also an optional bus tour of the area you could add on for additional cost. 

We thoroughly enjoyed our day exploring the scenery of the Hardanger fjord and the town of Eidfjord. We were traveling with our baby and were pleasantly surprised that the coach bus from Bergen had a built-in car seat and the boat had large table/booths reserved for families with small children and baby changing facilities in the bathroom on board. We made sure to book this cruise on a day with good weather forecast, which I would recommend is a must if possible to get the full enjoyment of the scenery.

reviews.title: Not as great while viewing from the confines of a bus
reviews.text: As part of a NCL Pearl cruise excursion, we opted for the Hardanger Fjord tour, a long long bus ride with a quick ferry ride to drive around to see the fjord. The fjord is stunning, but only being able to witness it while in a bus or on a quick stop, didn't do it the justice it deserves.

reviews.title: worth the trip
reviews.text: If you're not driving you can get there via a combination of public transportation, part of which is a boat ride. The ride is interesting and you can see how the landscape changes as you get farther into the fjord. There are also great views of the waterfalls in Eidfjord.

reviews.title: Spectacular!
reviews.text: We drove around the edges of this magnificent fjord. It takes hours but is well worth it. Highly recommended.

reviews.title: Scenic drive past the Hardanger fjord
reviews.text: Grateful views of the fjord especially in April when the ice is still melting away and you get a cross between white and blue

reviews.title: Beautiful fjords
reviews.text: Go out on the fjords as much as you can because that's why you are here. The narrow fjords are better. Get off on the beautiful towns and soak this in. Too surreal.

reviews.title: Beautiful Hardanger
reviews.text: A visit to Hardanger to experience the scenery, the mountains, the Fjord and all the villages, is a must if you visit the west coast of Norway. It’s amazing all year, but maybe May is the finest month when all the fruit trees are in full blossom.

reviews.title: Beautiful fjord, real west coast fjord
reviews.text:
This is one of the most beautiful fjords I have seen.  Definitely not a typical tourist destination.  We visited the manor house, very interesting.  Several great hikes in the area, also fished in the fjord.

If you are looking for an authentic Norwegian experience, this is a great option.

reviews.title: An interestring Fjord
reviews.text: I must say initially I was disappointed that there were no steep mountain sides plunging inti the Fjord, but never the less I really enjoyed the Fjord cruise and seeing the tiny coloured houses dotted about an immaculately clean landscape. I'd like to return one day and explore it some more.

reviews.title: Beautiful landscape
reviews.text: When we have guests from abroad we always make a point to rent a car to show the Hardanger fjord. It has spectacular scenery and you can stop at some nice little coffee shops, selling some local products

reviews.title: Gorgeous!  Take Your Time and Don't Try to Cover Too Much Distance In a Day
reviews.text: It was beautiful, even in the rain.  We were equipped with layers and light weight rain clothes plus waterproof hiking shoes.  We were comfortable exploring in all weather, which is what one needs to be prepared to do.  We especially loved the small villages and recommend that you stay at least two nights in each one to allow time to explore.  If the GPS says the trip will take two hours, be prepared for a four hour drive.  You will want to stop a lot!  There are so many amazing things to see along the way.  You may also have to sit and wait for road maintenance or discover that the route you planned to take is closed.  There is a website for that but we preferred to take the advice of the locals in the immediate area.  They know the micro climates better than anyone.

reviews.title: Excellent place
reviews.text: We booked a private tour there. As I know there buses going from Bergen to the Hardanger fjord on a regular basis. Recommendation - to visit steindalsfossen waterfall

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text: The longest fjord of Norway can be reached by local bus and catamaran boat which also seves as public transport. We took a ticket via internet and started relatively early in the morning and cam in the evening, all in all it took 12 hours. Too bad weather was terrible, but occasionaly we could get on upper open deck of the boat which stops in some 5 ports on the way. Numerous springs going down the slopes, numerous waterfalls along the road or along the fjord, and it seems every little settlement has its own waterfall. Internet say 40% of some sort of fruits in Norway comes from this area (like apples, pears, plums) and you can find local produces in these little towns. This is definitely not a very active excursion, but for our small group it was very pleasing and relaxing, in spite of nasty weather.

reviews.title: gorgeous
reviews.text: we loved our travel in Norway. Just driving was spectacular. The Fjords are amazing, and we fashioned a trip from Bergen into the Fjords based on recommendations and the national tourist routes.

reviews.title: What an amazing place!
reviews.text: We stayed in Eidfjord at the end of Hardanger Fjord.  It was out of season, with rain and sunshine taking turns showing their faces every 10 minutes. It was a beautiful time to be in this area, which is a spectacular place to be. There is so much to explore. As an american, I loved that I felt like there were almost no other american tourists. We went to a local food/harvest festival and truly enjoyed the local appeal. We stayed at Eidfjord Hotel which had great breakfasts. This is a magical place.

reviews.title: Wonderful
reviews.text: Hardanger was one of the places briefly visited on a day trip - was on a P&O cruise. Lovely countryside and interesting little town on the edge of the fjord. Wish we had more time to explore but of all the different places we visited I felt this may be one I would return to in order to get to Norway. We went in September and the weather was not cold but very very wet.

reviews.title: Gorgeous Drive
reviews.text: We had a rental car so we drove along Fv7 and highway 13 to enjoy the fjord at our own pace and be able to stop when and where we wanted.  It was a spectacular drive and there was not much traffic so were able to go slow and pull over when we saw a photo op.  The road gets kind of narrow in places, and it might not have been as fun if I was sharing the road with a lot of tour buses. Quaint little towns like Alvik, Kvanndal, Granvin, Kinsarvik, and Lofthus were what we came to Bergen to see. Very beautiful!

reviews.title: Simply stunning.
reviews.text: This was a wonderful trip in changeable weather which added to the ambience. .Amazing scenery and lovely settlements along its shores .Nice to see a dolphin pod.

reviews.title: Breath taking
reviews.text: Beautiful every step of the way I really enjoyed driving through the countryside and seeing the fjord.

reviews.title: Lunch stop at Norheimsund
reviews.text: Brief visit to Norheimsund which is a lovely, little town on the banks of the Fjord. Took a brief walk alongside in the inevitable rain. It's beautiful, as you would expect!

reviews.title: Great daytrip on nice day from Bergen
reviews.text: We visited this fjord by car, effectively going around the fjord on occasionally narrow roads.  This takes you through a picturesque village (Herand) and you can catch the return car ferry at Jondal where friendly convenient cafe for late lunch.

reviews.title: Traveling Norway 2018
reviews.text:
PRO'S: We took an all day excursion from our Holland American cruise ship docked in Bergen traveling along Hardanger, several other fjords and scenic areas immediately East of Bergen, Norway. It was a quick introduction to the Norwegian landscape and we liked it in general. Our encounter with locals in the area was pleasant and the people seemed to enjoy meeting tourists.

CON'S: The lunch and snacks at our two stops were okay and rather bland. 

SUMMARY: A one day tour of scenic fjords around Bergen in Western Norway was a pleasant enjoyable experience. It makes us want to return for an extended trip through Norway.

reviews.title: Highlight of our trip to Norway...so far
reviews.text: This is a review of the Hardangerfjord Cruise round trip from Norheimsund with bus roundtrip from Bergen. The bus ride was nice but the highlight was of course the cruise. It was a very rainy day with very short breaks of sun and despite this, it was an exhilarating experience being outside on the upper deck for as long as you could stand being pelted by rain. The clouds in the mountains actually added to the great pictures and videos. The difference between seeing the views through the window and standing on the deck is like the difference between being at a sporting event in a stadium and watching the same exact event on TV. So, make the effort and go up on the deck, even if you initially don’t feel like it. WARNING: Several people fell on the slippery narrow stairs up to the deck and one woman had major pain and crying. Use both rails at the same time to avoid injury, especially kids! As with all fjords, the narrower ones are more impressive. Be outside on deck for these and pay attention to details on land such as boat houses, farms, isolated houses, literally thousands of waterfalls. We saw two rainbows. Eidfjord has absolutely gorgeous surroundings. The boat has a 2 hr 45 min layover there. Bring change 10 Kr for public bathrooms. Ulvik very beautiful. Many charming stops along the route. Views are MUCH better than the Express Boat from Bergen to Balestrand (Flam). Bring food with you for this 11.5 hour day trip from Bergen. Boat had two bathrooms, only one had toilet paper. Not a big deal for some of us. Our primary goal for this trip was to experience fjords. The Hardangerfjord cruise definitely met this goal. We are now starting 3 nights in Balestrand and intend to experience more fjords differently.

reviews.title: Drive from Bergen to Hardanger Fjord
reviews.text: Breath taking scenery the entire drive. Stayed overnight in town on Kvam at Thon Hotel. Short distance from Bergen.

reviews.title: Sognefjord is better
reviews.text: Nice views but go on a fjord tour rather on Sogne Fjord, Hardanger is not spectacular enough and also quite busy

reviews.title: Most beautiful farms
reviews.text: This was one of the most inhabited fjords we saw.  It was lined with first farms and houses all in beautiful condition, then their were miles of family fishing and summer cottages; beautiful with interesting designs.  The water was clear and deep.

reviews.title: An easy one day self tour from Bergen
reviews.text:
We did DIY from Bergen-Norheimsund(Bus)-Eidfjord(Cruise)-Voringsfossen(local tour)-Voss(Bus)-Bergen(train). It was about 11`12 hours and it was cheaper if you DIY instead of purchasing the package from web site. There are tour companies providing similar trips with tour guide but they are more expensive.
During the trip, you spent most of time on bus/cruise/train, you got about 3 hours at Eidfjord and we chose to attend the local tour to visit the Voringsfossen (waterfall) and Hardangervidda Nature center. The waterfall was smaller than what we had seen from Youtube and the Nature center was an interesting place.
The view of Hardanger Fjord from cruise (2:45) was beautiful but not as magnificent as Sognefjord or Nærøyfjord. If you plan to spend two days at Bergen, this is a good choice.

name: The Norwegian Fisheries Museum
ranking_subcategory: #19 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #19 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #19 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: The Norwegian Fisheries Museum is about the fishing history and coastal culture of Norway. The old wharf side warehouses and the harbour with traditional boats makes a great setting for our stories about fishing traditions in Norway. Explore the history of the sea by immersing yourself in interesting artefacts and stories, or engage the whole family in a multitude of new activities. The cafe serve lunches. The historic seaside houses provide a casual and homely atmosphere, inside and outside. Museum shop. We offer Exhibitions Group packages, School packages, Conference facilities. Rowboat rental Getting there The historic ferry "Beffen" leaves every hour from Bryggen between 11 am and 4 pm, only weekends in May, all days in June, July, August and September. The museum is a 20-minute walk from Bryggen, or less than 15 minutes from the cruise ship terminal at Bontelabo. A 5-minute bus-ride from Bryggen, numbers 3, 4, 5, 6, 36, 39, 83 go past the museum.

offer_list.title: City Sightseeing Bergen Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour
Biking and Hiking in Bergen

reviews.title: very few informations and few artifacts on display! Morover oriented views for Norway benefit
reviews.text:
I decide to visit this museum on a rainy day to get more information about salmon farms (we see in every corner of the fjord aera  into Norway).
I ask prior to my visit at the desk and they directed to me to a collaborator who explain to me that a lot of my answers can be found into their museum exhibit rooms.
I spend ONE HOUR into all the display rooms w/o finding too much informations of the Norwaygian area ( million tons produced every year!!! and almost half of the revenue of the fishing industriy there).
When I ask again and visit the rooms again w/ this collaborator my answers have been poorly answered (food, pollution of the sea floor, health issue, escaping salmon that are hybrids ands will modify wild salmon genetics...).
Due to the importance of this fish industry in Norway I think that will worth at least an entire exhibit room!
International campaign against seal pups chasing that stop that massacre in 1984 worth a room w/ a film that show only one point of view of the Norvegian part (you can imagine which one!).
Same scandal w/ salmon farming is growing! Don't eat such a product and prefer wild caughts (Alaska, Pacific ocean that are regulated and not destroy the fjord environment as here!)

reviews.title: Fisheries History
reviews.text:
A look at the life of Norway's fish and life along the coast. It's in an 18th century wharf warehouse with traditional and interactive displays. 

Free shuttle to and from museum. And tours are available.

reviews.title: Small but memorable museum about the history and current state of fishing in Norway!
reviews.text: I love eating fish so was happy to stop by here. Interactive sections fun for kids and adults. Free parking and 15 minute walking distance to Bergen harbor

reviews.title: A piscine visit
reviews.text: This museum is located slightly away from Bryggen but do not worry there is a free to and fro shuttle service. The museum is in an old building but has lots of modern animated features. Gives lots of information on fishing and the fishes. A must visit.

reviews.title: Learn about fishing and enjoy the cafe..
reviews.text: This museum tells the story of Norwegian Fishing.  For kids there are good interactive displays.  Because I live in a fishing town (Sitka), I found conversations with the docents to be very enlightening.  I also enjoyed the displays, especially of gear types.

reviews.title: A lot to learn and enjoy
reviews.text: We stopped off from our city tour bus to visit this not knowing what to expect. we were pleasantly surprised by the quality and quantity of information available. Well worthwhile.

reviews.title: Unplanned but Worth the Visit
reviews.text: While in Bergen, the two museums we wanted to see were closed for renovation: the Hanseatic Museum and the Bryggens Museum. We did manage to go to the "annex" of the Hanseatic Museum, the Schøtstuene. When we finished with that, we weren't sure what to do, so we asked one of the docents. She suggested the Norwegian Fisheries Museum. While one can take a bus, we opted to walk and had a very scenic half hour stroll to get to the museum. While it appears to be the perfect place for class trips and is somewhat geared to the younger set, it was nonetheless an excellently done museum. It is set in historic wharf warehouse buildings but the exhibits are about as modern as can be as to technology, interactive displays and other media. There are a lot of hands-on exhibits. And there is what turned out to be a lot of interesting information about the backbone industry of Norway from both an historic perspective and a future-looking sustainability perspective. We ended up spending a couple of hours here. It also has a very cozy cafe serving yummy food and with nice views onto the water.

reviews.title: Better than Expected
reviews.text: We learned so much about fisheries, sustainability, history. I thought it would be boring, but it was quite interesting, with plenty of touch screens and activities for kids.  And everything explained in Norwegian and English.  The cafe is expensive, though. Two coffees and two pastries were $25!

reviews.title: Good exhibits in a great building
reviews.text: We were met by enthusiastic staff, keen to know where we were visiting from. The museum is housed in a traditional wharf warehouse, sympathetically refurbished to meet modern standards, and is equally as interesting as the exhibits. There are a range of exhibits, many of which are interactive, covering the history of fishing, the fish species and the marine environment challenges of today. Plenty to interest both children and adults. Worthwhile exploring the Sandviken neighbourhood if you're interested in modern waterfront residential architecture. Oh, and the museum has a good café!

reviews.title: Well worth a visit
reviews.text:
Very knowledgeable and friendly staff greeted us. 
This museum informs really well about the full ecosystem of the oceans, marine life with a focus on fish, fishing and traditional Norwegian fishing lives, with integrated displays and good children’s sections. 
The video of the three generations of fishermen and their working lives and the current challenges was particularly poignant.

reviews.title: Insightful Museum that tied our whole vacation together
reviews.text: Very well done insights into the Norwegian fishing industry, the fish, and great exhibits on the flord aquatic life. A little bit out of town,but a van runs back and forth to the Hanseatic League Museum. We spent about 2 hours there and coul d have stayed longer.

reviews.title: Fishing made interesting
reviews.text: The price of this can be included in that for the Hanseatic museum. The exhibits and displays are over four floors and include history of fishing, details of what is being done to protect fish/marine life and interactive displays which will keep children, teenagers and adults happy

reviews.title: Once Norway lived on fish
reviews.text: Somewhat outside the city center, you can come here by free shutlle bus (it is free if you have a combo ticked from another museum, predominantly from hanseatic museu which is now closed for 6 years) or by busses 3, 4, 5 or 6. It is interesting to see exhibition, but must say it is not spectacular. Sill, would recommend the visit. Norway is one of the countries that defied whale hunt ban (you can get whale meat in some restaurants) and also in one room you can see terribly cruel seal hunt and murdering baby seals. Not for everyone's eyes.

reviews.title: Spend as much time as you wish
reviews.text: You can see this museum in 45 minutes but if you start wandering about, you may get entranced and spend two hours, as we did.  This museum is outside the downtown and there is a shuttle from in front of the Hansweatic Museum right on the waterfront.  This is a modern spacious building and it is handicap accessible. It has interactive exhibits for kids and adults and some great short "films" that clarify the dilemmas of modern Norwegian fishing. Science, romance, and culture.  Well-sorth your time.

reviews.title: Educational, fun blend of history with modern technology
reviews.text:
This is a really fun museum that ranks up there with the best museums we've visited.  The use of technology to educate, entertain, and interact with children and adults is superior.

The scavenger hunt is super fun for little ones as well.

Seems odd to visit a fish museum, this one is definitely worth it.

reviews.title: How to make a fish and fishing very interesting
reviews.text: A very well presented and informative museum that exceeded expectations by making a fish and fishing very interesting. Well done.

reviews.title: Surprisingly interesting
reviews.text: Surprisingly interesting museum located on multiple floors, very interactive, covering lots of topics connected to fishing and the industry behind.

reviews.title: Cool interactive museum
reviews.text: Fun place with lots of interactive features. Fun for all ages, but particularly children will lovee this place. The buildings themselves are also interesting and the restaurant sits nicely on the back by the water. Well worth a visit! Free entry and shuttle bus when entry to Hanseatic Museum is purchased.

reviews.title: Fascinating museum in a historic setting
reviews.text: This is a good museum for adults and children. Historic and contemporary issues are dealt with in an interesting and balanced way .Visually good and lots of gadgets for the young..Nice staff .

reviews.title: Fantastic for children but also great for adults
reviews.text:
This is a relatively new museum. We were intending to go anyway but were delighted to be told when visiting the Hanseatic House that they were promoting the fishing museum so they handed us free tickets. There is also a free shuttle bus between the two museums which runs every half hour.

Judging by the sparse attendance in August this is clearly an under-appreciated facility.

It is spread over several floors  in two buildings and although there is a recommended route visitors are encouraged to wander at will. The rotes to the various sections are indicated by different coloured fish on the floor.

I would particularly urge you to watch the eighteen minute film on the first floor about fishing. Three generations discuss their love of this way of life. Sadly at the end they conclude that boats have got bigger and more expensive and that even if the young man were to get the money for a boat he could not afford the exorbitant cost of a quota. Their island faces depopulation as inhabitants are no longer able to fish.

In contrast I would suggest you skip the film on sealing, especially if you have children. Some of the scenes depicted are not pleasant.

The whole museum is very child friendly and nowhere more so than on the top floor where children’s photos are taken and their avatars are projected onto the picture of a town where they then have to interact with the display.

I will conclude with a small plug for the cafe with it’s home baked bread and charming atmosphere.

reviews.title: Interesting fishing hostory
reviews.text: This is a friendly and approachable museum for kids or adults. It’s a bit out of town but a free bus runs beginning across from the fish market (the Hanseatic Museum) often throughout the day.  We could it interesting and suggest it if you have extra time or if it’s raining.

reviews.title: Take children here on a wet day
reviews.text: If it's raining in Bergen, and at some time it will be, and you need to amuse the kids, take them here to the top floor. Not a huge museum and a little out of town so get the free shuttle bus that takes off every half hour from the Hanseatic Museum just across from the fish markets. This is a hands-on place for kids. I heard a few laughing as they fished from a revolving tub. Quite a small museum...but if you've got children and it's raining, this place might just keep you sane for an hour.

reviews.title: Out of the way but worth it
reviews.text:
In my previous trips to Bergen, I didn't consider this museum because it just seemed to be too far out of the center of Bergen. Although it isn't in center city Bergen, the museum is only a couple of stops from the Fish Market on one of a number of city buses. We originally planned to take the free ferry that departs from the Fish Market. But the ferry never arrived and we later learned that when the waters are rough, the ferry doesn't run. A sign would have been nice. So, if the harbor waters seem choppy, just get the bus. The museum's website clearly indicates which buses run to the museum.
At any rate, once we figured out that the ferry wasn't running, we decided to take the bus from Bryggen and we got off at Sandvikstorget. (The bus driver also pointed out the museum for us.)  If you get a Bergen Tourist Card, travel on buses and the tram is free as is entrance into the museum. 
The museum is located in an old fishing warehouse and takes you through the history of fishing from Bergen. I found the exhibits on fish farms and the history of seal hunting to be particularly interesting. And, the video interviews of fishermen from three generations was particularly entertaining, especially their discussions of seasickness! The museum also includes a lovely cafe in which you can have a cup of coffee or tea while overlooking the harbor.

reviews.title: Interesting for an hour from Bergen by boat
reviews.text: We picked up a cute little motorised boat from Bergen harbour which took about 20 minutes to reach the fisheries museum. The price included the entrance. The boat driver took us into the museum. There are interesting exhibits and interactive little games for children. It's not exciting but a pleasant way to spend 45 minutes before having a coffee in the gorgeous cafe next door and then catch the boat back to Bergen harbour. Really friendly helpful staff.

name: Bergen Aquarium

photo.caption: Hvordan ser en bøylepingvin ut? Bøylepingvin på Akvariet i Bergen.

ranking_subcategory: #27 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #27 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #27 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: "WHO WE ARE AND WHAT YOU CAN EXPERIENCE..." AN EXPERIENCE THAT GUARANTEES A DESIRE TO LEARN! Male penguins sometimes adopt eggs and become the world's best "mothers", some turtles can breathe through their backsides, the plastic we throw away every year creates a sheet in the ocean as big as some countries, and spiders use hydraulics to move: after a visit to the aquarium, you'll definitely know something you didn't beforehand. And you'll know it with your entire body - not just your head. At Bergen Aquarium, children and adults alike can see, touch, read about and follow the animals and aquarium keepers at close range. You can watch shows and feedings, and see how fish and animals act when in their element. Bergen Aquarium has been a must-see institution for visitors and residents alike since 1960. It's situated a short way from the centre of Bergen, in a fantastic parkside location with a view out over the seaward approach to Bergen from all sides. There's good food, too: Biologen Akvariet is a brasserie offering proper food made with proper ingredients. It'll give you energy for the whole visit, and then some.

offer_list.title: City Sightseeing Bergen Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour

animal_welfare_tag.msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.
Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.

reviews.title: really an amazing place for the whole family
