reviews.text: great film great for kids that speaks about fishing quotas. Great information. Minus: many information about using less plastic, but restaurant (which was great) serves plastic bottles :( such a contradiction.

reviews.title: Beautiful aquarium
reviews.text: We visited this place today. It was very neat and spacious and beautiful display of all aquatic animals. Even the penguins were so cute. We loved everything here and the kids enjoyed it a lot. The sea lion show was also very nice and enjoyable.

reviews.title: Fascinating penguins
reviews.text: Small but well laid out aquarium, also home to some reptiles, sea lions and penguins. Very clean as tidy as expected in this City and easy to navigate. Highlight was the penguins, watching the nest building and seeing the recently hatched baby penguins. If you want large sharks this is not the place to go, but good collections of Atlantic fish and a smaller but colourful tropical collection. Big displays about the problems with plastics in the environment.

reviews.title: Good short activity
reviews.text: We walked up from the train station, about a 30 min walk, and enjoyed about 90 minutes here.  Good collection of wildlife. Everyone enjoyed themselves.

reviews.title: Small aquarium with a couple of good attractions
reviews.text: If you have visited a large aquarium before, this one may seem underwhelming. That being said it does have some very good displays and I found the penguin, sea lion and otter exhibits entertaining.

reviews.title: What a place for a family afternoon!
reviews.text: It's a small aquarium, but the penguin feeding and sea lion feeding shows are great. Toddlers absolutely love all the displays. I went there a decade ago, and it was stinky, but no longer!

reviews.title: Nice for the Kids
reviews.text: This is a nice aquarium for the kids and is pretty much focused on the 4-8 age group. There is even a section of creepy, crawly buys and snakes. For adults, some of the exhibits in the bottom level are interesting.

reviews.title: Small but enjoyable aquarium
reviews.text: On our cruise stop in Bergen we jumped on the hop on- hop off bus. One of the stops was the Bergen Aquarium.   We arrived about 11:00 and they had a feeding and talk about the penguins. It was nice and the penguins are cute. We walked over to where they have a few sea lions and enjoyed watching them swim. We also walked through the fish aquarium area and it has numerous fish species. Even though the facility is small they have a good amount of animals and fish to see.

reviews.title: Small but great place for an afternoon with kids
reviews.text: The Bergen aquarium is small but lively. It is a great place to spend 2-3 hours, particularly on a cloudy or rainy day. There are live demonstrations with the sea lions and several other crowd-pleasing animals such as penguins, sea otters, and marmosets. There are plenty of baby changing rooms and a dedicated area for nursing mothers, as well as a cafe.

reviews.title: Small butnsurprisingly versatile
reviews.text:
In mid-september it wasn't crowded at all. What looks like a small place from the surface (penguins, sea-lions and otters) actually hides a magnificent collection of reptiles, as well as a huge number of fish and other (mostly) aquatic animals.
Easy to spend 3-4 hours there if you like fish and animals.

reviews.title: Great day out
reviews.text: Haven’t visited here for about 10 years and was impressed at the improvements with a bigger sea lion tank and playground for young children on the roof. The aquarium is fantastic for the variety of marine life it offers as well as the terrifying crocodiles which my 3 year old loved to watch. The admission price wasn’t too bad for Norway about £75 for a family ticket. We got there for about 1030 hrs and stayed until 1600 hrs so definitely value for money. The restaurant was good but would have liked fresh Sausage to be made fresh rather than the buffet style. However all in all a real must visit especially for the kids.

reviews.title: Go and meet the penguins
reviews.text:
It is a nice place and the staff is so warm and welcoming.
Entrance fee is a bit expensive :)

You can also buy gifts to loved ones there.
Visit there around afternoon or you can miss the seals, they are a bit early sleeper.

reviews.title: Great
reviews.text: The penguins were adorable, sea lion show was grat and the otters were so cute. Staff was very nice and ready to help. Many exhibitions with alot of different fish, snakes and crocodiles. Great exhibition about the plastic in the oceans.

reviews.title: Through worlds of terrestrial and aquatic animals
reviews.text:
Bergen Aquarium is not only place where we can see and learn more about different species of animals living in water but also on various small and average terrestrial animals. 

Near the entrance to the Aquarium are places where charming gentoo penguins (Pygoscelis papua) and clever sea lions are kept. In the big pavilion are kept insects, spiders, amphibians and reptiles from different parts of the world. Above that in the Bergen Aquarium are located the restaurant and nice gift shop. 

Bergen Aquarium is a nice place to spend several hours and to discover various species of animals.

reviews.title: Lovely aquarium
reviews.text: We are a family of four; two adults and two teenage boys.We went to Bergen aquarium today and the staff told us that they hid five eggs in the aquarium.Anyone who finds the egg will get a prize.The kids were so excited and we found one egg! We have seen penguin and sea lion shows and they were nice.The aquarium is not big but we have seen a lot of interesting animals with English and Norwegian explanation.I think it’s definitely a good place to go with family especially if you are interested in animals.

reviews.title: Stay away if you are older than 5
reviews.text: Having visited other aquariums, like Lisbon or Osaka, I was expecting something. Unfortunately these expectations weren’t met. The aquarium is quite small and definitely build to appeal to the younger public, which you can easily recognize by the low windows and easy to understand infos. The aquariums seemed in a pretty bad shape sometimes, a bit dirty and a lot of algae. Overall it was a bit depressing. Therefore save the 20€ entrance fee and take a stroll along the seashore. For kids I guess it’s entertaining.

reviews.title: Family visit
reviews.text: This may be a small aquarium but it is marvellous, you can see all the animals are well cared for. The glass for viewing animals was really clear so you could see them clearly. The information was easy to read and very informative. We loved it!

reviews.title: Disappointing
reviews.text: The Aquarium is quite small. We did see some very sweet penguins being fed. If you have young children probably a good place to go if you are just adults may not be so interesting. Good work being down on the impacts of plastic which was interesting to read

reviews.title: Pleasant aquarium.
reviews.text: Pleasant aquarium and great if you have kids. Not big but gives you enough time to see the feeding of different animals at different times. Cafe was reasonably priced.

reviews.title: Must visit place
reviews.text: This is the best aquarium I have ever visited in my life. U just get to say wow when u visit it. Well maintained and so well managed. Different types n variety of fishes here that u will go mad. U will definitely love it. Must visit place when u r in Bergen

reviews.title: Rather small aquarium
reviews.text:
The aquarium is the largest in Bergen but it is still relatively small compared to many I visited. Penguins would greet you once you stepped into the aquarium and the feeding time is 11 am. There is seal performance for about 10 mins at 12 pm. The different animals, reptiles , fishes are hosted inside the aquarium. There is a Theater which will screen some short documentary shows. 
We walked about 20 mins from our hotel and bus 11 to city. With Bergen card, you get free entry.

reviews.title: A great little Aquarium in Bergen
reviews.text: The day I visited the Aquarium was perfect, as the weatehr outdoors was cold with light snow. There was an sea lion show that was starting as I entered. The Penguins are fun too. The in the interior, there are several exhibits. Each was ell done, and it was a surprise to see suh a well done aquarium in Bergen.

reviews.title: Woth a visit, especially on the Bergen Card
reviews.text: We hadn't planned to visit this, but having bought a Bergen Card and then discovered that many of the museums we wanted to see were shut, we decided we might as well take a look as the card gets you in for free. There's an impressive amount to see here, not just fish in glass cases, although there are many of them, but also penguins, crocodiles and a variety of other animals who take the the water for at least some of their lives. The displays were mostly in English as well as Norwegian. There seemed to cater very well for children too.

reviews.title: A cute aquarium
reviews.text: Expensive, but worth a visit. The sea lion show was captivating, and we really liked seeing all of the fish up close. Daddy liked the snakes, too. Otherwise, some of the tanks and exhibits were a bit run-down...

reviews.title: Rainy Saturday morning at the Aquarium
reviews.text: A rainy Saturday morning in Bergen… what to do? If you have kids, then go to the Aquarium. They fed the penguins and there was a sea lion show on the morning I was there. Lots of kid friendly displays throughout the Aquarium. Seriously though, I went without kids (traveling alone) and I really enjoyed it. A part from watching the penguins, sea lions and sea otters, everything else was inside.

reviews.title: Enjoyed every second
reviews.text: I am a sucker for an aquarium, and I thoroughly enjoyed this one. it was a nice walk along the water from my hotel, and the Bergen Card resulted in free entry.  There were crocs, sea lions, snakes, spiders, otters, fish and all kinds of weird and wonderful creatures.  I was there for the sea lion presentation, which was thoroughly enjoyable.  The staff were very friendly and helpful.  A fun afternoon all around!

reviews.title: Quaint?
reviews.text: My husband and I enjoyed our trip to Bergan and thought we should take in the aquarium, it being in a sea side town.  After a long walk in the rain (tip:  Talk the Hope on Hope off bus), we finally found the aquarium.  For us it was a bit of let down.  Fine for school groups, and families with kids.  The real problem was we had visited the Toronton Aquarium the year previous and not much can compare.  So unless there is something you'd really like to learn, this might be a pass?

reviews.title: Small but interesting.
reviews.text:
Quite small for an aquarium but a lot packed in on three underground levels.
Shark tunnel a little dissapointing as sharks not very big. Many of the creatures are not really aquatic - snakes, spiders etc.

reviews.title: Great for a rainy day
reviews.text: We visited on a wet day before leaving for our flight.  A good selection of animals and fish and although it is smaller than some there is plenty to do and see for 2 or 3 hours.  Watched the sea lion show which was short but still very entertaining.   Would suggest you check daily programme for feeding times of the different animals.

reviews.title: Educational, very interesting and fun day at the aquarium
reviews.text: Mother with 2 kids went half day experience at the aquarium (11:30-15:30). We GOT to see the sealions show, watched a movie about whales and Even had late lunch/early dinner in the restaurant. The food was not to child-friendly, but tasted good for the adult. 😉 You can see all kinds of sea animals, and even touch some of them! 😍

reviews.title: Good selection of animals and fish
reviews.text: The place has a good selection of animals and fish and easy to spend a couple of hours wandering around. Staff seem to be trying hard but the building is looking dated and in need to a make over.

reviews.title: Great for a rainy day
reviews.text: A wet day in Bergen so a visit to the Aquarium was an ideal way to spend a few hours.  The outdoor exhibits need attention however indoor marine life on display was much more impressive.

reviews.title: Perfect little spot to visit with Bergen Card.
reviews.text: This is a typical aquarium but it was quite nice to visit. It was a bit of walk from the centre of the town, but very enjoyable. Got lots of fun attractions, otters, seals and penguins. As well as the usual snakes, spiders and fish! Overall a fun visit, especially for free with the Bergen Card. A good way to get out of the miserable weather too!

reviews.title: This Aquarium is great fun
reviews.text:
This is really a wonderful Aquarium and great fun. You can feel that they care about the animals. There is a lot of information about the animals and the marine life in the sea. 
There is a cozy cafe on the premises and parking facilities next to the Aquarium.

reviews.title: Small, personal and fun
reviews.text: Smaller than other aquaria around the world, this was well worth the visit. Nice variety. Interesting exhibits.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: A must in Bergen . A lot of medium size aquariums with all the different species of  fish ,both locals and exotic . A nice place to take the children both to watch the feeding of the Penguins  or the Otters. One drawback: the price is quite high!

reviews.title: Interesting place
reviews.text: We went a little late in the evening (5pm) and some exhibits are closed for referbishment, but there's still quite a bit to see, I would recommend going to the penguin feeding show, it was very interesting.

reviews.title: Great if you have time to kill
reviews.text: We visited the Aquarium with our last few hours before catching a flight home from Bergen. I'd agree with other reviews, it is a little expensive given the size of the Aquarium and is starting to look dated. That said, Aquarium's aren't cheap to run and Norway isn't cheap either so it wasn't too bad all thing considered. Good selection of fish and other creatures to see and all very accessible, we went on a Sunday and pleased to say it wasn't too crowded so we had time to see everything and get to the front without having to fight for a view.

reviews.title: Small but perfectly formed
reviews.text: A great little find and perfect for a cold rainy day.  It was about £25 each for the entrance fee, not cheap, but the experience was good. We saw the sealion display (although they kept us entertained for far longer just watching them swimming past the viewing window) and the penguins before going inside. They've done a great job of explaining all the fish they have in the context of Norway's different waterways (fjords, sea, rivers etc) and it offers a far better experience than any of the UK aquariums in my opinion.  There were some lizards and crocodiles too.  Avoid the cafe - overpriced and manned by surly teenagers with poor customer service. Other than that, well worth a visit!

reviews.title: Expensive but good
reviews.text: Even with my Bergen discount this still cost over £20 which I thought was way too expensive for what was an interesting but average aquarium. Apart from the fish, there are also reptiles and amphibians but these have no detailed descriptions or pictures with them so, if they are hiding, you would not know what they looked like. Good for the kids but not excellent at the cost.

reviews.title: Disappointing
reviews.text: Found this to be a tired but expensive exhibition. I love visiting aquariums around the world and although I didn't expect a large, glossy experience I found it to look like it was struggling to operate.

reviews.title: Great with kids
reviews.text: Quite lovely especially with children. Adults would enjoy as well. Lots of hands on exhibits. Very much a local display of fish

reviews.title: A great day, but to what cost?
reviews.text: A lot of fun, great place to visit for animal and marine interested people. Downside is the prices, you can get a discount if you bring your student-ID, but it is still too pricey. I won’t afford to go back sadly..

reviews.title: Go to see the seal lions
reviews.text: We went on a  wet Sunday afternoon to pass time and ended up watching the sealions almost by mistake. What good fun they were. Not a massive Hollywood show but a genuine display of good natured, hard working staff who had a great relationship with the seallions that had us laughing and sighing and clapping, a great moment on a cold wet day. The rest of the aquarium was as you'd expect from a small city -although the crocidiles were a surprise and the penguins were fun. Good little shop there too. Sometimes I thought the animals could have benefitted from more space but these places have their value in a world where natural habitat is so threatened by idiotic human behaviour which the aqurium were making efforts to educate us about.

reviews.title: Cute aquarium, limited displays
reviews.text:
Compared to most large cities this is a small aquarium. 
However it is well put together and the displays and aquariums are well put together and nice to look at. 
There are penguins, sea lions and otters in outside enclosures and they have talks/feeding displays/shows for each. 
Inside there are different habitat displays with fish and other sea life as well as snakes, spiders, Lizards and crocodiles. 
All can be seen in 1-2 hours.

reviews.title: Good spot for a rainy day
reviews.text: Nice to see some different penguins, and the 2 seals appeared very happy. Nice to see some unusual fish too. A pleasant visit on a cold day.

reviews.title: Place to take kids
reviews.text:
We visited the aquarium as couples. Collection if fishes and reptiles were average.Sea Lion and Penguin are really good attractions here.Its a place to visit if you have kids, Sure they will enjoy it.
Note: Bit pricey compared to collection of sea animals

reviews.title: Great aquarium!
reviews.text: When we first arrived at the aquarium we thought it looked a little small but were pleasantly surprised by the large variety of animals they had. The aquarium had a good layout and really made the most of the space. We caught the penguin feeding and sea lion show which were both great and presented by very friendly and enthusiastic staff. We had only planned to spend an hour here but ended up staying for 3 as we were enjoying it so much. Thanks for a great morning!

reviews.title: Good but simple
reviews.text: They take care of the animals in a good way altough it looked a bit small. They have pinquins, otters, sealions, crocodiles, little sharks, many differend fish, spiders, snakes and more. They show a movie about the salmon industry wich was interesting.  Good for a rainy day.

reviews.title: Excellent educational attraction.
reviews.text: This is an excellent small aquarium. Star attractions for the children are the Penguins, Sea Lions and Otters. All three have presentations at specific times during the day where their keepers entertain and inform. Indoors they have a Tropicana which houses caymans, snakes, spiders, marmosets and turtles. However the main displays are reserved for fish, ranging from sticklebacks to sharks, with a multitude of other ocean life in between. While this is undoubtedly an attraction its aim is to educate which I believe it does in a thought provoking and informative manner.

reviews.title: Dated
reviews.text: For an aquarium I was shocked at the lack of fish, saw plenty of spiders and monkeys though (who smell quite bad!).  The facilities are dated and I felt sorry for the sea lions and penguins.  There must be more to life!

reviews.title: Nice aquarium, look out for the seal show!
reviews.text: This is a nice little aquarium to spend half a day. They have penguin talks, a nice seal show where they show tricks, a movie theatre that shows good half hour movies (for example on Orca's or on the Norwegian Salmon Farming). There is also a touch pool.

reviews.title: Some good highlights, but room for improvement.
reviews.text:
Penguin feeding time was excellent. Amusing talk by staff member. 
Some areas were very empty looking and run down, especially outside area. 
Surprisingly good specimens in the indoor areas. 
Really enjoyed my trip with my 10 year old daughter, who loved it!

reviews.title: GO first thing in the morning, private feedings
reviews.text: Get there as close to 9am as you can - it's a real hike from the fish market area, and the buses only go once per hour and couldn't even find the bus stop to get there, but once we arrive, we got a private showing of the penguins, seal lions, and otters (there are no seals here, as others have mistakenly said). Seal lion feeding is right around 9:45 I believe, otters about 10 minutes later. I saw another review that someone's kid was upset there were no great whites in the shark tunnel - 1. great whites don't survive captivity, so there is no aquarium on earth you can see one; 2. this isn't NYC, it's Bergen, it's a small place, the aquarium is therefore small, so manage your expectations a little better in future.

reviews.title: Very good
reviews.text: Went by small boat for about 30kr from the fish market to the aquarium. Plenty to see not just fish. Very well laid out and worth a visit

reviews.title: The seals stole the show
reviews.text:
We gave our 9yo the challenge of creating our itinerary for a day, no surprise the aquarium was the first stop of the day.

Generally I find city aquariums a bit hit and miss. However I really liked the mix of outdoor and indoor elements, busy but not too busy it was an enjoyable place to explore

For us the seals stole the show, forever swimming past to check for an audience then blowing bubbles on their return. The outdoor penguins were cute and we caught the feeding time. 

Indoors a good variety of fish and reptiles to see. The crocodiles obviously wowed little ones & interesting reptiles. The shark tunnel didn’t live up to our sons great white expectations.

Only thing I found odd was in one display there were 2 monkeys (I can’t remember the species but small, black and white). Couldn’t help think it was unnecessary and could be in a better spaced environment

Price seemed a bit on the high end (740KNR for 2 adults and child = approx £74)

reviews.title: Wonderful little aquarium with a lot!
reviews.text: Got into Bergen before anything was open, so walked out to the aquarium. It is compact but multi-layered, and full of surprises. Penguins, otters, and sea lions are in pools/enclosures outside, a range of other aquatic creatures, reptiles, amphibians, and arachnids inside. They have frequent shows (one or two each hour) and there is a lot to see. My teenager was fully engaged and enjoyed the visit as much as I did.

reviews.title: No Wonder it's Rated One of Four Great Things (for Children) to Do in Bergen
reviews.text:
The national aquarium are paradise for kids (as well as adults who love animals). You will be fascinated even at the doorstep of Bergen Aquarium (Akvariet i Bergen) when you met the Gentoo penguins. 
Those charismatic waddlers, who are near threatened (IUCN Red List), are great examples of parenting. If they find their right partners, the two Gentoo penguins will have lifelong bonds (as what I've learned from the aquarium display board), and are highly nurturing. At breeding time, the two parents work to build a nest out of stones, grass, moss, and feathers; the mother then deposits two eggs, which both parents take turns incubating for more than a month. That's real good role models for us to learn from.
By the way, remember to check the penguin feeding time, usually 11am and 2pm (for which you can confirm on their website before the trip).

reviews.title: Nice place to spend a couple of hours especially if you have children
reviews.text: This is a really nice aquarium with a great selection of aquatic life on display. From penguins in an outside exhibit to tropical fish inside there is a lot to see. There is also an outside play area for younger children. Don't let the appearance of the building fool you into thinking this is a small display.  The only drawback to our visit was that it was crowded.

name: Bergenhus Fortress
ranking_subcategory: #28 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #28 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #28 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: City Sightseeing Bergen Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour
Bride's Veil and Steinsdalsfossen waterfalls with sceneries of Hardanger Fjord
Bergen Shore Excursion: Bergen Walking Tour
GUIDED TOUR: Secrets of the Fjords - the Osterfjord and Mo, 6.5 hours
Walking tour: Medieval Spirit of Bergen

reviews.title: A Nice Stroll
reviews.text: Nice place to wander around and get an impression of Bergen’s history. The fort also provides another visual perspective of Bergen. There is  limited historical information and access but it was a nice stroll.

reviews.title: very nice
reviews.text:
Dear readers,

this place is very old - it has lots of history.
we walked to this place - wear good walking shoes as the grass is mostly wet.
you will get a nice view from the top over the city to take picture.

reviews.title: Bergen trip
reviews.text: after a day on the off/on bus tour arround the city this was well worth getting off for, a nice walk around the fortressess

reviews.title: Not a very interesting place
reviews.text: It gives an impression of the history but a less of (closed) buildings and you have to go the same way back after a walk

reviews.title: Fascinating old place
reviews.text: This is certainly worth your time to take in while in Bergen. The building are very old, some as old as the 11th century. Really pretty interesting history in the area.

reviews.title: Exploring the fortress and museum
reviews.text:
The fortress is in close proximity to the cruise ship port.  Yes, we came in on a cruise.  There was a band practicing on the grounds as well as a small military museum near-by, which was free to enter.  Staff at the museum were wonderful.  There was a small sitting area where we were offered water and tea for free, complete with restrooms.   What a lovely gesture for us tourists!  Behind this area, with a short uphill walk, is a lovely panoramic view of the surroundings.  

Once out of the port, make a right towards the City Centre.  Surely can't be missed as there are sight-seeing buses parked there.  There is also a sign post, which says: "Sentrum," meaning downtown.  When you get to the fork in the road, keep to the left to head toward the Fortress. 

 Keep to the right if you wish to head toward the Fish Market.  Once at the fish market, look to the left and walk up the street between the two big buildings on the corner and this will take you to the Floibanen Funicular. One building has the name:  "Ann Madam."   Most attractions are within walking distance. Lots of restaurants and historical buildings around the old part of the city...wonderful ambience.

reviews.title: Tower was Great
reviews.text: The Rosencrantz Tower was really great, but I didn't find much else about the fortress to be very engaging.

reviews.title: Pretty but Not Much to See
reviews.text:
We visited Bergen on a cruise.  Since our ship docked next to the Bergenhus Fortress, it was the first place we explored.  The fortress itself is pretty with a number of historic buildings.  It was nice to wander around and check the place out.

That being said, there wasn't much to see.  Most of the buildings were not open to visitors, and construction closed many places that would be fun to see such as the Rosenkrantz Tower.  There was also some kind of carnival going on, which may have impacted the operating status of buildings.

So if you are in to visiting old fortresses or there is some event going on, Bergenhus could be a reasonable place to visit.  For everyone else, just walking through it is sufficient.

reviews.title: A nice castle
reviews.text: This castle is on the waterfront and is very near to Brygenn. Can be reached on foot. nicely maintained garden and area. Provides a good view of the Brygenn from the top.

reviews.title: Do it if nothing else to do
reviews.text:
The castle is on water front and very near to Brygenn.
Nothing special. Even the garden was not well maintained.

reviews.title: Maritime oasis
reviews.text: A few minutes walk from the famous Hansabrygge you find this old fortress surrounded by a quiet pleasant park offering som nice views over the port fromt its ramparts where you also find a statue of the former king Haakon who was borne prince of Denmark but chosen kin of Norway when independant from Sweden in 1905.

reviews.title: Håkons Hall and Rosenkrantz Tower
reviews.text: Keep walking past Bryggen and you will come to Bergenhus Fortress (Bergenhus Festning). The fortress contains Håkons Hall, Rosenkrantz Tower (both with admission fees), the free Fortress Museum (Bergenhus Festningmuseum) and some open parkland. The Hall and Tower date from the 13th century and are interesting, if somewhat expensive, visits.

reviews.title: Thank goodness it was free
reviews.text: Nothing to see. Nothing. On top of that they’re repairing the tower so you can’t see the outside and it’s only open 12-15. Don’t waste your time there!

reviews.title: Worthwhile
reviews.text: This is worthwhile to visit as it contains important historic buildings in Norwegian history and some of the few stone buildings. In fact I read that Scottish stonemasons had had to be brought over to help build the Rosenkrantz tower a success presumably there were enough not enough people with stone building experience in Norway. The parkland is pleasant and there are good views over the harbour.

reviews.title: Probably influenced by the weather
reviews.text: As it rains on 300 days of the year, many visitors to Bergen will end up visiting this old castle of the kings of Norway on a wet day. We certainly did and found it a little bleak . Currently the Rosenkrantz Tower is covered with plastic for maintenance and as a result you can’t get up on the roof. The Haakon Hall was amazing considering its age though some of the renovations inside have too much of a 1950s feel to give you a sense of the medieval heritage of the castle. The parkland area outside was very bare and cold the day we visited. Staff were all extremely friendly and well informed.

reviews.title: Skip the hall
reviews.text: There is one hall which is ticketed. Everything else is free. Take a stroll around but we thought the ticket price was too high to warrant it.

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: You can freely walk around this fortress and enjoy the nice gardens and views. Everything is well maintained, the main tower is under reconstruction at the moment.

reviews.title: Bergen Beauty
reviews.text: Bergen is a beautiful city and the fortress is another piece of history worth a walk around.  Great historic place right in the middle of the town near the water.  Don't miss this when you are there

reviews.title: Well kept fortress!!
reviews.text: We were walking along the Bryggen area when we came across this fortress. Its very well kept and maintained.

reviews.title: Well kept fortress!!
reviews.text: We were walking along the Bryggen area when we came across this fortress. Its very well kept and maintained.

reviews.title: Very Interesting
reviews.text: Unfortunately, I was there on the off-season and the tower was being renovated, so nothing was open and I couldn't go inside.  I did have a good guide book, so I was able to wander and read about what I was seeing.  It is quite beautiful and has a very interesting history.

reviews.title: Extraordinary place
reviews.text:
This museum is free and has a number of exhibits over 3 floors. They are small but fascinating , and cover the early settlements and history of Bergen; the modern military in Norway; but of most interest for me was the history of the Resistance movement in Bergen during the Second World War. 

The exhibit is easy to follow, and the guide is in many languages. The gentleman in charge on the day we were there was incredibly helpful, and found information for me related to other famous Resistance actions as well as recommended books to get more information. Free coffee, courtesy, and information. Superb!

Privilege to go there.

reviews.title: Pay a short visit to it
reviews.text: Surely you will try to see Haakon's hall and Tower, so great chance to walk thru the fortress too, its like a park with a fortress wall.

reviews.title: Beautiful area with great buildings
reviews.text: Worth a visit if you’re in Bergen.  Centuries of history and buildings from most phases still can be seen. Big refurb ongoing when we were there and with it being off season main sections closed. Military museum off the fortress well worth a visit too just check opening times if you’re off season

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: If you're in the vicinity this is worth a visit. It is particularly interesting to note its history and how it was rebuilt and restored after its destruction in WWII

reviews.title: Amazing Ancient Local Architecture
reviews.text: This was absolutely beautiful. The stone work combined with amazing warmth of the wooden high beams and floors is charming and incredible. So beautiful and wonderfully warm make you appreciate the talent and creativity of the life in Bergen centuries ago.

reviews.title: Castle tour.
reviews.text: As part of a Bergen city walkabout, the Bergenhus Festing should be on your itinerary.  Walking through the centuries-old structure will give you a perspective on Bergen's past.  It doesn't take long to walk through but if you take it slow and pause to reflect on all that took place on that site it is worthwhile.   Be sure to familiarize yourself with the Hanse culture and the WWII events that took place at the site.  It will make the visit more interesting.

reviews.title: not much too it
reviews.text: Perhaps I am getting jaded by lots of awesome travel, but neither of us found this very exciting.  It's basically some stone walls with a nice view.  Even the history isn't very interesting.  On the plus side, it's open early and late, so something to do when everything else is closed.

reviews.title: Enjoyed the history this place holds
reviews.text: Unfortunately, this place is under construction. However, we still felt like it was worth going up the Rosenkrantz Tower and walking the grounds. Enjoyed learning the history behind this fortress. The guy selling the tickets at the Tower was very helpful and told us a lot of interesting facts about the Tower. We liked going, but we love history too.

reviews.title: Under Reconstruction
reviews.text: If there is much here to see, we could not tell when we visited, because it is currently under reconstruction and all you can do is visit Rosenkrantz Tower and Hakkon's Hall. There are so many fascinating fortresses in the Nordic countries, that this left us flat. You should get a 50% discount for having paid for any of the Bergen historic museums, but we had to discuss that at length each time we paid. Maybe the museums all need to discuss this with one another??

reviews.title: Worth a quick look
reviews.text: A very large impressive fortress. An interesting building to look at but without a guide it would have been hard to appreciate what we were looking at.

reviews.title: Packed with history and information
reviews.text:
We chanced upon this museum when walking around Bergen ... the pleasant warden met us at the door and explained the layout and facilities (rest rooms and self serve cafe).
We then read all about the history of Norway and the development of Bergen, as well as a detailed insight into the 2nd WW era when Bergen was bombed by the English because of (imposed)U boat storage repair amd support in that area.
In addition, there was a special section detailed the brave Resistance movement.
We left with a good deal of respect for the Norwegian people and (most surorising of all) the whole exhibition was free of any charge.

reviews.title: Reconstructed castle
reviews.text: Most of the castle was destroyed in the second world war when a ammunition ship exploded. The castle was reconstructed. Nice to look at.

reviews.title: Nice park, not much to see
reviews.text: There is a park and some old stone buildings but not much else. Might be interesting to historians but otherwise not too exciting.

reviews.title: Kinda nice
reviews.text: I thought it was a nice old place but there is a ton of construction going on so you can't see that much.  Also they hold concerts on the grounds which also effected the ability to see much.  So I found it just ok.

reviews.title: Pretty park but not much else here
reviews.text: The fortress is not much more than a pretty park now, except for the Haakon Hall and Rosenkrantz tower which you can (pay for) and visit.

reviews.title: Part of the cluster of buildings
reviews.text: Made out of grey stone the fort is interesting the walk to the fort better.  Nice area wonderful walk next to the water.

name: Byparken
ranking_subcategory: #14 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #14 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #14 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: Bergen: Excursion with a city view from the top

reviews.title: VERY PRETTY AREA
reviews.text: Near the Lille Lungegaardsvannet, this is a welcome bit of greenery. The pavillion in the middle anchors the area. The flowers were in full summer bloom. It is a good spot to recharge the batteries.

reviews.title: A classic city park
reviews.text: The park in the city center is a open and green area. There is a lot of through-traffic of People walking and biking, but that only adds more atmopshere to the area. There are benches and even some tables, and a small coffeshop in the park. The Perfect location to sit and observe the buzz of the city life

reviews.title: Well Maintained
reviews.text:
Small park but enjoyed seeing. The gardens are well maintained with lots of flowers this time of year. There is a summer pavilion, statue of Edward Grieg, and next to is a water feature.

No cost to the park.

reviews.title: Nice small park
reviews.text:
Lovely little park with a bandstand which had some pretty flower arrangements. Lots of areas to sit and enjoy a pickup. Also next to the park is the fabulous lake Lille 
Lungegaardsvannet which makes for some nice photo opportunities with the Bergen hills in the background.

reviews.title: byparken
reviews.text: very small park in the city center with the statue of Edward Grieg and summer pavilion in the middle. if to cross the road there is a city lake with the fountain. there are many flowers around the lake.

reviews.title: Nice park to visit
reviews.text: Whilst sightseeing, it's always nice to relax in a park, and this park fits the bill. It's easy to find and nicely landscaped. There are flowers, statues, grass, a fountain, and benches, which is all you need to enjoy a city park. It's nice to see native folks, as well as tourists, enjoying the park. I was lucky enough to see it on a warm and sunny day, after touring the KODE museums. There is a light rail stop right nearby as well.

reviews.title: Edward Grieg Statue
reviews.text: This is a lovely park in central Bergen, framed by two beautiful buildings - KODE 1 on one end and the Rikstelegraf & Rikstelefon building on the other. In the center is a restored old music pavilion. On  the lawn in front of the Rikstelegraf & Rikstelefon building is a bronze statue of noted composer Edward Grieg. Plenty of grass and flowers. The park is worth checking out while exploring Bergen.

reviews.title: Gorgeous gardens
reviews.text: The light railway stops here and there is a lovely walk around the lake. Lovely flowerbeds and the cafe sells fantastic soft ice cream! Galleries to visit here too.

reviews.title: The grounds are so pretty
reviews.text: Lots of beautiful green grass and flowers and statues.  Benches to sit on and a good place to just sit and enjoy the surroundings.

reviews.title: Beautiful in the Summer
reviews.text: The planners and gardeners here do a fantastic job. I especially like the statue of the composer Grieg and the special display of roses and summer flowers. There are plenty of benches to sit on and one can grab a cup of coffee or an ice cream in any of the newsagents nearby. Some good memories from here.

reviews.title: Great spaces to soak in the sun
reviews.text: Bergen is full of little nooks and corners and this is one of the biggest. Plenty of action and lots of space to be comfortably tucked in your own space as well.

reviews.title: city park
reviews.text: Almost nothing to see there due to small size. It was helpful to find the end station of the city tram knowing that location beside this park

reviews.title: Small park
reviews.text: Very small park. Orientation for people travelling to the airport by light train line. Beside the park you can find the end stop. The statue of E.Grieg Norwegian composer you can see there

reviews.title: A pleasant stroll
reviews.text: The Byparken is located on both sides of Christies Gate and has a lake, bandstand and statues, including that of Edvard Grieg. Being near to the KODE museums it is convenient to take a walk around before or after visiting these.

reviews.title: Nice centrally located park
reviews.text: Nice sight but you will not loose too much time about it, as you will probably simply walk by it. There is a lake in the vicinity and chances you will sit there on the bench watching or feeding ducks, swans, seagulls...

reviews.title: A haven in the centre of Bergen
reviews.text:
Monday 3rd September we were sightseeing in Bergen, we had just returned from a trip on the Floibanen funicular to the top of Mount Floyen where City Park, Lille Lungegardsvann Lake lake and Festplassen were clearly visible from above. So we headed off to see these sights from ground level and up close.

It is situated in the heart of Bergen and is a short walk from the Fish Market and Tourist Information Centre.

The Park itself surrounds the lake and is populated with a number of interesting statues and colourful flowers and shrubs. 

It was a delight to walk around in the sunshine, it takes about 25 minutes to stroll around. It is an ideal spot to sit and relax and enjoy this park and all its has to offer

reviews.title: I loved the park
reviews.text: I was staying less than 5 minutes from the park and on the first evening it was gloriously sunny and the views from the park very beautiful.  Each evening I walked through the park and loved the slow wander back after a meal and drink. The park is a haven of peace and quiet with immaculately maintained gardens, a lake and useful information in Norwegian and English about the birds etc that can be seen.  Close to all transport but you still feel that you have got away from it all.

reviews.title: Gorgeous Park with Great views
reviews.text:
Date Of Visit: Friday, Aug 31, 2018

This park is situated across from / along side the Lille Lungegårdsvannet lake.  
This is all part of a gorgeous area of town where you will want to come to relax, take a walk, enjoy lunch outdoors, and take in the scenery. 

The grounds are perfectly maintained, there are gorgeous flower gardens in bloom. This is just such a beautiful & serene place to visit. 

It is conveniently located on the bus lines, there is a stop for the Hop on Hop offs, It is near the hustle and bustle of the town, but far enough removed that it feels like miles away.

reviews.title: Beautiful park
reviews.text: We arrived in Bergen and walked through the Byparken to get to our apartment, it made a very good first impression of Bergen! Very well maintained and provides lovely scenic views of Bergen.

reviews.title: Inner city park.
reviews.text: A buffer zone which helps to ease the urban density. Well maintained and pleasantly located near the train station and behind the commercial zone.

reviews.title: Beautiful Park
reviews.text: Very well maintained city park in town square surrounding fountains and museum(kode)...lovely spot to walk around or just relax or to take innumerable pictures...view is mesmerising...being in Bergen you cant miss going to this little gem. Recommended.

reviews.title: Just a Beautiful Spot
reviews.text: You walk around and are surrounded by beautiful flowers, statues and scenery. I was able to take a 360 degree video to post on Facebook for all our friends back home to see and for us to look at and remember our great time here.

name: KODE Art Museums of Bergen
ranking_subcategory: #9 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #9 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #9 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: KODE is one of Scandinavia's largest museums for art and music. It has a unique combination of art museums and composers' homes, of visual art, historical objects, concerts and parklands. KODE stewards almost 50,000 objects that can be experienced in four museum buildings in Bergen city centre, KODE 1-4, and in the homes of the composers Ole Bull, Harald Saeverud and Edvard Grieg. Welcome to KODE!
address: Rasmus Meyers alle 9 Rasmus Meyers allé 3, Bergen 5015 Norway

reviews.title: KODE Art Museums of Bergen
reviews.text: This museum was much better when the admission was free. And money is not the only matter here. It used to have a good collection of Norwegian artists, well selected and tastefully presented. Now they have a Munch exhibit, which is fine, but it's done at the expense of other painters. This time Bergen disappointed in general, and this museum contributed to my disappointment .

reviews.title: Soooooo glad I didn't skip this . . . . Go for the Munch if nothing else . . . but there's a lot more
reviews.text:
If your like me and The Scream is all you know of Edvard Munch's work, do not miss the opportunity to have your eyes opened to a remarkable body of work . . . 
I also love that the museum focuses on Norwegian artists so for example II felt we were exposed to dozens of wonderful impressionist works we'd never seen before.

reviews.title: Enjoyable art museum
reviews.text: I visited for the Munch exhibit, but also enjoyed several of the other collections including both modern art and old Norwegian masters.The ticket is good for 2 days and all 4 buildings which makes it a very good value for those interested in art and Norway.

reviews.title: Excellent value for money and a must if you like modern art
reviews.text:
The ticket lasts for 2 days and gets you into the 4 separate exhibition buildings. We were here on a cruise so only had limited time and only looked around two of the buildings but we did get to see the Munch collection. 

I have to confess that I don't appreciate most modern art as I find it lacking in talent and feeling and there are certainly plenty of examples of work that is both simplistic and pretentious; however I am rating on the basis of being a museum that is clear on the art that is on view. 

The Munch collection was well worth seeing for the various phases that he went through during a troubled life.

reviews.title: Outstanding Museum spread out in 4 different buildings
reviews.text: One ticket gets you into all building for 2 days.  Depending how you view things it could take that long but actually we felt we had covered things pretty in doubt 4 hours.  The Munch exhibit was extremely interesting as was offerings by other Norwegian masters. Period rooms and furnishings and other examples of earlier life were on display. There are lockers in each location for you to store you belongings, and a nice coffee shop in one of the buildings.

reviews.title: Wonderful Museum
reviews.text: The KODE is a really 4 separate museums in 4 different buildings. We enjoyed the exhibit of Norweigan artists including some by Munch. We especially lied a silver exhibit on another building.

reviews.title: excellent museum
reviews.text: we really enjoyed walking through the villa’s apartments while looking at spectacular masterpieces made by Norwegian masters. Totally recomended

reviews.title: Series of Buildings Housing Permanent & Visiting Collections
reviews.text: The KODE is a well-loved part of Bergen life, housed in four separate buildings by specialty. Each has a locker area for storing coats, etc, and an interesting collection. Beautiful grounds with tulips in bloom while we were there.

reviews.title: Art
reviews.text: A profile of Munch was the highlight for us, but also some old masters and a good celebration of Norwegian art.

reviews.title: Excellent museum in the heart of Bergen
reviews.text: KODE consists of a series of art museum buildings within easy walking distance of each other in downtown Bergen. Don't miss the display devoted to Nikolai Astrup, or the Rasmus Meyer collection that includes Edward Munch and Astrup as well as Dahl, Becker, and many other important Norwegian artists. Give yourself plenty of time - there is so much to see and do here!

reviews.title: Went for the Munch Exhibition
reviews.text: We only had a short time in Bergen, so made for KODE 3 to see what was on offer. Although a small exhibition, It was intersting to see his early style and the hints of what would later lead to paintins like the Scream. The ticket let you into other KODE exhibits, but we were in a hurry.

reviews.title: Interesting insight into Norwegian art
reviews.text: A good range of art forms across four buildings, all next to each other in the center of Bergen.  Admission (around £12 as of June 2019) give yous access to all four buildings for two days, so it's both good value and a great way to not get 'arted out' all in one go!

reviews.title: 1, 3, and 4 rocked
reviews.text: 1st great thing- your ticket gets you into all four buildings for TWO days, so if you are one of those people who can sit and look at one painting for 20 minutes, two days works great! 1st not so great thing- KODE 2 has only one room and it’s instillation was just bad, in my opinion, so check out what’s there before you waste your time. However the other three buildings each had something I REALLY enjoyed. Go and enjoy all the buildings. Check your bag in a free locker and even eat in one of the cafes. Very nice visit!

reviews.title: Best museum in Bergen
reviews.text: This museum is in 4-5 separate buildings along the small lake in the very centre. The best in my experience is the display of Nikolai Astrup, a painter largely unknown outside Norway. But his paintings and prints are loved and instantly recognized by many Norwegians. The display (in 2019) is aptly named "out of the shadow", I guess this refers to Edvard Munch's shadow. Astup has been called "Norway's other great painter" (Munch is of course #1). Also an excellent collection from the Norwegian romantic period and ancient furniture donated by Rasmus Meyer. One ticket covers all buildings and visitors must step outside to transfer.One of the buildings is a cool functionalist buildings previously home to the electricity supply in Bergen

reviews.title: Norwegian Art in a low key setting
reviews.text:
I went to three of the KODE Museums in one go - they're close together and one admission fee gets you into all of them.  The older and more traditional museum was my favorite.  It featured Norwegian painters, including Munch, and had a very nice collection of portraits, landscapes and more modern paintings.  It was quiet and well-lit and thus very easy to concentrate and focus on the art.  I had never heard of any painter except Munch, and I couldn't understand why - the quality was outstanding. I surmised that perhaps stylistically none of them were groundbreaking, but still, they were beautifully and skillfully done.  If you're in Bergen and you like art museums, go here.  

The more modern museum had an installation of various configurations of large painted pipes.  Not my cup of tea, but OK.

There was also a fascinating silver exhibit with every type of silver tool, cutlery, dish, pot, bowl or whatever you could think of, all beautifully displayed in a large room.

reviews.title: Wonderful - would have loved to spend more time
reviews.text:
MUNCH-MUSEUM I BERGEN
Opplev KODEs unike samling av Edvard Munch i KODE 3.

KODE and Bergen has the third largest collection of Edward Munch-artworks in the world. And a lot of other pictures. This is well worth visiting - and just in walking distance from Bryggen and other tourist-must-see. It took me some hours to realitet that I wish I had more time.  This is worth the visit.

reviews.title: Good museums in Bergen
reviews.text: I enjoyed visiting 3 out of the 4 museums in the KODE complex in central Bergen. Unfortunately, one of the museums was closed - oddly, the doors were open and it was possible to walk around inside - there was nobody in the lobby to tell me that it was closed, I asked in the cafe. Anyway, there was a good variety of artworks in the 3 museums I did visit. Look at their website to see which of the three you might enjoy visiting. They are included on the Bergen Card so if you have that, be sure to use it there!

reviews.title: Painting where so so
reviews.text: Very interesting to see the span of Munch’s Work also a lot of Norway painters I never heard of a lot of non famous paintings

reviews.title: KODE 3 and 4
reviews.text: You know The Scream but KODE 3 has so many Munch paintings, really different.  Excellent value of one ticket to see both museums.

reviews.title: Kode Art Galleries - surprisingly good
reviews.text: Walked from number 4 to number 1. As you. are passing the park you can hear wind chimes. Saw some Picasso very good. Not sure about Munch as his art was varied in style and didn’t get to see The Scream. Presume it was being cleaned. We used our Bergen Card which gave discounts. Beware they are not open on a Monday and only kode 1 is open on a Saturday. It could change from the end of may when they have their national day in may

reviews.title: Throught History of Norwegian Art
reviews.text:
KODE Art Museum is complex of four huge galleries which are located in the centre of Bergen. In every building are presented different exhibitions concerning art. 

In KODE 3 are beautifully exhibited artworks from the Golden Age of Norwegian art. In this gallery are presented inter alia paintings of Edvard Munch, J.C. Dahl and Theodor Kittelsen. 

Exhibitions presented in KODE 4 give the opportunity to see how art is changed from the 14th century to modern times. In this gallery, we can not only admire wonderful paintings of Norwegian masters but also see works of artists from abroad (e.g. Pablo Picasso).

To conclude, visit in KODE is the perfect opportunity to admire and learn more about Norwegian art. This wonderful travel through the history of art is possible at a cost of one ticket (to all four galleries). KODE 3 and KODE 4 are definitely worth seing during a visit in Bergen!

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text: We visited both Kode 3 and 4, and found both to be excellent. There were lockers to put your gear in which was helpful. There were brilliant displays of Norwegian artists with plenty of explanation and very well hung. We were impressed with the number of works by Picasso and Klee. Although we visited Kode 3 on Sunday, we were told to keep our tickets as they would admit us to Kode 4 on Tuesday which worked  well for us.

reviews.title: Varied and interesting
reviews.text: Not a big art lover but chose to visit with our deal on the Bergen card. Was some incredible paintings and art and was well worth the time spent in the different museums.

reviews.title: Must visit
reviews.text: This is a really nice museum with beautiful collections, even though the light used in the rooms is not suitable to admire the greatness of the paintings.

reviews.title: Good in parts
reviews.text: KODE 1 has a silver collection which is almost all household ware of one kind or another (i.e. spoons, cups, serving dishes). The display is quite good, although there is little if any English to help you understand what you are seeing. Some of the items are really quite impressive. KODE 2 had no exhibitions when we were there. KODE 3 has lots of Munch paintings, which while the Munch Museum in Oslo is closed (we saw maybe 5 Munch paintings in a temporary exhibition there) is the best you're likely to sere in Norway. We didn't get to KODE 4, so can't comment on that.

reviews.title: Norwegian and world artists
reviews.text: Kode is not one museum. This is association of five or six museums. One ticket bought in one of kode museums is valid for all others 24 hours. I was impressed by Hans Gude who is one of the most popular Norwegian landscape painters.

reviews.title: First class art across a range of genres in signature buildings
reviews.text:
The Kode museum is great value as you can visit four museums over two days on the ticket.
The most imaginative display was the silver exhibition in the shape of a magpies nest with mirrors. 
KODe 3 has the major exhibition of Munch who really stands out. His ability to convey emotions are real talent.

reviews.title: Great museums with good selection of art work.
reviews.text: Lots of different types of art styles to see here. We went in all the buildings and enjoyed a nice selection of Norwegian art over history as well as several other styles. Definitely worth a visit if you've got a Bergen card. A good way to learn about Norway and stay out of the bad weather!

reviews.title: Various exhibits in 4 buildings
reviews.text:
My personal favorite is the Nikolai Astrup exhibition, not a permanent one so do hurry if you want to see it, it will come to an end at 31 Dec 2019. As the museum writes on its homepage; "The exhibition sheds light on how the darkness of night and the mystique of childhood were important sources of inspiration for Nikolai Astrup."

Other famous Norwegian painters such as Edvard Munch, J.C. Dahl, Harriet Backer, Erik Werenskiold and Gerhard Munthe can be found at Kode 3. Just to walk through Kode 3 is an experience in itself, old furniture, crooked floors, and the paintings on the walls, it is like walking through a time capsule.

reviews.title: Great atmosphere - personnel with good insight!
reviews.text:
We were in for lunch but due to good recommondations and pleasent intercourse with the personnel we stayed for some hours during a saturday afternoon. 
Recommended course : Linguine zucchine accompanied with Roero Arneis

reviews.title: Beautiful Museum
reviews.text: There are 4 sections (buildings) but we only visited 2, bldgs., 3 &4.  We saw the works of many famous artists both old and new.  There were several paintings by Picasso and it showed how different his works were in different times of his life.

reviews.title: 4 buildings with something for everyone
reviews.text: one price to see exhibits in 4 separate building and need a few hours to see everything.shop in each building according to its exhibits.

reviews.title: Munch showcase
reviews.text: We only went in KODE3 and that was to see the Munch exhibition - superbly curated, well worth a visit. Discovered a few other Norwegian artists that really spoke to me too. Great value ticket as the £25ish entry fee also covers you for the other KODE buildings for that day and the day after too. Recommended.

reviews.title: A must do for any art fan
reviews.text: The KODE museums/galleries are an amalgamation of what were four separate exhibitions and are split over four sites which are close together. They include paintings by Edvard Munch and Johan Cristian Dahl, and are a very good representation of Norwegian painting and crafts. Very good for a morning or afternoon.

reviews.title: One of the must in Bergen
reviews.text: 4 large buildings offer a lot to be seen. Building No 1 is probably least interesting and if you do not have time you can skip it without much of regrets, however, if you do have time or if the weather is horrible, surely pay a visit to No 1 as well. Countless paintings could be seen in Kode 2, 3 and 4, Kode 2 seems to change the exibition and Kode 3 being particularly interesting, thans to paintings by Munch. Single ticket valid for all 4 kodes (120 NOK, divide with 10 for approximate in EUR), with bergen card you can visit without additional payment. Situated in a city center just behind the small lake.

reviews.title: Great place
reviews.text: Prefect for a rainy day!! 4 museums and free if you buy a Bergen card. Highly recommend a Bergen card. Lots of Munch and a bunch of other beautiful words of art. Highly recommend

reviews.title: WOW
reviews.text: A lovely group of 4 buildings on a square with a fountain, you could wander for hours inside.  The breadth of the art is spectacular.

reviews.title: Eclectic collection of art
reviews.text: Spread over a number of buildings we saw paintings, furnishings and a huge collection of silver. A good spot to visit on a wet afternoon.

reviews.title: Art alley is good value
reviews.text: We had one night in Bergen and the ticket for four galleries allowed us to spread our visits over two days.

reviews.title: Four for the price of one!
reviews.text: There are four Kode galleries and you can get round all four in half a day. The first houses silverware - which used to be the currency, but well displayed. Picasso and Munch great but loved Norwegian art. Some grizzly modern stuff. Cafes great -had a local apple juice. Great loos! Situated near picturesque lake and great thing to do if weather not good. One ticket for all four galleries. Staff lovely.

reviews.title: So Much to See that We had to do the Dreaded "Museum Triage."
reviews.text: My wife and I spent 2 hours in just the building that houses the Munch paintings and the works of their great Norwegian landscape and impressionist painters.  Unfortunately, we could not devote any additional time to see any of the other buildings in this large museum.  Our time constraints forced us to do 'Museum Triage" and we chose the "Munch Paintings Plus Building" as our one and only.   If you plan on going to this museum and also have limited time,  we recommend checking it out on- line in advance so that you can perform your own museum triage and make the most of the time you do have.  And if you have all day, enjoy yourself!!!!

reviews.title: A real revelation
reviews.text:
Probably like many I knew little about Norwegian art beyond Edvard Munch.  A previous visit to the excellent gallery in Oslo had acted as an introduction though.  

These four galleries were a real eye opener and most importantly a real pleasure to visit.  Galleries like this are not just for rainy days (of which Bergen gets many) but for enjoyment as a destination in themselves.  There was so much to see and the one ticket takes you in all of them.  The silver collection was stunning and brilliantly displayed and is worth spending time with to appreciate the silversmiths art.  The Singer collection is also impressive, I was unaware of the Norway connection.

For many the highlight will be the Munch paintings, so much more to him than "The Scream" with his changing styles over the years.  There are also some absolutely wonderful troll pictures by Kittelsen.  The landscape paintings by JC Dahl were so impressive and a boat journey the following day to Flam put those into perspective and the deservedly popular artist Astrup is well represented .  There is so much more besides through all four galleries including a good collection of twentieth century European art.

reviews.title: Cool
reviews.text: Just a great experience. After managing the lockers for our bags we moved from building to building enjoying the paintings. Hard to be explicit why, as we are not knowledgable about Norwegian art, but it was great with beauty and humour as well as Munch. We both really enjoyed meandering our way round on this early autumn day.

reviews.title: Great Art Museums!
reviews.text: Visited all four KODE art museums in one day, very enjoyable and good for a rainy day! The art work is very well curated/presented using innovative and modern techniques. Definitely recommend!

reviews.title: Interesting collections
reviews.text: One ticket buys access to four separate exhibition spaces and so represents decent value. I spent a very enjoyable morning wandering through two of these spaces. I enjoyed the Munch exhibition and also the landscapes of JC Dahl who was a new artist to me. The focus was on Norwegian art and I liked that. Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Excellent Museum with Manageable Collections
reviews.text: My husband and I often visit art museums while on vacation and we tend to find that you need big chunks of time and by the end your visually exhausted and can't remember half of what you saw.  The Koda museums don't do that! We visited Koda 1 and 3. The collections were curated well and displayed well (the magpie "nest" of the silver collection was probably the most interesting installation). They were relatively quick to view and when we left we knew exactly what we had seen.

reviews.title: Museum of Munk
reviews.text:
In KODE are situated the biggest collection of Munk`s paintings. KODE is a small museum, but there are enough art inside. E[hibition is full of emotions. Only 4 rooms of Munk - worth to visit it.
I wish I saw it again )

reviews.title: Expected more of this museum
reviews.text: The KODE is spread over four houses and has different exhibitions. Found the exhibitions not so special, took me about one hour for all four houses.

reviews.title: Great collection of art
reviews.text: The complex is huge and there are 4 separate buildings. Admission fee is included in the Bergen card and it is a great way to spend an afternoon.  Many wonderful artworks by Munch.  The modern art exhibits are also very innovative and stimulating.

reviews.title: Culture time!
reviews.text: One ticket gets you into several exhibit halls which are all next to each other.  Some incredible paintings can be seen, and they truly give you a deeper appreciation of Norwegian culture, way of life, and perspective.

reviews.title: Great rainy day option
reviews.text:
KODE is a series of art exhibitions spread across four gallery buildings.  You can visit on two consecutive days if you wish. The star attraction is the Munch exhibition which is a good précis of how his art developed across his lifetime.  The Dahl show shouldn't be missed either as his work was important to the forging of a distinct Norwegian identity.  Some of Dahl's canvases are vast depictions of Norwegian landscapes. There's a surprisingly good collection of twentieth century art with quite a few Picassos thanks to an enlightened early acquisition policy.  

Each building has a different character and some have more to see than others.  KODE 2 has a good bookshop and a cafe which has delicious scones.

reviews.title: Worth to visit
reviews.text: It’s free to visit if you have Bergen card. We visited Kode house 2 & 4 only. A lot of silver art work were exhibited in house 2. In house 4, mainly paintings from famous Norwegian painters including Edvard Munch were displayed.

reviews.title: Check before you go
reviews.text: 4 different buildings host 4 different exhibit.on august 10 we were unlucky on building 1(kode 1).basically nothing interesting was on display,unless something like your rich granny's silverware collection is your idea of art worth looking at. Instead,kode 4 had some fine pieces by Munch (Not "the scream" which is displayed in Oslo),by Paul Klee andnorwegian Painters like Astrup.

name: Troldhaugen Edvard Grieg Museum

photo.caption: Troldhaugen was the home of Norwegian composer Edvard Grieg

ranking_subcategory: #5 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #5 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #5 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: Enchanting residence of the composer Edvard Grieg and his wife, who lived there every summer from 1885 to 1907. The museum also comprises the chamber music hall, Troldsalen, where daily concerts are held during the summer season. Museum building with shop, exhibition and cafeteria.

offer_list.title: EDVARD GRIEG LUNCH TIME CONSERT AND SIGHTSEEING AT TROLDHAUGEN - PRIVATE TOUR
Biking Tour and Grieg Concert in Bergen

reviews.title: A very enjoyable visit!
reviews.text: We wanted to visit the Edvard Grieg house and museum while in Bergen but heard that it's not easy to get to.  We were glad to see that we could purchase a package tour from the TI.  The package included a bus ride to Troldhaugen, departing at 11:00 a.m. from the TI near Bergen's harbor. Then at 11:30 there would be a  guided tour of the house. This would be followed by a 30 minute concert. Then there would be free time to visit the museum and stroll the grounds and/or get a bite of lunch (cost not included) in the cafe.  We'd be transported by bus back to Bergen, arriving at 2:25 p.m.  It sounded like a perfect way to spend 3.5 hours.  I tried to book 2 tickets online but my credit card wasn't going through so we decided to just go buy the tickets in person at the TI.  We got there at 10:15 a.m. and had to take a number to be served, so it was 10:30 by the time we got to the desk. Unfortunately, they said that the excursion was sold out for that day. I asked if we would still be able to do the guided house tour and concert if we got out there on our own, i.e., was it just the bus that was sold out? The answer was yes, it was only the bus ride that we couldn't book. Then the helpful person at the TI instructed us on how to take the tram out to the edge  of town, and how to walk from the tram stop to the Grieg property. He warned that it was a 20 minute tram ride and a 20 to 30 minute walk, and the only guided tour of the house each day was at 11:30, so we'd have to get going, and walk briskly, in order to not miss the tour.  He could have sold us tickets for the house tour but suggested we not buy them until we were there. That way, if we arrived too late, we wouldn't have wasted the money on the tickets.  We had a bit of trouble finding the tram station, then just missed one tram and had to wait 7 minutes for another, so that by the time we got off the tram and started the 20 to 30 minute walk, it was already 11:10. We were sure we'd miss the tour. However, that day's tour was running late and we got there on time!  The tour started at 11:45.  A big group was convened for this tour.  They'd come off of a couple of tour buses.  Two guides divided the big group into subgroups of about 30 to 35 people each, so there were actually two guided tours, spaced about 5 minutes apart.  As a result of all of this, it was a little hard to appreciate the beauty of the home.  The rooms, of course, had ropes to mark off the areas where tourists weren't supposed to go. With 30 to 35 people congregated behind those ropes, it was crowded. However, our guide did a great job of telling us interesting information about the family and the home. We had no trouble hearing him and the information was very nicely presented.  The house tour lasted only about 25 minutes, and then it was time to move into the concert hall for our concert, scheduled to start at 12:15.  We enjoyed the concert so much!  The pianist was very, very talented. It was a treat to listen to the Grieg compositions while gazing out of the window, at the back of the stage, onto the composing hut where the music was written.  A beautiful design.  After the concert, we spent time roaming the grounds, walking down the heavily wooded path from the house to the composing hut, admiring the fjord view from there. We saw the crypt where the ashes of Edvard and his wife, Nina, are entombed. We admired the garden. We spent a lot of time in the museum reading more about the lives of Edvard and Nina, and thought that the museum was very well done. The cafe is beautiful, with a wall of windows over the fjord, but we didn't order any food in there. After our visit, we took our time strolling back to the tram stop, in comparison to the brisk pace we'd used to not miss the house tour. It was fun to see what the outskirts of Bergen look like, the residential neighborhoods outside of the touristy city center. We loved our time at the Grieg home and museum!  I wish the house tour had been a little less crowded.  It would be nice if they would offer it at regular intervals throughout the day instead of just one time each day.

reviews.title: HOMAGE TO ONE OF NORWAY'S FAVOURITE SONS
reviews.text: The bus tour package was first rate. The tour started at 1100 near the Bergen Tourist Information office  where you got a sticker to wear. The bus ride to the site was 20M, the host providing some commentary on Grieg and pointing out other touristic matters along the way. After getting our ticket, we toured Troldhaugen, the Grieg home. Two or the rooms have original pieces. The concert was next, lasting some 25M, pieces by Grieg naturally featured. Thereafter there was time to look inside his little hut where he did his composing. A walk down to the original grave site was followed by time at the museum. There was a restaurant on site if you wanted a little something to eat. The return trip was at 1400. The price including transportation was 290 krones. Full value was received.

reviews.title: Superb pianist
reviews.text: The concert Sunday evening in Trollhaugen was incredible. I have never in my life heard a better pianist, and I have heard many. Sound, artistry, technique and interpretation was just completely amazing by this norwegian-russian-asian woman. Cool mix. Interesting to experience this level so far away. Speechless. Will tell my friends in Melbourne about this. Grieg's place was interesting. His grandfather came from Scotland, I learn new stuff every day here. Bergen is these days filled up with old tall ships racing around. We are happy also because of that. Norway is a bit similar to New Zealand except crazy prices of beer.

reviews.title: A must if you are a fan of Edvard Grieg!
reviews.text: We had a very interesting experience. We had a guided tour of the house and the grounds and we could walk down to the little house that Grieg wrote in overlooking the water. We were treated to a concert of his music in the small hall they had on the grounds. Be sure to sit on the side towards the left of center so you can see the pianist at work.

reviews.title: Fantastic tour
reviews.text: The tour started to the information centre, Bergen where we were met by a very lovely young guide. We drove by bus last Bergen conservatory . The house where Grieg spent his summer months is well worth the drive. The 45 minute concert by the pianist was awesome. This tour was well worth the trip. Great job !

reviews.title: Consider an arranged tour
reviews.text:
Grieg chose well when he picked this location for his home.  It’s beautiful.  But know this:  it’s a haul to get out there without a car or arranged tour on the bus.  We got there on our own, taking the tram (about 20 min) then walking almost 30 minutes To get to the house.  Once there, aside from the house itself, we had a frustrating time.  The display of photographs and written panels of text seems like a lousy way to present someone’s life (especially tiring to stand and read your way through his history after the long walk).  We were encouraged by the staff to watch the film in the small theater — but this is also disappointing, not anything about his life, just pretty pictures of Norway with his music as background.   There was a concert — but we were shut out of it, as it was private for Viking tour group members.  (We would gladly have paid to occupy one of the many empty seats, but this was not an option.)  nothing for it but to spend another 30 minutes to trudge back to the tram stop, then stand on a crowded tram the 20 minutes or so it took to get back to Bergen.  

A bus tour organized through the TI would have been a much better option!

reviews.title: Interesting house with lovely views. Shame about the piano recital
reviews.text:
The visit was an organised trip by bus from the tourist office in Bergen, with an English speaking guide, who was very good. The house itself is an interesting period property, and the detail we were given inside added to the enjoyment. I certainly wouldn’t put anyone off seeing it. Outside there were lovely views. And you could understand why they had chosen to build a property there, and how the ambience would have aided his composing.

Part of the trip included a 30 minute piano recital in the adjoining concert hall. Apparently, various Norwegian pianists receive an invitation to perform this duty just for a week, and they are then given a free rein as to which of Greig’s compositions to include in their recital. I think our pianist forgot that he wasn’t playing to an audience of experts but to an audience of tourists. Many of us would recognise and enjoy Grieg’s best known pieces, but he chose to ignore all of those, and instead to fill his 30 minutes with some very obscure and (dare I say) boring compositions with his own arrangements. Such a shame. Looking around the audience I noted more than one dozing off

So, I would award 4 stars to the house but (in the week I went) only 1 star to the piano recital

reviews.title: Beautiful mudic
reviews.text: We first did a tour of Edward Grieg’s house. Then we walked around the beautiful grounds. This was followed by a concert of Grieg’s music by a very talented pianist. Enjoyed our visit.

reviews.title: Pleasant enough
reviews.text: Going to the Grieg Museum is a worthy excursion from Bergen city center. It's lovely to get outside Bergen and see the-well maintained home and gardens.

reviews.title: A pilgrimage for those who love great music by Grieg.
reviews.text:
Goosebumps abounded as I made my way up the wooded lakeside hill to summer residence and adjacentmhutnof the music immortal, Edward Grieg, in Bergen, Norway.
Touring the site is as much about the love and emotion  for Grieg as well as the beauty for the place.

This is a no miss location.

reviews.title: Wonderful!
reviews.text:
Took an arranged trip from the Tourist Information Centre to Edvard Grieg's house which included coach transport there and back, an English speaking guide, a guided tour of the house and an evening piano recital in the purpose built concert hall in the grounds.

The guide was exceptional, a lecturer in music at the university, he was not only knowledgeable about the man, the house and his music, he also knew a lot about Bergen's history.

He took us around the house and pointed out all the things that we would have missed if we had been on our own and then showed us the grounds and Edvard Grieg's grave.

The concert was amazing. the pianist, Ryoma Takagi, had recently won 1st prize in an international completion featuring Grieg's work and played on a stage which had a picture window at the back and looked out over the water.

An amazing evening!

reviews.title: Beautiful home of Edvard Grieg
reviews.text: Our second visit to the Grieg Museum. Interesting tour that talks about his life and his music. Most days there are also concerts in the small concert hall.

reviews.title: Go for a concert
reviews.text: We took the trip from the Tourist Office which includes bus, house tour and lunchtime half hour piano concert. All excellent. We knew from a previous visit that it’s a bit of a walk from public transport and we are now 10years older. So this worked well for us.

reviews.title: Had a very nice Piano Recital
