reviews.text: Went to the museum and then to the Concert hall and had a short concert by a local pianist Jens Harald Bratlie and it was really very nice and very well done.

reviews.title: A Musical Delight
reviews.text: We visited the Edvard Grieg Museum and home, where we were treated to an inspiring concert of Grieg's compositions.  The concert hall overlooks the water and is close to the building in which Grieg wrote many of his compositions.  The visit was both enlightening about Grieg and a celebration of his work.

reviews.title: Live Music
reviews.text: Interesting house, but good to have a guide to bring it to life. Concert hall beautiful, worth catching some live music there.

reviews.title: Grieg’s beautifully situated summer retreat
reviews.text: While Grieg’s house is worth a visit in its own right, it also boasts an amazingly beautiful setting. Take the tour arranged through the Information Centre, which includes the return bus, a guided tour of the house, and a spectacularly professional lunchtime concert of Grieg’s work.

reviews.title: Lunch concert makes it worth the visit
reviews.text: Although the tour of the house was not terribly interesting, the 30-minute concert was lovely and made the trip a worthwhile excursion. The shuttle bus from the TI made it very easy to enjoy to enjoy a short concert and to learn about Grieg’s sad life.

reviews.title: Picturesque glimpse into greatness
reviews.text: This wonderfully managed home of composer Edvard Grieg is a must-visit in Bergen. The entrance building has an excellent overview exhibition of Grieg's life and work, along with a cafe and gift shop. Visit his cozy house and walk down to his composer's cabin next to the water. A lovely modern concert hall has been added in which wonderful short concerts are offered every day. You can also walk through the woods to the grave of the composer and his wife. This is a wonderful place to be steeped in the life of a brilliant and beloved composer.

reviews.title: Outstanding Concert a Tribute to the Great Norwegian Composer Grieg
reviews.text: We took the concert and tour with bus transport from the Information Center to Grieg's home outside of Bergen. One could easily get there by car. Set on the shores of a peaceful lake, he could find the solace he needed to create such beautiful music. A 30 minute piano concert of a selection of Grieg's music is held in the modern concert hall, which has excellent acoustics. There is a small cafe and gift shop. Ample parking. One can tour the house, visit the grave and peer into the  hut where he composed. Check out the piano in the house and notice that it is missing some keys! Even if you are not that knowledgeable about Grieg, you would have heard his music used on TV commercials, cartoons and in movies. Use the Bergen card to get a discount and prebook your seats as it is quite popular to come here. Be aware that there are uneven steps to his grave and in some other paths. Not an event for small children.

reviews.title: Lovely concert and visit
reviews.text: The Bergen Card made this museum and concert well worth it. I took the light rail to Hop then walked 15-20 minutes to Troldhaugen. The exhibition in the ticket/cafe building was very nice. The garden, writing cabin, gravesite and waterfront were all so beautiful. The house tour was only three rooms, so a little disappointing, but what was in there and the guide (English tour) were excellent. The half hour concert was fantastic, a really lovely way to end the visit!

reviews.title: Lots to see and do at Edvard Grieg’s museum campus
reviews.text: Finally made it to Edvard Grieg’s place outside Bergen, Norway. I was disappointed that little more than one room is open for viewing in the house itself and we were rushed through to accommodate the crowds. Even so, the entire lakeside campus was beautiful especially on a warm sunny day. The concert hall where we heard a short piano concert is acoustically perfect and even has a sod roof!

reviews.title: Small museum but worth a visit if you have a car
reviews.text: You have probably heard Edvard Grieg’s music but don’t known who he is—so come here to learn a bit about his life and see 3 rooms in his little house. At 1pm they have a 30 minute piano concert playing his music too that you can buy tickets for. Otherwise there is a movie playing his music coupled with scenes of people walking around Norway which I enjoyed. There is a good student discount if you have your ID!

reviews.title: Lovely house, but ...
reviews.text: It was annoying to have paid to see the house - the house is what most people want to see, after all - only to get to the house to find dozens of people outside, who were unable to get in because there was a recital going on to which we hadn't got access. Everyone had to wait outside - just as well it wasn't raining! - and by the time we did get inside there were so many people who'd had to wait that we could hardly see our own feet, let alone anything else.

reviews.title: Wonderful visit
reviews.text: We took the tour which included house tour, museum and concert.  Wonderful couple of hours exploring Grieg’s headland home with stunning views. The 30 min concert was beautiful.  Easy 20 min bus ride from town. A highlight of our stay in Bergen.

reviews.title: Interesting Museum and Recital
reviews.text:
We visited Troldhaugen on a trip to Bergen.  It was interesting to learn a bit about Edvard Grieg and see the area where he spent his summers.  You can just imagine the composer working in his small shack while enjoying the peaceful serenity of Norway.

The museum is well done.  There are a number of artifacts presented nicely.  The house was nice to visit as well even if it was a bit plain.  But the highlight of the visit was the recital.  A local pianist played several Grieg pieces.  They were some of his lesser-known works, but it still made for a nice concert.

We enjoyed our time visiting Troldhaugen.  If you have an interest in classical music, this is definitely a worthwhile place to visit.

reviews.title: Had an extra couple hours
reviews.text: Grieg home at Troldhaugen was excellent.  Didn’t now anything about him...and was quite taken with what we learned.  Really an inspiring individual, between overcoming personal physical challenges, and attempting to fulfill his own purpose in life.  Made a major contribution to Norwegian culture.  Very happy to have gone there.

reviews.title: Piano lunch concert
reviews.text: We were lucky to have been able to catch the lunch time piano concert today. We also took the 20 minutes English tour. A must see!

reviews.title: interesting and a wonderful setting
reviews.text: Time your visit so you can attend a lunchtime recital. They take place every day. Behind the stage is a huge window with a magnificent view. Well worth it.

reviews.title: Grieg’s house
reviews.text:
The journey here from Bergen took about 20mins. The museum and cafe have been  built in a discreet position,  not very far from the house, which overlooks the lake. The tour of the ground floor of the house was most interesting, quite homely, and peaceful, and much of the furnishings are as they were  when Grieg lived there, with family photos and memorabilia. The small hut, where Grieg sat looking out at the lake and countryside when composing, is towards the shore, down lots of steps, but one can only look through the windows. 
A small concert hall is very near the house but built in a hollow with a grassed roof, so it does not obtrude. We were lucky enough to  hear a pianist giving a piano concert whilst we walked around.
The shop had quality items but they were expensive.

reviews.title: be inspired!
reviews.text: This is a lovely place to visit, and you can see how the composer took his inspiration from working in his small cabin.The walk through the gardens down to the share is worth the effort

reviews.title: A Gem of a Tour
reviews.text: What a beautiful tour - from Thomas greeting us on the sidewalk outside the Visitor Centre,  his very knowledgeable talk, the little gem of a house with the amazingly concealed concert hall. The acoustics were excellent,  the performance top notch, and the tour was very good value.  To listen to Grieg under these excellent conditions AND take in the same view he enjoyed while composing - very special indeed. Thanks to everyone and especially Thomas.

reviews.title: Troldhaugen and Edward Grieg
reviews.text: This is very important to come to this museum with experienced guide. Our guide Ole from Vinol Tours was a big encyclopedia if to speak about Edward Grieg, his music and life story. Very important to buy the ticket that allows you to go to the lunch concert that is available every day for visitors.

reviews.title: Great to learn about Grieg and hear his beauitful music in the place he loved.
reviews.text: I recently took the organised bus trip from the tourist information office to Troldhaugen and thoroughly enjoyed my couple of hours there. The tour guide who showed us around the house was friendly and informative and we learnt so much about Grieg, his life and his works. We then had some spare time to explore the garden, his writing hut and visit the small museum and café before attending the 30 minute piano recital in the beautiful little concert hall which was the highlight of the trip. You really feel how this lovely villa and the perfect location on the lake was such an inspiration to him.

reviews.title: A good tour highlighted by a 30 minute concert
reviews.text: We bought our tickets in advance at the Bergen Tourist Office.  The bus left at 11 AM sharp for a 20 minute drive to the site.  There is a 5 minute walk from the parking lot to the museum.  There was a brief tour of the property and the Grieg homestead.  We then went through the small museum.  The highlight was a very good piano concert of Grieg compositions in the surprisingly beautiful and accousticly perfect concert hall.  I'd recommend this tour to anyone who has the time to do it.

reviews.title: Wonderful opportunity to learn about Grieg and hear his music
reviews.text: I visited this house by bus and participated in a tour, where we got to see a few rooms on the ground floor of the house. Know ahead of time that you have to take a short (5 minutes or so) walk through a wooded area to get from the bus parking lot to the house. It was lightly raining when I went, and I did get wet! Aside from that, being able to see his house and many family photos and decorations was a unique experience. The guide knew a lot about Grieg, his family and his music. There was ample free time to visit the museum and walk the grounds (to see his "composing hut" and his gravesite) before the 1pm concert started. The pianist we saw was exceptional and the acoustics (and views) from the concert hall were excellent. I enjoyed this very much and would not hesitate to return if I ever go back to Bergen.

reviews.title: Probably the highlight of Bergen
reviews.text: Fantastic place a few km outside Bergen. Located on the side of a fjord this is a lovely trip. There is a small museum, a café and Grieg's house to visit. There is also a concert hall where there is a daily piano concert at 1pm. The concert we visited was exceptional.

reviews.title: Private concert was exceptional
reviews.text:
We visited the house and grounds which were all very nice. On a tour with Tauck and we had a private concert of Mr Grieg’s music. Absolutely exceptional!!!!  
We came by bus. There was ample parking, but we did have a distance to walk from the bus parking. The concert was well worth the walk!

reviews.title: Great visit, view and concert
reviews.text: Been here before but still a delight to visit the museum and enjoy the Grieg concert. The views are stunning, the location only a few kms away from Bergen city.

reviews.title: Beautiful residence of composer Edward grieg
reviews.text: During our stay in bergen, we visited the villa of Norwegian composer Edward Greig and it was a very pleasant experience. You can take day trips from bergen tourist office which includes the concert also or can go by yourself using the bergen light rail. The villa and composer's hut is situated in a very serene atmosphere offering stunning views.

reviews.title: Great concert with a beautiful view
reviews.text: I went on a P & O cruise excursion to the Edvard Grieg villa and Museum which are both small but interesting.  The concert was excellent with a beautiful view of the lake and Grieg's studio from the concert hall.  If you are a fan of classical music you will love the excursion and understand why it inspired Grieg to write such beautiful music.

reviews.title: Beautiful Views, Lovely Concert
reviews.text: Visited the Troldhaugen, the Edvard Grieg Museum, as part of a Viking ocean cruise that was docked in Bergen, and I highly recommend it for music aficionados.  Our private piano concert was wonderful, and the grounds were quite picturesque.  Our guide, Torgen, provided us with a lot of information about Grieg's life, wife, and death.  A great way to spend an afternoon.

reviews.title: An amazing touch of local classic music
reviews.text: A very cosy and tidy house-museum, situated in a very beautiful landscape. The home-museum It is amazing to see the furniture and the accessories the great composer was using and also see the famous piano he played.

reviews.title: A Very Informative Visit
reviews.text: I enjoyed the visit to the Grieg museum and having the opportunity to understand more about the life of this composer.  Looking toward the water as one sits in the concert hall to hear a recital provided a fitting, evocative setting for the music.  The piano was played too hard for the concert I attended, but that may be a personal opinion.

reviews.title: Troldhaugen
reviews.text: Historical Summer cottage of Edvard Grieg and his wife rustic on the lake with gorgeous views of Bergen. Concerts throughout the year at Concert Hall and Museum. Worthwhile visit !

reviews.title: A peaceful escape from hustle and bustle of life.
reviews.text: No wonder Greig could write in this beautiful, serene setting. It was magical to visit this Summer house where the composer and his family escaped and entertained. Our guide was very knowledgeable and was very helpful. The only thing which would have made this tour better would have been if we could have attended a concert on the day. We travelled there on the train and walked following the signs which could be clearer. Lovely cafe if needed. The grounds are beautiful and were just bursting with Spring flowers.

reviews.title: Calling all music lovers
reviews.text:
What a tribute to a great man....!! He lived a  simple life. Contributed to the humanity with his work of art. He is immortalized with his compositions. Life well told.
Don't miss the museum where his music is played for you to quietly enjoy. Spend a few minutes there. The Hardanger fiddle is another.... This house is nestled among the woods fitting his creative juices to flow so that we ordinary mortals can enjoy.

Well worth the visit.

reviews.title: Lunch time concert
reviews.text: It was magical to attend a concert in the lounge of Grieg's home. I had 2 Japanese guests with me. In the autumn concerts are smaller and take place in the house instead of the concert hall  I have been here many times but it was especially nice to see the house a d grounds through the Japanese friends' eyes.

reviews.title: Great
reviews.text: Visited here and came out with lot of knowledge. It’s museum but encyclopaedia on Edward Graig. U must visit here. I don’t know how to express what felt being there. Wanna know bergen then it’s must visit place.

reviews.title: God stop if you are a music lover
reviews.text: The actual house and cottage where edvard Grieg wrote music.  The museum also tells the story of the Hardanger Fiddle.  Very interesting instrument with a unique sound.  Beautiful place to visit in summer.

reviews.title: Spectacular views
reviews.text:
If you're a fan of classical music, this could be a cool little pilgrimage. If you're not, the views are ethereal in the winter. Basically there's something for everyone.

This place was Grieg's summer house, basically. It is pretty cold in winter (the lake literally freezes over), but you can see life in the water — urchins and fish kicking about. 

If you have time on the way back to the airport, get off the tram at Hop (pronounced 'Hoop'). It's a 15–20 minute walk from there, and a good way to spend a couple of hours on your last day in Bergen.

reviews.title: Spent longer than we meant to.
reviews.text: Although a reasonable walk from the required bus stop, it is not out of reach for an average person. I enjoyed spending time in his home and wandering down to the lake where he had built a composing studio/hut. Gorgeous in winter and probably very pretty in summer.

reviews.title: What a peaceful, beautiful location
reviews.text: Throughly enjoyed the Grieg Museum and house and the views afforded from the composer's hut. We had a knowledgeable guide and were lucky that the sun did unusually shine basking the inlets in sunshine. The exhibition was informative and the film about Grieg's music stunning using local imagery to underline the music. There was a nice cafe with a great view. Well with a visit out of season! I hate to think how busy it must be in the summer months.

reviews.title: Composer`s house
reviews.text: Edward Grieg is famous Norwegian composer. I was surprised that he had not only Norwegian but also Danish and Scottish roots. Villa gives facts about his life. This is possible to buy tickets for the lunch concert almost every day

reviews.title: With pianist friend
reviews.text: Excellent outing! Lots for musicians to enjoy! And others. A must when visiting Bergen. Take a pic-nic and enjoy the nature around.

reviews.title: See summer home
reviews.text: Home is interesting but limited size for looking.  Guides are brief and not too in depth.  Try to go when there is at concert.

reviews.title: Listen to Grieg' s fantastic music played on his piano in his own home.
reviews.text: Lovely estate by the fjord Nordaasvannet. Well worth visiting. Å bit tricky to get to if you do not travell by car or bus.

reviews.title: Wonderful!
reviews.text: We bought the ticket at the tourist centre, and took the bus tour. It was a wonderful experience. The guides in the home were excellent, beautiful setting and fantastic coffee shop. If you enjoy music you will love the piano concert in the fabulous setting...acoustics were exceptional. .....even on a rainy day!

reviews.title: Cool to see the pictures and learn some history about Grieg
reviews.text: Good to see the home and learn about the composer.  Seeing pictures of Grieg and the time that he lived there.

reviews.title: Part of our tour
reviews.text: Visited here as part of our tour. It was interesting enough but if you aren’t into old music it might not be your cup of tea.

reviews.title: If you love Grieg's music, you will enjoy his house, grounds, and concert.
reviews.text: We bought our tickets at the tourist office in Bergen, so met the bus and guide right there.  (We got a senior discount) There was a short walk to the house and concert hall in the rain from the bus, but it was beautiful and not difficult. The house that the Griegs built was lovely and had many personal articles and photos.  The tiny house that Grieg wrote in is close to the water; their graves are down some slippery (in the rain) stone steps, but interesting to see. The pianist for our Grieg concert was just OK, but it was a pleasure to hear Grieg's music there. Nice gift shop.

reviews.title: Favorite Composer Comes to Life
reviews.text: Wonderful museum and lovely concert, the grounds are gorgeous, with views from the concert venue, very friendly staff, nice cafe, but the music was heavenly!

reviews.title: Well worth the effort to get there
reviews.text: We were staying in Bergen for a day and we were delighted that we made the effort to get out to this lovely place. Very good conducted tour of the house which was delightful. Lovely grounds and very pleasant café. You need to allow about an hour to get out there from Bergen. Take the airport light railway out to Hop station which takes about 20 minutes, trains run every 10 minutes and is cheap from the city centre tram stops. Then you have a 20-30 minute walk, some of it uphill to the house. There is a bus from Bergen but runs very infrequently. At certain times of the year there are lunchtime concerts.

reviews.title: a taste of Grieg
reviews.text: Bit of a hikefrom the bus lot  but cabs will take you right to the entrance. Lovely perferformance venue, access to the realtively small Grieg home, Nice museum/gift shop and a pleasant coffee shopt.

reviews.title: Not a Must See
reviews.text: Grieg is a renowned Norwegian composer. I really know nothing about classical music, but even I recognized some of his more famous pieces. Having said that, this is nothing more than a small old historic home  in a pleasant garden setting. Unless you are a Grieg groupie, there are better ways to spend your time in the Bergen area.

reviews.title: If you love Grieg, it is inspiring
reviews.text: This little house with a work shed and the gravesite are just out of town, and laid out in the way it looked when Grieg was there.  The guides were great

reviews.title: Song of Norway - Visiting Edvard Grieg's Home
reviews.text:
We visited the Bergen Tourist Information Office, and one of the tours they offered was a tour & concert at Troldhaugen, the home of Edvard & Nina Grieg.  My childhood was full of music by Grieg thanks to my mother, who loved the composer and ensured most of her piano students played his pieces, so this was a trip with great significance for me.  
We met our bus and tour guide outside the Tourist Information office; our tour guide was well-informed and entertaining, offering lots of great information about Grieg, his friend Ole Bull, and the 19th century Norwegian musical community 
If you take this tour, be prepared to walk about ¼ mile from bus parking to the Grieg homestead.  On arrival, we split into two groups – one to stay in the performance center/museum and the other to tour the Grieg home.
The home, built in 1885 with great input from both Edvard and Nina Grieg, was planned to be a museum even before Grieg and his wife died.  It opened as a museum in 1928, ad now features a concert hall, the home (called a Villa), and the Grieg’s tomb, near the water below the home.
Only the main floor is open to the public, and includes a room filled with items of great significance to the Grieg family, the dining room, a living room which features the piano Grieg used during his life, and is still used for concerts.  According to our guide the guide, the furnishings throughout the house were either original to the house, or accurate to the period of use.  There is also an enclosed porch which Nina Grieg converted into a conservatory, and which features a beautiful stained glass rose over the door.
The Griegs were great entertainers, and their home was often filled with guests.  Frustrated by the lack of peace and quiet due to those visitors, Grieg had a small cabin constructed near to the water, and where we were told he composed some of his most famous musical compositions.
A short (but rather rain-slicked) walk down the hill from the Villa, Edvard and Nina Grieg share their eternal rest behind a tombstone in the hillside that bears the inscription of their name.  Here Grieg rests in the Norwegian woods he loved so much and wrote of so often.
In 1985, a beautiful concert hall was built especially for the performance of chamber music.  The picture window behind the stage area is the perfect frame for Grieg’s cabin and the water behind it.  The hall has seating for 200 people.  We were privileged to enjoy a lunch-time concert featuring pianist Martha Berit Belt.  Her performance of several Grieg compositions was breath-taking, and a perfect end to our tour of Troldhaugen.
For Grieg fans, this tour is a must when in Bergen; but even non-Grieg fans will enjoy and appreciate the history which has been so carefully curated.

reviews.title: a must for pianists or Grieg fans
reviews.text:
It's better plan 3 hours there that you can have enough time to immerse the whole surrounding( house, composer's hut, lake and his final resting place), plus enjoy a live concert without rushing. 
The house has many Grieg's personal photos and paintings on the wall, as well as his own music scores which will make all music lovers treasure. Think about stepping into a composer's own home and fell like he is there. What an unforgettable experience.   
I was pretty lucky visiting there on a sunny day in September that I didn't walk on the slippery paths. But I think I still will be be appreciated the views even on a raining day. Besides, Bergen got it's fame as a rainy city. Also Grieg loved to take strolls during raining days in his property.

reviews.title: Bergen City Tour
reviews.text: This is a small museum and the tour is short. This was the home of the famous Norwegian composer Edward Grieg.. The highlight of my tour was my attendance at The International Piano Competition that was held while I was visiting.

reviews.title: Short but sweet
reviews.text: The museum is relatively small, and there are just a few rooms in the villa to see, and only one of those is furnished.  The walks to the composing hut and grave are both steep and slippery if wet.  I had googled info about this place before arriving, and it was helpful - there is no info at the hut or graves, for instance.  There's about a 5 minute walk from the parking up to the attraction.  The movie is just a DVD of places in Norway set to his music - it was lovely, but not what you might be expecting.  Overall we both found it charming.

reviews.title: Culture and social history
reviews.text: Loved it. Taken by bus on the 20 minute drive to the summer house. Beautiful and atmospheric with interesting tour of house, giving interesting details about Grieg, his wife and life; followed by 30 minute concert. We were told the hall was built to provide excellent acoustics and it really showed as the sound of the music was so pure, I didn't use the cafe but spent my time in the pleasant grounds. Good value package as taxi would bemuch more expensive.  Tour gets booked fast so go to touist info as soon as to book.

reviews.title: Piano concert at music festival
reviews.text: When Levi Ove Andsnes is participating on the piano, the rest of the program is just a must. This time different young artists playing violin and strings with very high professionalism.. we will come back

reviews.title: Great history listen. Great mudic
reviews.text: So many interesting things in Bergen. But it is not complete if you do not learn more about Bergen born composer Edvard Grieg. His museum and home are lovely and interesting. You can see the very spot where he composed many of his best known music.  You also learn he was very self absorbed   Interesting all the same

reviews.title: Atmospheric
reviews.text: An excellent and informative representation of the great man’s life. The tour of his house is a must but the highlight was the piano concert in front of a huge glass window looking out over a lake.

reviews.title: must see
reviews.text: do not hesitate to go see this lovely museum and home for an insight of Norwegian music and culture.  Be sure to be there for a concert. We had a terrific guide when we were there and the pianist was awesome.

reviews.title: Not to be missed if visiting Bergen
reviews.text: A trip to Edward Greig's house and museum was the highlight of my stay in Bergin.  We tried to get the bus to attend the concert but this was booked out so we hired a taxi which was very reasonable.  The museum is well set out and Greig's house is so authentic. The furniture and artefacts are so interesting.  The views from the house and the hut where Grieg composed  are amazing.  We attended the concert in the beautiful new concert hall where a wonderful pianist performed works by Greig for a half an hour.  I am surprised that there is not more regular busses laid on by the authorities in Bergen to this fantastic attraction in honour of Bergen's most famous son.

reviews.title: Highlight of our visit to Bergen
reviews.text:
A group of us recently visited Edvard Grieg's house - an amazing oasis with fantastic views and a real sense of "history".  His house is wonderful filled with original furniture and, of course, his grand piano.   Our guide was excellent - so precise with little snippets of personal information.   Grieg's small composing hut was also available to view and it was easy to see where he got his inspiration.  A short lunchtime recital of his music was a delight. The hall was tiered with a glass window out to the wonderful scenery beyond - a super experience. A museum, film show + lovely cafe are all on site.   This is an amazing place to visit, well worth the effort and not to be missed! 
Tourist Board offers transport + entrance - a good & easy way to visit.  However, the bus was booked out on the day so we purchased entrance tickets & took a taxi there & back (a bit expensive but more flexible).

reviews.title: Lunchtime Concert with Provided Transportation
reviews.text: We are not Edvard Grieg afficionados, although I knew his Per Gint work, but this was a welcome change to schlepping in and out of museums and shops. Our actual concert was in the Troldhaugen home of Grieg, due to the international piano contest, and the setting was so intimate that you felt like it was in your own home. Both the Tenor and the Pianist were outstanding! While I was disappointed not to be able to be in the actual concert hall, with it's view of the composing hut and lake, how often do you get to sit less than three feet away from an internationally known pianist and watch her hands massage the keys? My only constructive criticism is that - and again this may be due to the contest - the visit seemed disorganized and with long waiting spells. But, worth the wait.

reviews.title: Loved the home!
reviews.text: We are on a tour and had a local guide for a city tour and also for this home/museum.  Really nice to have someone give you the inside scoop on things you are seeing.  I just loved the interior of the home, the curved staircase, wood ceiling and detailed crown molding, just beautiful.  The area is beautiful.  The composers cabin and their gravesite are not handicap friendly.  Many steps and uneven terrain are involved in getting to them both.  The burial site is up in the mountainside, not in the ground!  The museum also has some interesting personal items of the family.  There’s a cafe as well.

reviews.title: A lovely home, a fascinating museum and a concert made this a delight.
reviews.text: My husband and I were part of a small group to tour the house of Edvard Grieg.  He is so well known and it was insightful to visit his home and learn more about him and who were his contemporaries.  The museum was also helpful in providing information about Grieg.  There was a small cafe where we grabbed a light lunch before attending a concert.  The pianist was quite good, p,aging a variety of Grieg’s works, but he was also accompanied by a vocalist, who was really the highlight of the concert!  I truly recommend a visit to Troldhaugen, but hope you will also be able to attend a concert while there!

reviews.title: Beautiful house in stunning surroundings
reviews.text: The tour was excellent and you got a real feel for the man and his music. You only see the downstairs of the house but it was very interesting. The grounds are wonderful to walk around even on a damp rainy day.  The walk down to the lake is a little steep but worth the effort. We stayed for a short concert that was first rate. 23 pieces based on folk tunes in 40 minutes! Great acoustics in the concert venue as well as a fantastic view.

reviews.title: Lovely Visit
reviews.text: Loved visiting this place though it was pouring with rain and it is not all indoors  The concert was fab and the tour of the house really interesting.

reviews.title: Nice place with concert
reviews.text: Did the tour from city center that includes bus transportation, guided tour of the house and a piano concert by a music professor. The guide was informative, the concert was excellent. From the concert hall, you have a view on the fjord, very scenic!!

reviews.title: Wonderful program
reviews.text: We had visited BERGEN 3 YEARS ago and had done The mountain walk and covered The city and wanted something different.  We booked online ahead of our cruise and paid for The tour and concert direct via this trip advisor suggestion. We were not dissapointed.  We were dropped off by bus from cruise ship and with map Found tourist info centre. You wait outside for bus at 11am a guide met us at 10;45 to issue stickers for bus and came with us to escort us to The café where we met our tour guide for The house and a Little historische re The composer.  The guide was very good ,it was all very well executed.  At The end we were given time to see garden and Lake then led to The concert building for a fantastic piano performance.  The bus dropped us off at The info centre.

reviews.title: Charming house and museum
reviews.text: We loved visiting the house where Grieg lived and seeing the studio where he composed many of his works.  The house is lovingly furnished and seems almost as if he just left today to go for a walk. The guided tour included lots of personal stories which added to the enjoyment.  The adjacent museum is also very informative.

reviews.title: 5 stars...but probably only for us classical music nerds
reviews.text: If you are not a classical music nerd, this place is unlikely to interest you. If you are one of us, well...this place is much nicer than most of the famous composer must-do tourist spots that you visit around the world. Museum was quick and interesting. His house and views are lovely. And very close to the city.

reviews.title: Museum of music
reviews.text: Visited the place on a gloomy day but the house of Edvard Grieg, which serves as an important part of the museum, is nice as it takes you back into Grieg’s time. The view (photo) is still great and it is no wonder that beautiful pieces of music were composed here. It is worthwhile to join (you’ll have to pay separately) the lunch concerts (and on busy days better to book online as the auditorium was fully a packed when we visited) that they have most of not all days as it really brings Grieg further to life. It’s a little bit out of town so easiest if you have your own transportation but you might be able to get on a bus.

reviews.title: Very Interesting and Honor to a Bergen Master
reviews.text: I am far from a great music expert but do appreciate the talent it takes to excel in any form or aspect of music...Edvard Grieg was a true music master and led an interesting life in a beautiful city.  His home site museum is a fitting tribute to his contributions.  This is worthy of any Bergen vistor's time to see, a must-see for music lovers.

reviews.title: Surprisingly Good
reviews.text: I booked a visit to the museum as part of an excursion on a recent cruise. At first, this was just to fill some time in a city I was not familiar with. However, it turned out to be quite fascinating. You have almost certainly heard Edvard Grieg's work whether you realize it or not. He is a famous composer from Norway. This tour takes you to his home, his composing studio, his grave, and the concert hall built on the property. There are breathtaking views of the area including the water, the mountains, and more. The home is the museum and offers quite a bit about Grieg there. I would recommend finding a good tour guide. Also, book the piano recital in the wonderful music hall. The performer changes on a weekly basis, so your experience may vary.

reviews.title: First-rate musuem experience
reviews.text: Top-notch museum.  Lots of interesting artifacts presented in a professional manner.  We really enjoyed the lunchtime concert as well!

reviews.title: The victorian house near the lake
reviews.text:
If you want to get there, take the Light Rail tram from Byparken (near the octagonal lake) and get off at the Hop stop, it takes around 25 minutes.
Then, you have to walk for 25 minutes following the clear signposts.
The visit is interesting: at the Welcome Centre where you buy tickets, there is a small but comprehensive exhibition about Grieg's life and musical activities.
Then, you can visit Grieg's victorian villa where he spent 22 years with his wife Nina (the summer months).
Actually only the 3 rooms at the ground floor are open to visit: there are free guided tours of the villa in English, ask the reception.
Then, you can visit the composer's hut where Grieg could concentrate and composed its masterpieces.
If you walk to the lake edge, you can see the burial place where Grieg and his wife are buried.
The view on the lake is really lovely.

reviews.title: For music lovers
reviews.text: An in depth experience regarding the home, life, and family of Edvard Greig. This will not only give you a sense of his environment but also a window into his creativity.  Very worthwhile for Greig enthusiasts.

reviews.title: Concert and visit well worth it!
reviews.text: It was interesting to wander the grounds as it's a beautiful area.  The combination with the concert is what it made worthwhile as pianist was very enjoyable.  The concert hall overlooks the lake with an incredible view.

reviews.title: Summer home of Edward Greig.  Very interesting and site affords a nice panoramic view of Bergen.
reviews.text: My parents loved Grieg’s Peer Gynt  Suite  so I couldn’t resist going to this museum which is the composer’s summer house.  As you would expect, it has original furnishings when the composer and his wife lived there.  A great little gift shop where you can buy little souvenir music boxes of some of Grieg’s most famous pieces. A very enjoyable couple of hours.

reviews.title: Excellent Edward Grieg Museum
reviews.text:
We had a guided tour of Edward Grieg’s summer house. Excellent display and exhibition. 
The lunch time piano recital at the concert hall was excellent. Just piano pieces from Grieg.
Worth the visit

reviews.title: Marvellous Music Museum
reviews.text: Every Classical music buff should visit here, if in Bergen! My (non-musical) husband even loved it. Grieg’s home is in magnificent condition, the artefacts and paintings are excellent. We gained great insight into Edvard Grieg, with one of the highlights being a young pianist playing 3 of Grieg’s Piano Concertos. Not to be missed!

reviews.title: All Grieg All the Time
reviews.text: Troldhaugen is a combination museum, historic site (Grieg's summer home and composer's hut), and concert hall.  It also has a nice little cafe.  It was fascinating to see the views  of nature that helped to inspire Grieg.  The museum is small, but jam-packed with information about Grieg, his family, and his sources of inspiration.  There are daily lunchtime concerts where his works are performed.  Well worth the trip!

name: Bergen Tourist Information
ranking_subcategory: #15 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #15 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #15 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description:
At the Tourist Information in Bergen you can book accommodation, activities, fjord tours, sightseeing, train tickets or the Bergen Card for Bergen and the region. 

Location:
The Tourist Information is located on Torget, the Fish Market. 
 
At the Tourist Information, you can book all kinds of accommodation: hotels, B&Bs, family and youth hostels or private accommodation in a family home. You can choose between 40 hotels in the city center and the rest of the region - ranging from small, charming hotels to big chain hotels with excellent facilities.
 
Currency Exchange / Bureau De Change:
The Tourist Information have the best opening hours in the city for currency exchange. You can change most currencies. You can also purchase services and products with foreign currency.
 
Tickets for sightseeing, fjord tours and concerts:
Suggestions for sightseeing and harbor excursions in the city, as well as tickets for all the well-known round trips and fjord tours that depart from Bergen. In fact, many tours start right outside the door!
 
The Bergen Card - practical and inexpensive: 
Get free offers and good discounts with the Bergen Card. For sale in the Tourist Information.   
 
Free brochures: 
All the brochures you will need for Bergen and Fjord Norway as well as exhibitions that will guide and inspire you on the rest of your trip.
 
Train tickets:
Book your train tickets for all rail journeys in Norway.

offer_list.title: Bergen Card
Private Tour to Sognefjord, Gudvangen, and Flåm from Bergen
Fjord & Glacier Tours - Bergen
Bergen - Walk with a local
Bergen - Mostraumen cruise

reviews.title: Very Helpful
reviews.text: For any visitor this is a great place to start your visit to Bergen, the staff are so friendly and helpful, they will help you to make the best of your visit to this beautiful City.

reviews.title: Incredibly helpful!
reviews.text: We went into the tourist office to book a variety of tickets and they were were incredibly helpful and very patient! Thoroughly recommend them if you have any questions about Bergen and getting around.

reviews.title: Very helpful in planning our trips around Bergen
reviews.text:
This is a beautiful building and the staff is very helpful and knowledgeable.   Please be courteous and take a ticket to get in line. The staff was very helpful and knowledgeable. They helped us plan our trips around Bergen as well.  There are some souvenirs that you can purchase from here.  Lots of maps and brochures are available for free.

They have comprehensive information about Bergen and surrounding areas. Highly recommend talking to these folks.  The location is easy to spot because it is right next to the Fish Market.

reviews.title: EXCELLENT PLACE
reviews.text: I am surprised at some of the recent reviews. I found the place one of the best travel information sources I have ever visited. There is staff behind the desk to answer specific questions. There are several sections of wall filled with pamphlets. Best of all some areas are highlighted with further information and pictures, pamphlets on the topic immediately available in that display. It is located near the wharf and fish market, clearly marked. It is on the second floor with elevator access.

reviews.title: TOO long waiting time and poor information (mainly seasonal employees). Don't worth the waiting time!!!!
reviews.text:
We spend at least 45 minutes to get the information we need.
Only 5 booths where open for tens of peoples (a Saturday morning at 11AM - during rush hours!) into the waiting list (you must take a ticket w/ your rank under the waiting list to access one of this booth later).
Morover the employee seems don't not well know their museums (exhibitions status: open or not...)

reviews.title: Too busy
reviews.text: What a queue : having to take a ticket and queuing is not expected in such a place. I took some documentations and left as quick as I could....

reviews.title: Next to Fish Market
reviews.text:
There is lots of information and advice available. They well also book tours, tickets for the funicular, etc. There were three people working at the time we were there and it was a bit slow. Make sure you grab a number for your turn.

They also have information on what's open or closed do to weather.

Helpful word, you will need to have Norwegian currency or credit card. The center will exchange, but we did not find one place that accepted foreign currency.

reviews.title: Really in need of improvements
reviews.text:
This place is too small and too poorly organized to handle the numbers of tourists jamming it during the summer months.  Focus on commercial sales v. Real tourist info — for example, they’re ready & eager to sell bus tours, but there is no information on the city transit system (maps, routes, schedules).  If you really press on the public transit info, they can sell you passes — but the main thing seems to be to sell tours or hop-“on, hop-off bus tickets. Not nearly enough staff to fill The need.  Expect long waits to talk with someone (and no seating either).  Lousy toilet facilities, dark and gloomy, mixed men & women, also with very long waits.  
And you need a credit card to use one.  Individual staff were great when one finally gets to talk with one.

reviews.title: Busy place
reviews.text: Turist info is by the fish market and harbor. It’s busy,, but they have a good system and several people at the desks. Here you’ll find maps and info on Bergen and area. You can also buy tickets here for certain attractions. Don’t buy the tickets for Fløyen funicular here! The queue is longer for prepaid tickets than at the ticket office for Fløyen! We had the Bergen Card. Gives free travel on Bergen’s public transport and free entrance or discounts on attractions. He Bergen Card is worth it if you’re into museums and need transport at the same time. We got our money’s worth and then some, but only because we visited some places we normally wouldn’t have been to. Great value for some, but do your homework!

reviews.title: Bergen trip
reviews.text: this has got to be the tourist information centre I have visited, they had everything you needs here, very busy though

reviews.title: Helpful
reviews.text: Go first day to sort out your days in Bergen, staff helpful and able to book tickets there. Lots of information at convenient location

reviews.title: Great place to find what is really going on
reviews.text: It is very busy, take a number.  Good view of the Fishmarket and the inner harbor as you wait.  Plentiful supply of brochures and maps.  Knowledgeable , enthusiastic young, friendly pretty well describes the staff.  If you have not been to Bergen before, and you’re not on any tour,it is the best place to start

reviews.title: Helpful
reviews.text: Some people were better than others as is always the case in these places but on the whole the staff are young and enthusiastic and we got the answers we needed. It is housed in a modern building with large windows overlooking the hanseatic wharf of old Bergen.

reviews.title: Super busy
reviews.text: Take a number! they were really busy, but super helpful and there are plenty of brochures, right near Fishmarket and a nice view.

reviews.title: Brilliant place to plan your Bergen experience.
reviews.text:
Very busy but worth the wait. Money exchange and loads of information.
Glad we waited right next to the Fish Market.

reviews.title: Long lines
reviews.text: Good information, but long lines at the tourist center. They could use twice the space, and twice the agents.

reviews.title: They can answer all your questions
reviews.text:
But it can be very busy and you have to take a ticket.
Very good practical information, prospecti and suggestions
Also for buying tickets

reviews.title: Helpful with purchase of tickets
reviews.text: Purchased tickets for next days bus trip to Grieg's home.  Very helpful personnel.  Also able to purchase stamps for postcards

reviews.title: Ticketing
reviews.text: Most things covered in this centrally located office. Staff use a ticketing system which helps. A few seats would be nice.

reviews.title: amazing
reviews.text: it was  an  amazing  tour   OMG  the  nature ,  the  views  , the  fjords  ,  amazing  . our   guide was  very  professional  , every  thing  was  on  time  ,I  recommended it    to  all

reviews.title: Very informative
reviews.text: If you have any questions, this is the place to go. Centrally located, they have a lot of brochures and information on everything in the area. We bought our tickets to the Floyen before we went, saved us from standing in the ticket line when we got there. The agents were very friendly and helpful.

reviews.title: Extremely Helpful
reviews.text: We went there upon reaching Bergen and got our Bergen passes. Received advice and recommendations from the very friendly and efficient staff. Waiting time is short. Location is convenient, next to fish market.

reviews.title: The friend in need
reviews.text: Very good information system. A good experience.You get all the necessary tips and information all about the activities in Bergen

reviews.title: Very Helpful
reviews.text: Go pick their brains.  The staff are knowledgeable, and if you tell them what you are after, they will offer you good options.

reviews.title: !!!Lost!!!
reviews.text: We went in here for a little advice, as we had lost our sense of direction!  There was a ticketing system in operation, which was not apparent when we walked in.  We just walked up to an assistant when they were free - and they politely pointed out on our map where we were and said we had to queue.  Just knowing where we were on the map was all the information we needed.  Think they were there mainly to book people onto trips

reviews.title: Lots of good info
reviews.text: Excellent service, very helpful. Everything you wanted to know about Bergen and more. Maps, flyers and multiple brochures available.

reviews.title: Bergen Information
reviews.text:
On the waterfront next to the fish market is a modern building housing the information service for Bergen. Here you can get information about the sites and buy tickets for fiord and coastal trips. You can also buy a Bergen pass which is only a good deal if you will be staying a few days and want to see several museums and get a discount on fiord trips 
It’s problem is that it is very busy so you have to take a number and wait to be served but once it is your turn the staff is very patient and helpful. In our case maybe too helpful, when we asked what to be sure to see in one and a half days our helper pointed out at least 12 different places which we couldn’t possibly cover in the time we had. All were interesting but it was hard to prioritize.

reviews.title: Friendly and informative
reviews.text: The people who helped us today were wonderful. They spoke English well and were well informed. They have tons of info on all the things you can do. You should stop in when you get to town, collect some things, figure out what you want to do and go back to book tours or get the Bergen Card.

reviews.title: Not a clue!
reviews.text:
We wanted to do a boat tour around the harbour so visited Tourist Information to see what was available. We were told about a sailing boat that would cost us NOK 690 each (about £69 EACH - there were 5 of us).

We asked if there was anything else and we were told the only other trip, apart from visits to the Fjords, was a ferry that was mainly for taking people to work.

We reluctantly agreed to go on the sailing boat and paid our money.  We asked what the boat was called, only to be informed that it didn’t have a name. We asked how we were supposed to know that we were on the correct boat if it didn’t have a name – we were given a print out with a picture on and told “that’s the picture of the boat”.  We were informed that the pick-up point was “about a 15 minute walk away, just past the church”.

Once the trip was over (we only had 1½ hours when we were told it was 2 hours), we walked round the harbour and noticed the hop-on/hop-off boats which were only NOK 100 £10 per person.  Needless to say, we were furious!  

If you should visit Tourist Information in Bergen and they try to fob you off into paying a lot of money for going on a boat, please be aware that you can do the hop-on/hop-off boat tours for a lot less money – and probably more enjoyable!

reviews.title: The go to place for tourists
reviews.text: The one place in Bergen which gives you all information about travelling around and things to do as well as currency exchange and booking of tours and tickets. The staff is very patient and give all the information one requires as well as tips on travelling around. We would have been lost without this.

reviews.title: First class
reviews.text: This information centre was first class in terms of the staff and their friendly, knowledgeable, interaction with the public, but also in terms of the amount of readily available brochures, leaflets etc. most of which were free. There were lots of ideas to choose from and help was available. I’ve been to tourist centre in many parts of Europe but this one was really excellent.

reviews.title: Very helpful in Bergen
reviews.text: The tourist information centre is opened until 10 pm which allows late arrivals time to find out the place for the following day. Given it’s not dark until 11 pm it makes sense to stay open late. They were very helpful with where to eat, public transport and places to see.

reviews.title: Tourist information building
reviews.text: This is the starting place for many tours in Bergen. This building was built at the Fish Market. All information about Bergen attractions you can find on the 1st floor. Good place for photographers

reviews.title: Easy to find TI
reviews.text: Most visitors arrive by cruise liner. The tourist information off is close to the port and fairly easy to find. When ships arrive it is extremely busy but the staff do their best to help. Free wifi is availabile if you follow the instructions on the wall. I found this difficult to follow and staff were too busy to help. I gave up

reviews.title: I was immediately helped when we arrived by a very pleasant clerk.
reviews.text: We were looking to get the Bergen Pass and were not real clear on the line we should stand in.  Walked to an open line and asked the clerk where we needed to go.  She said she'd take our number and help us.  She gave us much more information than we came in seeking.  Very nice experience.

reviews.title: Nice building but only 1 or 2 working.
reviews.text: Nice building, somewhat difficult to tell where the tourist information as it is shared with others. Slow service

reviews.title: Modern Scandinavian Design
reviews.text: Accessible by life, this modern information centre is on the second floor.  Take a ticket and wait for your number to be called.  Very efficient, friendly staff and definitely the place to head for if you are new to Bergen or Norway.  Lots of information for Bergen and "What's on" and all the information you need for travelling in Norway and the activities you can do.

reviews.title: Helpful information re airport transport
reviews.text:
We checked here regarding transport to the airport from the city centre
We thought the airport bus on offer was the way to go however the staff told us about the light rail which leaves from the centre centre and is much cheaper
It does take around 45 mins compared to the bus which takes only around 25 mins but if you have time it’s a saving

reviews.title: Get there early
reviews.text: Excellent resource.  Very crowded.  Need to take a number.  If you are using transportation and getting museums, the Bergen pass is a great bargain.

reviews.title: Useful and busy information center
reviews.text: Located above the indoor fish market the Bergen TI is modern, clean and full of pamphlets and information. There are helpful employees working the main counter to provide information and help book tours. Bergen attracts lots of tourists so the TI can get fairly busy at times. There may be a wait if you need personal attention.

reviews.title: Informative and clean
reviews.text: Good tourist information centre. Everywhere was clean and a lift t9 get to it if you cannot manage the stairs

reviews.title: Super helpful
reviews.text: The staff here is super helpful and can assist with booking all kinds of things, like bus tickets to get to the airport, cruises and boat rides, and museum passes. Highly recommend stopping in if you have any questions when you're in Bergen.

reviews.title: Excellent Info!
reviews.text: I was pleasantly surprised by the great resources and the interactive displays. Definitely worth stopping here to ensure you leave the most of your time in this beautiful city!

reviews.title: Very efficient and well laid out
reviews.text: In a lovely modern building above the indoor fish market there is a lot of useful information and the staff are very helpful and well informed. We had previously bought a Bergen card and exchanged our voucher at the TI and we booked Norway in a nutshell there too.

reviews.title: Very efficient
reviews.text: It's the best place for foreign exchange . Very efficient staff. Most of the tickets for places of interest is available .its one stop shops for your needs.

reviews.title: Great information
reviews.text:
On the second floor of  the fish market you find the information center. It is the place to find all sorts of information, pamphlets, brochures about Bergen. I would say it is the first place to go when in Bergen. Plus you can find out about the  many bus routes and tours available. 
Also, the staff is very knowledgeable, helpful and courteous and patient.

reviews.title: Go here first!
reviews.text: Very nice and complete preview of what you can do in Bergen. Nicely laid out with friendly folks to help.  Can get a bit crowded, but that’s life. Go here first and plan your time here.

reviews.title: Essential
reviews.text: If you want to get the most out of your visit to Bergen and the surrounding area, then you really need to go here. The staff are very knowledgeable and friendly, and there is a wealth of brochures available in a range of languages.

reviews.title: Worth calling in
reviews.text: Situated on the second floor of a modern building in the fish market area, there is a lift if you can not manage the stairs,this is a well run tourist information centre where they operate a numbered ticket system so hopefully no one jumps the queue.The staff are very good and speak English and will help you with any questions regarding accommodation,sight seeing trips,there are also plenty of brochures to choose from.Here it is possible to change currencies,also there is free WiFi which i found very good.

reviews.title: Lots of helpful information
reviews.text: This is a very busy information centre, but they have a great system, where you take a number, so no one can jump the queue. The staff are very helpful and speak English.

reviews.title: Great help
reviews.text: In Bergen for the day and wanted to get some information about what is here, Town map etc. They are very helpful and give you very helpful advice. Worth calling in.

reviews.title: Advice to jump the line.
reviews.text: In common with all enterprises, money talks.  If you want to jump the line, merely take a waiting ticket to say you want to change currency.  Bingo!  You're next in.

reviews.title: Friendly, helpful, knowledgeable staff
reviews.text: I can only repeat what someone else has put ....   "Easy to find on harbour look for a green sign with i on it. Upstairs take your ticket and wait your turn! Very friendly and helpful and will answer all your questions."  I can only add why are ALL (at least the ones we met in the various cities) the Norwegians so friendly and helpful?

reviews.title: Good for information, money exchange and ticketing.
reviews.text: All travel and sight seeing and activities brochures are available here. Just above the famous fishmarket in the pier of Bergen.

reviews.title: Very helpful
reviews.text: Easy to find on harbour look for a green sign with i on it. Upstairs take your ticket and wait your turn! Very friendly and helpful and will answer all your questions.

reviews.title: Closed at four in winter.
reviews.text: We returned after it was closed on our first day. Very helpful staff and a central place to begin walking from. This city is easy to walk around as long as you don't mind cobblestones.

reviews.title: Best tourist office in the world
reviews.text: The staff here are amazing. When we went to make some inquiries a lot of initiative was shown by the staff member. She gave us extra information on the Bergen ticket that we had purchased online and an informative booklet on the fjord tour that’s we had booked online. Do go in and source these useful pieces of information before heading out on trips.

reviews.title: Brilliant service
reviews.text: Very pleased with the service and help we’ve received here. Tips on where to go what to see, help with booking a boat trip, opening hours of cable car and weather conditions, bus and tram information, absolutely brilliant!

reviews.title: Confirm all information here
reviews.text: Tickets, timings, hours, routes... confirm everything here. They should be able to help and it's in a beautiful location too just beside the fish market.

reviews.title: An eclectic experience
reviews.text: Walking along the water front and experiencing the sights and sounds of market place is so enchanting. It is such an experience that you will remember for ever. Generally, we liked everything about Norway. The people, the environment, the antique buildings, market places, shopping experiences and food. Of course, the food. The building depicted in this picture is fish market. Don't miss it. Go inside and experience the hussle bussle of people. Taste some dishes prepared there for you. It is just wonderful.

reviews.title: Right in the city
reviews.text: I came here to buy postcards only, you can get stamps to post overseas also. The staff were friendly which is usual and appreciated in Norway.

reviews.title: Very helpful staff
reviews.text: Stopped by on first day and got some great advice on what was open and best way to purchase tickets. Opted for the 48 hour Bergen card for best value for our choices.

reviews.title: Very helpful
reviews.text:
It’s right there in the heart of the city in front of the lake. I just needed to get my euros exchanged to NOK, went there at the guy on the counter was very helpful. He exchanged the currency in less than a minute and gave me coins on request. They even gave me good information about the city and tours. 
One can buy tickets from here of sea tours etc. it’s at the right location to serve the tourist in the best way possible.

reviews.title: Excellent information to plan time in  Bergen
reviews.text: On my first full day in Bergen, I went to the Bergen Information center, The associate who helped me plan my three days was excellent. She informed of those places that would be if interest to me. Once we had the discussion, it was apparaent that the three day Bergen Card would be the best value while I was there. My stay in Bergen was excellent because of her help.

reviews.title: Bergen card - make sure they tell you what is closed
reviews.text: The Bergen Card is a great idea, but outside the summer season opening hours are reduced and several sites are either completely closed or have reduced activities. However, the Bergen Card doesn't reduce prices in this period, so it's much less of a good deal. Also, check for everything you want to see, as they won't tell you what isn't open (e.g. because it's being refurbished) and you can't rely on museum's websites to be honest about it either. However, if you ask the right questions, the staff will politley give you the correct information.

reviews.title: Had lots of good information
reviews.text: We were headed up north and wanted suggestions about what places were worth stopping off to see and guy who help me was full of good information.

reviews.title: Information about tours
reviews.text: You can find there information about all types of tourist services including day trips. This Center is at the fish market

reviews.title: Helpful staff but very poor exchange rates
reviews.text: 0.82 to 1 ration of their exchange rate is very poor, considering how important tourism is for them.

reviews.title: Helpful!
reviews.text: If you plan on spending a couple of days in Bergen, grap the Bergen Card.  Worth the money.  Very helpful staff.  On the plus side the fish market is down stairs, and there's lots to see and enjoy there.

reviews.title: Better to do your own research!
reviews.text: Not particualary helpful or should I say the two people we saw were not particulary helpful.  Having said that you can buy most tickets for most attractions / activities here but you will obtain more info by doing your own research especially when it comes to Fjord tours.

reviews.title: We Recommend this Wintery Bergen Fjord Cruise
reviews.text: We walked into the tourist center at around 11 am, wondering about booking a 2-hour cruise in the harbor. Luckily, they had space and we were surprised to find ourselves 30 minutes later greeted by our captain, Arve, on a 40+ foot sailboat just for 9 people. IT WAS COLD, but so worthwhile! Arve told us about the history of the area and explained about changes that have occurred in Bergen over the years. We loved his sense of humor and it was just a joy to spend 2 hours happily freezing with him at the wheel! The tourist office folks very extremely helpful, as well!

reviews.title: Holiday
reviews.text:
Very friendly and helpful service.
Can exchange money. Elevator access.
Much tourist literature available.

reviews.title: Holiday
reviews.text:
Extremely helpful staff and friendly 
Centrally situated and easy to find
Very modern building and has everything at hand that's needed to tour
Also does money exchange and seems to be the best to do everything in one place from your maps to yours to exchange your money

reviews.title: Very helpful, great place to get tickets.
reviews.text: Lots of info and maps available. We booked our Fjord tour tickets here which was really useful, as well as sorting our Bergen Cards. In a good location central to all the attractions in the town.

reviews.title: Pretty good and responsive staff!!
reviews.text: Located right on top of the fish market, its easy to locate and the staff are very friendly and responsive.

reviews.title: Very good Tourist Center
reviews.text: We stopped in here to pick up our Norway in a Nutshell tickets.  The ladies working here were very friendly and informative, taking their time with us to answer all our questions about our NIN tour, as well as sights around Bergen. Definitely worth a stop in!

reviews.title: Excellent Honest service
reviews.text:
We found the people in Bergen very friendly, honest and helpful. The first great experience was when we landed at Bergen airport on 22nd September and wanted to enquire the shuttle bus to Bergen, the Bergen Flybussen lady attendant patiently explained how to get to our hotel and assited with our luggage, informed the driver on our hotel stop and open the middle door for us to go up instead of queing at the front door which was a cold day.. She is so kind, considerate and helpful.

The second time was the young long blonde hair slim lady (unfortunately did not get her name) at the tourist information counter which we we checking what is best for us with the 2 day visit. we were trying to get the Bergen card but we do not much like to see more museums. After asking us what we like, l find her very patient, helpful and honest to tourist like us telling us to pay for the individual attractions rather than getting a Bergen card which would be more expensive. She even told another local man to hold on while explaining to us who was impatient waiting for exchange.

The information centre is organized with que numbering system to attend. while waiting to be served can browse through the brochures availabile at the centre. The tourist information centre is location upstairs of the fish market at the harbour area

reviews.title: A busy place right on the waterfront--very helpful people.
reviews.text: A great asset to tourists from around the world--assistants are fluent in many languages and can help with planning travel and visits within the entire country.

reviews.title: Very helpful and efficient
reviews.text:
The information Centre in Bergen is located above the smart looking Fish Market building and has a lift going up.
The local maps and Information pamphlets regarding all activities can be got from here. They also do booking for the ‘Norway in a nutshell ‘ tour which is quite a complete explanation of the Norwegian Fiords in a compressed time of a single day!!!
The staff all speak English and are helpful.
There is also a Money Exchange service available here.

reviews.title: Helpful staff
reviews.text: The tourist information centre is easy to find and the helpful staff provide a great deal of helpful information.  The staff speak excellent English and this is a useful starting point to help you plan your time in the area.

reviews.title: Depends Who You Ask
reviews.text:
We have been there three times during our month in Norway.  The employees are always nice but only one was truly helpful and knowledgeable.  She recommended some great road trips.  To be honest though, driving in Norway this time of year, 
October, takes much more time than the GPS says it will.  We turned the "day trips" into two night stays.  We stopped a lot to take photos and to enjoy the scenery.  We were stopped several times for road maintenance due to the unusually heavy rains, and had to take alternate routes multiple times due to road closings and early snows.  We had snow tires but local people warned us against travelling on some of the mountain roads.

We bought a 48 hour Bergen card so we could take the bus for a change.  The woman at the tourist office circled some places on the map and made it sound like they were easy to find.  They were not.  The bus system isn't that easy to navigate.  We had to ask several locals and use the GPS on our phone to find them.  It was easier to walk than to take the bus in many instances.  Most of the drivers speak very little, if any, English.  A local person said the Grieg Museum was much easier to get to by car than by bus.  The Science Museum was hard to find but we did find it with the help of two very nice employees in a sporting goods store.  The only reason we were able to navigate the trip back and forth to where are staying in a cottage near the Sotra Bridge is because we got to know the area well on foot and by car before taking the bus.  It isn't that obvious.  We had an easier time in Costa Rica where the bus stops are not even marked, mostly because we speak some Spanish and are fluent in French.  We speak some German, which is a huge help when deciphering Norwegian but, next time, we will study. Norwegian before we leave.  We should have at least learned how to correctly pronounce the names of the places we planned to visit.

Trip Advisor was at least as much help as the tourist office.  Some of the local experts give great advice and one even sent us a private message with a great recommendation for a day trip to Radoy from Bergen.  It was truly a doable day trip with ample time left over to take some long walks and even to stop at IKEA on the way home.  Norway is beautiful and the people are very nice but travelling can be a bit of a challenge and also very expensive with all of the tolls, ferries, narrow roads, weather, and a bus system that is fabulous only if you speak Norwegian and are also very familiar with the geography.  I don't think the people in the tourist office understand what it is like to be a tourist here.

reviews.title: We found this Tourist Information center very helpful in every way.
reviews.text: We found this tourist information center extremely valuable -It has so much information available and the workers are very knowledgeable.  We got Senior discounts for both 'Norway in a Nutshell' and the Grieg house & concert tours and good advice as to which to do first.  The weather looked better for the first day so we did the 'Norway in a Nutshell' tour then and Grieg in the rain.  We had gone into the center looking for a fjord tour 'seen from above' but were delighted with the two tours we purchased.

reviews.title: Very helpful both during and after our trip
reviews.text:
We booked our Norway in a Nutshell tour at the Bergen Tourist Information office and the process was very smooth. Unfortunately, our actual tour did not go as smoothly and, due to no fault of our own, we got on the wrong boat, missed part of our tour and had to take a public bus and run to catch our train back to Bergen. 

When I contacted the Bergen Tourist Information office to let them know about the problems with our tour and inquire about a refund of our public bus fare they went above and beyond to make things right. A special thanks to Oddbjørn for his kind assistance.

reviews.title: to crowded
reviews.text: I entered  and got discouraged by the huge line. So maybe they do a good job, I could not experience so. So I decided to explore on my own, with some help of the internet

reviews.title: Helpful but Bergen card is poor value
reviews.text: While in Bergen in late August I wanted to see as much as I could while I was there. The tourist information suggested I bought a Bergen Card as a way of saving money. However, this is not the case in the Summer as the discounts you are entitled to are against the premium prices and therefore it actually costs you more than if you paid at the individual museums etc., unless you start at 8, finish at 5 and walk quickly around each place.

reviews.title: Helpful
reviews.text: We went in to take our Bergen cards (free public transport in core zone plus freem visits to some museums and discounts on some other museums and attractions). Bergen card is worth if you are aiming to have 3 rides on public transport a day and, say, visit 2 museums a day. We went for a 3 day bergen card and used it also on a tram to the airport. Staff helpful and free wifi available at their premises. On a ground level you have fridges with fish you can choose and several restaurants would prepare it for you (each having their own offer in the fridge).

reviews.title: Lovely building
reviews.text: Although we didn't actually use Bergen Tourist Office, we did pass the building and I was hugely impressed at the modern architectural style of timber and glazing. It's nice to see a town spend money on a place to invite tourists to see the local attractions and have nice views from within.

reviews.title: Super helpful!
reviews.text:
It's possible to book so many activities here in this one place! We started by popping in just to see if they could verify for us the starting point for a fjord cruise we wanted to do, and we ended up buying the tickets there in advance. It was really convenient. I heard them talking to lots of other people and giving advice. The staff were all really nice and helpful. I went back on the last day of our trip to see if they had stamps as the hotel did not, and they also dropped my postcards in the mail for me!

The waiting number machine was

reviews.title: Should be located on the ground floor
reviews.text: The key to tourist information services is a clear address and good access. The Bergen Tourist Office fails this test. It is located on an upper level and access by the lift is unclear and cramped. When going up in the lift we were still unsure if we were heading for the Tourist Office, Once inside the service is effective and efficient.

reviews.title: Very helpful
reviews.text: If you need info ... this is a great resource.  You can book tours, etc. direct from here, or get lots of ideas of what and where to go and do things next.   It is on the second floor above the fish markets/restaurants in this large building.

reviews.title: Limited use unless you’re needing to book something
reviews.text:
Went for a nosey but nothing more available than we’d got elsewhere. I think if you were needing help to book something it might be useful but they have a ticket system and one man we met gave up
Waiting. It is in a super location however right on the water.

reviews.title: Helpful
reviews.text: A good spot to plan places to explore and also book cruises plus buy tram and bus tickets. The Bergen pass which I purchased was also a worthwhile investment as i caught buses to a couple of knitwear factories.

reviews.title: Bergen tourist information staff blase, beware buying Bergen card
reviews.text: The tourist information staff in Bergen promote the Bergen card but neglect to inform you of limited attractions & limited openings. They have attractions that have been closed for years still on their list of attractions. The staff could have easily pointed out that Bergen tourist attractions had just switched to winter hours. This means daily closures & limited hours. For example St Mary's Church is only open twice a week between 12-2. It would have been easy to reschedule our lunch. Bergen doesn't open their attractions before 10/11 am & closes down at 3/4 pm if they are even open that day. They also neglected to point out their booklet with the winter hours schedule. We were there Oct 2, winter hours start Oct 1. Rather a disappointment, we did the am fjord cruise (tickets purchased from the tourist information), had lunch then arrived at 3 closed venues, 2 of which we found out were under renovation and wouldn't be open for years. Other Scandinavian cities attractions had closed at 5 pm.

reviews.title: Friendly helper
reviews.text: They are so friendly to solve all questions! Dont forget to get tickets before asking any questions!

reviews.title: Lots of info
reviews.text: We came in exhausted and hungry, and went straight to the desk to book a fjord tour. Robert from Germany was super helpful and gave us advice for over 45 minutes. We are ready to enjoy this city thanks to him!

reviews.title: Made my trip - literally
reviews.text: Great ticket system avoiding stessful queues, I picked out several leaflets, took them to the counter and asked assistant to sort my itinerary. And that's just what he did! Excellent English spoken and patient, comprehensive advice. Assistant advised I go on my fjord tour following day because of weather and he was totally right. I had done my homework but 3 day Bergen pass saved me around £15 and I could have used it more. Tours get booked up quite quickly so good to forwaed think. This is such an excellent resource..

reviews.title: Very informative
reviews.text: I think we went to the tourist information center each of the four days we were in Bergen. They are very informative, accurate and very friendly. We bought our Bergen card, tour bus and Fjord tours there. We also got information such as were to the IKEA bus. They also gave us great suggestions on where to eat and what not to miss, I recommend a visit.

reviews.title: Business
reviews.text: Welcoming and helpful staff, large amount of written information available including currency exchange

reviews.title: biggest crabs on the planet
reviews.text: Nice facility with staff to help. Situated above a seafood restaurant with very nice display tanks of live seafood waiting for a customer. Shame about the building as the style is not complimentary to the surrounding architecture as well as blocking the heritage views.

reviews.title: Helpful and informative!
reviews.text: This place has a lot of information on places and things to do in Bergen and surrounds.  It is very well run with a numbering system and the staff are quick, helpful and efficient.  You can also just wander around and get brochures.

reviews.title: Busy but very efficient and helpful
