reviews.text: Does just what a good tourist office should do.  The ticketing system works very well and I only had to wait a short time to be served, I was picking up tickets for a pre-booked trip.  The girl who served me also gave me some excellent advice on where I could find good quality local beer, she was spot on, one of my beers of the year.  Plenty of useful information available and of course you are in Norway so everyone is so polite and helpful and speaks perfect English.  Great ambassadors for a really wonderful country.

reviews.title: Very Helpful Staff
reviews.text: We were able to get some great information on tour options and they actually saved us some money with the advice they gave us. I am really glad I went in to see them and learn about other options available for our family.

reviews.title: It is what it is
reviews.text: Just your average tourist info with some tired and fed up staff repeating the same old info over and over. :)

reviews.title: Bergen tourist information
reviews.text: The Bergen tourist information was full of people from all countries it Organiz place they are helpfull.

reviews.title: Very helpful
reviews.text: During my trip I visited the tourist information twice to book tours and the staff were very helpful and friendly. Can get very busy during midday so would recommend going in the morning or afternoon.

reviews.title: Walk Bergen!
reviews.text: There was really no where else I could write a review encouraging visitors to just go WALK Bergen, so I chose this tourist info site. We took a cruise in and had not booked any excursions, we just wanted to walk the city and see what we stumbled upon. Great choice. Though the second largest city in Norway, this picturesque jewel can easily be traversed in a few hours. There are some very ince parks, shops, galleries, old churches, the Hanseatic Port area to be explored. Architecture is very nice, and all with a nautical flair that reminds me of a small, Hanseatic San Francisco. We just loved the place, despite our limited, cruise stop time line. There are a number of great museums we didnt see, but we went in a couple old churches, shopped, rested in parks and on picturesque hilltops, and had a great lobster with salad in the Hanseatic port. If youve got some shoe leather to spare to burn off all those cruise ship buffet calories, just WALK Bergen. It was a blast.

reviews.title: Money change, tickets, information - it has it all
reviews.text:
Monday 3rd September we were out and about exploring and sightseeing in Bergen, this was the first stop on our Celebrity Silhouette cruise of the Norwegian Fjords. 

We walked the short distance from where the boat docked in the Port, to where this Information Centre is located at the top end of the Port. This unusual shaped building is situated nearby the Fish Market and Flowers Market, it cannot be missed.

The main reason for coming here was to exchange some money into Norwegian Krone. There was a seperate queue and numbering system for the exchange and the information and ticket desks, we did not have to wait long to be served.

There was a ticket machine there for Floibanen funicular, it was quicker that having to wait to be served.

The staff were really helpful and polite.There was a wide range of literature available for free  about tours and tourist attractions. Need some ideas or advice about what to do in Bergen, then visit here.

There was a Western Union Bureau de Change across the road from here, but no exchange rates were on display, we thought the Tourist Centre would be the better option, it was.

reviews.title: An enthusiastic young man promoted the city well
reviews.text: We went to the tourist information in the Bryggen Old Town and we were so impressed by the young man who was so keen to help us when we first arrived in Bergen.  He can give you ideas for what to do in 2, 3 or more days depending on your interests of course.  It was a delightful change from what we encountered at the Old Town Tourist Info in Stockholm...someone who needs to look for a different job!  He does focus on historical sites so if other activities appeal more to you maybe go to the main tourist information site.

reviews.title: Helps to Focus
reviews.text: Remember to pick up a ticket when you walk in the door if you need to talk to someone.  Loads of useful information on information boards with take away leaflets and plenty of staff to talk to behind a counter with a ticket system.  Definitely helped me focus on what I wanted to see.

reviews.title: Bergen Tourist Information
reviews.text: The TI is a modern large facaility with several positions and a helpful staff.  It is located on the Bryggen waterfront.  Their knowledge of tour details and options is impressive.  It is convenient to be able to buy tours there.  Useful restaurant information is available in brochues and from the TI staff.  There is a efficient "take-a-number" system that moves you quicjkly to a TI staff member.

reviews.title: They can help you with anything
reviews.text: Big tourist information, very competent employees. Lots of material on anything you can visit around Bergen. Employees are helpful and friendly, can also book tours for you.

reviews.title: understaffed
reviews.text: I stopped in here twice and both times it was so busy you had to take a tag and wait to talk to someone.after waiting 15 minutes each time I gave up.Have your own planning and reservations done.

reviews.title: Packed!
reviews.text: Be prepared to wait a while to get info or book things. Don't get the Bergen card, not worth it, almost nothing is included. Staff is helpful, but you can probably do most things online in advance.

reviews.title: Very busy tourist information office,
reviews.text: This is a large building - clearly signed  at the end of the fish market coming from the Bryggen.  You may have to queue for quite a while to get answers to queries. Masses of leaflets etc.well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Useful information at Bergen tourist office
reviews.text:
We got very useful information at the tourist information center in Bergen Norway and booked a trip that was wonderful. We started in Bergen by train to Voss then by bus to Ulvick, then by boat to Eidenford, then to the mountains then by boat for a great cruise in the fiord then back to Bergen. Everything was on time and well organized. You see this part of Norway using train, bus and boat in a relaxed way. You get brochure and maps and good commentary on every part being seen, with time for lunch and we were not hurried. The professionals at the tourist office were courteous and well informed and gave useful options of what trip or things to see in this gorgeous part of Norway. It is a good alternative to having your car and and making the journey on your own 
BS Foad, MD

reviews.title: Bergen Tourist Information is still living in the 20th Century! NOT efficient!
reviews.text: There are many very good things about this Tourist Information. The staff are friendly, knowledgeable and speak very good English. The problem is the amount of time it takes to do anything there. The TI is not very large, and when I last visited (August 2018) the staff seemed overwhelmed by the number of tourists. Some people (like us) just wanted to purchase Bergen passes, but we had to wait THIRTY MINUTES to do so. This problem could be solved by a very easy remedy. Why doesn't Bergen TI INSTALL SEVERAL MACHINES IN THAT CORRIDOR NEAR THE BACK THAT IS CURRENTLY SERVING NO USEFUL PURPOSE?  That way people could buy their Bergen cards and other tickets via the machines, while leaving the staff available to answer more complex questions. NOT efficient!!

reviews.title: Good service
reviews.text:
I was so impressed with their efficient service. One must visit this place right after you arrive as they have information on all fjord cruises and even sell the tickets . They exchange money too. 
It is right at the end of the fish market . Try to go early 8.30 am as the queues become long.

reviews.title: Great source of information
reviews.text: Lots of literature to help plan your trip; however, long lines to wait to speak with representatives or simply pick up tickets.

reviews.title: To go place
reviews.text: Situated right in the middle of town...is surrounded by all the hustle and bustle of harbour, fish market etc. The right place to visit to know how to explore Bergen, staff is very friendly and informative and they help you in explaining directions and way to reach any destination with utmost patience...a great plus.

reviews.title: Expert Help
reviews.text: Situated right in the center of town with all the hustle bustle...staff is very friendly and helpful in giving away all the details and direction required to roam around...place to visit if you need any information regarding how to explore Bergen...thumbs up.

reviews.title: Great service, lines too long
reviews.text: You can find information and tickets on nearly everything to do in the area.  I would have rated it higher but the lines are long and seemingly slow.  It does offer free wifi which is quite helpful

reviews.title: Way Too Crowded
reviews.text:
The place was packed with people.  Although the take-a-number system of maintaining order in places is usually quite helpful, it didn't seem quite so useful today.  The room was very noisy and confused, with people speaking in many different languages, all of which blended into the general ruckus.  With little room for anyone to move, it was hard to avoid having someone in your face while someone else was busily talking in your ear... to someone else.

And, of course, the process was extremely slow.  I was not able to complete my wat due to time issues-- I had to be somewhere at a specific time and couldn't wait long enough to get the information I needed.  So, my time was wasted.

Another thought-- I didn't see an elevator (lift) or escalator.  For mobility challenged folks-- like my wife-- there was simply no way to get upstairs to the Information Bureau.  I hope the problem was simply that I missed the accessible accommodation.

reviews.title: Always a great Place to Go To
reviews.text: First of all it's in a great building and you can find the WC there.It's right in the center of the harbor so you are surrounded with fish restaurants galore. And you have the maps and knowledgeable people there to help you find what's under your nose but you didn't look.

reviews.title: Lines can be pretty long
reviews.text: Very nice and helpful staff. They sell tickets to most tours. Only thing to be aware of is that the lines can sometimes be very long for peak hours and it can take 30 mins or perhaps even more to get help. They have numbered tickets for waiting so no need to be standing in lines though.

reviews.title: forced here and UGH
reviews.text: booked a tour online b4 traveling (Norway in a Nutshell). told I had to pick up tickets here.  take a number and WAIT ..... stood around for almost an hour just to p/up tickets already paid for.  If all you need is a map this place may be great. To buy or PICK UP .... terrible.  p.s. I went to the similar location in Oslo ... they were set up the same and just as slow and I later discovered gave me the WRONG TICKETS for what I'd bought ..... I'd questioned b4 I left and they said "trust me" ... I did and got hassled at everyplace I tried to use my City Pass

reviews.title: Very useful place
reviews.text:
Very useful place and well organized. 
We decided to change our long day trip already purchased with a 3 hours along the Fjord and they helped us out. 
Thanks!

reviews.title: Be prepared to wait at least an hour to have a question answered let alone a booking made
reviews.text: I am not sure whether we were there on a particularly busy day or if there were not enough staff.  There were huge queues of people (in spite of a numbering system) waiting and all we wanted was to book a walking tour!  If we had known it would take that long, we could have walked to the museum and done it there ourselves!  We didn't want to risk just turning up in the morning in case it was sold out and we couldn't book ourselves online as we had no way to print our tickets.  So go if you are desperate, otherwise, figure out another way.

reviews.title: Busy but efficient
reviews.text: Take your ticket number and about 6 staff all serve people in turn, very quickly and very efficiently. Lots of booklets and leaflets

reviews.title: Huge place with an even bigger line
reviews.text: The office is on the 1st floor and they have for handicapped and strollers an elevator. In order to ask a question you have to take a number and the line was too long for us so we just picked up a map of Bergen, a tourist information booklet of Bergen and left right after that.

reviews.title: Very helpful staff
reviews.text:
The tourist information centre is located just beside the Fish Market.
When you get in, take a numbered ticket: the average waiting time is 45 minutes due to the crowd of tourists.
Here you can book all the fjord tours and excursions around Bergen and there a huge number of detailed leaflets describing the attractions and activities.
Very useful but long waiting time.

reviews.title: Very convenient.
reviews.text: Next to the fish market.  We picked up our Bergen cards here and the hop on hop off bus stopped here.  Next to a street lined with shops and restaurants.

reviews.title: Long wait just to get a Bergen card
reviews.text: Very helpful staff but you have to take a number to speak to someone be it to ask questions, buy a Bergen card or book a trip. We waited 30 minutes just to buy a Bergen card which took us literally 2 minutes.

reviews.title: Poor service
reviews.text: Having booked a Norway in a Nutshell tour we had to collect our tickets from Tourist Information Office in Bergen. This proved to be a real mission with an hour long wait. There is no separate desk for those only picking up tickets and you have to line up with all the people discussing which tours to book, each one of which takes at least 20.mins. Very frustrating and unnecessary. A hassle that could be so easily solved with a separate desk!

reviews.title: Tourist Information Flub
reviews.text:
In May, I purchased 4 tickets for the Sognefjord tour...7000 kroner (900 usd) online. When we tried to board the boat for the fjord tour we were told the tour had been overbooked by 5% and the T.I had failed to provide our names on the list of passengers, advising us to return to the TI to remedy the situation. The TI then told us the boat crew was new and they didn’t need our names. They refunded our 7000 kroners (now worth $832) and gave us Bergen cards for the day. Don’t really know who or what caused the mix up but there was nothing we could do. Several other people had the same experience that morning. 
The TI was very crowded on the afternoon of Thursday, Aug 9 when we picked up our tickets. Took an hour for our number to be called. When we did get to approach the counter, the staff person was very courteous and professional. We had the tickets but got no tour.

reviews.title: Lots of helpful information
reviews.text: An excellent tourist information centre.  Extremely knowledgeable staff although it was very busy when we visited mid morning and lunchtime. Ticketed queues and the wait can be long.  Money exchange available.  You can also book fjord tours and boat trips from here.

reviews.title: Informative Staff
reviews.text: The Staff are courteous and give you the exact information you want. very knowledgeable and able to cater based on your requirement as tourist

reviews.title: Large information center, very crowded but well organized.
reviews.text: This is a place to visit before you plan your other activities.  It is near the fish market and while it can be very crowded, they are well organized.  You take a number as soon as you arrive and wait your turn.  We waited about 20 minutes in early June.  Lots of information/ brochures and maps, some maps you have to buy.  You can also buy tickets for the funicular and other attractions.  Worth visiting this place first to help you organize your day or days in the area.   Good free internet and clean bathrooms.

name: Fish Market
ranking_subcategory: #29 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #29 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #29 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: City Sightseeing Bergen Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour
Walking tour: Medieval Spirit of Bergen
Bergen: Excursion with a city view from the top

reviews.title: Fish Market
reviews.text: When we visited Bergen in 2006 the Fish Market was both an attraction and the place to buy good quality food from local fishermen. Today it's a tourist trap. The market is smaller, the fishermen are gone, you see no locals buying seafood here any longer, fewer counters, but make shift tent restaurants instead. And the prices are 2-3 times higher than at a supermarket. We ended up buying smoked eel and whale and both turned out to be subpar.

reviews.title: Best seafood
reviews.text: Great market.. So many options, one is in the picture below. My only concern was the whale was available very freely and no one bat's an eye lid.

reviews.title: Not Impressed
reviews.text: We perused the goods and had a light snack. Based on our experience I found the quality of the food wanting and the service unfriendly. Better to get away from Bryggen for meals.

reviews.title: Fresh fish and fancy restaurants
reviews.text: Enjoyed the fish selection, I ate at fish market twice at different restaurants. Good service but expensive. It was worth the visit,  They had indoor and patio seating overlooking the wharf. Nice views as I enjoyed the fish and potatoes, very popular dish in Norway.

reviews.title: Fresh Paella
reviews.text: We had huge dishes of steaming hot paella cooked right in front of us on woks made fresh on the street with shrimp, cod and mussels.  The fish market is right off the wharf.  Highly recommend this dish and we tipped accordingly.

reviews.title: If you are a foodie, a fish lover this is the place!
reviews.text:
Long before I visited Bergen I read about famous Bergen Fish market. Now that I have visited Bergen and I completely understand that why Bergen Fish Market is so famous.
Everything that you want to try out here might be worthy of experiment.

I had my lunch there with local beer and then coming back I had my dinner too with Fish Soup, Sea Urchin and some other dishes which I can't remember but it was awe-inspiring and so tasty.

And yes that fishy smell all across that aroused my hunger instantly.
Have some beer, something eat from here and chill out. That's the ideal happy day!

reviews.title: Bustling and colourful
reviews.text:
There are excellent fish sellers with a fine range of very fresh fish and seafood along with street food and sausage vendors. 

Everyone is very friendly and there is a great atmosphere.

reviews.title: Fish Soup!
reviews.text: We wandered through the fish market and loved all the stalls. We then decided to have lunch.. a bowl of salmon fish soup and white fish soup. The salmon soup was a little spicy but yummy.. with chunks of salmon in it. The  white soup was lovely too, creamy and delicious, again, lots of fish in it. Relatively inexpensive. Do yourself a favour and buy some...

reviews.title: If you like fish dishes this is the place!
reviews.text:
I've been to a number of towns with a fish market, but never one as big as this, or selling such a great variety. I've seen big crabs and big lobsters too, but there were giants on sale.
Even if, as a tourist, you're not buying, it is well worth a visit.
Plenty of opportunities to try the fish, cooked or sushi style.

reviews.title: GREAT COLOUR
reviews.text: Such places are always fun. I liked seeing salmon done as gravlax, pepper salmon and with dill. There were other fishes, an ugly type staring back at you. Some crabs were of an impressive side. There were some lobsters too. Locals were buying fish while tourists were taking pictures. There were many areas where you could have a [rather pricey at times] meal.

reviews.title: Lousy fish at inflated prices
reviews.text: I had read that the Bergen fish market was the place for a good fish meal so off we went. There are lots of tents selling raw fish and meals, plus plenty of proper restaurants around the periphery. We went to one of the tents, hoping for better value. We ordered a monkfish meal, know that this is an exceptionally tasty fish. What we got was absolutely dreadful, accompanied by a bit of salad and a few potatoes. And it was no bargain either. We later found that prices in the proper restaurants were pretty much the same and I’m willing to bet that they would not dare serve the rubbish that we had.

reviews.title: Holiday to norway on a cruise
reviews.text: Fish Market was a great experience, lots of unusual foods to be found, places to sit and eat a fresh salmon sandwich well worth a visit if going to bergen, stunning place

reviews.title: Ok
reviews.text: Nice to stroll through, but not anything exceptional. We walked thru a couple of times. Nice, fresh seafood selection. Did not eat, just looked.

reviews.title: Must see!
reviews.text:
Dear readers,

this is not only a fish market, but a beautiful and interesting place to eat and to shop. I promise you will love it, like we did!

reviews.title: Land of sea food
reviews.text:
A large variety of all king of sea food, all fresh and tasty. Should be careful though some items are pricy 

Great place...

reviews.title: Fish market
reviews.text: Tourist hot spot. Do what you will here, but there are many vendors close by that cost less. Not a must see in my opinion.

reviews.title: Worth a Walk through
reviews.text: Worth a walk through to see the diverse types of seafood in Norway. Many of the booths have similar products but it's still an adventure. Some of the vendors provide meals and/or samples of smoked meats.

reviews.title: Repetitive
reviews.text: Nice fish market, but very repetitive - every vendor has pretty much the same offerings.  Lots of fish and shellfish along with Norwegian sausages, soups, and more.  An hour here is plenty, not counting the time you might need to dine here.

reviews.title: Great but touristy and expensive
reviews.text: Nice place but clearly organized for tourists and rather expensive for market food. Nice views and central.

reviews.title: Overpriced
reviews.text: Short stretch of booths that sell very expensive food (known for their fresh catches). Seems like a tourist trap to me.

reviews.title: Worth seeing!
reviews.text:
The fish market is small but has a full selection of all of Norway’s seafood. Right next to the great Tourist Information and right on the Harbour. There’s lots of places nearby to eat seafood. Compare prices and make up your own mind. 

A friend was very upset that she missed out as her flight was delayed but there so many better things to see in Norway- fjords, mountains ice snow and waterfalls.

reviews.title: Lots to choose from in fish
reviews.text: The Fish Market in Bergen is the best I’ve seen.  looking at what they have is interesting in itself. They of course sell and prepare food which can be eaten in their  tents at the back. We had Fish n Chips which was the best I’ve Had outside of UK. Reasonable price, but a lot of the fish is very expensive! Great visit.

reviews.title: Not just fish
reviews.text:
Walked through the outdoor area (red tents) of the fish market. We understand there is also an indoor market in the building with the info center. 

Pretty standard farmers market, but did have much more than seafood items. Fruit looked fresh and they were serving reindeer hotdogs, moose burgers, and apparently whale meat.

reviews.title: The fish marked has lost its charm without the fishermen there
reviews.text: It used to be the fishermen themselves who had stalls with their catch of the night. Now half of the sales people are not native Norwegian and some did not even speak the Norwegian language.  I am the first to advocate that people living in this country shall work, regardless of their origin or skin color, so there is nothing wrong about them working here, either.  But it is not the same genuine fisherman’s marked as it was when I visited here 30 years ago. The stalls are beautifully laid out with fantastic looking fish, shellfish, and sea shells, and many of the stalls also serve lunch platters. For a good seafood lunch this must be the place to go.

reviews.title: Just to look
reviews.text: Came past here and a great place for either buying fish or eating at various outlets to eat we went past some great dishes being cooked like prawn paella also a mussel dish. The setting is great as it’s by the harbour.

reviews.title: Wonderful Ambience and Fresh Seafood
reviews.text: This is a market in which you stroll, gaze, take in the various seafood choices and then feast on terrific fresh food.  Stroll through the entire market prior to deciding where or what to eat.  It is worth the time and thought.

reviews.title: Underwhelming
reviews.text:
Pretty small area if u have travelled before, still a good source of outdoor food,so worth a stop, especially if hungry.

Go through on your way to everywhere

reviews.title: DON'T BUY THE SAUSAGE TO TAKE TO US.
reviews.text: The sausage seller assured me it was legal to take sausage back to the US. Great way to sell sausage, but it's NOT legal. Sister got a $300 civil penalty, and we both lost $45 of sausage...😢

reviews.title: The Fishmarket, A Must See in Bergen Norway
reviews.text: All Fresh and displayed for your pleasure.  You can pick your meal and they will cook it right there for you or you can have you fresh fish wrapped up to take home.  We were there on a rainy day so it was not overly crowded, but on a sunny day it has to be wall to wall people. A wide central walkway can handle a good sized crowd and there are plenty of tables and chairs.  Really good fun and eye popping piscatorial photo ops.

reviews.title: Fish
reviews.text: Ok for a fish market. Can also eat here as several stalls serving fish dishes. Wouldn’t put myself out to visit

reviews.title: A great experience
reviews.text: An easy walk with interesting sights and information and fabulous food! Spoil yourself! Eat well, try something different!

reviews.title: What a riot!
reviews.text: When the cruise ships are in avoid it! When they had sailed it was so much easier to see menus, get a table and sample some fresh seafood. Pretty expensive, but it is Norway!

reviews.title: Just walking by is fun.
reviews.text: One of these most interesting and unique markets you will ever see, Numerous outdoor stands and restaurants selling and in some cases cooking fresh seafood, Not to be missed

reviews.title: Great tasty berries here
reviews.text: 2 days in a roll that we brought strawberry, blackberry, and raspberry at fish market in Bergen, they are so tasty and awesome sweet, many kind packages with different prices, definitely buy the one in open paper tray not in the plastic box, they taste better .

reviews.title: Symphatic fish market
reviews.text: At the fish market you can find a lot of different food of the sea. There is as well the opportunity to have lunch or dinner in the restaurant of the differtent booths.

reviews.title: Pretty fake
reviews.text:
Sorry but this is nothing but a tourist trap. 119NOK for five average fried scampis, and let’s be honest, you could just make that yourself at home, why even buy it at the fish market? I also asked a salesperson about rakfisk and they said it was Swedish, and I kind of just laughed it off because they’ve clearly only heard about surströmming, nice try though. 
I could not hear any Norwegian at all in this supposedly old and authentic fish market, weird. Definitely a fake Norwegian market. 
Nothing wrong if you want to go to touristy areas and enjoy a relaxing trip rather than exploring the authentic side of the country, but if you want to experience the real Norway, at least go and stay in cabins and travel between small towns in inland areas located in Southern Norway. Having done that myself I could immediately feel the difference.

reviews.title: Use all your senses
reviews.text:
Looking and hearing, it is very interesting. Everywhere they give you information and demonstrations and you can taste the product.
For llunch or/and dinner a very good place for eating fresh fish and shellfish

reviews.title: taste of norway
reviews.text: Lots of stalls with typical fare reindeer whale and moose meat caviar and cloudberry jams. Quite pricey but able to have a taster and see if you like the food on offer. Friendly traders. Huge crabs and many varieties of fish available.

reviews.title: Fresh Fish, Caviar Selections
reviews.text: This market is right in the middle of town and a fun place to view the market offerings, the locals, and the fish. Caviar...all types of caviar are also available. Big fish, little fish, red fish, white fish, fish I've never heard of. Much fun!

reviews.title: Fresh Fish
reviews.text: Various fish and seafood. Delicious food. Beautiful view around the market. Helpfull staff. I tried cod fish grill, cause this food was big portion so i shared with my friends.

reviews.title: Delicious fresh berries
reviews.text:
The fish was ok but the strawberries are some of the best we’ve ever eaten. Excellent raspberries too. The other berries looked good but we didn’t buy them. 
We went back multiple days to buy the berries from the stall and the end furthest from Bryggen. Buy the berries!

reviews.title: Great spot to wander
reviews.text:
Plenty of fresh seafood on offer here. Most of the places will also cook up anything they have on offer and you can eat it at tables behind their stall. 

Great views and fresh seafood to sample or eat. 

30 minutes is adequate unless you are eating.

reviews.title: A rip off
reviews.text: We paid more than $50 for two shrimp plates that were stale and chewy. This was a terrible experience. I recommend to walk through the fish market but do not buy anything at least in the outdoor section.

reviews.title: Culinary Adventure for Fresh Fish
reviews.text:
What a delightful and tasty learning experience! Wild sea and river salmon and other local Fish and seafood as well as dry salamis made of whale, reindeer or moose. 
Pick out the fish or seafood and have it cooked on the spot. Add salad, fish soup, bread and butter and sit in the area behind the show cases.
After the meal, add a cup of fresh berries and wander through the picturesque streets.

reviews.title: nice
reviews.text: Nice place, the smell of fresh fish and a lot of happy faces are goood signals. A bit too much for turists, though.

reviews.title: One of the coolest fish markets around!
reviews.text: This reminded me a bit of the Pike Street Market in Seattle, but of course it has its Norwegian character and location.  Lots of different types of fresh fish, outdoor restaurants, and other sites in proximity to the beautiful, historical buildings of the harbor.  It is definitely a go-to site here in Bergen.  It is pricey, but very enjoyable!  I had the Bergen soup at one place and it is essentially a Boston clam chowder---very good!

reviews.title: Large selection right on pier
reviews.text: Extensive variety of fish from whale to shrimp. Fish sandwiches or dinners prepared onsite.  Tried the trout in a sandwich that was very tasty.

reviews.title: Stay away and use your money elsewhere
reviews.text: This is not a local fish market any more, and hasn't been for decades. I'm sorry to say that it has degenerated into a tourist trap. Locals never shop here anymore and that should tell you to stay away. Too expensive and bad quality.

reviews.title: An expensive bite to eat?
reviews.text:
If you like fresh fish, this is the place to grab a bite to eat, however, we found the prices quite steep for a simple fish on a stick...210 Kroners, pic attached.  Being from Canada this worked out to about a whopping $33.50.  The fish market is located around the waterfront.  There are many beautiful photo spots around the area.  Many attractions, restaurants etc in close proximity with lots going on, even protests, on the day we were there; however, a lovely place to spend the day.  The Floibanen, Funicular Railway, is located ahead of the fish market, a few minutes walk.  This railway takes you up to Floyen mountain where you can enjoy the spectacular views of the port/city.  Oh, there are numerous goats residing up there.   

To get to the market place from the cruise ship port, exist the port, take a right towards the City Centre. You will see all the sightseeing buses along here and  a sign post saying:  "Sentrum," which in Norwegian means downtown.  Pass the buses and when you get to a fork in the road, stay to the right.  If you go to the left you will be heading towards Bergenhus Fortress area.  You will be walking along the coast Once at the corner, on your right will be the fish market and if you go left you will be headed towards the Funicular. To get there, walk up the street between the two buildings on the corner. The one on the right says: "Ann Madam." This is indeed a very beautiful area.

reviews.title: Nice visit
reviews.text: Located near the tourist spot and pier. Many stalls serve seafood and sell local made food products like sausages, caviar, fish and others. Good to have a walk.

reviews.title: Feast on the harvest of the Norwegian Sea
reviews.text: The Bergen Fish Market is in the heart of the waterfront area near wonderful fountains, parks, the Grieg Academy, the cable car, many shops, and a very picturesque harbor with a backdrop of eye-catching architecture and a mosaic of colorful storefronts. The market offers a great variety of vendors offering fresh seafood to take home or they prepare it for you, where you can enjoy it under cover at community or individual sit-down tables. It rains a lot. We walked the stalls several times before selecting our meal and watching it be prepared. Bring a camera, as this is a very photographic area. You can spend time enjoying walking the waterfront or going a short distance for wonderful parks and fountains. There are interesting shops and restaurants everywhere and you can enjoy a taste of Norway.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: If you really like fish this is the place for you. Some of the very unusual fish was a bit strange but all very fresh. For British visitors the prices are very high. Approx £27 for fish and chips.... alfresco. Good atmosphere tho.

reviews.title: A rare sight
reviews.text: A walk through the Fish Market, both the covered area and the open air stalls is a must.  All sorts of fresh fish and local delicacies, such as reindeer sausage on sale.

reviews.title: Fish on display.
reviews.text: Possibly not quite as big as before, but not to be missed. A splendid display of sea food. Very fresh !

reviews.title: Go for seafood
reviews.text: You can choose your fish or crab  and they prepare for you. Beers and soft drinks are avialable but no wines. Everything is very fresh and tasty. If you can enjoy your oysters without a glass of champagne this is the place to go. Recommended.

reviews.title: Dr Shashi panikar
reviews.text: Visited the Bergen Fish market.It is a very different experience for travelers where many stalls offering freshly cooked dishes which are reasonably priced. I really enjoyed my visit to the Fish market.

reviews.title: Fun to just look at the various fish.
reviews.text: The market is interesting.  There are varieties of fish, and other seafood.  It is enjoyable just to view the fish even if you are not buying.

reviews.title: Bergen
reviews.text: Visit to the fish market is a new experience.With many stalls offering different freshly prepared dishes which are reasonable compared to eating in resturant

reviews.title: What a choice
reviews.text:
Such a selection to see as well as buy.
The area was one of the hubbub areas of the town. Tourists seem to flock to see this part of town and try out a little something new

reviews.title: Feast for fish fanatics!
reviews.text: It could also be a learning on the various varieties of fish there. Fresh. Alive. Colourful. Variety. Enjoy to your eye full or tummy full! One fishy meal for sure!!

reviews.title: you can’t miss it
reviews.text: As it’s right on the water front under 2 rows of red marques.  As you’d expect it’s not cheap as it’s all seafood , but there is seriously so much variety. You can eat in at some place s or takeaway.

reviews.title: scandinavia
reviews.text: very very touristy.  We were told that most of the vendors are not Norwegian - they have asian vendors because of the large numbers of chinese tourists.  pricey but so is everything in norway.

reviews.title: Fun Market
reviews.text: It was fun to visit this market right on the harbor. There was a terrific selection of vendors from seafood and local foods to fresh produce. Vendors were happy to provide samples or talk about their products.

reviews.title: Fish!
reviews.text: Fish market was small (compared to others) and I thought pricey.  There are several restaurants in the area also.

reviews.title: Not very Large but Lots of Fun
reviews.text: As fish markets go, Bergen's is of moderate size. But the fun part is picking your meal and having them cook it. This can be done rain or shine. We had lunch there twice and it was lots of fun. We also were interested to hear the fish sellers speaking a myriad of languages.

reviews.title: Norway and Fish
reviews.text:
Seems like every town in Norway has a fish market because they catch it fresh, sell it fast and eat lots of fish. This one is typical-a bar, several stands with lots of really fresh fish, prepared fish and fish ready to be quickly cooked along with several restaurants at the back facing the water. Everything looks great and this particular fish market has several different types of caviar along with dried fish and even whale.
Look around, talk to the folks behind the counter, have lunch or reserve a table for dinner and enjoy some of the freshest fish you will ever taste.

reviews.title: Walking tour of a fresh sea food restaurant
reviews.text: This market sells a variety of seafood. It will serve you then and there. However, this does not mean that the stuff is cheap.

reviews.title: A small open market near the waterfront.
reviews.text: If you like shellfish this market is a must because there were lots of stalls offering free tasting before you buy. It was very busy with a huge selection of fish available.

reviews.title: Gorgeous fish
reviews.text: Lots of variety.  Especially fun to see when it is sunny out.  VERY crowded when there are a lot of cruise ships in port.  Grab something for lunch or to take home.

reviews.title: Lots of fresh seafood displayed
reviews.text: We walked through this market. There are several vendors selling multiple types of fish, crab, etc. You can pick out something, take a seat at a table, and they will cook it for you.  There is nothing like eating fresh seafood.

reviews.title: Interesting place
reviews.text: Quite a touristy place with fresh seafood and loads of caviar displayed. Tented market. Quite a few counters selling marinated fish. A few restaurants too. Very crowded seating and live cooking. Food is average at most places but there are some well known ones which are good like Fish Me and Fjellskal.

reviews.title: Adds flavor and importance to the area.
reviews.text: The Fish Market makes this area of Bergen come alive. Can’t imagine it not being here. Products are fresh, help will be glad to answer all your questions, and lots of choices for a variety of seafoods. Prices are high so shop around and find your best deal. The workers are always willing to answer any of your questions. Have fun, this is an ocean fishing port.

reviews.title: Fascinating!
reviews.text: I loved visiting the Fish Market in Bergen! Fun to look at all the exotic fish on display. We picked shrimp & calimari for lunch with fries, & they made it right there while we watched. Then you find a table & enjoy! Not an experience I ever had coming from Minnesota!

reviews.title: Great place to eat
reviews.text: Great cosmopolitan area with all types of food, seafood of course, but tasty fresh fruit as well.  Good place for lunch and dry if it's raining, well Bergen is the 10th wettest city in the world!

reviews.title: A must in Bergen
reviews.text: One can hardly miss this point of interest as it is in the center of Bergen along the piers and wharves of the coast. A bustle of activity where the latest catches are for sale for locals and tourists alike. Very lively area operated by  most friendly people

reviews.title: Great market
reviews.text: Excellent local fish market open most days, which does fish, food, and a few souvenirs. Some of the seafood is vacuum packed so you can take way on cruise, etc. Also does food to takeaway or eat in via the many seats available.

reviews.title: Good food BYOB
reviews.text: There are a few places cooking at the fish market. The one we chose had plenty of choice and we could put tables together to seat all 10 of us. Food was great - soups, kebabs, smoked, grilled and steamed seafood served with salads, potatoes and bread. The place did not have a liquor license so we drank low alcohol beer! The waitress said it is OK to bring your own beer or wine though.

reviews.title: Small market
reviews.text:
Just on the beautiful water front is the fish market. Not only live fish but platters are on display.
You can select and order for fresh preparation.
Other shops are also there.

reviews.title: Nice place to have dinner
reviews.text:
Very nice ambience and food. Price is Norwegian standard. Friendly people and a good way to spend our afternoon. 
They serve whale meat if you're curious

reviews.title: Huge array of fish
reviews.text:
It’s worth a look. The stalls had a huge array of seafood of all kinds and even if you weren’t buying it was very interesting to walk around and see the enormous variety and some unusual examples too.
A Norwegian guide elsewhere later told us that the market is for the tourists and that ordinary Norwegians do not buy their fish from here. (eg. A prawn salad on a medium sized plate was £26)

reviews.title: great market!
reviews.text:
We loved the Fish Market, and stopped by every day we were in Bergen. Unlike most people, who use it as a restaurant (which is probably pretty fun too), we bought fish and seafood to bring home and cook (it's nice to stay in a place with a kitchen!). 

Yum! with minimal cooking materials, I cooked what was probably the best salmon we ever had! excellent smoked mackerel as well! At one of the other stalls, we picked up some cloudberry jam and hard whale sausage - also delicious.

and so convenient! The place gets pretty crowded with tourists (even June 1st!) but it's still a great place to shop.

reviews.title: Great seafood by the Fish Market
reviews.text:
We walked through the outdoor stalls in Fish Market by the harbor. We walked into one of the larger “tents” on our left side (if we walked away from the tourist info center). Sorry, I didn’t notice the name of the tent restaurant, but the staff were wearing blue shirts. 

Of course, we had to have the Norwegian seafood! My husband went safe with the salmon, and I, wanting to try something special that I can’t try anywhere else, went for the whale steak (don’t judge, it’s legal in Norway!).

Both meals were cooked wonderfully. Whale meat, as it turns out, have the looks, texture and taste more like beef than any fish meat I’ve ever seen. It can be quite tough, and tender if cooked “medium well” (I think. It’s pink in the middle!).

Anyway, it’s quite an experience, and Bergen rains a lot, so if you don’t want to get wet, choose the middle section of the tent.

reviews.title: Hectic and Wet
reviews.text: The waterfront was extremely crowded and hectic but it was a Saturday. Given there was a march on as well the place was packed out. If you don’t mind the chaos and crowds then that’s fine but it detracted from the experience. The heavy rain didn’t help. Probably worthwhile under different circumstances.

reviews.title: A great Norwegian food experience!
reviews.text: We loved the fish market. Everyone in our group of 11 with pre-teens, teens and parents easily found something delicious to eat and the service was exceptionally warm and friendly.  The displays of local sea food are so interesting and fun to look at as well!

reviews.title: Great food!
reviews.text: Stop by and eat at one of these restaurants in Bergen's Fish Market.  We ate at Fjellskal and it was really good, especially the Salmon and Cod.  Delish!  The views are awesome too!

reviews.title: Awesome
reviews.text: Definitely worth a visit to this upmarket fish market. The fish/ seafood is so fresh. We got a tasting of whale meat. The staff are all very friendly. The produce is magnificent with a huge selection of seafood as well as cheese and reindeer and other meats. There are some beautiful restaurants as well but you need to book to eat in the restaurants. Definitely worth a visit

reviews.title: Bergen fish market
reviews.text: It was interesting to visit Bergen fish market. Staff very friendly and seafood looked fresh. Didn't eat there as there were better places nearby. We were told that the locals don't eat there. I

reviews.title: Fish Lovers Paradise
reviews.text:
If you like fish and seafood you will love this place.  When we were there-there was a market opposite.  The Fish Market is enclosed with restaurant table seating outside.  A very impressive market, very large market with filleted fish and live seafood.  You can also buy caviar.  Every stall was very well presented and if you have worked with fish it was extremely fresh.

The market opposite was selling fish and seafood, some stalls had local delicacies of smoked salmon, gravadlax, reindeer, boar and beef preserved meat.  Great place when the sun is shining, a glass of wine and fresh fish.  What more could you need?

reviews.title: Beautifully presented fish market
reviews.text: No smell of fish as everything is so fresh. We had a wander and decided to stop at the bar for a beer. Lovely sat there taking it all in. Obviously many many tourists but as we sat enjoying a beer we got talking to a local man on his lunch break from work just popped in to buy fish for his dinner that evening to welcome home his son who had been working away. So proud of the fish and seafood of Bergen. The best in Norway he said. Who am I to disagree.  Ate in one of the restaurants here later in the week so can vouch for just how good the fish is and have reviewed separately.

reviews.title: BS
reviews.text: The “fish market” is nothing but a tourist trap. We were told there is no longer any Commercial fishingreal commercial fishing in Bergen. It’s just a place for the thousands of people getting off cruise ships to think they’re doing something authentic in Norway. There are no real fjords here and you have to travel hours to see them. The place is ridiculously expensive, $15 for a beer. I suspect much of the fish is not really fresh. Their fish and chips, a small piece of fish and some soggy fries on a paper plate cost over $30. If you want some shrimp and a 2 inch section of crab leg it’s over $50. Stay away is all I can say. Also, the place is absolutely filthy. There is garbage all over the streets and sidewalks and the tourists from some countries which will remain unnamed this point are horribly rude pushing their way in front of others, screaming and yelling at waitstaff and restaurants…

reviews.title: Fish
reviews.text: A good place to visit. Lots of interesting food and seafood-delicatesses. Some rare and some funny fresh fish. Lots of plases to eat and taste some local fish. A «must» when you visit Bergen.

reviews.title: Fresh and Friendly
reviews.text: Fresh seafood, variety cook, reasonable price (for Norway cost of living). Open in summer even on Sunday and you can take a walk to old town. Prepare your hand sanitizer for your own hygenic is recommended after finish your meal. Worth your visit.

reviews.title: Unique but pricey
reviews.text: This is unique fish market geared toward the tourist. Good food but a bit pricey. Can get crowed when the cruise ships come in.

reviews.title: Fresh and Beautiful
reviews.text: I love these markets, especially the fresh fish, shellfish, and raw bars. They had some species I never saw before

reviews.title: Quick walk through is all you need
reviews.text: It was nice to walk through but not much else. We did eat at one of the expensive restaurants and was disappointed by the food. I expected a better selection on the menu.

reviews.title: Lots of different types of fresh seafood, gifts and food to eat.  Expensive for the most part but staff friendly and hel
reviews.text: Nice fish market down on the waterfront in Bergen, Norway.  There are many different kinds of seafood products and many of the places are cooking the seafood right there on the dock.  There a couple of formal sit down restaurants but the prices on everything seemed quite high compared to US prices for similar food.  Staff at the various booths were helpful in answering questions and providing guidance.

reviews.title: Best salmon I have ever had!
reviews.text: This was a wonderful perfect lunch. The seafood was incredible and I haven’t stopped craving the salmon.

reviews.title: Road trip Norway
reviews.text: Fun to stroll thru, we did east a a small place there can't remember the name but go its entertainment

reviews.title: Fresh, Fun & Impressive!
reviews.text: Walked the market in the morning on our only day in Bergen. It was busy, lots of people, lots of vendors and so much fresh catch to choose from. The giant crabs were incredible! There was also condiments (vegetables, spices, spreads, etc) available to accent your purchase for those looking to take home dinner or just nibble while you shop the market. Certainly worth the visit.

reviews.title: Worth a walk
reviews.text: It’s a “go to”place just ‘cause your in Bergen, but be prepared for high prices, the harbour is worth a walk around

reviews.title: Busy!
reviews.text: The fish market is located at the base of the harbour where you can buy or sit and eat all types of fish. The hustle and bustle of this place makes it worth a visit though obviously a bit smelly

reviews.title: If you ❤️ fish...
reviews.text: then at least walk by here! Yes, it is pricey and geared toward tourists. I still had to indulge in some piping-hot, freshly made paella. The nice man who worked there remembered me (I had stopped by late the day before, when they had already finished that day's paella) and I was very happy to return the next day. It was quite expensive but every bite was delicious. There were many venues there and if you like fish, or even not, there's something for nearly everyone. My opinion is that if you can afford it, it doesn't hurt to splurge once in a while for some extremely tasty food, so that is what I did. It's fun to walk around the market and the restaurants right nearby and see the variety and smell all the tasty smells.

reviews.title: Well worth a visit to the Fish Market
reviews.text: An interesting place where you can view all the fresh fish and sit and eat them after being cooked especially for you. Have a look around and compare prices if you dare - it is all expensive (this is Norway)

reviews.title: Nice if you're hungry!
reviews.text: Lots of food trucks and vendors available here. IF you're hungry, you're not going to be disappointed by the quality, selection, and people. Definitely give it a visit if you're in the area!!!

reviews.title: Expensive but worth it
reviews.text: Amazing fish dishes. Expensive but gorgeous food. Well worth it. Gets a bit cold with the wind coming off the water so use the blankets provided :)

reviews.title: A bit pricey
reviews.text: Well if you drift off the main downtown market area you will find much cheaper options for purchasing fish

reviews.title: An experience for all fish lovers
reviews.text: Here you will find all sorts of fish, mussels, lobsters and crabs, and even whale meat is offered here. If you have no problem with the whaling, you should try it. It really tastes great.

reviews.title: Try the marinated salmon :)
reviews.text:
You can take your fresh fish in there.
Also, there are places to eat different types of salmon and other delicious seafood

reviews.title: Didn’t seem fresh
reviews.text: Maybe just me but after walking for four days in Bergen I didn’t see any fresh fish being delivered and the food just didn’t look great.

reviews.title: Shocking prices!! Way too expensive.
reviews.text: Looks very nice, but the prices are far too expensive that normal people can buy anything here. 1 kg shrimps cost nearly 1000,- nok pr kg. Stay away. They must understand that prices are too high. If you are a millionaire or your company pay for you and you want to wast your money, then you can buy some shrimps here. It is not worth the money. You can find cheaper food anywhere else.

reviews.title: NOT!!
reviews.text: Does not worth spend any money there!! Very touristic place. Only those who do not know will go there. Very expensive for what they offer

reviews.title: Big variety
reviews.text: So much fresh fish options.   Everyone really friendly and helpful.   Take home or have them cook there.  Warm areas to eat.  A bit windy and cold being right by the water

reviews.title: Excellent!!!! The best!
reviews.text: Excellent food and good price. The king crab in garlic butter was fantastic! A dream eating there! And the staff is very nice too!

reviews.title: For tourists
reviews.text: This place is more for tourists and nothing else but that been said you still can find good food at reasonable price at fish market. They have smoked whale meat which you can only order in Japan or Norway. I suggest to try at least one dish at fish market and you won't be disappointed.

reviews.title: Very Up-market
reviews.text: We were there in April - perhaps it's different in other months. It's not really like a fish market - it's a few very high-end stalls associated with some up-market restaurants. Lovely stuff but you're looking at the gold-standard!

reviews.title: Fishy fish
reviews.text: If you are a fish lover then this is the place to be in. Great place to buy your favourites as well as buy your fish get it cooked and get it served too. It's a paradise for fish lovers

reviews.title: Excellent fresh sea food
reviews.text: Fish market itself is an amazing sight and you have several restaurants inside which offer a variety of sea food items. Added to this there are fresh fruits and berries available, we have eaten the most tasty strawberry from here.

reviews.title: So Much Beautiful Fish
reviews.text: This is a fun place to browse, and then eat in one of the restaurants. I'm not saying that the prices for the smoked salmon are great, but if you only have so much time to pick up that tourist gift for home, this would be the place.

reviews.title: Wide variety of sea food
reviews.text: We visited the market as a tour group. Has indoor restaurants overlooking the wharf. Had a tasting plates at one of the restaurant, which included whale meat which I was not keen on. Later came back for lunch and had sushi which was freshly made.

reviews.title: The bar needs attention
reviews.text:
The fish market itself is an amazing sight, and I imagine one can get excellent fresh seafood for their dinner. We had a thirty minute wait for dinner, so were seated at the bar so we could order a drink for the wait. We ordered a quite expensive Hendrix martini and a Manhattan. They were the worst cocktails we’ve had in recent memory. We’re not even sure they used the right liquor.  So, we paid our bill and politely left to find another place for drinks and dinner.  
Buyer beware. Perhaps they don’t expect tourists to return, so they can serve whatever they want.  We have found that off the ‘beaten tourist path’ you’ll find better quality service, food and drink.

reviews.title: Stay away from overpriced seafood
reviews.text: The prices in Bergen fish market is double or triple from what you find in the nearest grocery store, with better quality, so do yourself a favour by NOT shopping any seafood there

reviews.title: Sea food at its best !!
reviews.text: Bergen Fish Market something that when in Bergen you cannot miss even if your not a sea food enthusiastic. To see the variaty and getting the possibility to try and a a bit of everything is something of an experience that you will never forget! People are very friendly and available to help to choose.

reviews.title: If you like fish .....
reviews.text: Even if you have no intention of buying anything, or eating in the restaurant, it's worthwhile having a walk through the fish / shellfish counters just to see what's on sale. We did this and a member of staff kindly and enthusiastically described the various species on show. No fishy smells, a good indicator that everything is fresh.

reviews.title: Aimed at the tourists
reviews.text: This under covered fish market is worth a visit just to see the variety of fish,crabs and shell fish available all of which looked fresh.You can buy to take away or have a meal on site though i didn't it looked a bit pricey. This market appears to be a bit of a tourist trap especially those from cruise ships.

reviews.title: Super expensive. Once is enough.
reviews.text: Is just a seafood restaurant. Seafood are expensive which you can get better ones in other countries and less costly. Anyway once is enough.

reviews.title: Great market
reviews.text: First fish market I have been to that did not smell like fish.  Everything is so fresh and you can buy seafood to take away or eat fabulous meals right there.  They have a variety of other food as well.  Fresh berries were incredible.  Everyone is so friendly and helpful.  Great experience.

reviews.title: Pretty fish market but don’t eat there.
reviews.text: Nice market with lots of fresh fish on display but would avoid eating there again. Overpriced and can get better meals else where.

reviews.title: Amazing food
reviews.text: We had the day in Bergen and came across this market. The seafood is fantastic. Such a variety of fish, crabs and shellfish. It is worth a wander around just to see what’s on sale.

reviews.title: Fascinating place to visit
reviews.text: This is no ordinary fish market. It is filled with exotic fish treats gathered from the coasts or Norway. There are so many varieties of sea food to sea and sample like salmon, king crab, langoustines, air dried cod and many others. The whole area is surrounded by restaurants and there are many stalls offering to both sample and sell their seafood. The whole place has a carnival like atmosphere. There is often street entertainers either in or close by that adds to the carnival feeling.

reviews.title: Entertaining and knowledgeable  staff
reviews.text: We had a tour through the fish market today and the young staff were so knowledgeable and quite funny as they helped the guide out. We were impressed with the enjoyment they showed in their work.

reviews.title: Fresh fish all day - buying , eating or take away.
reviews.text: It's not just a fishmonger's shop. You have different restaurants offering fish and seafood delicacies prepared in several ways.

reviews.title: Expensive tourist place
reviews.text: This is not exactly a fish market.  Rather, it is a seafood place with several restaurants selling expensive seafood to tourists.  The Tourist Information is just above.

reviews.title: Not Really a Fish Market
reviews.text:
As a fish market, this is a grand collection of expensive seafood restaurants. Fish dinner of monkfish, halibut and a shared entree of Rakfish were all impressive but for my money, the halibut was tops. Nearly $AUD200 for dinner for two. Bottle of Australian Chablis selling for $AUD108.
Staff in the market area were very helpful in identifying, for first-time visitors to Bergen, the variety of fish for sale.
Good surroundings for a first meal in Bergen.

reviews.title: Place to visit, but does not represent Norway in a good way
reviews.text: A place to visit but does not represent Norway. Seems overpriced, try out local restaurants nearby, who will serve you more typical Norwegian food. Be sure to visit Ulrikken and Fløyen :)

reviews.title: Fishy Visit
reviews.text: Had a great fish tasting menu here with salmon three ways,prawns, crayfish and smoked whale meat, assured supply, with a lovely dry white wine. Good value, well presented.

reviews.title: Crowded
reviews.text: A crowded place where all the tourists visits, and where you can find reasonable priced food to eat on the go, or sit down.

reviews.title: EVERYTHING IS EXPENSIVE
reviews.text: I felt like it's a tourist trap. I went during the winter in Mar and only the indoor market was open. Go somewhere else to eat or cook your meals.

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text: I was a bit wary of an indoor fish market but thought it ideal as we visited Bergen during very cold weather so it was lovely to be able to go inside and inspect the fish at leisure. What an amazing variety and all so fresh and well displayed. We bought fish to take back to our apartment to cook on two occasions and quite delightful. Staff were helpful and chatty.

reviews.title: Tourist trap
reviews.text: Yeah nice to see some of the unusual fish including whale but given where I live this is 2nd rate to a real live fish co-op.... one for the tourists!

reviews.title: Expensive but must visit
reviews.text: You can find most of these in the supermarkets at quite a discount. But this is worth a visit to see what's exotic. Note them and buy them from the Sens market (?)  a block away. Sushi is good and so are the produce in case you want to indulge.

reviews.title: An excellent fush
reviews.text: It is not necessarily cheap but you can certainly find something soothing your budget. Go in the eveving where you have a great view on Bryggen.

reviews.title: Expensive and not the best place to buy in Bergen
reviews.text: Some of the products that are on sale here are much cheaper in supermarkets for the same thing. Also, if you are looking for fish and chips, look elsewhere. There is one restaurant that does great crispy fish like you would find in Ireland or England but all the chips are here are frozen. The prices are high to catch tourists but there are better places to eat and buy in the town.

reviews.title: Interestibg
reviews.text: We had a look around this market . There is a Hugh range of seafood available some which we had never seen before and also a few restaurants,  we found it fairly expensive compare to home but it is well worth a look .

reviews.title: Fish!
reviews.text: What more can I say about the fish market than you can view and buy fish. There are a few restaurants within the market that you can eat the fish that is on display at.

reviews.title: Everything is tasty
reviews.text: We chose to have dinner there twice and we would go again if we stayed longer. Try the whale steak and the Bergen soup.

reviews.title: Interesting but a bit expensive
reviews.text: There was a good range of seafood but it is very obviously marketed towards the tourists. The food was relatively expensive for what was offered. Worth a look as you walk around the harbour foreshore but maybe not a special trip.

reviews.title: Lunch
reviews.text:
Had the king crab, Norwegian lobster, prawns and mussels.  
Excellent service.  
A bit pricey.
Taste could be improved with a tastier chilly sauce.

reviews.title: Never saw like this
reviews.text: It’s right there at heart of the city. You will get to see so much variety of fishes available there. I never saw such a variety of fishes in the fish market anywhere. You must visit here when u r in Bergen.

reviews.title: A “Must Visit” in Bergen!
reviews.text:
This is a “Must Visit” when visiting Bergen!
We had dinner here on our first evening in Bergen and we were spoiled for choice with a huge selection of fish dishes. 
From “fish & chips” to “platters” , the world is your oyster. ( no pun intended)
Can definitely recommend this.

reviews.title: Far from a real fish market
reviews.text: Very few real fish stores. Restaurants and souvenir shops. Money destroyed traditions and expectations. Ground floor of the tourism office building. More interesting things upstairs vs downstairs. Dissapointed.

reviews.title: Not what it used to be
reviews.text:
We first visited the fish market in 1998, it was great! Fresh local fish and lots of interesting sights and smells.  However, over the year it has changed into a tourist trap, mostly tee shirts and typical souvenirs.  It has lost all of its charm.

I will recommend several nearby restaurants, the Bergen fish soup is good almost everywhere you go on the bryggen.

reviews.title: One of many visits
reviews.text: I lived in bergen for many years and have to say that the Fish Market of today is nothing but a tourist ripoff. Pricing is daylight robbery and most items can be bought at supermarkets within a few hundred yards of this Fish Market for ablout one third of the price the Fish Market will charge. Okay and interesting to take a walk through, but leave your wallet in your pocket. Looking for good seafood, try Enhjorningen Fiskerestaurant a very good seafood restaurant

reviews.title: Amazing variety
reviews.text: The people is very friendly and talkative, international, several lenguaje, variety of fish and seafood, freshness and not cheap.

reviews.title: Not really a fish market but 3 retail outlets in same building
reviews.text: Right on the harbour side so one would expect the fish to be fresh, but how much of what they sell is caught locally?

reviews.title: Fresh Fish
reviews.text: I am not an adventuresome eater but this market tempted me to try seafood  I had not had before. In the three days in Bergen we ate there three times _ twice outside and once in the lovely all glass restaurant.  Everything was so fresh, it was a treat.

reviews.title: beautiful place.
reviews.text: I was expecting a large outdoor market for some reason, but this place was indoors and beautiful. The people we talked with were very friendly. I would definitely come back and eat here.

reviews.title: A Must for Bergen
reviews.text: The fish are fresh or smoked but all look and taste great after looking at the great variety of seafood you can stop at the restaurant and have a great seafood meal.

reviews.title: Great fresh fish
reviews.text: Great concept with lots to choose from and 4 different menus. Made selection so difficult. Will go back when in Bergen.

reviews.title: Great Variety of sea food
reviews.text: Really surprised to find such a place! Full of options, very clean, huge variety:) I really liked also that you could show which fish you want and they would have prepared it for you in a very short time. Excellent. Whole family enjooyed.!!!

reviews.title: Don't know what the fuss was about
reviews.text: Literally just a small indoor fish market with a restaurant attached. It's nowhere near as interesting or impressive as the one in Tokyo, for example, but if you like seeing dead fish, this is the plaice for you? Just dunno what the fuss was about. Not really a tourist thing to be honest.

reviews.title: Very nice
reviews.text: Ate here three times twice for soup yum and we came back for dinner for a seafood platter was very nice. Staff were lovely, soup was prepared fresh.

reviews.title: A great place to see as well as the prices!
reviews.text: There is an abundance of fresh seafood which all looks very tempting but the prices of some items, particularly crabs and lobsters, is staggering in some instances. Makes our seafood look vert cheap!

reviews.title: Seafood at its freshest
reviews.text: Whether you want to buy some sort of seafood and eat it at the tables set up here or just wander around looking at all the wonderful fresh seafood, this is a very interesting place to spend some time, the day I was wandering around there was a group of musicians playing which provided a nice atmosphere while I ate my fish meal,

reviews.title: Wonderful displays of local produce
reviews.text: There were opportunities to taste  small bits of salmon, whale and other smoked/pickled fish. We went back and enjoyed a lovely fish stew.

reviews.title: Lots of fish
reviews.text:
I went to the fish market and it was all inside.  No outside fish were being sold.  
The fish inside was bountiful, beautiful, fresh and tasty.

reviews.title: Fresh and nice but not that cheap
reviews.text: We already read about it not being a cheap place to have a meal, but being here on a Sunday meant not having a lot of options and certainly not for eatibg fish. Although the food was great and fresh, we’re not quite sure it was worth it’s money.

reviews.title: Tourists spam.
reviews.text: Too expensive which is a tourist spam. You can find a menu with more than 10 different languages, you can see this is mainly for tourist!

reviews.title: Nice Atmosphere, vibes and food
reviews.text: Fish Market in Bergen is awesome. Friendly and authentic vibes. Fresh and delicious fish from the sea.

reviews.title: Go for a Cod
reviews.text: Norway’s cod is famous worldwide , when I visit the Fish Market I couldn’t think of any other plate to have. Totally recommend it!

reviews.title: Bergen Fish Market
reviews.text: The Fish Market in Bergen us the best known and most visited outdoor market in Norway. Situated in the heart of the city. It sells a wide range of seafood delicacies, fresh seafood, local cheese and cured meats. The outdoor market only open from Mei to September but Mathallen the indoor part of Fish Market is open all year except on Christmas. Fresh seafood sold is very diverse, prices are comparable with quality but seafood delicacies is sold at quite expensive prices.

reviews.title: Looked around, didn’t eat
reviews.text: It was cool to walk through, and I’m sure it’s probably delicious. But it was a little fancier and pricier than we were looking for.

reviews.title: Walk through to see the fish for sale in a modern building
reviews.text:
The fish market building is very modern building which contrasts nicely with the older style of many of the buildings in Bergen so it’s worth seeing.

Inside is the most amazing array of fish for sale/ to eat there, some of which we had not seen or heard of before. The sizes of some items were amazing ie the crabs.  We love to eat fish but it was hard to see the live cranes and lobsters all crammed into tanks.  Worth a visit and not at all smelly!

reviews.title: Very small and expensive! We visited in late September.
reviews.text: We visited here in late September and the market was very small and very expensive. I don't know if it was just because of the time of year? But, it was nothing like we thought it would be after reading the reviews. You can find cheaper good seafood and local munchies at other locals and restaurants.

reviews.title: A bit disappointing
reviews.text:
It is a great place but was disappointed due to the high expectation we had. We expected it to be a massive food hall, but found out that it was a small little place:)

I am sure the food is good.

reviews.title: Tourist Fish Market
reviews.text:
We found the Bergen Fish Market a bit touristy and pricey. Then again, it's a tourist spot in a tourist town so that's what you expect. 

There were local treats to purchase (gifts) along with snacks to eat. 

I doubt we spent more than five minutes walking through the Fish Market. Not that there was anything wrong with the market. We would rather spend time walking about seeing other kinds of things.

reviews.title: Restaurant
reviews.text:
A visit to the Fish Market restaurant turned into major annoyance in discovering that whale meat was on offer. This is a disgusting revelation since Norway widely and publicly champions itself to be seriously environmentally friendly and vigorously protecting the planet by preventing pollution.
So this was seen as a sad contradiction of their commitment, which I can assure you is practised widely especially on the high seas. The Hurtigruten Cruises are jealously proud of their efforts to protect  the nature existing around their expeditions. They should be celebrated and congratulated.
So, this bold sale of whale meat here in Bergen must must be widely criticized..... shame on the Fish Market restaurant!!!!
They must sanctioned by us all😡😡.

reviews.title: Holiday
reviews.text: Shocking disgusting At the end of our holiday we go to the fish market for sea food and see whale burgers and steak Our whole holiday we have been told how Norway is trying to protect its seas and environments and underneath their tourist office in the middle of town this is happening Shame on you for serving this on your menu You are expensive and your wine was terrible and then to serve whale on your menu I am beyond words I will be sending a further e mail to the fisheries minister

reviews.title: A taste of Bergen
reviews.text: Took some friends from outside of Norway for food here. They liked it a lot. The fishmarket is a nice place for tourists to get a taste of local food.

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text:
It is very rare to find such a place 
Very interesting to see fishes alive and various type of seafood

reviews.title: A modern upmarket fish market
reviews.text: It was interesting walking around to see he variety of fish and shellfish available, all beautifully presented. There were groups of Japanese tourists being taken around. For me, it missed the atmosphere of a real fish market and is more like a showcase for visiting tourists

reviews.title: Very disappointed
reviews.text: Our expectation on the fish market was very disappointed. This market is very commercial only concentrate on dining. We expected to see the atmosphere of a seafood market but nothing appear, is a real let down.

reviews.title: Amazing fish but extremely expendive
reviews.text:
The fish market is a highlight of Bryggen. It’s is incredible and the range even better. If you love sushi then this is the right place for you. 
It’s not cheap peeps. In fact it’s crazy expensive but worth it on a special occasion. 
Enjoy

reviews.title: Small but interesting!
reviews.text: We stumbled on it by chance--the harbour area is quite small and you really cant miss the fish market. It was interesting seeing the fish and sea food that is available . As South African travellers we found the prices very high so we had to be satisfied with just looking!

reviews.title: Expensive
reviews.text: I would always eat at the fish market but it’s overpriced. The seafood was good but the sushi just okay.

reviews.title: Lunch at the wharf
reviews.text: If you like your fish, you must go to the fish markets in Bergen. While your there, buy yourself some very nice fish for lunch!

reviews.title: More shop/restaurant than fish market
reviews.text: We were expecting a traditional fish trading station / old fashioned market where fishermen bring their catch to sell, and this is in fact a large fish shop & restaurant, with prices to match! There is a very large selection of fish from Alaskan crabs to whale meat. You can choose fish and have it cooked in the restaurant, but at a significant cost. We opted for fresh baguettes, stuffed with shrimps for NOK95. A really delicious lunch!

reviews.title: Fish, fish and more fish!!
reviews.text:
Loved my visit here, though couldn't eat any fish because I was alone and for a single guy things are a little expensive. But if you are like 2-3 people there are lot of options...crabs, lobsters, susi etc.

But I did try the ice-cream and hot chocolate and it was pretty damn good.

reviews.title: Seafood anyone??
reviews.text: So fresh! Every seafood imaginable here! Fascinated by the King Crabs (we did a King Crab experience up in Kirkenes, caught them, cooked fresh for us to eat!) Just delicious! The Fish Market is very local to visit.

reviews.title: Don't Miss a Visit Here
reviews.text: We loved our fish soup and fresh breads so much that we returned for a second visit.  There are tents with tables and chairs so the weather doesn't intrude.  The soup was perfection.  There are numerous vendors with something for everyone.

reviews.title: Fab food!
reviews.text: We ate here twice as the food was so nice. The fish soup was great and the fish and chips excellent. Nice staff.

reviews.title: Great Fresh Fish Lunch
reviews.text: The people behind the counter at the fish market are so friendly and outgoing.  My friend and I stopped in for a look.  We were talking about what the ball of yarn looking thing could be when a clerk walked over and told us it was a coconut.  My gullible friends thought he was serious.  We laughed and he continued to explain how to eat a sea urchin.  He spent several minuted with us telling us all about the various strange looking fish.  It was informative.  He was funny.  Very entertaining.  We went back on Saturday for lunch there.  It was Amazing!  the fish was so fresh and the portions were large.  I highly recommend this place.

reviews.title: Amazing, but a caution
reviews.text: This place is incredible with all of its fish and specialty items for sale. We were staying at a neighboring hotel with our own view, so we decided to picnic to save money, given that the take away offerings here looked so amazing. Unfortunately, one evening I got food poisoning from cross-contamination by shellfish (in our fish cakes), due to my shellfish allergy and carelessness on the part of that vendor.

reviews.title: Variety in a small place
reviews.text: The market was smaller than I expected but was full of diverse fish so a really enjoyable, if brief, experience. I didn't eat there.

reviews.title: Highly Overrated and Overpriced
reviews.text: I live in Bergen.There's very little Norwegian about this place. Sellers (international seasonal workers) who speak the languages of the daily catch of cruise ship passengers in the harbour, are trying to sell overpriced fish, which in most cases is doubtfully even caught in Norway. Most stalls are owned by the same guys, too. Go and spend your money in a locally owned, small restaurant instead.

reviews.title: Fish market is ok, sad to see the fish in the small fishtanks.  Don't recommend over priced restaurant.
reviews.text: The waitress in the restaurant was not very service minded, not a smile. The restaurant was nearly empty, but we had to argue to get a table by the window. Food over priced as well. The market has an amazing selection of fish and seafood, but no need to have big fish and cray fisk in small fishtanks. Across the road there is a really nice lokal fish shop, go and support them instead :-)

reviews.title: Good but more expensive than Oslo
reviews.text:
We spent 2 nights in Bergen before flying off to Oslo. We stayed in First Marin hotel about 5-10 minutes walk to the Fish Market. It is below the Tourist information centre which is upstairs. 

You can get any kind of seafood and is fresh. Price wise is different and cost about 20% higher if you dine in compare to take away. We had King Crab and prawns for takeaway and dine in not in the fish market itself but outside in those make shift tent where they sell fresh seafood also.
