Many people are eating at the make shift tent now but it closes early by 8.00pm. The price is cheaper by about 15 to 20% and taste as good. We had 3 meals of king crab, prawns and mussels. We were given slight discount since had eaten so many times there. The mussels are really good. Had also tried the Whale meat but not recommended. King crab cost about 1000-1200nok per kg dine in.

But we found that the fish market in Oslo was selling about 950nok per kg dine in for King Crab at the harbour terminal restaurant which is cheaper.

reviews.title: Fish market PLUS restaurants
reviews.text: Thought a fish market would be an interesting place to visit but not what I expected. It's a group of restaurants with  shop-style fish on display and for sale all under one roof. You can certainly buy fish, crab, prawns etc here but for visitors a meal is the best option. There are several places to chose from and you can feel certain the fish is fresh.

reviews.title: Didn't eat here, but learned a lot about local fish!
reviews.text: The gentleman behind one of the counters in the fish market was a delightful tour guide, telling us about all the fish in the case. He walked all the way around the ice-filled cases with us, telling us about the fish, comparing a particularly scary looking one to his ex-mother-in-law, and just making our visit 25 minutes of fun.  You can get any of the fish prepared for you in the adjoining restaurant.  If we had been staying in a place with cooking facilities, we would surely have purchased something to cook!

reviews.title: Fresh catch
reviews.text: Lovely atmosphere. Service was wonderful. The shrimp was so fresh and very tasty. If you are there on “all you can eat” sushi night. It is worth it.

reviews.title: Interesting to see and experience.
reviews.text:
This location has had a fish market for hundreds of years. The offerings are pretty amazing, including that they sell dried and cooked whale meat----while illegal in most countries it is still legal here. I was shocked to see this and did not purchase.
Many fish dishes are prepared and offered on site.

reviews.title: Only Place To Buy Fresh Fish
reviews.text: This is a lovely market with an incredible variety of beautiful and very fresh looking and smelling seafood. The staff was friendly and enjoyed showing off what they had to offer.  It was nice to see a fish market as they are very uncommon in Norway.  We spent a month travelling in Norway, staying in BnB's with kitchens for half that time and never found a grocery store with a fresh fish section.  A local we met on our Hurtigruten voyage, where we had wonderful seafood, said that, when she was young, her mother could buy fresh fish from a local fish market or directly from a fisherman, but now, all of the fish in Norway is pre-packaged , except for this one market.  If you want fresh fish, your best option is to either buy it here or eat it in a restaurant.  You will pay a lot but it will definitely be delicious.   We didn't actually buy anything at this market, as much as we wanted to, only because of the prices and because we visited this market toward the end of our trip.  We had already had some wonderful seafood meals both on the Hurtigruten Ship and in some nice restaurants in Norway.  We are from the coast of Maine where fresh fish is available everywhere and is also affordable so we had the luxury of knowing we could get all we wanted at home.

reviews.title: Fishy
reviews.text: I always like to visit local markets and shops when I'm overseas as they always have plenty of weird food on sale, this fish market is full of weird food! Weird yes, but it's all so fresh and interesting and you want to try everything! Makes the fish counter in the shop I work in look incredibly boring!

reviews.title: Fish and Seaford galore
reviews.text: We stopped in to look around after we went upstairs to the info booth to get our tickets for Norway in a Nutshell.  It was interesting to see how may species of fish and seafood that was available.  We stopped back another day for some hot chocolate and sweets.

reviews.title: Don't believe the staff!
reviews.text: I bought sausages to take home, and thought the staff were somehow Government-accredited and believed their advice.  I was wrong. My purchases were confiscated by Australian Customs and the whale meat got me a citation/ticket for trafficking in endangered species.  I suppose you could eat there, many people did and seemed to enjoy it, but I would not support a dishonest business like that.

reviews.title: Great fresh sushi!
reviews.text:
Great place for some ”local snacks” like king crab, fresh shrimps and smoked salmon. We ended up with picking some sushi. Very well done - raw fish at it’s best! 

Approved by worldbytina.se

reviews.title: Knock-out fish
reviews.text: After our fjord cruise we stopped for lunch - it's a hive of activity, lots of amazing fresh fish to choose from and some fabulous little restaurants too.  By far the best fish i've had.

reviews.title: Freshest local fish
reviews.text:
The Fish Market is in a very modern building in contrast to older buildings around it. There is a vast variety of fresh, smoked and cooked fish mostly locally sourced, that you can sample and enjoy right there. The staff are extremely helpful and all speak English !
The smoked whale can be tasted here.
All in all worth the time and money

reviews.title: Interesting market
reviews.text: This indoor market was much smaller than I expected but is very interesting for the variety of fish on offer.  The staff are informative and helpful and as you always find in Norway, they speak excellent English.  You won't spend that much time here unless you choose to eat in the excellent restaurants within the market. Some may find some of the products on sale unpalatable - but they are traditional foods.

reviews.title: Great Meals
reviews.text: The fish market in Bergen is really a collection of stalls where fresh seafood is sold and cooked to order.  We ate dinner here twice while in Bergen.  Everything we tried was delicious.  The setting is casual and fun.  It is Norway, so the food was expensive by US standards.  But, a great experience

reviews.title: A right old whale of a time!
reviews.text: With food fish at the forefront of this one - the (now) indoor fish market of Bergen is an absolute must for foodies! Friendly staff who can tell you the source of everything you’re eating and some very traditional Norse dishes to boot. The whale steak (minke) was incredibly tasty and sustainably fished (yes, I am aware that whales are mammals).

reviews.title: Smaller then expected, 5 min walk through, but Great, Fresh Variety
reviews.text: Seafood is superb, fresh out of the waters! However, don’t plan to spend more then 5-10 minutes here as it is very small. A few good restaurants within to try!

reviews.title: A pleasant fish dinner
reviews.text:
There are three different restaurants at this location to cater to all tastes. For the non seafood eaters there are vegetarian and non fish options, I didn’t see anything vegan. The atmosphere is unique and the food is good.

Take care with where you sit, there are seats that are on a raised platform and it’s very easy to move your chair back and fall off. It’s only a few inches, but enough to knock you off your chair.

reviews.title: Incredible fish and sea food
reviews.text: We spent a couple of hours at the fish market escaping the rain. The selection of fish is amazing, the various shop keepers are friendly and helpful and the fish was cooked to perfection. I had an assortment of caviar canapés that were delicious. This was followed by a couple of sushi dishes and capped off by a perfectly grilled piece of salmon and washed down by a very tasty Sancerre. Whether you are seeking shelter from the rain or if you are simply trying to sit somewhere to grab a bite to eat and watch the world go by, the Bergen Fish Market is the place to visit. We loved it

reviews.title: Astounding selection!
reviews.text: What a pleasure to take in the visual extravaganza of fish and seafood. Some vendors offered samples to taste (thankfully, yum!)

reviews.title: Wonderful displays of fish!
reviews.text: You simply have to try the fish - all different sorts, and they will tempt you with small slices to try. We tried whale meat - just like beef. Had a light lunch at one of the little cafes within the market (try the one that has a covered outdoor area), and try the sharing platter. One of Bergen's best attractions!

reviews.title: Excellent Array of Raw and Cooked Fish
reviews.text:
If you are a fish lover this is definitely the place to visit.  A variety of stalls, some selling fresh fish while others provide tables and chairs where you can try out their offerings.
The fish market is situated besides the Tourist Information centre where you can book trips and find out anbout the local area.

reviews.title: Fun
reviews.text: Fun place to see lots of different and huge seafood and fish. Thought the market itself would be larger in size

reviews.title: great smoked salmon
reviews.text: Lots of visually interesting things to see, but a definitely working fish market with almost any seafood you want, fresh and ready to eat or take home

reviews.title: Fresh fish/food
reviews.text: Under the red tents ... great food.  Walk to the end .. return on the  other side  ... THEN  make your choice if you want some food.  The  tents have seating if you eat there.  Near the west edge of the harbor inlet ... there is the tourist info center on the second floor of a large building.  In the large building are more restaurants and more fish markets.  There are PAY restrooms in this building also.  The tourist info center has some great maps, brochures, information about  Bergen  and the rest of the fjords and Norway.   Very helpful place.

reviews.title: Too expensive!
reviews.text: Brilliant displays of fish but just so expensive. We got a couple of fish skewers, crab leg and a small piece of smoked salmon and we were £50! The fish was great but just to pricey and that was take away.

reviews.title: What a busy place
reviews.text:
I guess as the harbour is the arrival/ departure point for most tourists in Bergen, it makes sense to have a big venue like the Fish Market right there on the waterfront.
This is not someones new idea, they have been trading fish in this working market since the 1200s.
That is not a typo, and I do have many, over 800 years.
This city has so much history that is hard for us Aussies to understand.
Our beautiful country is so young in modern terms but so ancient in terms of cultured people.

reviews.title: Very touristy
reviews.text: Local history and architecture is interesting but all the shops are a real turn-off for me. The art museum is wonderful. If traveling with kids every neighborhood seems to have a small pocket park

reviews.title: Fun area to explore
reviews.text: Lots of fish, eateries and interesting things to see in area.  The problem is if you have to use the washroom you need a "card".  Because we were not local residence we didn't have a card.   \ Luckily a few very nice people left the door ajar  so we could use the facilities.  These are the little things you need to know when exploring new countries and cities.

reviews.title: Charming and interesting to walk around.
reviews.text:
Many stalls there, although touristy, it's still nice to walk around and get the feel of this historical authentic place even you don't dine there. 
There are in-door and out door fish market. In-door fish market are way too expensive, but have a great night view in front of the water. Out-door fish market close around 5-6 pm, it's setting is more casual. We had our early dinner at out-door fish market, the seafood is fresh and tasty, price probably half of the price compared with in-door market. 
Highly recommend trying fish soup in Bergen. We had  soup in 3 different places(an vendor we grab-n-go, one at out-door fish market, one at a restaurant), all good and delicious.

reviews.title: Absolutely worth it!!!!
reviews.text:
Little pricey but so well worth it you go in pick your meal they cook it with all the sides at first I was skeptical but then our food was amazing my little boy and I both
Got to pick the monk fish I ate and the lobster he ate. The sides as well were great
And you pick what you want cooked in and staff very very helpful. If ur gonna splurge do it here. Free WiFi as well.

reviews.title: Fresh, but very expensive!
reviews.text: You would thought the price would be better than restaurant, but no, it is very expensive there. But we are on vacation and have to try the famous fish market. We later bought the fish from the street vendor and cooked at our airbnb. They can also cook for you too. Just no tables to sit.

reviews.title: Fresh! Fresh! Fresh!
reviews.text: See what they have, pick what you want, and all fresh are in your mouth! The price can be less if you decide to take out!

reviews.title: Something fishy...
reviews.text: Visited as part of my walking tour and really interesting to see such an amazing array of fish - of all shapes and sizes. Prices not as high as I'd expected. Norwegian fish and chips very tasty. What I loved was the abundance of shell-on prawns that you could just scoop up.

reviews.title: A bit of a tourist trap really but certainly worth a visit
reviews.text: OK that is what it is a tourist trap but it is something of a main attraction in Bergen and I walked around it each day I was there as I found it fascinating.  Great location on the harbourside with both the indoor and outdoor areas.  There are a few other stalls as well and I shopped at a lovely fruit stall where there was a strong leaning towards local produce.  The fresh lingonberries (tyttebaer in Norwegian) that I bought were really tasty, much like a smaller version of cranberries.

reviews.title: Good seafood for very good prices.
reviews.text: Well located in the harbor area of Bergen. The dining area is not plush(think picnic tables)...but very good seafood at expensive prices. Yup.. a tourist thing...but still enjoyable.

reviews.title: Tasty and fresh seafood
reviews.text: The fish market (which is more like an open-air restaurant) is located in the historical city center of Bergen, next to the harbour. It is not a huge place but has many different kind of meals to offer. You may choose between prepared plates or you may set up your own plate to be made. We took fish and chips, it was ready in about 15-20 minutes and it was very tasty. I'd recommend everyone to try out a meal once.

reviews.title: USA travelers take caution purchasing meat gift packs.
reviews.text: We purchased a salami gift pack at the Fish Market in Bergen recently.  We were assured by the local vendor Mat Tradisjon that we would get the gift pack of moose, reindeer and whale salami through US customs just fine if it was unopened.  We reported the meat on the US customs form when arriving in San Francisco and it was promptly confiscated.  The customs agent said we had been duped by a Norwegian salesperson.  Travelers beware!

reviews.title: Somewhat overrated
reviews.text: One of the most famous attractions in Bergen but from my point of view it is overrated and overpriced.

reviews.title: Nice but noisy
reviews.text: Had lunch and went for the smoked fish plates with scrambelled eggs. Nice presentation and tasted very good, but little attention from waiter and a lot of noice brings the experience to average.

reviews.title: Tourist trap
reviews.text: It’s for tourists. Prices are high and it’s small. I think it’s more seafood restaurants than fish market. Good place to sample Norwegian seafood including whale meat. I would look for more authentic fish market.

reviews.title: Outrageous Prices, Average Seafood
reviews.text: We heard about the fresh king crab that the fish market offers and thought that we might just try a fresh king crab out of the tank.  There were 8 of us prepared for this tasting event and thought we might order one live king crab from the tank and just share.  When we inquired about the cost of a king crab with an average weight of about 7 pounds, we were given the cost in Norwegian krones.  When we converted the price to U.S. dollars, we thought there must be some mistake either in what we heard or our monetary converter.  So we decided to ask the waiter to tell us how much the crab would cost in U.S. dollars.  After a quick calculation, the waiter told us that the crab ONLY cost U.S. $650.  Wow, only cost $650.  We estimated that if we ordered some beverages, bread and clam chowder plus the tips, it would cost each of us about U.S. $100 just to try a piece of live king crab.  You guess it, we decided to skip the live king crab and just ordered sampling dishes of probably frozen king crab legs.  That plus the drinks and bread, the damage was a reasonable $30+ per person....

reviews.title: Not a Pleasant Experience
reviews.text: We were looking forward to having some fresh fish and seafood while we were visiting Bergen.  We walked through the fish market and the seafood did not appear to be or smell very fresh.  It did not appear to be "the fresh catch of the day right off the boat". Also, the people are a little aggressive trying to sell their items and they make it difficult to buy from multiple vendors since they said you could only sit in their seating area if you buy from them. And it is ridiculously more expensive to sit there and eat than to get the food to-go.  If we are ever in Bergen again and the seafood actually seems fresh, I would order to go and then sit by the harbor or by the lake to eat. Or I'd probably just go to a nice sit-down restaurant and have a nicer meal with less ambiance.

reviews.title: Great to see the catches of the day
reviews.text:
We didn’t actually eat here but it looked fantastic and was good to show the kids different fish and crustaceans. Walked through everyday on a weekend trip 
Some of the market sellers gave us info on the type of fish caught and what they tasted like so was good.

reviews.title: SUPER expensive
reviews.text: The fish market is really a building housing a handful of restaurants.  It's not a traditional fish market where fisherman bring their catch; it's a much fancier market with seafood on display (some local, some not at all).  in warmer weather there are also stalls outside the market selling a range of seafood items and prepared plates.

reviews.title: Charming and Interesting
reviews.text: Complaints that this market is a tourist trap are not invalid; that being said this was still one of my favorite things to do in Bergen. Yes its crowded, yes there are tourists taking photos everywhere, but absolutely NO -- it does NOT take away the spectacle and charm of it all. You're still in a historical fish market in western fjordland Norway for goodness sake. The Products are definately overpriced; so eat before to fill your bellies if you want to save cash. That being said I would at least get something small to split for the experience -- that comes from a bargain traveler with an aversion to tourist traps. I loved it ALL.

reviews.title: Lots of very expensive seafood !
reviews.text: The Fishmarket is right at the Port of Bergen and just across the Tourist Information Centre.  There is a great variety of seafood but comes in small serving sizes and with a very high price tag.

reviews.title: Tourism vs. Tradition-Indoor vs. Outdoor
reviews.text: I will say to begin with, as a tourist, I thoroughly enjoyed the two meals we had at the fish market.  We were here at the end of the season so it was not as crowded with tourists, I can only imagine what a nightmare it would be with all the ships in port.  While people complain about how "overpriced" the fish is...I haven't seen a restaurant in the 8 days we've been in Norway that wasn't expensive.  Unfortunately for the locals, this must be frustrating to have your traditions overrun with curiosity, for that I am sorry.  As for the market, we ate in the outdoor tents, our guide said "you will pay a lot for the indoors market", that area felt like just another restaurant.  Outdoors you hear the fish mongers competing for sales, the bustle of the city, and the smells of the cooking fish, and if the wind is just wrong the smell of fresh fish...stay outdoors...it's covered to protect from sun and rain and they have heaters when it's cold what's not to love!

reviews.title: Tradition meets  modern solutions
reviews.text: I have been visiting  Fish Market many times  to enjoy fantastic fresh and tasty ,, frutti di mare,, in a busy , tidy and  quiet place  . Bergen is an example of  place to see how Old fish market tradition are adopted to the modern city   live  .This solution is  giving an opportunity for any type of customer .On the other hand  the all goods around are  representing traditional Norwegian food which is great, Many attractive sea cities should to learn from Bergen masters  to promote local fishery , farmers and local products ,

reviews.title: Modern Building but still good
reviews.text:
In a very modern building but fascinating collection of fish etc.
You can buy food from the stalls and there are restaurants attached.

reviews.title: Overpriced seafood market
reviews.text:
We recently visited the Bergen Fish Market on our short 2 night stay in Bergen. It's located in the heart of Bergen, within a 5 minute walk from the shopping district and another 5 minute walk to Bryggen Wharf. It's not possible to miss the Fish Market if you're on your way to visit the Wharf.

This place is nothing short of touristy - from the Chinese and Japanese signboards, to the Spanish-speaking staff - it is quite evident that this place caters to the many tourists who visit Bergen on a daily basis. 

We chose a shop that was closer to the side of the Bergen Visitor Centre. We ordered 3 pieces of fish - halibut and salmon - fries, vegetables and a salad. As you would expect, food isn't cheap and our meal came up to about US$60. The food wasn't bad, but neither was it memorable - it was average.

There are many other seafood restaurants scattered around Bergen that offer a more cosy dining experience, with better prices.

reviews.title: Massive crabs, wonderful fresh fish smell about the whole are.
reviews.text: We arrived early whilst the market was being set up which was very interesting to watch especially as it was a beautiful clear and warm morning.  The fresh fish smell was marvellous.  Later after visiting the funicular railway to Mount Fløyen railway we returned when the market was in full swing with plenty of free samples to try.  If fish is your dish this place (plaice) is for you.

reviews.title: Overrated and Overrun
reviews.text:
Crowded, noisy, and smelling pungently of fish, this is an authentic site with an overly touristy "attraction" draw.  The fish is expensive; we didn't eat anything, so I don't know if it was good.  There are a number of nice places nearby that are less expensive and more friendly.  

Go there, walk through, take in the sights, and keep going.

reviews.title: Interesting Place
reviews.text:
The internal Fish Market has a number of interesting stalls selling varied fish but they also have live lobster and the largest crabs I have ever seen in tanks.
The external fish market has stalls selling fish but also make up sandwiches and baguettes with fish and salad.
There are also stalls selling hot cooked fish including fish & chips. There are also burger outlets doing moose and reindeer burgers or dried meats.

reviews.title: Fresh Seafood & more
reviews.text:
Date of Visit: Friday, Aug 31st, 2018

We were informed we had to visit the Fish Market because it is a must-do when you visit Bergen, so we did. 

The fish market contains many stalls, booths, tents, etc of fish vendors selling their catch. There are places to buy fresh fish and seafood, places to grab a seafood meal, food stands where you can get a grab-n-go meal as well. 
This is a bustling place, with many locals and tourists checking it out and shopping. 
I had one goal when visiting Norway, and that was to try Reindeer – and unfortunately every stop we made, we did not eat due to timing. However at the fish market I hound a food stand making reindeer sausages, and burgers – which I finally got around to enjoying. 

This would be a great place for locals to get fresh fish for dinner, and it is definitely a great place for tourists to enjoy a small meal. 

It is part authentic fresh fish market for the locals, but it is also part touristy destination - and with all of the trappings that entails. 

There are some stands selling other items that are not as easily perishable as fresh fish – such as brown cheeses, canned herring and other fish, gifts, and much more. 

The prices are reasonable, but I always have to finish that off with “for Norway”. 

Enjoy your visit to Bergen, and do not miss out on a visit to the Fish Market. 
It may not be amazing, but it is a nice place to visit.

reviews.title: Authentic fresh fish
reviews.text: Fresh fish just captured where you may either eat there or else take it home to cook it yourself. It is a modern place but yet it has retained its quaintness. Price wise it is a bit on the high side especially if someone is coming from southern countries but the experience is well worth it.

reviews.title: Expensive tourist trap
reviews.text:
The fishmarked has become a marked where no locals go to buy food, but a marked where hardly any sales people speak norwegian,  and shoppers are tourists. If you go, go to have a look but don’t buy anything. If you are looking to buy salmon or brown cheese, stop by any other food store, several just minutes from the fish marked. 

If you are lucky to stumble across a farmers marked over a weekend, note that this local farmers and you can safely buy local products.

reviews.title: Authentic lunch
reviews.text: This fish market is historic it looks a little doggy since the surrounding buildings are so beautiful but don’t be put out by this. We had lunch at several of the stalls, dishes were prepared well, the freshest seafood I’ve ever had. The stall give out samples, I sampled whale, reindeer, berries that we don’t have the USA, it was great! I stall workers are great they are very chatty and a wealth of information. It’s not cheap though, Norway was one of my most expensive trip I’ve ever taken but worth it.

reviews.title: Very disappointed
reviews.text: We were very disappointed. Seafood was not overly fresh and very tasteless. On top of that way too expensive! AUS $31 for fish and chips! There are indoor and outdoor markets too. Very touristy.

reviews.title: Good seefood
reviews.text:
A good selection gril seefood you can select what you want and they will grill it for you.
The people in the market very kind and helpfull.

reviews.title: Interesting and Good for a Snack
reviews.text: The market was interesting and there was a good variety of fish, and meets. I must say I drew the line at whale meat and was disappointed to see it on sale.

reviews.title: Choose carefully, mine was awful
reviews.text: Randomly picked a place in the fish market one evening and it was way below average. I ordered fish and chips and it honestly tasted like frozen fish from a packet. Unfortunately I don't know the name of the stall but my advice would be to choose carefully as I'm sure they can't all be this bad.

reviews.title: Great Place to explore sea food
reviews.text:
SeaFood Street where we can find lot of seafood delicacies, its worth a romantic time to dine in the social eating place beside restuarants.
Note: A bit expensive but worth the experience and not to miss while inbergen

reviews.title: Don't like fish - still worth a look
reviews.text:
Monday 3rd September and we docked in Bergen and we went out and about exploring and sightseeing  and one of the first things we encountered was the Fish Market. 

Bergen fish market situated at the top end of the Vågen harbour, nearby the Information Centre and about 10 minutes walk from where the boat docked.

A number of outdoor stalls and restaurants selling every variety of fish products. Some of the stall holders were happy for visitors to sample their wares.

It was very busy and as a person that does not eat fish, it was not overly exciting. However it was an insight to Norwegian living.

There a number of large glass tanks containing lobsters and large crabs on view.

One restaurant was offering a special seafood platter for 1,500 Krone, about  £150, bring your credit card.

reviews.title: Fresh seafood for sale, and meals
reviews.text: We walked through the Fish Market, and viewed all the stalls. There were tanks with Live Crabs and Lobsters. The crabs looked like Alaskan King Crabs, as they were huge. There were many different kinds of fresh seafood meals for sale, and they had soup ready to go. Prices are high, as is all of Norway for food. It is an interesting place to visit, and not to be missed. If you have a credit card with no foreign transaction fees, use it. You will get a better exchange rate.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: Nice place to have a look around. Lots of stalls selling fish and seafood. Many had the option to eat as well. Food expensive ( as is normal in Norway) so we didn’t try anything but it was a nice place to wander.

reviews.title: Lovely place to visit
reviews.text: If you come to Bergen you have to visit the fish market.and if you have a camera take loads of photos  because the size of the fish will surprise you

reviews.title: Best seen and visited in the evening
reviews.text: We were in Bergen for 2 nights on a recent Trafalgar tour. It was our favorite city as we are walkers and it provided many opportunities for such. The fish market is much less crowded at night and we enjoyed people watching while having a couple Hansa purchased at the nearby 7/11.

reviews.title: Mouth Watering
reviews.text: Walking through the market and seeing the wonderful array of fresh fish was remarkable. We had just come from breakfast on our cruise ship but promised ourselves to taste some seafood on our way back to the ship later on. This we duly did and end enjoyed delicious fresh shrimps and salmon. Yum.

reviews.title: Interest8ng
reviews.text: Worth looking at but can be expensive  lots of stalls selling all types of fish and sea food. Sandwiches look quite filling.

reviews.title: Just right
reviews.text: It's hard to come up with a hundred characters when all you want to say is that the atmosphere was great and the fish soup was cheap and tasty.

reviews.title: A photographic, colorful, iconic tasty venue.
reviews.text:
A modernized approach to their old fish market. Doubtful that products are freshly, wild caught. The ubiquitous Salmon are farmed Atlantic, of questionable value. However overall there is a GREAT selection of fish / seafood, and dried meat products, for a very tasty lunch,  at their colorful seaside cafes. 

They cater to cruise ships with their packages of caviar. Suggested you taste these before buying. They are mostly a by-product of their fish farming, and are said to “not” require refrigeration, due to their processing. Not sure about that, but their “processing” certainly renders them “mushy” as opposed to the desired “pop”!

reviews.title: Very good but not cheap
reviews.text: The prices will make your eyes water, especially if its your first trip to Norway. More likely to be attractive to a fish eater who knows their fish rather than a general tourist.

reviews.title: Plenty Of Fish
reviews.text: Visited Bergen as part of a cruise very unusual to see all the live crabs and lobsters for sale in tanks along with lots of other strange fish , very busy and interesting.

reviews.title: Holiday Visit
reviews.text: Wow what a place so many different fish on sale and so many restaurants it was very difficult to decide where to eat. We had vouchers from our cruise ship that entitled us to either a Smoked Salmon, Prawn, or Ham and cheese roll.We decided to have a local beer with it which was very good. A very interesting place to visit.

reviews.title: Variety
reviews.text:
So many varieties of sea food. No wonder it is a popular place. Yum. We walked through all the aisles. Some were cooking food right there. Buy, taste. Just great. All fresh. 
Done in hygienic way. Also the ambience was great. We walked around the area and it has some very interesting shops. This is an interesting place.

You love seafood? This is a must visit place. You will miss out if you don't.

reviews.title: A market more for the tourist trade
reviews.text: We usually love going to the local fish market in both small and large cities.  As there are often so many huge cruise ships in Bergen, this market seems to be set up more for the tourist trade as they don’t need to walk far from their ship to visit.  We thought the modern, food court style indoor “market” was a more appealing place to eat (on the other side of the water) + you can get some good photos, with water in foreground, of the traditional/colourful timber buildings of Old Bryggen.

reviews.title: Interesting place
reviews.text: Visited with the family and brought a sandwich from one of the venders who sold a variety of sandwiches from sea food to ham and cheese. Very interesting  variety of food including live crabs and lobster and something for those who don’t eat fish, the staff are very friendly and helpful.

reviews.title: Seafood paradise
reviews.text: Loved the fresh seafood which was being cooked and served so fresh at the fish market .The pink Salmon and calamari which are a favourite were yummy.

reviews.title: Interesting Products
reviews.text: We walked through the market.  There were many interesting seafood (fresh and dried) in the market.  You can order what you want and if need be they will prepare the dish for you.  There's sufficient seats in the open seating area.  The vendors are also helpful.  We didn't know what some of the products were, and the vendors were very willing to describe them for us.

reviews.title: Seafood market
reviews.text:
There is a lot of seafood. You can buy to eat here or to-go, or to-home )
You can taste whale, wild salmon, crabs...everything you can imagine of seafood types of meal. Looks good, taste - better )
Tourist place.

reviews.title: Fish, fish and more fish
reviews.text:
Amazing place - you could wander round for ages looking at fish!!!
We had a meal in one of the restaurants, which wasn’t cheap, but we thoroughly enjoyed.
You haven’t seen Bergen if you haven’t been here.

reviews.title: Order with Extreme Care.
reviews.text: The 'market' is a street along the water with various stalls/tents all hawking the same cooked-to-order foods. Can't recall which we decided to have LUNCH because they all looked the same. We put together a family platter for 3 - one skewer of shrimp, one of scallops, a small sized fillet of salmon, a medium sized cluster of fresh king crab legs, a beer and two sodas. They 'threw in' a bed of lettuce, grilled vegetables and a side of potato salad. The bill came to $400!  Yes, it was good, but not that good.  It was a most unpleasant surprise.

reviews.title: Everything fish and seafood!
reviews.text:
Open air market with stands of fresh fish and all sorts of seafood. 
Expensive but it is a tourist area of Bergen and everything is fresh and delicious!
I am sure this is not where the locals go but it is easy to get to from the cruise ports. Can be very crowded if lots of tourist are in town,
Definitely worth a walk through even if you can resist the giant crab.

reviews.title: Not reallt a fish market
reviews.text: This was a fish market  of renown for generations. Now it is mainly a place where tourists buy seafood.

reviews.title: Overrated!!!
reviews.text: It’s outrageously pricey and a tourist trap. But if you are in Bergen very limited options to eat so why not eat fresh fish here. It’s just like Pikes in Seattle.

reviews.title: Lots of sea food
reviews.text: This is very central in Bergen at the waterfront. They sell sea food and they also have areas to eat sea food right there.

reviews.title: Fresh Sea Food
reviews.text: I liked the way and how freshy is the taste I recommend you to try it is a good quality . Different taste and nice to try

reviews.title: Small but nice
reviews.text: It’s a bit small but they have a lot to offer. From the port, it’s around 5 minutes bij foot. Next to the touristoffice.

reviews.title: Great evening stroll and fun dining
reviews.text: It is right next to Bergen harbor and the place has a wonderful vibe with lots and lots of people eating and having a good time. Definitely worth a walk and if you fancy sea food, there's plenty to try.

reviews.title: Enjoyed the ambience
reviews.text: I don’t really like fish, but this large marketplace was a must see.  Many types of seafood were on display, some very unusual to Americans. Samples were provided, and meals including fresh fish could be ordered to eat in a tented picnic area.

reviews.title: If you like fish, this is a must do!
reviews.text: Fish market is right on the harbor with open air stalls each serving relatively the same fish options. The fish was very fresh and tasty.

reviews.title: Touristy but Fun
reviews.text: OK.  So this is purely a touristy hangout as locals don't come here to buy fish, but what is wrong with that.  It's a great spot for photo op as there's a good amount of sea creatures on display, including mink whale meat that you don't see anywhere else but Norway.  You can also sample and taste "caviar" from Norway, pick fresh seafood and have it grilled, then grab a seat and devour it with a plate of paella while chugging down a bottle of local beer.

reviews.title: Heaving seafood place.
reviews.text: If live king crabs,  king prawns and all the denizens of the deep...is your thing, then do go along to this place. Great vibes, great smell, great tasters....and we ended up on the chairs of the fish market....enjoying the atmosphere n eating. .. that is great also. but still a ripoff;))

reviews.title: They cheat on you
reviews.text: I've been to the first shop on the left (looking at the typical Bergen houses) where a spanish guy sold me 4 scallops stick for 640 krones. When I asked the reason, having I bought the same 4 for 320 krones the day before in a different shop of the market, he just said that in his shop this is the price. I was stupid for not asking before the price of them and I fell in the classic tourist trap! Avoid if you can!

reviews.title: SO many choices, great food
reviews.text: You have to eat a least 2 meals here - one for paella (made by actual Spaniards) and one for a fish dish. The salmon was so fresh and tasty. Ask the workers for recommendations on local food, since they do have some items like prawns that aren't local.

reviews.title: Feast for the eyes
reviews.text: We enjoyed walking around the wharf area, and were particularly interested in the different types of seafood available in this market.  We weren't there to eat, but saw lots of people enjoying their meals.  There was also an incredible collection of fresh, local produce; we saw the chef from our cruise ship conducting a tour and buying a lot of fresh food.  You don't have to spend money to enjoy this attraction.

reviews.title: Heart of Bergen,
reviews.text: You absolutely must visit this place when you are in Bergen. There are so many outlets selling smoked fish and caviar which you may take home, preserves, gifts etc. Few artists gather there also so you may find a nice gift.  There are masses of food outlets. When a lot of ships are in port there are lots of outdoor cafes serving things like fish cakes, which I was told were very good.

reviews.title: Wonderful Meal
reviews.text: Must visit if you are in Bergen. We were there for 2 days and had 3 meals there. That’s how good the food is.

reviews.title: Amazing FRESH FISH and SEAFOOD
reviews.text: The cost of food throughout Scandinavia is expensive.  By accident,  a casual hotel restaurant just across the water from Bryggen had as an appetizer mussels for about $12.00 (USD) and I ordered them in they came in a soup tureen size bowl and the best I’ve ever had (a bit better than the Green Lipped Mussels in New Zealand) !!!!!  So for 3 meals my husband and I had mussels and fresh baked crispy bread and a salad and it was wonderful.  All the fish in Bergen is amazing!

reviews.title: Fresh seafood at affordable price
reviews.text:
At the Bergen fishmarket you have a large choice of fresh seafood. There are several places where you can order what you want to eat. And under the covered seatings you can enjoy your meal. If you are not so hungry, bad luck, you can buy a sandwich with shrimps or salmon.
Prices are reasonable when you compared it with the surrounding restaurants.

reviews.title: Stop off on Norwegian Fjords cruise
reviews.text:
Bergen was our last stop off on our Norwegian cruise. It was raining fairly heavily but we were glad we wondered the 15 or so minutes from the cruise terminal to find the market. 

We only walked through but there’s lots to see. Wonderful fresh crabs, prawns, lobster and smoked salmon. I’d never seen smoked salmon being calved before, the guys were skilled and kept eating the salmon as they cut it. 

This is a very touristy area and the prices are crazy high (not unlike a lot of Norway) so we didn’t buy anything but it was fun to walk through.

reviews.title: Tourist trap
reviews.text: These are all foreign workers peddling fake goods to tourists. Literally nothing authentic about this place. You’ll inevitably have to walk past it and that’s the only bother you should give it.

reviews.title: Just wander through
reviews.text:
My wife is a market addict and I been dragged through food markets (including a lot of fish) all over Europe.

For once however I found myself fascinated. As well as a range of wet fish there are many stalls selling hot seafood snacks.

It is possible to have a sit down meal but the market is probably best as a transient experience (with perhaps the odd nibble).

reviews.title: Great fish
reviews.text: Expensive but you have to do it😂 On the advice of the hotel clerk we went to the place inside - it was raining - and had shellfish platter and halibut and salmon. All good but pricey.

reviews.title: Great experience try everything!
reviews.text: We really enjoyed the Fish Market.  Try the whale!  The reindeer sausage with lingonberries is great!  Best stop for lunch

reviews.title: Tirip to Fyords
reviews.text:
We have been advised that best and fresh seafood is to be found in fish market in Bergen. Total disappointment !
First it smells very bad !
Secondly they catch you from the street, give you a table and then keep you waiting for about 40 minutes for a very simple combination of seafood served in paper plates with beer from bottles.
If you complain about lateness, they argue with you in a very unfirendly way.
Price is high versus the quality of the food and the service.
1 piece of giant shrimp is 120 Krones = 13 E.
Never ever again !
On the otherhand the one at the left end of the port Fjelskal is excellent and worth the money !

reviews.title: Brilliant (if you like fish!)
reviews.text:
Visited here on foot / explored ourselves 

Make the most of all the free samples on offer - salmon, roe, caviar, whale 

If you want to buy some fish like everywhere in Norway, it’s not cheap !

There are also a few restaurants / cafes nearby if you want to sample the fish

You can also buy a range of meats and cheeses at the market

reviews.title: Dead Fish To Eat
reviews.text: They have set up a row of tents near the waterfront in Bergen that sell seafood meals to tourists. There are probably 20 or so vendors, all fairly similar: Fish on Ice in a glass display case near a menu, and tables/chairs set up behind the counters.   Having a seafood meal is probably a good idea in Bergen, and this is a quick way to do that.

reviews.title: Not much to review here...
reviews.text: Not much to review here...it's a typical tourist fish market...sells more than fish...other foods, souvenirs...you will be in the area anyway and can just walk through.

reviews.title: Pricey, but delicious
reviews.text: This place is exxxxxxpensive. But the seafood is crazy fresh and delicious. You can easily drop $100USD for two here, so it depends how much you want to pay for fresh King crab, salmon, shrimp and so on. One of the most reasonably priced options would be the fish and chips, which we really enjoyed. Also, check out the fruit stands if the season is right, and pick up some local berries and plums from the region.

reviews.title: Easy to get ripped off
reviews.text: Since this is an outdoor fish market by the harbor, one could be forgiven for assuming that the fish would be fresh. Not necessarily the case.  We ordered two lunch meals from two different vendors; one was good, one was definitely not fresh. And the prices are exorbitant.  I also got a warning after the fact from one of our tour guides who had previously worked there that the fish was “not always the freshest”. Yuk.

reviews.title: Very interesting
reviews.text: The fish market looks very cool and has a variety of fish and shellfish available. There are 3 restaurants inside. We went to "Fish Me" and the food was good (except for the mussels in wine and cream sauce), but the service was a bit off. All together an okay experience.

reviews.title: Mediocre
reviews.text: Located right at the center by the port, fish market is a place you can find small group of sea food sellers. They have all portable setup where cooking, dining and selling take place in open air covered by red tents. It doesn’t look they care hygene much. The taste was acceptable. There is room to bargain the price if you come with a group.

reviews.title: Lots of fresh fish and seafood
reviews.text: A good range of fresh fish and seafood at prices that could be considered reasonable for expensive Norway.  Certainlyh everything is very fresh.

reviews.title: Nice to walk around
reviews.text: We visited the fish market while we were in Bergen. It's not super big but it had a lot of fish and seafood. We didn't stop to eat anything though. So I can't say anything about the food. But the seafood looked good.

reviews.title: Wonderful place to stroll through and view the fish on sale.
reviews.text: Many of the fish stalls offer food with a fixed menu and price. Thronged with people on the weekend but quieter during the week. Well worth the visit.

reviews.title: Great place for a meal
reviews.text: Ate in the red tents of the fish market as well as the glass enclosed restaurants under the visitor center. Both good, but recommend under the visitor center for bigger selection and more refined dining experience.

reviews.title: Dinner
reviews.text: The food on the fish market was not really good. You pay a lot of money for small plates. The only thing I would eat there is the lobster or a king crap, because for this 2 meals the prices are good and you get a fresh cooked highlight of Norwegian cousin.

reviews.title: Overpriced
reviews.text: It's a nice walk but don't shop or eat there unless your intention is just to support the local economy.  Everything is fresh but priced for cruise ship passengers who may not have time to venture a block more into the city to get better prices.

reviews.title: Nosense: expensive like a restaurant
reviews.text: At the fish market in Bergen, if you are Italian, you are lucky, they will speak to you in your language. Although the dishes are good, given the place I did not expect to pay them as if I were in a restaurant. Otherwise you do not understand why one should choose to stay in narrow tables one close to the other. That said, I found nice and friendly people, but if I come back for Bergen I would go to a restaurant in the Olivia chain or similar.  The error must not be repeated twice

reviews.title: Sea food paradise
reviews.text: If you are a sea food lover you will simply drool over in this place. You can find all the possible crabs, fish, lobster or octopus literally in piles. Paella is worth trying at one of the counters...must go place.

reviews.title: For your eyes and your stomach
reviews.text: A large variety of ocean living animals can be find there in different small restaurants. You can stay there for a lunch but also you can take it home and have 10% discount. It is not cheap, but interesting and you can find very tasty foods. Sometimes it can be very crowded.

reviews.title: Excellent king crab, sushi
reviews.text: Loved the fish market! Great browsing, photos and fun to buy and eat lunch. Restaurants line up right in front attached to the market. We had excellent king crab and sushi. All done to order, simple and tasty. Another day we got sushi to go for our flight.

reviews.title: Bernard Fisk
reviews.text: For the best fish soup in Bergen, go to the fish market. Enter from the west side & it’s the first seafood establishment on the left (see picture below) - Bernard Fisk.  Great Norwegian staff serving great seafood.

reviews.title: Great fish!
reviews.text:
Great variety of fish on display and for sale.
We went for dinner one evening and had an excellent meal. Very touristy and expensive but that is the same the world over for this type of venue.

reviews.title: Great to visit just to see what Fish are on offer
reviews.text: We have walked round the Fish Market admiring the various stalls a few times. We have enjoyed our perigrenations

reviews.title: CRABS
reviews.text: I have never seen such large crabs and Lobsters and Prawns. They were still alive and in tanks and obviously very popular as a lot were being eaten around the market. A very smart and tidy place with expert advice from friendly staff.

reviews.title: So fresh
reviews.text:
You’ll never find fresher fish. Walk around and pick the stall you want to choose from, then order and sit down.  
It’s a splurge but go for the king crab and giant prawns.

reviews.title: Beautiful market,
reviews.text: It is always fun to stroll through and open air market.  This one is particularly well sited and picturesque.  Fun place to spend a few hours.

reviews.title: Happening place to have a grab of fresh seafood
reviews.text:
This is a place recommended by a friend and our air b n b host. It was not a disappointment at all. We walked in the indoor market and were welcome by the vendors showing us their fresh catch.. 

The outdoor market was more lively as there were more people. The vendors were selling either fresh food or the local delicacies (caviar paste, caviar etc..)
You can even get tax free shopping from the stalls. Gives us another reason to buy. 

It will be great if the weather is good. Ours was a rainy day.. but it was still fun walking through the market.

reviews.title: Touristy and overpriced
reviews.text:
Don't recommend buying the questionable quality there. Big tourist trap!
If you want to eat expensive seafood served in an unloving manner in a market just for tourists...go ahead!

reviews.title: Piles of fish
reviews.text: I was encouraged to visit this market and there was nothing special about it.  I suppose if I needed to eat, I might have felt differently. But a good seafood restaurant would have been just as effective.

reviews.title: For tourist only.
reviews.text:
This is a tourist place only.
The prices are far too high here.
Although all the fish seen here are fresh and the service is friendly here.
But if you are out to get a fresh bite of fresh fish or any other thing from the seawater , then this is the place for you.
You can a lot of delicate things here including king crab and whale meat.
The staff in nearly all the sale stalls are young people from all over the world , only working here in the season, that makes it easy to communicate here on any language.

reviews.title: Very expensive, trap for tourists
reviews.text:
The fish is indeed very freshly caught, no doubt, but....the price is too high and it seems that no local people buy fish at the Fish Market. So, the Fish market is a trap for tourists.
You can buy the same fresh fish for less: go to the small shop in Strandkaien street, just on the right hand side of the Shopping mall Wallendahl, in front of the Norled boat terminal.

reviews.title: It's Something you  Should Do
reviews.text: How can you walk by without walking inside to check it out and maybe even eat there. It's under the tourist information site so it's easy to find. There is one building that has it's restaurants and display inside and another outside. Both are fun and nice to see.

reviews.title: Great seafood
reviews.text: All seafood are grilled or sashimi. We tried the king crab, salmon, lobster, shrimp and halibut. The king crab, salmon and shrimp are good. The lobster is disappointing. The halibut is a bit tasteless. Fish cake is cheap but delicious. Must try.

reviews.title: Seafood here was good and way overpriced
reviews.text: We visited the fish market in Bergen since we are already here and thought fresh seafood would be delicious. Well it was delicious but the price is just over the top and way higher than what you pay in a restaurant. I understand it’s expensive in tourist zones but 1x oyster for 90 kronor each is ridiculous, especially since we aren’t sitting in a 5 star restaurant. Anyway we went with the flow and ordered one crab leg and one sea urchin. Payed 550 kronor for the crab leg and 100 for the urchin. By the way, don’t waste your money on urchin at this place. The urchin tasted weird and had nothing to compete with the urchin we had in Japan before.

reviews.title: A little more than fish
reviews.text: Even if you're not hankering for  reindeer or whale salami, this is a fun place to stop.  It's almost the only place unless you want nearby McDonald's, 7 Eleven or other familiar chains.  There are stalls with arrays of beautifully-assembled rolls brimming with tiny shrimp and other seafood, also freshly-cooked fish dishes. Large cups of luscious berries and soft ice cream were also available.  Picnic tables behind the stalls made it easy for a group to gather foods from various places and eat together.  There are also full service restaurants in the area which is close to where cruise ships dock. There is a general place with toilets requiring Norwegian coins or credit cards (!) but people were holding doors open for one another.

reviews.title: A place to go but heavy on ur pockets
reviews.text:
Good place to go..arrays of fresh from the sea dishes...do have a try but be careful of the prices...a simple fish n chips might cost u 350kr...n for two like photos attached will drained ur purse of 700 kr
A friend ordered king crabs etc n the dish cost him 1500 kr...
Personally not a place to go for food.There r other joints in the building next to it...n there is a Tourist office where u can change ur money..
Sorry not for those on a tight budget.

reviews.title: Great Place and vibes
reviews.text: Great place to spend some time enjoying the vibe and buzz of the Bay Area lot of restaurant and flea market

reviews.title: Should be cheaper
reviews.text: Prices from spaceship. Instead of fresh i got smelly shrimps You have to be carefull... Not recommended

reviews.title: Is ok - but not excellent
reviews.text:
One of the worlds leading public markets for north sea fish and seafods, very interesting and nice - must visit.
But the food is really bit touristic, not 100% no.
There are a big range food places and the other nearby under roof fish market with their restaurants rival strongly, both in range of fish (super fresh !!) and seafods and the cooking way. the tent restaurants are full of guests and yes is one experience but there is so much more around nearby.

reviews.title: Frantic and fun
reviews.text: A section of the city by the wharf with vendors that specialize in every conceivable form of seafood. Crabs, shrimps, lobsters, scallops, fish, you name it they have it.  If it comes out of the sea they have it either fresh or cooked.  A true seafood lovers dream.

reviews.title: Fish by the Sea
reviews.text: "Don't eat the fish unless you can see the sea" :)  The fish market in Bergen is in the harbour in the center of town. Bustling with vendors of King Crab, Scallops, Salmon, Monk etc. Pick your food that is still living and have it cooked for your meal! Great place at a great price!

reviews.title: Salmon & blueberries
reviews.text:
The melting pot of the town, don't miss it! 
I recommend freshly grilled salmon and a "takeaway" cup of blueberries for a nice walk afterwards.

reviews.title: Interesting but avoid the lunch in here
reviews.text:
We had a few walks here. 
Interesting place but the lunches cooked in it aren’t worth the price, you get a plate full of vegetables, mostly onions, salad  and peppers, and a little bit of fish for 25€ each. It’s better to go in one if the little restaurants with the menu for  lunch.

reviews.title: Fun but a bit over hyped
reviews.text: If you are not afraid to eat fish prepared outside then you might enjoy this one block of fish sales and seafood dining. There are tanks of king crab and lobsters and row after row of fresh fish to buy. There are sit down tables for a variety of paella and other shrimp and seafood fry. We passed on eating there.

reviews.title: Tourist trap but,....
reviews.text:
It’s a definite tourist trap 
But hey your a tourist
Plan to get a fresh catch Neil down by the docks asked for a beer as well

reviews.title: Great way to 'shop' for lunch or dinner
reviews.text: The noisy, smelly fish market is the place to check out the multitude of fish/shellfish/seafood brought into Bergen by the fishermen and either have them cook it up for you on the spot, or take home to do yourself.  Everything from King crab legs, monkfish, salmon and more!  Lots of choice and you can even have berries for dessert (another stall) in summer!

reviews.title: Beautiful clean and amazing fish market
reviews.text: We started our day in Bergen after we got off the cruise ship at the fish market. It’s a bunch of stalls covered with a red covering. The place is clean and it is a pleasure to walk through. My only regret was we came just after breakfast so did not have a chance to try any of the crab, lobster , salmon or other tasty fish.

reviews.title: Nice to walk by, but pricey
reviews.text: It was nice to walk by and take some photos, but the menu can be pricey.  Which is above the Norway prices as everything here is pretty touristy.

reviews.title: Returned again and again
reviews.text: They had everything Norwegian and fishy.  So many fish and crustaceans I had never seen or eaten.  And old favorites like Monk fish. 11 types of caviar.  Cod soup and a kind of Paella Norwegian style.  The prices were not set so we had to shop around, but we bought jam, and sausage and caviar as well as a lunch- Bergen fish soup and a dinner. Oh, and a snack of a Reindeer (caribou to US) hot dog which was extremely tasty.

reviews.title: Good wandering
reviews.text: Nice area to stroll by the various stalls.  We had some fish and chips and a fish cake which were delicious and a lox bagel which was just OK (no cream cheese, so felt a bit dry).

reviews.title: Seafood heaven
reviews.text: Vibrant and tasty place to go.  You can get seafood prepared many different ways here.  First time I saw whale meat.   Did not get to try it. The vendors are super friendly and multi lingual.

reviews.title: Not much charm left.
reviews.text: A touristtrap that doesn't have much of the charm it used to have when live fish was being sold.Ok to walk thru and see this on the way to or from Bryggen or Fløyen.

reviews.title: Amazing place to just wonder.
reviews.text: We just walked and looked at the stalls we spoke to the friendly stall holders. As we were on a cruise we were unable to purchase the stunning fresh fish. Highly recommended

reviews.title: If in Bergen
reviews.text: You will have to try this place, but it is a tourist trap.  We had lunch only once and it was enough.  We ate at Age Sorensen Fish Stand.  The crab was too dry, the portion very small and the price was high for what we ate.  If you choose crab you think you will get a big piece (as they are displayed) , but it was not the case.  There are other restaurants with better food, service and prices close by.

reviews.title: Fish, fish and more fish!
reviews.text:
What an experience it was to walk through the fish market!  Fish of all kinds!  After doing the Floibanen, we decided it was time for dinner.  Fortunately there was a McDonald's nearby for the 3 kids on our group of 8!

We 5 adults had our choice of so many different kinds of fish, it was difficult to decide.
I got the jumbo (6 inch long) shrimp but found it very messy to eat.  It was okay.

reviews.title: A must-see while in Bergen.  Have a great lunch or authentic dinner there, too!
reviews.text: Live and eat among the locals at this historic fish market in the center of Bergen, steps from the Hanseatic market.  I’ve never seen crab legs the size of the ones I saw here.  All varieties of seafood for sale and several restaurants onsite to enjoy the Norwegian delicacies.  DO NOT miss if you are in Bergen.

reviews.title: King Crab Lunch
reviews.text: Fantastic fresh fish what’s not to like ? Very busy atmospheric venue. Had my first experience of King crab here. So so fresh. Services was prompt considering how busy this restaurant was. I’d like to go here in the evening the next time.

reviews.title: TRY SOMETHING DIFFERENT
reviews.text:
This if definitely a touristy place. I'm pretty confident very little locals come here, and I'm highly confident most of the people there are tourists. Since most are tourist including myself, the price of the seafood are on the high side. But I can't deny the quality of the food. Probably the best smoked salmon I've ever had in my life. 
One thing you should do is try something different. We tried the whale meat, which of course is controversial. 
Overall, a unique experience, never have I seen such enormous crabs in my life. Be prepared to have deep pockets if you intend to have a filling meal here in Bergen Fish Market.

reviews.title: Amazing to see 😁
reviews.text:
We walked round the fish market whilst here.. Wow so many different types they were great to see! They sell the fish fresh also they sell cooked like in paella 🥘 
Highly recommend if your in the town 😁

reviews.title: Amazing variety of fish and seafood
reviews.text:
We initially weren't sure what the covered stalls were from across the road and decided to investigate what was so popular, and discovered several food stalls and fishmongers. 

It seemed that local people were buying fish and seafood from the fishmongers to take home, while tourists and non-locals were eating at the tables provided - a real mix of everything fish and seafood lovers could wish for.

Unfortunately we had already eaten by the time we visited, but will definitely eat there, should we find ourselves in Bergen again!

reviews.title: Great to walk through and explore. Very expensive!
reviews.text:
A must go while in Bergen but buying anything here will cost more than other places. The fish stands are extremely high quality and have amazing selection of seafood, especially smoked salmon, whale and cod. You can also find prepared meals here (ie paella, fried fish, sandwiches, etc) and other smoked meats, such as reindeer, whale and moose. 

Great location right at the bottom of the harbor by city center and one of my favorite spots in Bergen. Just look for the red tents and have fun exploring!!!

reviews.title: Spectacular fish market
reviews.text:
Very exciting and colourful fish market at Bergen.
We had dinner there later in the evening.
The whale steak was unique. May never ate it again. 
Expensive place. Crowded. Reasonable service. 
Tourists everywhere

reviews.title: Fish market... just a fish market
reviews.text: I love fish markets, and maybe it is nice to be there early in the morning, but around 11 am it’s just a fish market. And yes, I love to see breiflabben. ;-)

reviews.title: Super
reviews.text: Fantastic place with a soul. If you come to Bergen and just don't visit this place, you'll never know what you missed. Nice people and fantastic food.

reviews.title: Tourist thing to do
reviews.text:
I enjoyed the fish market. Great fresh seafood and plenty of places to get a quick/fresh lunch. A lot of the vendors offered free samples of things which was nice because a lot of it I had never tried before like whale, reindeer and moose. 

It is a bit of a tourist trap and as such can be a little pricey. Although, when in Bergen, the fish market is a must see. Especially the outdoor one in the summer.

reviews.title: Small, nothing special and expensive
reviews.text: This is a small fish market and it did not have anything special about it.  The prices were rather high.  You have to pass through here on your way to the tourism office which is next door otherwise I would not make a special trip to see this market.

reviews.title: Food
reviews.text: Most amazing place if you are looking for fresh seafood. The choice is so vast and they cater to all languages. The cooking is done right in front of you and to your choice. It is expensive but worth every  krone spent. The Restaurent’s are simple but food is great. Must stop if you are a foodie who loves sea food

name: Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf
ranking_subcategory: #6 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #6 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #6 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: City Sightseeing Bergen Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour
Walk with a Witch in 16th Century Bergen Audio Tour by VoiceMap
Private customizable Tour to Sognefjord and Flåm from Bergen
Best Views of Bergen - Segway Day Tour
Food and Culture walk

reviews.title: Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf
reviews.text: The iconic picture of the Bryggen front is a thing of the past. It's all stores now catering to tourists. To be fair it was pretty touristy back in 2006 when we first visited Bergen but with proliferation of the cruise industry it became a tourist promenade. Bergen overall disappointed this time. It turned into a tourist hub and thus lost its former charm.

reviews.title: FORMER CITY OF THE GERMAN MERCHANTS UNMARRIED CENTURY XIII IN BERGEN
reviews.text: Restaurants, housing, shops museums, crafts. Beautiful and historic enclave where its walls, stairs, rooms, ceilings smell of the past. With its narrow streets, its balconies. All in wood, where you can see how the pieces of wood are missing or destroyed over time are hand-replaced to follow this wonderful heritage of humanity.

reviews.title: OK, but not fantastic
reviews.text:
The old wooden houses give a nice impression, and are typical for many Norwegian coastal towns.

It is ironic that Bergen plays up the Hanseatic story, since it was not even an official Hansa town, just a simple trading post.

Today, the harbor is mainly a food court and a giant tourist shopping mall...

reviews.title: Bryggen tour, Hanseatic Museum, Bryggen Museum, St Mary Church
reviews.text:
Excellent guides, who give interest inside in the history of the place, living conditions, architectural skills, merchant life aso.
The Church has unique treasures, it was not allowed to take photos, so we stayed longer to contemplate them.
Merchant routes in the Middle Age were mapped as well as firestorms, destroying regularly the city of Bergen

reviews.title: Don’t Let the Crowds Stop You
reviews.text: Take the time to meander the streets, the fort, and along the waterfront. Bergen is lovely though the crowds are overwhelming, especially when a cruise ship is in. We steered clear of the shops full of tchotchkes and marveled at the  charming back alleys and streets. We also wandered over to the  Nordnes Peninsula, which we found just as charming and much less crowded.

reviews.title: Colourful buildings with cultural heritage hidden behind
reviews.text: This row of colourful buildings capture your eyes whenever you turn the corner in this area.  Situated a little before the funicular we visited it after going up the mountain.  These shops are quirky, the floors can be uneven, small in some cases but full of beautiful merchandise.  Some of these shops extend a long way back and you can exit or enter from a door at the side which brings you out into the older buildings which are hidden behind. There is a lovely are just outside where you can sit and watch the boats and ships in the harbour.  Plenty of places to eat.  We found this well worth a wee visit.  To see the narrow alleyways and twisting staircases was amazing.

reviews.title: Boring place
reviews.text:
Nothing to see or to do...
The city is full of drugs edict. Needles r in the streets. I wes over welm from the big numders of junkis...

reviews.title: Good preservation of important cultural heritage
reviews.text:
These colourful buildings occupy a prominent location on the harbour front and extend along narrow alleyways to the rear. The shops at the front are impressive but since their interiors in no way reflect the age and history of the place they are, to my mind, a lost opportunity. 

Once you go behind into the alleyways you get a real sense of the history and given the number of tourists you get a feel of what would have been a very busy commercial district.

reviews.title: good place
reviews.text: Typical picture postcard place. There will be lot of tourists from all over clicking pictures with the beautifully colored building in the backdrop of the sea

reviews.title: History & Culture Everywhere
reviews.text: Spent a complete day visiting this unique city.  Although Norway's second largest city it doesn't seem big at all.  Walk the famous warf and visit the historical wooden buildings and the shops within.  We were,icky to be in town for the conclusion of the "tall ships" festival and races.

reviews.title: THE COLOURS AND THE HISTORY
reviews.text: Bergren became rich in the middle ages as part of the Hanseatic League, a collection of northern European cities and guild organized to protect their commercial interests. This feature was a core part of the World Heritage Site designation for the area. The colours of the buildings are bright and contrasting. Alley ways away from the wharf show more of the nitty gritty part of such vast commercialism. You can take boat rides from here, amble about, have a drink or a meal, appreciating the history of the place. Several museums expand upon the role of the Hanseatic League.

reviews.title: Cruise to norway/bergen
reviews.text: Bergen is such a wonderful place, loads to see and do, well worth a visit to fish Market, funicular, Christmas shop etc, places to sit and eat on the front looking over the water

reviews.title: A very compact historical area
reviews.text: Our tour group visited the Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf. For its importance in history and commerce, it is a very small area - maybe two city blocks. I recommend strongly taking a guided tour - there is a lot of history down every alleyway. A second reason for getting a guide is that most of the museums related to the Hanseatic League are closed, undergoing renovation.  After the tour you can go back and visit the many shops in the area.

reviews.title: Very nice
reviews.text:
Dear friends,

its really beautiful to walk in this area, just don't forget an umbrella and good walking shoes and a long rain coat to keep you dry.

reviews.title: Fun to walk but busy
reviews.text:
The area is small at only about one city block.  The old wooden buildings are very quaint.  The alleys between the buildings make for nice strolling.  There are different types of shops, many with good quality merchandise.  

If you can avoid the busiest times of the day, this area is worth an hour or two of your time.

reviews.title: What an amazing experience back into the middle age period!
reviews.text:
This part of Bergen into the UNESCO list worth the visit to Bergen.
It push you back into the middle age period when sailing boat trade into the haven w/ different goods.
Even new shops cannot trouble that impression because there is no obvious signs of modern time.

reviews.title: Busy Area of Bergen
reviews.text:
Depending on time of year the Wharf area can be very congested. One of the main gathering spots for travelers. Easy walk from Cruise Line Terminals, maybe 10 minutes depending on pace. Restaurants, shops and tourist center all within 10-15 minute walks. 

Hope on/off buses are right at the terminal as well.

reviews.title: Expected More
reviews.text: Bryggen Wharf was nice, but not as nice as many other European port cities (e.g. Nyhavn in Copenhagen).  Buildings are old and historic but there are not many of them.

reviews.title: Should visit
reviews.text: If you’re here, you should visit, especially when sunny, unfortunate it was raining, but can imagine it’s amazing a nice day. Walk around and take something to eat next at the fish market! ☺️

reviews.title: Like a Picture Postcard
reviews.text: A must visit place in Bergen, very lively and fun. The fish market offered lots of souvenirs for friends and family back home, and tons of free tastes.

reviews.title: Trademark of Bergen
reviews.text: Bryggen is a must see when in Bergen. You can’t miss it when down by the harbor. Lots of things to see here in way of Bergen heritage. Door on door souvenir shops. Bryggen Husflid is a great souvenir shop and the cheapest of them all, with a good selection of everything, from magnets, clothing, Christmas baubles and mugs. Walk between the buildings to find more hidden heritage at the back. At the Bryggen harbor front there are many outdoor cafes for a short rest and with normal Norwegian prices. Thee are also a few museums situated here.

reviews.title: Check Out Every Alley
reviews.text: Neat piece of history, even if only part of it is left. Need to zig zag up and down every alley and check out the interiors. Many of the stores go back really far inside through what I have to assume is a collection of buildings now linked. Check out the stairs to the Christmas shop, far right if looking from the water side.

reviews.title: The wharf is too touristy, but walk the back streets also
reviews.text: The UN World Heritage listing Bryggen (the wharf) has old buildings. However, nearly all the shops there are just tourist shops with good stuff as well as tourist junk. Between the buildings there are small narrow alleys. Make sure you walk there also. There is plenty to see there with museums, art galleries, cute open spaces. And don’t forget to look up at the buildings themselves.  They are really interesting!

reviews.title: Make sure to walk through to the back area
reviews.text: Beautiful Norwegian buildings from the front and lots of art gallery’s / cool shops if you wander through to the back.

reviews.title: Quaintly beautiful!
reviews.text: The wharf is made up of old buildings of various colors. It looks so pretty and quaint. There is a part that is truly very old and very interesting to walk through. Across the street is the fishing booths and other items. A very pleasant way to spend a few hours.

reviews.title: Very Scenic - But Busy!
reviews.text: Yes, the area along the waterfront is very scenic.  But it is, also, very busy - especially on a nice sunny day.  Walk a few blocks away from the waterfront area and one will see a quieter, and perhaps more realistic view of daily life in contemporary Bergen.

reviews.title: Lovely but not cheap
reviews.text: Enjoyable couple of hours wander around the wooden built shops and bars of Bryggen. Interesting timbered construction, eclectic groups of shops - two interesting jewellers - and several outdoor and indoor bars. Beer only £10 a pint for local brews, cheap for Norway.

reviews.title: Worth a walk around the old part of town
reviews.text: The Germans controlled this area of warehouses during the heyday of the Hanseatic League. Apprentices worked in unheated space to ship “stockfish” (air-dried Atlantic cod) all over Europe. A pleasant walk around this area, now filled with small shops and a few museums.

reviews.title: Pretty touristy
reviews.text: Worth a stroll around for the photo ops! There was a nice Christmas shop that had reasonably priced decorations, was worth the walk to the 3rd floor! Plenty of cafes and souvenir shops.

reviews.title: Must see in Bergen
reviews.text: From the left side of the wharf this looks like a bunch of old buildings. However when visited up close, these buildings have many narrow and interesting alleys

reviews.title: A place oozing with charm and energy
reviews.text:
As we strolled through this location of beautiful shops and remnants of a past age, the energy of the Hanseatic  League 
is inspirational.

A must visit.

reviews.title: Beautiful historic area, but garbage is everywhere
reviews.text:
No doubt, this section of Bergen is picturesque, but it felt neglected to us. It was easily the dirtiest place we had ever visited. Even the WWII memorial was literally filled with garbage. Norway sacrificed so much in that war that it seems so wrong to neglect this important part of Bergen’s history. 
We understand that it is probably the visitors, who are mostly responsible for the trash on the streets, we could not possibly blame the Norwegians for disrespecting their own heritage, but something must be done. An education campaign, more sanitation staff, stronger law enforcement are just some ideas that come to mind.

reviews.title: Symphatic are for walking arround
reviews.text: In the Hanseviertel Bergen you can walk arround. There are a lot of sightseeings, shops, pubs and restaurants.

reviews.title: Must see this !
reviews.text:
This is what gives Bergen its character and it’s heart.
Walk around and visit the Brugge Museum. Walk around to the other small museum which tell you the history of the area.

reviews.title: Delightful historical area.
reviews.text: Charming area of historical buildings on the wharf. They are wooden buildings very close together which now house shops of Norwegian products. It was nice to wander through the area then go to the fish market.

reviews.title: very colorful and is the photo you always see in travel guides.
reviews.text: there are shops and eateries and just looking at all the ships makes it a free and fun hour or two.  you can also take tours from the water.

reviews.title: Much more that the tourist shops out front
reviews.text: The tourist shops are just the fronts of the remaining buildings. We signed up for the tour, and heard the story of the history of Bryggen, and walked through the warren of buildings that remain.

reviews.title: The heart of Bergen-a delight that can't be missed
reviews.text:
Bryggen at Bergen

Bryggen is the UNESCO’s World Heritage site within Bergen. It is the collection  of  the brightly colored wooden shops by the harbor.  The buildings are visually and historically interesting  and the shops have some very nice products to consider.  The shops had art, souvenirs, wool products, fishing gear, and snacks.  We had time to wander through it several days and found it to be quite pleasant.

reviews.title: Quaint area
reviews.text: Quaint area. Wonderful fish market, restaurants and coffee shops. Great shopping area where we found lovely Norwegian sweaters. All the locals were very friendly and open to share. We even got a little lesson in Norwegian from a local clerk in a children’s store. Great fun

reviews.title: Picturesque Buildings
