reviews.text: The Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf is a nice walkable area with picturesque gabled wooden buildings that were once used as warehouses by the Hanseatic League.  The buildings now house museums, shops, restaurants and pubs, and is a great area for people-watching.  The fish market and funicular to Mt Floyen are also nearby.  Be prepared to walk around in the rain as Bergen rains around 240 days/year.  Despite the rain, it’s a nice place to explore.  There are guided walking tours, but we enjoyed exploring the area on our own.

reviews.title: Picture perfect!
reviews.text:
This is an historic district in Bergen and is on Unesco's World Heritage List.  Although there were many fires over the centuries, these beautiful wooden houses were always rebuilt along the same type of building plans and techniques.  So, take the time for some pictures of these beautiful buildings along the Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf.  It's a great place to find something to eat or just people-watch. The fish market and funicular are within a couple mins walk.  There other attractions within walking distance.  

Getting to city centre from cruise ship.

Exit the port, go to the right and pass the sightseeing buses.  You will also see a sign pointing to "Sentrum," which is the city centre.  Once you get to fork in the road, stay to the right.  You will soon come upon these beautiful buildings/houses on your left.  If you continue pass the houses, the fish market is on your right and the way to the funicular is on your left...go up the street between the two big buildings on the corner.  The building on the right says; "Ann Madam."

reviews.title: Still don’t loose the feeling
reviews.text: What would you do when the area is getting dark, shops are closed for XMas Holiday and nobody is around to be asked ? Yeaah we took pictures and don’t wanna miss a thing eventhough it’s very cold and windy. Turned out had a nice experience to celebrate the night.

reviews.title: What a place for pictures
reviews.text: If for no other reason go for the picture possibilities but it is a great place to people watch. It is very crowded but the scenery is good and it is a lively place. The fish market is interesting also.

reviews.title: Beautiful Waterfront
reviews.text: One of the iconic sites in town, the lovely waterfront with handsome boats and pretty wooden houses.  Very picturesque.

reviews.title: One of the truly Norwegian places to see in Bergen!
reviews.text: Having seen a bit of Norway, I thought that the Byggen Wharf was one of the places that I thought captured the essence of Norwegian architecture and culture.  It reminded me a bit of the guild houses in Bruges, Belgium and other similar places.  Still it has its own unique charm and there are lots of local shops to stop in at and this area makes a terrific photo op.

reviews.title: incredible for wandering and exploring
reviews.text: We spent at least an hour having coffee at one of the many cafes in the Hanseatic Wharf area, and then we explored the many artisans and shops within the wharf district.  Great, easy walking, close to the fish market, which is also well worth seeing.  We had a glass of wine and a cheese plate at the Radisson Blu for lunch and it was a gorgeous day for very little money.

reviews.title: Atmospheric
reviews.text: We first visited about 9.30sh on our way into town. Calm and beautiful. Very interesting craft and gift shops just waking up. We passed back that way late afternoon and the atmosphere was bright and bustling heaving with people on a glorious sunny day. Still a great place so whatever time of day just walk behind the front to still find old Bergen.

reviews.title: A beautiful area of the waterfront with an intersting history
reviews.text: Facing on to the main fjord these long houses, as they are called, offer a glimpse of Bergan in the past.  Now a variety of shops and restaurants, if you cut up the side passages you can see how far back these buildings stretch, hence the name long  houses.  Originally occupied by Germain traders they formed part of the Hanseatic trading empire.

reviews.title: Bryggen.
reviews.text: Wonderful historic area to explore. Colourful old buildings with alleyways and balconies, art shops etc..Do not miss this.

reviews.title: Awesome view along harbour
reviews.text: This is a place where you walk,shop,sit eat and enjoy the colourfull buildings of typical conical shaped buildings,see ships in the harbour.We werre on a group  tour.so saw from bus and had stops to take colorful photos.Enjoyed panorama of the harbour town.

reviews.title: GREAT HISTORIC CENTRE
reviews.text: A GREAT PLACE to wander through the alley ways & immerse yourself in history. Both inside & out this is amust see place

reviews.title: The Hanseatic League
reviews.text: The Hanseatic League was a trading company in the 13-14 hundreds. They came to Bergen to trade grain for dried fish. This area of Bergen still has some original:reconstructed buildings and a museum. There is a tour telling you about the League that ends at and includes the museum. This is a lively area to wander around. Today the buildings house craftspeople selling woodblock prints, fishing equipment and lots of knitted products. Great to walk around the narrow walkways and see the buildings. Not great for wheelchairs.

reviews.title: Good little souvenir place
reviews.text: This area is super cute and full of rich history.  It is neat to see the slanted stair cases, the old floors, and the vibrant colors.  It really felt like you stepped into history.  Plus, if you are a souvenir lover, this is the best place to go!!  Full of options.  And if you're a rock lover, there is a little rock shop through the alleyway and in the back of Bryggen with locals rocks and minerals.

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: This was a great place to walk around. Plenty of shops to look round.  Get very busy in the mornings when the cruise ships are in.

reviews.title: Beautiful and Active Harbour
reviews.text: We would sometimes just go sit by the harbour and enjoy the view.  Best seen from the tourist information side of the harbour.  One day we even enjoyed the boisterous arrival of a Pirate ship!

reviews.title: Living History
reviews.text: There are plenty of places where you can go to see old buildings, but these are still in use, which makes them that much more enjoyable.  Walking around through the narrow alleys and courtyards into the little shops felt like a trip through time.

reviews.title: scandinavia
reviews.text: we took a walking tour which made this area more interesting.  These old buildings are now mainly restaurants, pubs and business.  it is very crowded .  it used to be where the german merchants had their shops - only men (up to 400) lived here and worked here - I believe he said that because they were wood no stoves or fires were allowed -- can't even imagine.  they slept in one room and stored their products (fish etc) in the other.  must have been quite the place.  I would recommend a walking tour.

reviews.title: Lovely
reviews.text: Picture perfect Bergen on the wharf.  Great place to walk, shop and enjoy the view.  Wander thru the shops, lots of local artists.

reviews.title: Pretty Area
reviews.text:
The Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf is a collection of historic buildings along the waterfront in Bergen.  The history of the buildings as used for the Hanseatic League housing tradesmen and their shops is interesting.  Nowadays, though, the buildings mainly house shops selling somewhat overpriced merchandise.  There are some exceptions (e.g. coffee shops and restaurants).

Overall, though, the Bryggen is really pretty.  The buildings are colorful and make for awesome pictures.  Wandering around the uneven wooden planks was fun and different.  And I enjoyed the time we spent in the area.

There are some museums in and around the Bryggen.  Unfortunately at the time we visited they were all closed (I believe this is mostly due to remodeling).  I do think the area would be more interesting with more historic background or a guided tour.

If you are in Bergen, you're going to visit the Bryggen.  It's a good place to spend some time wandering around enjoying the sights.

reviews.title: Lovely Bergen waterfront!
reviews.text:
Enjoyed wandering around the Bryggen waterfront area of Bergen.  The fun part is exploring the wooden alleys between the Main Street buildings.
There are tons of shops and places to have some excellent Norwegian beer on the promenade.
Great place to stroll and stop for a drink!

reviews.title: Helen Campbell
reviews.text:
Looked forward very much to visit the harbour area
We were not disappointed!
Brilliant colourful quayside

reviews.title: Trademark of Bryggen
reviews.text: While visiting the Bryggen area one gets a good view of the skyline and the historic buildings for which Bryggen is known for. These multicoloured buildings give a special character to the whole landscape.

reviews.title: Old Nordic buildings.
reviews.text: The quirky buildings add character to the Bergen waterfront and most are now souvenir/craft shops. The traditional knitwear is lovely to look at but very expensive. We had three cruise ships in port the day that we were there which made it a huge struggle to get in and out of the shops.

reviews.title: Historic and special
reviews.text: Before going there I thought that there are only nice colourful facades and never expected that thete is a complete quarter of wooden buildings with restaurants, shops, workshops and museum. Impressive is the age of those buildingds and their very good condition, taking into account that they are made of wood!

reviews.title: Great spot to relax
reviews.text: This is a beautiful and historic area. Lots of little shops and outdoor cafes to sit and enjoy the surrounds. Close to the cruise terminal so it’s a quick walk.

reviews.title: Beautiful old buildings
reviews.text: Modernized with lots of shops and restaurants.  Pretty across the water.  Interesting little alleys behind the storefronts.

reviews.title: Nice walkable wharf
reviews.text: This is a nice wharf that has good views. There are restaurants and shops all around. There are also a few historic sites that you can go to.

reviews.title: Wharf seeing
reviews.text: It's a wharf with boats, water views, tourists, markets, and everything you might expect at a wharf; it just happens to be in Norway. Overall, it's fine. There are a lot of tourists but wharf seeing! There's one row of stalls serving seafood dishes, and the day I went, which was Saturday, there was a small farmers market near the famous row of wooden homes that is featured in most pictures from Bergen. There was also music playing and it was festive. Overall, visit if you are in Bergen.

reviews.title: Worthy of UNESCO designation
reviews.text: Walk thru the entire "village" and enjoy history. Excellent Hanseatic museum to educate visitors. School house from 1666 and buildings from the Hanseatic era provide a close up look into the past. Well worth the visit.

reviews.title: Great area
reviews.text: Lovely wharf with lots of shops, restaurants and bars. Some of the buildings are the fabulous old style Norway type houses. There are several cafes, bars with nice views overlooking the harbour. There is also an excellent fish market most days where you can get food to sit down or takeaway.

reviews.title: Simple and beutiful
reviews.text: Nice place to visit, actually, the most important place to see while in Bergen. Friendly and relaxing atmosphere, people walking by or sitting and drinking beer, buying souvenirs... it is for free, of course, to walk and enjoy the sun (if you are lucky like us), watch the sea and boats, listen to the cries of the seagulls... Colorful houses are beautiful, although a bit like movie scenery :)

reviews.title: A must visit in Bergen
reviews.text: Think of Bergen and these coloured wooden houses come to mind. The area isn't as big as we expected, but it's a must see. Marvel at how unlevel the buildings and stairs are. Some nice workshops and tourist shops lie behind the wooden buildings. Well worth a slow amble round, although not a lot to actually do.

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text:
This is soul of Bergen.
Well maintained colourful buildings.
It was nice to walk in the narrow historical lanes.
Great.

reviews.title: Heritage preserved
reviews.text:
Without Bryggen,  Bergen is incomplete. 
Old Heritage kept Alive with Touch of class.
Their r inside narrow  lanes with shops to see lot of good but Expensive stuff. Baker Rest serves Good Coffee and Snackss. U cross over to other side of Harbour and Take a photo from that side, its Amazing.

reviews.title: Old wooden buildings
reviews.text: The old wooden buildings have been very well preserved and it’s worth going up the quiet alleys and lanes behind the Main Street to get a close look at the many and various interesting buildings. There’s a great sense of history,  but all are in use and  occupied by shops, cafés or other businesses.

reviews.title: Nice Historical walk
reviews.text:
Easy to get through quiet small streets, buildings are in good maintenance. 
It would be helpful if they provide historical information about the area and buildings. 
Note: The day I went, the museum was closed.

reviews.title: Quaint Area with Plenty of Shopping
reviews.text: If you are looking for shopping and/or restaurants (besides the Fish Market) this is the place to go.  We enjoyed walking the area, taking some pics, and poking our heads in the shops.

reviews.title: Lovely for a wander
reviews.text: We just wandered up and down the Bryggen. Weather was wet but still this place had charm and vibrancy. Yes it was busy with tourists but the shops are good and the atmosphere is great. Stopped off for a drink in a bar to escape the rain a bit.  Great place and very picturesque from every angle and in any weather. Great little snickets to wander down and admire the timber frames. Wouldn’t have missed it.

reviews.title: The surroundings of this area are happening
reviews.text: Bergen is a small little old town and this is one of the places that you see with big cruise ships parked around here.... there are so many people around it is fun to be in the evenings or you can say any time of the day because it is a happening area

reviews.title: It’s a UNESCO world heritage site for a good reason.
reviews.text:
I suspect all the reviews for this area are glowing.
We’ll add ours to the chorus.
Wonderful spot! A must visit.

reviews.title: Wet but interesting
reviews.text:
Very crowded and extremely wet but it was good to see the famous Bergen waterfront.
The historic timber buildings are striking and colourful even in the wet.

reviews.title: Brygge area of Bergen.
reviews.text: This area dates back many hundreds of years.  It is an interesting area to visit.  The staff at some of the information booths are very knowlegable and can give you the history of that section. If history is your interest, then make sure you go there.  If  your wife likes to shop, don't let her go!  There are lots of shops there.

reviews.title: Excellent, excellent, excellent.
reviews.text:
The whole area is breathtakingly beautiful.   
My tip is have a wander round the area, on the sea side and also land side.
The architecture is stunning.
For the finale explore the alleys.  Forget the shops (which are primarily artists) and admire the buildings.

reviews.title: Postcard of Bergen
reviews.text: Actually we had more expecations about this area of Bergen. It is not really a quarter, but a few wood houses that became stores or restaurants.

reviews.title: Nice place to walk
reviews.text: Lots of sights in this area, including the yachts moored,  restaurants,  and fish market. A real treat was an amazing sunset which doesn't happen that often we were told

reviews.title: Scenic
reviews.text: Walked down from near the train station to this area. Lovely port area with many fish market stalls- both to buy and to dine. Many gift shops and restaurants- loaded with Norway souvenirs and products. We spent some time sitting and watching the people go by. Not a good spot to visit in Bergen's 266 days of rain a year.

reviews.title: Very touristy and pricey. Can be crowed when the cruise ships arrive.
reviews.text: Very touristy and pricey. Can be crowded when the cruise ships arrive. Would suggest first thing in the morning or late evening.

reviews.title: Brilliant Bryggen
reviews.text: This street forms the iconic vision of Bergen. Set right on the waterside this street of colourful timber-framed houses is a must-see. All the shops are tourist traps and generally expensive, but then what isn't in Norway? The cafes along the main street are very popular and better service will be found up some of the alleyways between buildings which also house smaller establishments although the people watching is not so much fun as sitting on the quayside observing life in all its forms. There are some great interpretive boards explaining the devleopment of the site and where restoration works have been undertaken.

reviews.title: Very pretty
reviews.text: Very pretty old houses full of tourists. After a few days in the quieter fjords it was a shock to be among so many people again but the houses are well worth a look

reviews.title: Must see in Bergen
reviews.text: Bryggen is an Unesco World Heritage Site. It’s a classic part of Bergen with its colorful buildings along the wharf. The Hanseatic League of trading cities set up Bergen as a Hanseatic office. Some of the original wooden buildings still standing date to the early 1700s. It’s interesting how many of them seem to lean and sag but look solid at the same time. There is so much history here and the buildings are slowly being restored using traditional methods. Our walking tour took us through several of the buildings and I think having a guide will help you enjoy this area the most. And of course you will want to take several photos of the iconic view of these colorful buildings.

reviews.title: A busy town
reviews.text: This is where you will find the popular photographs of the old houses. Best to take photogaphs from arcoss the other side of the harbour

reviews.title: The heart of Bergen
reviews.text: I don't know what else I can add to what the others have said about this experience. The buildings on the outside are stunning, colorful, and very Nordic-looking. Behind the facades are old structures which lets you see how people lived years ago. If you are touring Bergen, even just for a day, this is a must-see. There are even places to eat and shop in the old structures. A very enjoyable experience for all.

reviews.title: Historic Bergen
reviews.text: Spent a wonderful few hours exploring the alleyways behind the shop frontages it was.lovely to see how the Norwegians are persevering their history with artisan craft en taking up residence in the shops and galleries within the Bryggen .  Disappointed with the Christmas shop situated on the third floor of a gift shop it is difficult to access and once accessed it is poorly labelled and items priced the assistance stops on the the second floor with no one available to ask for assistance we walked out without purchasing anything .  The rest of the Bryggen was a pure joy definitely a place to look closely at next time in Bergen

reviews.title: Stunning
reviews.text: Visited as part of our stop in Bergen. Looking at the front of the buildings you would not have a clue what is behind. The restoration that is being undertaken is amazing, as are the buildings. Shops and cafes have been sympathetically incorporated into the the buildings. There front of the area is pedestrianised, which is in front of the harbour area.

reviews.title: Lovely
reviews.text:
Beautiful buildings, evident history and lots of exploring to be done.

Clean. Tidy. Lots of shops.

Very quaint and memorable wharf.

reviews.title: First hand history
reviews.text:
Being part of a world heritage site to have had the opportunity to walk in the footsteps of ancient Hanseatic merchants on Norway’s national day was a real honour. The harbour was teeming with modern day merchants and mariners.
A true joy to be part of this fabulous celebration. 
A place where all my fellow Scots would feel at home 🇳🇴♥️🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿
Braw
Aye

reviews.title: Very scenic sight
reviews.text: At the root of the history of Bergen and situated where locals and visitors stroll. Very pleasant on a sunny day!

reviews.title: Interesting wharf
reviews.text:
We took a guided walk of the wharf and buildings. Very interesting history. The buildings are all leaning because of the unstable ground. 
We had lunch sitting outside looking at the water. 
Beautiful weather - the wharf was very enjoyable.

reviews.title: Charming row of colourful houses
reviews.text: Old part of Bergen which used to house hanseatic traders. Very charming to walk around and explore. Be sure to wander into little alleys as there are all sorts of cute shops hidden in between.

reviews.title: A treasure
reviews.text: Don’t miss visiting the Bryggen, buildings are so interesting and go down the little lanes as there are some fantastic galleries, silversmiths etc hiding down them.,

reviews.title: Beautiful little harbour
reviews.text: Take a walk around the waterfront and pass old wooden brightly coloured houses and small craft shops and little cafes. Very touristy but pleasant nonetheless even on a freezing winter day.

reviews.title: "Picture Postcard"
reviews.text:
Very picturesque harbourside walk.These very old wooden,individually painted houses epitomize what the average person imagines that Scandinavian riverside houses look like.
     You also find many small individual arts and crafts businesses along here offering a plethora of small souvenirs and trinkets for sale,well worth a "nosy"

reviews.title: Great tourist items
reviews.text: Nor too many people.  Walked the waterfront.  Some unique stuff in tourist shops.   Some repeats.   Toilets available.  Buildings are so cool.   Leaning all one direction.   Wow.   Beautiful day for shopping.

reviews.title: Beautiful historic harbour.
reviews.text: The Bryggen harbourside is bright and vibrant. Even in the rain. Full of people, shops, restaurants and cafe's. Lovely historic building. Look into the side alleys. Full of shops and workshops.

reviews.title: More than just Little Houses
reviews.text: These 300 + year old houses are full of history and very intriguing. It’s simply amazing they are still standing and mostly still constructed of timber used in the original build. You can smell the sweet timber scent when you walk down the corridors between the houses. These houses once served as storage for fish ready to sell to merchants, now they house boutique shops of all varieties.

reviews.title: Charming historic place to visit
reviews.text: This area is lovely to walk around and has a super story to its past and is quirky and charming. It’s full of little gift shops. There’s not much to do there but it’s pretty and s very iconic view from the harbour.

reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.text: We were very lucky to have a guided tour of this village.  The colours of the houses and shops are spectacular.  The guide told of a ship that was carrying explosives had engine trouble and was guided into the harbour.  A mark shows where the anchor still lies today.  The guide was very informative about the history.  Just to see the colours and sample some of the traditional pastries is worth a visit, then maybe chose to do a tour whilst there.  You won’t be disappointed!

reviews.title: One of the main attractions
reviews.text: A UNESCO world heritage site bryggen is of the main attractions while you are in bergen.  With its beautiful surroundings it's brimming with tourists.

reviews.title: Port side
reviews.text: The smell of fresh sea water and fish market, seagulls flying all over, yachts and boats coming in and going. If you don't live sea side like me, you should experience this.

reviews.title: Awesome day!
reviews.text: We arrived in Bergen and stayed at the Raddison right on Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf. We are just passing through here to get to our final destination, but wow I wish we could stay another night. There is a tone of walking and sight seeing. I’ve never seen a town that has this type of character. It looks like there is some good hiking, too. My complaint is that the shoppes were all closed because it’s “Sunday.” Not sure what that has to do with anything, as people still eat and shop on Sundays. I was also a bit surprised at how cold it was, but there’s nothing anyone can do about that. We still had a great time just looking at the outside of all the buildings. I liked how the sun was still out at 9:30 pm, making it feel like the day was longer. We did’t eat because prices are 3-4X what they are in the southeast US, but we did see a lot of places that looked really good and had a fun atmosphere if you are a foodie or want to splurge.

reviews.title: Fantastic piece of Bergen city to enjoy from start to finish!
reviews.text: Bryggen is a definite landmark in Bergen and a walk back and forth here can be done more than once a day. The houses leaning onto one another stretching towards the sky with their colours is just so calming and nice. A must place to see when in Norway on the west coast. Very highly recommendable and there are many really nice places to eat as well. Traditional food prepared and served with style. GO!

reviews.title: Full of character
reviews.text: Though a bit of a tourist trap this Unesco World Building Heritage site is a must to see,just to wander around this well preserved old area with its colourful wooden shops,cafe's A nice area just to sit back with a beer ( cost between £8 - £9 soft drink about £4 ) if you can get a seat always packed and admire the harbour views and the different  ships moored up

reviews.title: A UNESCO World Heritage Site
reviews.text: This beautiful old area of Bergen is symbolic and not to be missed. Outdoor bars and cafes are always packed.

reviews.title: Spend Your NOK Here
reviews.text: When in Bergen, if you have spare Krone, you'll want to spend them here.  Not only can you find some gorgeous Norwegian sweaters, you'll enjoy the historical aspect of the venue, as well.  We bought plenty of woolen Christmas gifts for our adult kids while exploring the Wharf, and we also enjoyed seeing the beautiful ships docked in port.  It's a quick walk from the pier where cruise ships dock, so there's no excuse to miss out on this UNESCO site.  Go.  Shop.  Bring plenty of Krone.  And take a look around while you're walking.  You'll see leaning wooden buildings and colorful carved wooden figures hanging out on the store fronts.  (My fave is the unicorn, but the stag's head is a close second.  Word has it that these were added several centuries ago so that illiterate German workers could find places without having to read the native language.)

reviews.title: Just really cool
reviews.text: I can see why this is heritage sight.  As you walk through the buildings and alleys, you really get a sense of the past, and of the beauty of the city, situated as it is on the water.  Walking through the alleyways gives you a real sense of discovery and, frankly, it's just really a cool, chill thing to do.  Some of the shops are interesting and unique- worth popping your head in for a look.

reviews.title: Explore Bryggen as well as the Wharf
reviews.text: One of our favorite parts while exploring Bergen. Learn the history of this Hanseatic Village at the Bryggens Museum and then walk along the water to see the beautiful colorful Bryggen store fronts and restaurants. I also recommend walking around the block to the back of the Bryggen homes to explore how they all connect.

reviews.title: A great touch of UNESCO world heritage
reviews.text: The Bryggen Wharf is an amazing historical place to visit. With the colourful authentic wooden houses and small handicraft shops, it gives you a real feeling of visiting the 14th century.

reviews.title: Quaint wooden cottages in line and colourful.
reviews.text: This is a UNESCO world heritage site with some restaurants and souvenir shops. But just looking at the colorful cottages in the evening sun is a delight.

reviews.title: Just a wee bit different from Edinburgh
reviews.text:
Well  preserved buildings,  wooden buildings with some quite quirky shops. although  quite expensive. Did some exploring down the side streets  which were 
very picturesque

reviews.title: Interesting, but not outstanding
reviews.text: The old buildings are wonderfully preserved, but we had trouble discovering anything interactive or particularly informative about the history of the place

reviews.title: Great to explore!
reviews.text: Enjoyable hour or so spent exploring the alleys along the wharf. Fascinating architecture and some nice little shops for souvenirs. Quite a few of the shops were shut as it’s out of season still but enough were open and it was nice to soak up the atmosphere without hoards of tourists!

reviews.title: Loved roaming here
reviews.text: The old buildings and laneways are beautifully preserved and still functional businesses. View across the harbour on a cold winter’s night is delightful.

reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.text:
Today there are 62 buildings remain (after may fires) of this former Hanseatic  trading empire from the 14th  to mid-16th century. The houses are really well preserved and maintained.
This site is classed on the UNESCO world heritage list

reviews.title: must see
reviews.text: Hopefully the clouds will break at some point for the iconic photo of this lovely street.  Worth exploring the shops.  We walked it twice.  Its a short excursion if you are tight for time.

reviews.title: Stunning History
reviews.text:
Best part of Bergen? Old wooden buildings sensitivity restored and some historic, some offices, some artisan shops, some cafes
, some gift shops. In all well worth a visit.

reviews.title: It's neat to see after seeing it in pictures
reviews.text: I was so looking forward to seeing the wharf that I had seen in pictures and I have some great pictures of my own to show for it!  There are some restaurants and shops in these buildings, and it is worth meandering around the back to find some other shops--there is a Christmas shop there, too.

reviews.title: Historic site well worth an extended visit.
reviews.text: The museum is in the right-most building as you are facing the wharf.  The museum is quite old and kept intact with many rooms and bunks giving a real feel for like in the seventeenth century.  The historic floors and walls are delightfully wobbly and dark with photos and other information on the walls.  I really love the feel of this place, very far from the tourist shops in most of the buildings.  There is very poor authentic lighting throughout, so I regret not having a good camera and flash for photographs.  There are narrow stairs in places, so there is limited handicap access.

reviews.title: Beautiful colourful harbour
reviews.text: It so brilliant arriving in Bergen and seeing the colourful harbour for the first time.  March was a great time to go because it was pretty quiet.  One of the houses is having some work done at the moment so is covered in plastic.  The little alley ways behind the harbour are lovely to wander around.

reviews.title: Impressine World Heritage Site
reviews.text: This is incredibly impressive and well l preserved. It is the only area of Hanseatic buildings left in the world. Bergen was one of the Hanseatic ports and provided salted fish for vast areas and of Europe. Do walk behind the shop fronts up the narrow alleyways and marvel at the amazing wooden structures including flooring of wood throughout the indoor and outdoor areas. A definite must see in Bergen.

reviews.title: Fascinating placeI
reviews.text: I like wandering along here and in and out in between the old buildings from the Hansiatic era in Bergen. It is a picturesque place with very interesting construction. Many of the shops sell souvenirs and I especially like the Christmas shop. One can always find a little something to take back to family and friends.

reviews.title: Photogenic Houses
reviews.text: Maybe the source of the most photos in this town, this line of old wood and stucco houses is very handsome and they look out on the lovely harbor.

reviews.title: A must see in Bergen
reviews.text: Each visitor to Bergen must see these old, colourful wooden houses in the wharf. There are usually shops there with souveniers but you can also enter some of the houses and see what they looked like in the past (see the picture). There is a special Christmas shop there, opened all over the year. Of course the ideal place to take nice pictures is from the opposite site, everyone walks around anyway.

reviews.title: Too pretty
reviews.text: You can walk all around and complete the harbor in about half an hour. A tug boat goes back and forth. Peep in for historic building and shops.

reviews.title: Abundance of colour - especially against the black sky of a threatening down pour
reviews.text: Excellent setting - no wonder these gorgeous frontages are on every postcard! Great for window or real tourist shopping!  If you can blag the key from reception - go up to the turret of The Clarion hotel and get the 360 panorama

reviews.title: Nice walk
reviews.text: This is the icon of the city. Shops are opened on Sunday. Take the opportunity to explore the alleys between the buildings. This area is a must see when in Bergen.

reviews.title: The photo of Bergen you see
reviews.text: We passed here every time we went out, it was just around the corner from where we stayed and on route to the centre. Fantastic old timber buildings, quirky wonky doors, some restoration works ongoing, tourist shops selling the usual tat and some nice unique shops in the alleyways off the front. Beautiful buildings. Good photo opportunity obviously

reviews.title: Beautiful old buildings
reviews.text: Beautiful old buildings along the wharf but now mainly tourist souvenir shops but worth viewing whilst walking around the city

reviews.title: UNESCO World heritage site
reviews.text: This is UNESCO world heritage site in Bergen. Visiting here was like a dream come true. It’s so beautiful and out of the world that you can’t even imagine without visiting it personally. Made in more than 200 yrs back it’s still preserved. Colourful Bryggen looks awesome. Must visit place when u r in Bergen

reviews.title: Hanseatic wharf
reviews.text: To live beside this place was good decision to do. We walked along passages of this historical place. German hanseatic League was owner of old timber houses along the harbor

reviews.title: Unesco heritage
reviews.text: Really amazing Bryggen and how have been preserved during years, is untouchable the ancient spirit, really nice walk in between the buildings.

reviews.title: Great character
reviews.text: Fantastic to see this heritage preserved and so accessible.  Beautiful setting and a source of many great photographs too.

reviews.title: Original wharf houses you can wander around and inside too
reviews.text: The Bryggen Wharf is noted as one of the highlights of Bergen, being a row of wooden houses that have survived largely intact for a long time. They look very scenic from the water-side, but the best bit is that you can wander into many of them, even onto some of the upper floors. They are actually very complex buildings, some of which have floor plans. What at first looks like half a dozen houses actually contains several dozen separate spaces, mostly (probably all?) now occupied by businesses. There is refurbishment ongoing in at least one of them.

reviews.title: Wander along Bryggen
reviews.text:
What a wonderful location to just 'be'.

Pop into small shops, check out the alleys and met the 'ugly fish'.

reviews.title: Beautiful area and some interesting retailers.
reviews.text:
Another must see area. Many units do seem to be closed in the winter but still enough to see. Some original artists have galleries and the prices were sensible. 
Perhaps a map of the units and tenants would be helpful.

reviews.title: trandition and beauty
reviews.text: I had seen pictures before but when I arrived there , I thought i was inside a fairy tail. I did not care about rain or cold. It was beautiful day and night.

reviews.title: Nice place to walk around
reviews.text: On a dry day Bergen is a very nice city to walk around in and to take in areas such as this where there a lovely buildings, boats and shops.

reviews.title: The past in the Present
reviews.text: It’s wonderful just walking along the wharf outside these historic buildings. Yes, the summer months are crowded. It the shops are crammed with interesting things and I spent a very pleasant afternoon wandering around from shop to shop. When I reached the end of the wharf I went to the street behind the shops. As an artist I found some interesting angles in the rooflines and back laneways and saw these buildings from a different perspective.

reviews.title: Trading place
reviews.text: I can make a mistake but age of buildings at bruggen exceeding 400 years. Slanty Slanted houses reflect the spirit of medieval trading market that was famous with dried fish as main selling article

reviews.title: Great place to spend an afternoon
reviews.text: The Hanseatic Wharf is an excellent place to spend half a day. There's plenty to see and do, with shops, restaurants, bars and the interesting architecture. Wandering around the old wooden buidings is a real treat.

reviews.title: World Heritage Site
reviews.text: Even in mid-January, Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf and area is a wonderful area to stroll and admire the beautifully restored buildings. Unfortunately, some of the museums and many of the shops were closed at this time of year, but there is still lots to see and do. The January visit allowed me to tour without the crowds, and I had the opportunity to admire the area under a blanket of show. I can't wait to come back and tour in the summer months.

reviews.title: Interesting buildings
reviews.text: The colorful buildings are very photogenic and located on the harbor.  The shops in the buildings are very oriented toward tourists.  There were a few artists tucked down alleyways and behind the main storefronts that are worth seeking out.  We were there in the winter so some stores were closed.

reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.text:
We stayed near by.
The whole area is beautiful- beautifully restored and maintained.
Bergen is one of the oldest port cities in Northern Europe so it was great to learn about the history and its significance.
There is cafes and shops scattered along the foreshore.

reviews.title: Must visit!
reviews.text: You can’t miss this place when you visit Bergen, nice little houses you can see on most post card. The best place to take picture is just opposite the wharf.

reviews.title: World Heritage Site
reviews.text:
A UNESCO World Heritage site . It's history dates all the way back to the 12th Century and went thru a series of fires, but has always been rebuilt . Safe to say that this was the oldest part and the Center of Bergen in the beginning. Had Been used as a dominant trading center for the Germans All the way back in 1360 to the 1700s . As Fire was common , and this has always been wood in construction ,no candles or open flames were permitted. This made winter here terribly cold and dark . But must have been great during summer .
Presently , the original wooden structures and hallways, now houses different restaurants ,offices, shops , and cafes. I had the opporunity to visit during summer in the past , and recently during winter. It is much more vibrant during summer when restos set up al fresco tables outside and the place is loaded with little kiosks, selling all wares . During winter it is quieter but you feel the history thru it’s walls just the same . The Heritage site includes the Fish Market across the river, the wharf , and the Bryggen Hanseatiske Museum . Most definitely a must visit when in Bergen

reviews.title: Streets of Wood
reviews.text: After the funicular, this is my second pick for a visit to Bergen. Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf, now under a UNESCO World Heritage listing, has been lovingly restored and maintained with a practical use. Although the beautiful wooden buildings are certainly showing their age, today they also operate as offices, studios and retail shops. If you are a history buff, a student of architecture, or a curious person, there is a lot to see here. Although very little is open on a Sunday - this practice may go someway to keeping Norway high in the happiest country stakes - you can still wander through these lovely wooden streets and marvel at the stories that must have been made here.

reviews.title: It's just a small part of Bergen
reviews.text:
I always thought that Bergen looks like this everywhere. That's the same photo you see in every guide.

Unfortunately this is just a very short street. Buildings are beautiful indeed but they are occupied by businesses and offices.

reviews.title: Amazing place
reviews.text:
We were a group of friends . 
Meeting in Bergen for a night out .
Stunning place really nice building's surrounded the city .

reviews.title: Bucket List Item checked off!
reviews.text:
If you love history, friendly people, water falls, and tunnels, then Bergen is the place for you.  We were so lucky to visit Bergen in September.  Our good friend has been inviting us to come an visit her beautiful country and the lovely city of Bergen.  So this September we did just that.  She advised us to bring water proof, comfortable walking shoes, and a good rain coat.  We did.  We were grateful for the good shoes, but mother nature was kind, and we only need our rain coats a couple of times.  

We spent a couple of days of days in the city of Bergen.  We loved Bryggen, with all of it's old buildings.  Make sure you explore all of the alley ways.  We enjoyed some visiting all the shops, and love the art work we purchased that now hangs on our walls.  

We also wandered the Maritime museum and the Museum at the university.  Both were good.  Skip the aquarium, and spend that money else where, like the Rosenkrantz tower.   Definitely take a ride on the funicular.  We had a clear blue sky day, and the vista's are amazing. 

The shopping district is large and fun to wander through. Remember to ask for the tourist receipt that allows you to get back the 25 % tax.  We missed a few of these receipts, but we did get over $700 back on everything we purchased.  

And if time allows, go and see the visitor center and check into a Norwary in a Nutshell tour.  Well worth your day.

We loved Norwary, and if time and money allowed we would go and explore some more!

reviews.title: Beautiful Bergen!
reviews.text: This city is just so beautiful day and night! We definitely want to come back here. There’s so much to do but just bumbling around the city is an absolute pleasure!

reviews.title: Colorful building with lovely shops and alleys
reviews.text: I and my family had a great time walking around Bryggen. When we visit the wooden houses, it is like stepping back into the past. We really enjoyed going up and down the stairs and walking in the aisles along the wooden houses. The building currently functions as a shop and some museum but unfortunately some museums are closed for Christmas and New Years holiday.

reviews.title: Such a beautiful wharf
reviews.text: Wow. Such a lovely stroll!  We drove by in the daytime and walked around in the evening, after Floyen. They light it up at night so you can still see it. Loved it.

reviews.title: Fab houses with lovely shops and alleys
reviews.text:
It’s like stepping back in time as you wander along the front of the houses and then through the alleys with the crazy angles of the steps and building overhanging edges.  

There are some lovely shops - mainly tourist type though - lots of Norwegian jumpers and types of souvenir items and a lovely Christmas shop.  

The site is UNESCO and it’s clear to see why - and not busy when we were there although I am sure it will be busier in the summer time.

A lovely stroll and not far from the main modern shops in Bergen.

reviews.title: Colorful buildings!
reviews.text: My friends and I had a great time walking around Bryggen. It was a great feeling to walk through houses that has historical background. They might have been more crowded in the times of the Hanse, with marketeers in front of them. We went on Christmas Day itself and even attended a Church service at a nearby Church.

reviews.title: Colorful
reviews.text: Everything about Norway is beautiful, but Bergen - or Bryggen as they call it - is a beautiful place of 'history stood still'. Some of these buildings were built over a thousand years ago. You won't want to miss them!

reviews.title: Stunning wharf with old historic beauty
reviews.text: Bergen is worth a day out of your trip.  Easy walking and the area called Bruggen is a must.  Walking behind the old buildings will make you feel like you in an old fishing village great atmosphere and stunning photo options ...wooden walkways and small shops.

reviews.title: A  beautiful historic area
reviews.text: We walked there from opposite and what a magnificent sight it was at sunset on the cold but sunny day we were there. We were particularly interested as we have been to many of the towns and cities that were part of the Hanseatic league. Some of the houses only date back to the 1900s as many were destroyed over the years by fire but they have been beautifully restored. Unfortunately, the Hanseatic league museum I particularly wanted to visit was closed for renovations and will be for the next 6 years so I was disappointed from that point of view.

reviews.title: Worth a detour
reviews.text: It was a great feeling to walk through houses that were build more than 1000 years ago,although most of them had to be rebuilt several times due to fires. They might have been more crowded in the times of the Hanse, with marketeers in front of them. Today quiet and with limited tourist attention - at least in the winter 😉

reviews.title: Stunning wharf
reviews.text:
If you are going to Norway then don’t miss Bryggen. 
Take the time to discover the wharf area....not just the front....go behind and walk through the old buildings and drop in to have a cuppa and a bite to eat at the hidden little cafes. 
The town is stunning. Best view is from the hotel the clarion Admiral which is directly opposite the old wharf and close to the fish market❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
We were there pre Christmas do the market is a must with a nice cup of mulled wine. 

Many pretty places in the world but this one is pretty high on the list.

reviews.title: Delightful area.
reviews.text: We enjoyed walking around this historic area. The old wooden buildings were well restored and give a glimpse into Bergen's past. we were disappointed that the museums in the area were all closed for renovations.

reviews.title: Mesmerising
reviews.text: This place is so lively and calm at the same time. Absolutely beautiful, will be coming back for certain

reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.text: Pure charm, beautiful and so very interesting. The entire area with the wharf all lit up was a sight to behold

reviews.title: Excellent atmospheric place
reviews.text: A piece of old Norway, nice and atmospheric. A lot of merchants that sell norwegian food, but the prices are too high. You can find almost all products in the nearest supermarket at lower prices.

reviews.title: Very picturesque and fun to explore.
reviews.text: This place is lovely to walk along and is right in the centre of Bergen centre. Lots of fun tourist shops to go into, both in the front and if you venture into the back of all the buildings.

reviews.title: Very beautiful in sunshine
reviews.text: walk between the houses and explore many interesting corners and sights. Best light in the morning and with Christmas decoration at night.

reviews.title: The old charm
reviews.text: Just walk around this place and you will get to know about the food, culture and get to buy some authentic Norwegian pure woolen sweaters and souvenirs to take back home.

reviews.title: Beautiful walk around the wharf!!!
reviews.text: Its a UNESCO world heritage site and for a reason. Its a very pleasant walk around the evenings with the fish market on the other side of the water.

reviews.title: Delightful step back in history
reviews.text: Excellent variety of shops, though stay out of the more touristy trinket places.  Step off the beaten path to find the bakery, art work, and exceptional handcrafts.

reviews.title: History beautifully maintained
reviews.text: Beautiful coloured buildings preserving the history of Bergen. Narrow laneways between to explore.  Some shops sell hand knitted jumpers with Nordic designs while others sell children's wear, souvenirs etc. Well worth a stroll down by the water.

reviews.title: Scenic and historic
reviews.text: Loved this scenic spot - strolling the cobblestone walks, exploring the fish market and colorful, historic buildings that line the wharf!

reviews.title: Lovely
reviews.text: Don’t just look at the front of the buildings, have a walk in between the building to see those at the back.

reviews.title: Photogenic Waterfront
reviews.text: Everyone takes their photos of the old wooden houses and many boats at this historic waterfront.  Lots of places to eat and drink, and some shopping.

reviews.title: Lovely, just lovely
reviews.text: Enjoyed our time just sitting and people/boat watching.  Very active harbour and pedestrian traffic.  Enjoyed a glass of wine too!

reviews.title: Small version of Nyhavn, Copenhagen
reviews.text: This small area of Bergen reminded us all of Nyhavn, Copenhagen where we had just visited.  It is very picturesque but after reading about the area I expected many more small shops, galleries, etc. then what we encountered.    Still, worth a walk over there, and also photos from across the harbor (at the fish market/tourist info center) are very nice.

reviews.title: Boats, water, restaurants and more.
reviews.text: This place is absolutely best in the summer but during the autumn you still get a feeling of the place, but can't compare too the summer. Close to the water, lots of boats, many restaurants nearby. Hard to miss and a must visit.

reviews.title: Not what imagined
reviews.text:
These are the wooden warehouses/shops along the waterfront.  They are painted in different colours, there are alleyways here and there.  Mainly tourist shops now with artisans in the alleyways.  Very expensive.  The distance to the water's edge is very wide.
Bergen itself is the dirtiest city we visited in Norway, first one with a McDonalds, lots of litter, chewing gum on pavements and dogends.  Bit of a shock after such serene places elsewhere.

reviews.title: Great place to stroll
reviews.text: Stayed very close to the wharf so walked along this historical area each day and was impressed each time. Great alleys to wander up and down, interesting shops and restaurants plus amazing and colourful buildings - the face of Bergen. An array of sailing boats, ferries and other vessels provided interest. You could not visit Bergen without spending at least a couple of hours just strolling around.

reviews.title: Very Historic
reviews.text: A pleasant surprise. Lots of lovely shops. Make sure you walk to the back of the old shops, as there are some neat sites to see.

reviews.title: Beautiful Bergen
reviews.text: Bryggen is such a cool place to visit, when you consider how old it is and where it is its amazing its still standing! I'm not surprised the Norwegians are proud of this piece of history. As a tourist its a really nice place to wander around and buy some souvenirs or have something to eat and drink, an essential place to visit if you're in Bergen

reviews.title: Still impressive on the second visit
reviews.text: Been here twice now. Second time was just as good. Nice and unique buildings. Enjoyed wondering around looking in the shops and having a drink in a bar. Love it here!

reviews.title: Must-do walk
reviews.text: This is a lovely area to take a walk and explore, any time of day.  There are plenty of shops and places to eat, and be sure to explore the side streets as well.  It helps to have a good guidebook that explains the sights.

reviews.title: A piece of history
reviews.text: Far smaller than expected, Bryggen is a little taste of history. It's lovey to explore the wooden buildings. unfortunately the Hansiatic Museum is now closed, which would have helped to provide moe meaning to this area, but still very much worth a visit.

reviews.title: A must when in Bergen
reviews.text: You see in the travel brochures and then you are standing outside any one of the old fisherman's stores. Bryggen is a must.

reviews.title: great town to visit, shop and have lunch
reviews.text: A good way to spend the day walking around the town, shopping, having lunch and looking out at the pier.  The buildings are so quaint.  Such a pretty town!

reviews.title: Great walk
reviews.text: The Hanseatic wharf is colourful and makes for both an interesting and enjoyable walk in Bergen. Needless to say there are numerous shop and bars and will probably be busy depending on when you visit.  Well worth walking in the narrow side streets and getting an idea of how Bergen would have been like in earlier times.

reviews.title: Lovely and great shopping
reviews.text: In October, many things are either closed or are open for shorter hours, but it is still a very enjoyable place to visit.  There are few tourists, which is nice.

reviews.title: Must do
reviews.text:
Perhaps the most prominent attraction, Bryggen Wharf is a long, comfortable, and interesting stroll along the water front.  It is very commercial with shops, restos, and crowds.  The colorful buildings appear to be original; a few are obviously leaning and could use renovation within the UNESCO Heritage Site rules.
There are many side streets which appear interesting but we didn't visit.  There is much more to see than just the waterfront.

reviews.title: Part of our tour
reviews.text: Very interesting place, especially if you have an informative tour guide who explains the history well.

reviews.title: Capsule of History
reviews.text: What a great experience for this history teacher! Love the wharf and just love Bergen, will return soon, Colorful, well-maintained, like all of Norway!

reviews.title: Very special spot
reviews.text:
When you consider the dates of original construction and re-construction, it becomes something of fascination to be able to walk along the rows of shops.
The little alleyways and lanes that are full of interesting places make this area even more intriguing.
During the day the colours of the old buildings look great but at night the lights give it a very different feel.
It really is a must do walk when you are in Bergen.

reviews.title: Protected by UNESCO
reviews.text: You must visit this place if you a visitor of Bergen. Old timber houses that were built centuries ago preserved old spirit. It was the main center of trade in old times

reviews.title: Such a rich history
reviews.text: Bryggen is a beautiful and colourful place full of history, definitely worth a visit!  The constant restoration of the wooden buildings ensure that they are still in use today housing small shops you can wander through.

reviews.title: Highlight of everyones stay in Bergen
reviews.text: UNESCO recognized heritage, depicts history of Bergen. Do come though corridors between the buildings, do not observe only from front side as you will be amazed how long they are, how they were built and you will find shops, galleries and restaurant in the back. Hanseatic museum is there too (in first of the buildings) and we were extremely lucky to see it on its very last day (30th September) before its closing down for 6 years due to neccessary repairment to entire building and adjancet houses. You'll learn a lot of how life looked before, how cruel it was and finally, that - believe it or not - Norway once was a poor country surviving on stockfish.

reviews.title: Interesting Place to Stroll, Shop and People Watch
reviews.text: This is an interesting place to spend a couple hours. It’s a quaint historic port area that bustles with tourists and locals. Shopping, eating, historical building to visit, and gentle wandering people watching.

reviews.title: Pretty Bryggen
reviews.text:
My Dad, husband and I had a lovely afternoon wandering the streets around the UNESCO heritage buildings of Bryggen where there are sweet little shops to look at, cafes selling beer and coffee and little cobbled streets to discover. 
We walked down from the funicular railway, which was a nice 30mins stroll back to our cruise ship - we probably could have done it much quicker but we wanted to take in the sights of Bryggen. 
There doesn't seem to be lots to do here but a few hours wandering around and maybe just relaxing with a drink or doughnut watching the world go by and visiting the little arty shops is a nice way to relax.
Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Good view of original buildings
reviews.text: Nice place around wharf to walk around and see years old scandinavian design buildings. say like Leggo Houses with different colours. Fish market nearby.

reviews.title: Quaint Wooden Buildings
reviews.text: We thoroughly enjoyed walking round the Hanseatic Wharf.  Many of the buildings were art and craft shops and we spent a happy 40 minutes browsing and admiring the wooden buildings which date back to early 1700s.  Definitely a must if you are in Bergen.

reviews.title: Like Williamsburg for Norwegians!
reviews.text: You can wander in the little streets and buy things or just look at the crazy architecture.  Great beer and restaurants too

reviews.title: "Much written spot of Bergen tourist"
reviews.text:
This particular Bryggen Wharf and those multi coloured row houses were much written touristry spot of Bergen. Yes it was great to stroll around the famous UNESCO heritage Bryggen wharf. We had all seasons of weather in 4 hours. Sunny, freezing, rainy, windy.. May be in clear sunny skies, the colourful background would be amazing for photo shoots. We got the oppurtunity to take few clicks whenever sungod smiled with clear skies.
Its an experience.

reviews.title: Really enjoyable visit and plenty to see.
reviews.text: It was a gorgeous day in July, the wharf front was really busy. We looked around the shops had a coffee  then walked to next street up past the church and around the back of shops where you could see how close together these building were. They have been added too and extended for years. You can walk in between and in some of them but the real picture is at the back where you can see the roof lines. There are some pretty shops and a very packed jam second hand shop on this road also. You can walk up to the  railway and then turn back down to wharf and visit the fish market.

reviews.title: First Time to Bergen
reviews.text: This area is a must visit in Bergen, easy walk and will take you right along the harbor.  Lots of shopping to do there, don’t expect any cheap deals.....

reviews.title: A Millenium of History in Bryggen
reviews.text:
Bergen is a very walkable city, and one of its delights is how so many fascinating places are all within walking distance of each other.  Case in point is Bryggen, which was a trade center for the German Hanseatic League in the 14th century.  Narrow wooden buildings separated by equally narrow passages face the harbor and provide a glimpse into the life of this community of merchants who lived and worked in these buildings.  Because of the high incidence of fire (the city has been destroyed multiple time by fire that catches hold of the wooden timbers and spreads like, well….wildfire) no fire was allowed in the warehouses and living quarters, so all cooking and socializing was done in the Schotstuene, consisting of three assembly halls and a kitchen).  During winter months, due to the danger of fire, hot meals were served here, and the space was also used for teaching, meetings, parties, and courtrooms.  
In addition to simply walking around the very scenic row of buildings (a UNESCO World Heritage Site), you can get a first hand look at how these merchants lived and worked by visiting the Hanseatic Museum which is on the far side of Bryggen.  It’s fascinating to walk in the steps of merchants who lived in this space 800 years ago.  The exhibits throughout the museum (in English) show how the stockfish was received in Bergen, flattened and dried for shipment, and the upper floors are furnished in much the same way they were in the 14th century.  
Tickets for admission were 160 NOK (about $20), and this museum was well worth the cost.

reviews.title: Great history and architecture
reviews.text: There is so much history here ... take the time to explore this area.  There are shops, small restaurants, ice cream and candy, etc. all in this area,.  The colors of the buildings mean something.  There is a great museum on the corner on the end near the fish market restaurants under the red tents.  If you like fresh seafood .... you want to eat here.  The museum also has free restrooms and a nice gift shop inside.

reviews.title: Historic Bergen - Bryggen
reviews.text: Poke around the narrow walkways to get a real feel of the buildings. Tourist shops have been established all around there, but they sell good quality things, both large and small. Good place to find unusual gifts. Offices are located in some buildings, and I took a picture of the old pully system still used to hoist things to the upper floors. Understandable when you see the narrow stairs going to upper floors.

reviews.title: Stunning!
reviews.text: Even with works ongoing this was a super place to see. So much character and little books and crannies. Loved it.

reviews.title: Have You Ever Seen a Post Card in Real?
reviews.text: The title says it all. A live post card. Wonderful scenery. Just around the corner. One thing I cannot forget on this day was I wanted to watch Ant-Man and Wasp in a local theater so I was trying to impress my fiancée by taking lots of good pictures of her. Anyway finally she said no to the movie.

reviews.title: Interesting and scenic
reviews.text: Historic and interesting area to explore with lots of tourist shops and artisan stores plus good eateries.

reviews.title: charming historic wooden buildings and back alleys
reviews.text:
This is probably the place that most tourists won't miss in Bergen. Through the narrow streets and dark alleys at Bryggen is like going back in time to when Hansa (the German Guild of Merchants) dominated this part of Bergen. 
We went there several times in 2 days, walking through narrow alleys with crowded during the mid-day, and before the sunset in late afternoon with very few people there. Admiring the colorful wooden buildings, though the area is not big, don't miss this group of biggest/oldest wooden buildings in Europe.
A small courtyard with a carved wooden stock fish is interesting to remember Bergen's old method to dry fish till nowadays.  All small shops and museums are very unique.

reviews.title: 7th wonder of the world! Amazing.
reviews.text: Muchore than we expected. So many places to eat, shop, take Fjord cruises you name it it’s here. And the people are so nice.

reviews.title: Underwhelming
reviews.text: This is just a short row of buildings - 3 of which were covered in construction wraps - that are brightly colored.  It just looks like it's for tourists.  The shops are a convenience store, a bar, gifts - nothing worth going out of your way for.  I didn't even take a picture.

reviews.title: City walk and Bergen history.
reviews.text: The Hanseatic wharf and section of Bergen is a must see as part of any Bergen city tour.  We took a day to walk the streets of downtown Bergen and the wharf was where we started.  There are many high-end shops, tourist-oriented souvenir shops,  and eateries to enjoy.   It is clean and friendly as well.

reviews.title: A beautiful UNESCO World Heritage site.
reviews.text: One of the most photographed sites on the planet these buildings are centuries old. They are being restored and the walking area in front, behind and through them is fascinating. A very good historical center explains the significance of the Hanseatic League and these buildings.

reviews.title: wonderful walking area
reviews.text: Wandering in and out of the little lanes was a treat.  You could sit and eat and drink over looking the harbour.  Great photo opportunities.

reviews.title: Very pleasant browsing
reviews.text: Lovely place to wander, Shops are fine but it's more about just being there. I got a great explanation on a walking tour but this is so much a part of Bergen's history you must go for a wander. The beautifully painted houses ARE Bergen and add to the view with the mountains as a back drop.

reviews.title: Easy walk, interesting buildings
reviews.text: "Bryggen" is pretty small but offers an interesting glimpse into how people lived several hundred years ago.  There is a museum about the Hanseatic League for more information.  Many of the shops are occupied by gift shops now.  Easy to find and walk around

reviews.title: Colourful historic area
reviews.text: Being very close to the cruise terminals it is an area that can get very busy, but I was lucky as few ships were in town.  It is pretty and provides the iconic tourist photograph of Bergen.  Some restoration work going on at the moment.  To see it properly you need to go through the narrow lanes and see the rear of the buildings and courtyards. Not surprisingly given its location very much given over to tourist shops.

reviews.title: Pretty Area
reviews.text: This section of town along the wharves is full of colourful buildings, interesting shops and fascinating history.  These buildings are a legacy from the Hanseatic League at a time when modern day Norway, Denmark, Germany formed a powerful trading cartel. This is a must place to wander to take in the sights and soak up some history

reviews.title: Beautiful area. Steeped in history.
reviews.text: Bryggen is beautiful. The Hanseatic league history is fascinating, and now known by most Americans. It is fascinating to learn. The buildings and back alleys in Bryggen are beautiful. It is a bit too touristy, but this area is appealing to many who visit Bergen, and the area most probably go first (we did).  The restaurrant Bryggeloftet and Steuben is there and it was wonderful when we went. Certainly it is a "can't miss" when you go to Bergen.

reviews.title: Very pretty, colorful and historical part of the city
reviews.text: Bryggen is a very pleasant area of Bergen with historical, colorful wooden houses. You might wander around and just enjoy the views and the atmosphere for hours. There are mostly souvenir shops in these houses, this might be a bit disturbing for some, but I think that they were quite okay.

reviews.title: Beautiful wharf area
reviews.text: We were here last year when it was raining so it was even more enjoyable to be here in the sunshine. Although a few of the buildings were covered due to repairs, there is still plenty to be seen. We enjoyed looking at the nearby boats and popping into one of the many restaurants for lunch.

reviews.title: Interesting historical architecture
reviews.text: The Hanseatic Wharf is a historical area of Bergen where the origins date back to the 12th century. Although the area has been affected by fire on more than one occasion, the current properties add to the attractiveness of the town

reviews.title: Beautiful buildings
reviews.text: Mostly tourist shops occupy the ground floors of these buildings but it’s a lovely area to walk along and some of the shops are interesting.  The streets are cobbled so comfortable shoes are essential.

reviews.title: Several buildings have works
reviews.text: Several buildings were covered in scaffolding which rather spoiled the effect. You need to get back off the quayside into the narrow passageways to really get any sense of the history of the place. Some very enterprising businesses tooled away back there.

reviews.title: MUST see in Bergen
reviews.text:
When you're in Bergen it's a must to visit Bryggen. 
Dont forget to go up in the perpendicular alleys to see the art shops and cafe's. You'll find a window in front of a construction, in one of the houses, where you have a view to the old construction - It's a kind of fantastic these houses have been there for so many years.
Don't forget Bryggen is a tourist trap, and everything is a bit more expensive here, if possible !!!
Enjoy your stay!

reviews.title: A place to stroll in history
reviews.text: This is one of those picturesque places that only gets better as you find out more about its history and importance.  It is close to where the cruise ships depart so gets a lot of traffic but I find it hard to believe that anyone would not come away impressed.

reviews.title: A Must in Bergen
reviews.text: The wharf and its history are a must in Bergen.  So interesting to see the German influence and how fishing shaped the area.  A visit to the Hanseatic Museum is also beneficial- not large but worth the visit.

reviews.title: Bryggen Hanseatic Wharf
reviews.text:
Bergen City is a beautiful old city that dates back to the Vikings and it was the draw for us.
I have read about the wooden houses and how pretty they are.
It is incredible to have these old wooden houses in full function status and enjoy.

reviews.title: History
reviews.text:
A beautiful old building with Bergen history and hanseatic traders.
It’s sinking and closing soon for renovation.
It will be closed for 6 years. See it now

reviews.title: Beautiful Bryggen!
reviews.text: Surely the most photographed area of Bergen!  We explored this area and the most interesting parts are the ones inside.  Try to get inside the different buildings and feel how it is to live in the past.  Some of the buildings are now under repair and hopefully they will bring it back to its former glory.

reviews.title: super touristy must-see
reviews.text: The wharf (bryggen) at Bergen is a super touristy area of town, but the views are beautiful and the line of wooden structures is the most iconic image of the city.  Most of the wooden houses have been converted into shops - some crafty and local and others very touristy and awful.

reviews.title: Fantastic survival of old wharf buildings
reviews.text:
a great place to stroll round even in bad weather. fairly massive timber buildings lovingly restored. so close together surprising they had not burnt down (probably a lot did) now protected by sprinklers etc. (some UK house could learn from this).
Shame about the tourist shops though.

reviews.title: Shops and Restaurants
reviews.text: We walked around this area to find some cocktails and dinner. Cool area to watch the boats and people move about. Many options for food and shopping. Was fine even in the rain.

reviews.title: Great area to explore and shop
reviews.text: Bryggen was fun to explore and look in all the wonderful little shops. It was the perfect place to find a few souvenirs to bring home with us.

reviews.title: Beautiful!
reviews.text: Small shops with souvenirs and Norwegian products in beautiful buildings that definitely deserve a visit. Don't miss it!

reviews.title: مميزه
reviews.text:
من اجمل المناطق المميزه في بيرغن تعيشك الماضي الجميل في هذي المدينه 
One of the most beautiful areas in Bergen is the beautiful past in this city

reviews.title: Atmospheric historical place
reviews.text: While the shops are pretty much entirely set up for tourists, the Hanseatic museum puts the area into perspective. There is a bus to take museum goers from the meeting rooms to the other section of the museum, a 7 minute bus ride away- good if it begins to rain.

reviews.title: Nice Views, Scenery, food, and shopping
reviews.text:
Date of Visit: Friday, Aug 31, 2018
Bryggen Wharf is one of the iconic places everyone who visits takes photos of, and tells you to visit when you go. 
It definitely is a must - do when you are in Bergen. 
This is where you will find those colourful wooden buildings all in a row along the harbour. 
This is a highly trafficked tourist area, full of shops, bars, restaurants, etc. 
IF you visit Berge, you will eventually end up here - I guarantee it. 

The area is bustling with people - tourists and locals alike. 
You will see many tour buses, hop-on hop-off buses and many other cars driving up and down the street.  You are situated right on the water, and it is the perfect eperience for Norway tourists. 
You can find all of the souvenirs, and gifts here that your heart desires. 

There are several alleys where you will find other great shops owned and feature local artists, and crafts persons. Be sure to check them out. We spent more money in the back alleys than we did on the main street. 

There is a great food truck that is situated here as well "Norwegian Traditional Food" 
We ate here, because the name told us to. We wanted traditional Norwegian food, and this food shop did not disappoint. They had traditional Norwegian food, that is for sure. 
Which was amazing I might add, but the service of the gentleman working the cart was even better. He understands he is catering to tourists - so he helped out these tourists and guided us on some amazing items. Thanks. 

The views from this area are beautiful. lots of cool buildings, views of the mountains, the harbour, boats, and much more. 

Traveller Tip:  for the best photos of the iconic coloured buildings -  get there EARLY in the AM if you can before the tourists arrive - and you might get that perfect shot. 
For great food - eat at the above mentioned food cart. You will love it.

reviews.title: A nice walk along the harbour
reviews.text: Enjoyed our time in this area. We ate one day at the fish market - bought a fish sandwich and a reindeer hot dog from one of the street vendors. The only problem is this area can be very busy with cruise people. Try to go when there is not a lot of cruise people walking around.

reviews.title: Amazing Views
reviews.text: We enjoyed all of our Bergen, Norway moments but the wharf really stands out. The fresh fish market is a MUST if you're in Bergen, as is the wharf walk near the downtown.

reviews.title: Signature Area by the Harbour
reviews.text: These lovely colourful buildings, shops and cafes by the harbourside in Bergen are really interesting and a nice mix of the modern and the traditional. Built after the fire of 1702 you really must make some time to enjoy this UNESCO Heritage site when you visit Bergen.

reviews.title: A quaint quay with a modern use !!
reviews.text: Going to this place is like getting a bit lost in time and in a novel for from a foreign author for me that I am from Malta. A very quaint place with a modern use and the timber work is fantastic

reviews.title: Historic, beautiful and well worth a visit
reviews.text:
Monday 3rd September and we were out and about exploring and sightseeing in Bergen, it was the first stop of our Celebrity Silhouette cruise of the Norwegian Fjords.

One of the sights not to miss in Bergen is the old wharf area and it's buildings, it is known as Bryggen, which means the dock.

The colourful wooden buildings are situated on the eastern side of the Vågen harbour and only a short walk, about 10 minutes from where the ship docked. The area  has  been included on the UNESCO list for World Cultural Heritage sites since 1979.

These iconic buildings have been converted into a variety of bars, restaurants and gift shops.It was a lovely sunny day when we visted here and the restaurants and cafes had tables and seating outdoors along the waterfront, adding to the atmosphere of the place. It was a wonderful experience wondering around here.

reviews.title: Colorful Wharf!
reviews.text:
Historical and colorful wharfs with the ship deck nearby. A must pic with colorful bryggen wharfs if you in bergen on both day and night. Great street to walk and enjoy the colors, tradition of bergen.
Oic with bryggen wharf is mandatory if one visits bergen.Please dont miss it

reviews.title: Nice ande tidy view.
reviews.text: Geared to maximize the space for as many tourists as possible. Heritage waterfront buildings are crafted into a balance of attractions which offer something for everyone, e.g. restaurants of varying sizes, cafes with bespoke themes, fish market, wooden old-town, hotels and much, much more.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: Lovely historic area of Bergen. We enjoyed wandering around and looking at the old buildings. Didn’t visit the museum as it was £16 each which we considered quite expensive.

reviews.title: Colourful!
reviews.text: The multi-colored buildings of bryggen are well known , they are the symbol of bergen, just like gamla stan is the symbol of stockholm, or nyhaven the symbol of copenhagen. but when you start wondering around the wharf, you'll find a lot of restaurants, pubs and shops - which make a very nice day!

reviews.title: Not a whole lotta there, there....
reviews.text: I understand this is an historic area; however, it's directly adjacent to a very busy street and a working port.  The historic buildings themselves house mostly all tourist souvenir shops.  (And all the shops are stocking mostly the very same items as every other shop...)   The sidewalk is extremely crowded with tourists, as are the shops.  And, once you've seen one shop, you're seen them all.  You can spend an hour walking around - but, it's not a pleasant hour... It's crowded, noisy, and there's not much to do, (unless you have souvenir shopping as your goal).  I think the UNESCO designation is really offbase/a stretch here...

reviews.title: Very scenic wooden houses and boats
reviews.text: We stayed at the Thon Rosnkrantz Bergen so we’re just steps from the Wharf. It’s very scenic and there are a few cute shops, restaurants and the Hanseatic museum.

reviews.title: Very picturesque
reviews.text: The Hanseatic wharf is very scenic, we were lucky to have a guided tour and learned about how and why the workers came, conditions in which they lived, etc.  The buildings are now mainly tourist shops and restaurants but worth seeing. Wander around through the back alleys. Best view is from the other side of the wharf.

reviews.title: Don't Pass it By!
reviews.text: The Hanseatic wharf in Bergen is a really cool, colorful place with lots more to see than you know at first glance! We pulled into the cruise port and planned to see Bergen by shoe leather only. Though the buildings and maritime hustle and bustle along the wharf were picturesque and cool, we kept on walking past it and into the city where we walked for hours. It's not till we were returning from our walkabout that we noticed there is much more to see in the Hanseatic Wharf area than we were aware of on our morning pass by. There are warrens of shops in old alleyways hidden behind the street front. Old wooden buildings built higgledy-piggeldy bumping into each other over your heads. Be sure to take all this in before you leave the lovely town of Bergen. You'll enjoy the time!

reviews.title: Impressive
