The museum presents the history of shipping, its development and importance to Bergen and Norway from prehistoric times to the present day. Our exhibitions offer a vast collection of ship models, paintings and various items related to seamanship and life on board, providing a good insight into Norway's rich maritime heritage. Coffee, tea, snacks, cold drinks and ice cream. Limited museum shop. FREE WIFI. Research library. Closed: 1 January, Good Friday, Easter Sunday, 1 May, 17 May, Whit Sunday, Christmas eve, 25-26 Dec. and New Year's Eve. The research library is also closed weekends. Guided tours of the museum between 20 June and 18 August, weekdays 12am (English). Welcome!

reviews.title: Many models
reviews.text: A lot of well built models on display and some pieces from older and newer vessels on display, however, I would have wished for more info about Hurtigruten for example. If you have a spare hour, why not go there.

reviews.title: A history of life viking life at sea
reviews.text: the artifacts date back to very early times to the present. I was thinking there would be many more old viking ships...was a bit disappointed.

reviews.title: Small but interesting
reviews.text: We found the ground floor interesting. A few too many models upstairs, but also some interesting exhibits. Worth a visit.

reviews.title: The best maritime museum probably in the world.
reviews.text: This is a wonderful experience.  The film loop on Viking ship burials was so moving.  We thought a lot about it afterward.  The models, film loops, maps and text on all manner of shipping to the present time, on naval battles, on disasters at sea were exquisite (the models!), absorbing (the English-Dutch-Norwegian battles for example -- and of course the World War II history at sea with U boats, subs, convoys - the Norwegian Resistance - for those of us with Grandparents or parents who fought in WWII this was the real stuff -- so well presented!

reviews.title: A lot of ships
reviews.text: Some of us expected a bit more Viking related exhibition, but the museum focuses more on ships including modern ones. If you like them, I believe it’s a great place to visit.

reviews.title: Interesting museum
reviews.text: Well laid out over two floors. Covers from Viking times to present day. Free entry using the Bergen Card.

reviews.title: Learned more about Norwegian Maritime in Bergen than any where else in Norway.
reviews.text: Very impressive museum with a great arched hall with one of their vessels and a video of sea escapades playing on the walls and ceiling.  The displays and information were very well done!

reviews.title: Skippable musesm
reviews.text:
The viking ship that is all over their advertising is a model, not an actual ship.
I would recommend skipping it unless you are into model boats.

reviews.title: Only museum with free food and drink
reviews.text: This is the only museum that I have ever been to that kindly offered hot drinks and delightful cinnamon whirls. The history of Norwegian shipping is told in a very factual and slightly old fashioned manner. More interesting  was a newer section on Norway in the First World War. One disappointment was that there was no full sized Viking ship, but there are some models of old ships.

reviews.title: Reccomend to visit
reviews.text: We came almost at closing time but got inside. Museum is fascinating, charming, relatively small. There ar many amazing detailed ship models, Dont forget to read labels and posters to get understanding of how Norwegian fleet has been developed.

reviews.title: Excellent look into maritime history of Bergen
reviews.text:
Well laid out on two floors. Lots of very interesting exhibits. Would probably appeal more to teenagers and adults. 
Good for a couple of hours. Nice building. 
We used the lift. We were warned it’s difficult to use. It stopped mid floors on the way up and we accidentally pressed three by mistake. For a few minutes when it got there the doors would not open and it would not go down. We were at the point we were about to press the alarm when it started moving down. 
Staff were very friendly and helpful. 
Good views towards the sea from 1st floor.
I would recommend the visit but avoid the lift if you can.

reviews.title: Great history of Norway at Sea.
reviews.text: A fun little museum that is definitely worth a visit, good for kids and adults. Learnt lots of interesting things even about British maritime history as well as all over Scandinavia. Very friendly staff.

reviews.title: Top of the rainy day list
reviews.text: Really clean, concise exhibits detailing the maritime history of Norway... the actual maritime artifacts and historical pieces they hold are worth seeing! We wish we had more time here, but it closed earlier than we expected so we had to rush through a bit, however definitely could spend hours depending on your level of interest. (The special exhibit on World War I was my personal favorite!) There is a small area geared to children but the rest of the museum would likely be a bit dry for them. Also be forewarned that some of the explanatory "tags" on things were solely in Norwegian, so be prepared with your translation app or just enjoy the visuals as I did.

reviews.title: Interesting museum
reviews.text: It is a really informative museum, you can learn a lot of things about the Norwegian maritime history since the Viking era until now. Admission is free with Bergen card.

reviews.title: Nice mid-sized museum
reviews.text: Not many instructions how to get there (first option is to climb the hill above the city center, where Natural History museum (now closed) is situated). We were lucky to try bus no 10, got out right after the tunnel and went via passenger bridge to the buildingon top of the hill looking like the city walls - actually in that building the museum is situated, turn after the gate to left and you'll see it. They will recommend a short (some 10-12 minutes) film on Vikings and you will be shocked with brutality they have shown, especially to the women after the death of leader. Museum is mid size and can be seen relatively fast but was interesting with some of the replicas of Viking ships and maritime exibits of later eras. great view from one side to one of the Bergen's ports.

reviews.title: Beautiful museum
reviews.text:
Loved the Maritime museum, so well laid out and all the exhibits are beautifully presented....we had the place to ourselves which was a bonus 

Very informative and gives you a real feel for Bergen’s history

reviews.title: High on our list of museums to visit with our grandson!
reviews.text: Enjoyed finding our way walking up the streets around Johanneskirken and behind some of University of Bergen buildings, where we found this fantastic museum.   Our 12 year old grandson loves European history, anything to do with both World Wars before, in between and after, and maritime history:   this was a very exciting and absorbing visit for the three of us.   So many model ships and boats to look at, so much to read, so many battles between the Danes, Norwegians and Swedes!!   Towards the end a very interesting exhibition of ships used during WW2.

reviews.title: Have to have an interest in maritime history
reviews.text:
Son-in-law wanted to see a viking ship.  Unfortunately, they only had a small replica and pieces of real ones.  The different style ships over the years was interesting.

Children in our group of 8 got bored very quickly.

name: Theta Museum
ranking_subcategory: #31 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #31 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #31 of 110 things to do in Bergen

reviews.title: Complements Oslo’s Resistance Museum
reviews.text: Theta Room was so-named by British intelligence during WWII. It is a fascinating and appropriately well-hidden location, where for a few months, Norwegian Nazi Resistors ran a radio operation. A visit here complemented our earlier tour of the Resistance Museum in Oslo. Much effort has gone into creating the atmosphere of the time, though most of the artifacts are not original. The hours are very limited but the guide seems serious and devoted to the heroes who ran the Theta Room. Allow about a half hour for your visit.

reviews.title: The most interesting museum we visited in Bergen, and we saw them ALL
reviews.text: Very limited days and hours, but well worth the visit if you can make it fit in your visit. Tiny, tiny, room in Old Bryggen which housed a resistance unit in WWII. The gentleman giving the talk was extremely interesting.

reviews.title: Inspiring
reviews.text: We visited this museum this week. It’s small, 1 room, but such an amazing story. A wonderful woman told us the history of the young men & a woman who worked for the Resistance from this location. Very inspiring.

reviews.title: Interesting little room about the resistance
reviews.text: We're a family of adults and we got there just before it was closing and it was a fascinating little room, however we weren't given any time to look around in it before we were sat down to listen to the story about it. While our guide was well informed, it was a hot day and he had a strong accent so it was difficult to understand. He talked for about 20-30 minutes straight and it was a struggle to pay attention, even though what he was saying was very interesting. Good to see if you are interested in WWII and have run out of things to do in Bergen.

reviews.title: Quick look see
reviews.text: Learned a lot about the resistance in Bergen.  Had read a book on the Shetland bus before we came and knew about the coordination with the UK but it was interesting to see how covert things were to have such an impact in the war.

name: Bryggens Museum - Bymuseet i Bergen
ranking_subcategory: #20 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #20 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #20 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: New main exhibit: Under Ground Bryggens Museum's new main exhibit is not completely finished, but we've nonetheless chosen to open our doors this summer for the benefit of the thousands of tourists who's only stay in Bergen may be the summer of 2019. The new exhibit uses thousands of artifacts and modern historical and archaeological research to let you come closer to the everyday lives of the medieval people of Bergen and Western Norway. Runic inscriptions with gossip, poems and spells tells us about faith and love, while ceramics from Europe and the Middle-East shows an extensive and international trade network. The new exhibit also displays the unique Guddal-garment - a nearly thousand year old find, which is one of extremely few relatively intact pieces of Norwegian medieval clothing.

offer_list.title: Bergen Panoramic Tour - Shore Excursion from Bergen

reviews.title: Don't visit,  museum under renovation! Collection presented w/o any labels!!! closed area!!
reviews.text:
When I buy the Bergen pass card I think (this museum was included into that package) that it will be very interesting (old artifact unearthed during the clearing of the land after a fire in 1955).
What was my GREAT deception when I discover that the area where the excavations where conducted is completly closed to any visit!
My deception increased when I discover a lot of artifact presented almost in the dark into numerous glass cabinets w/ any explanations!!! HUNDREDS of artifacts are not labeled nor at least dated! You have to try to find by yourself at what they have been used  and when !! Imagination is in power!
Moreover they gave to you some letter format Xerox copies in bad quality w/ only fews tens of artifacts described of an unique  round glass cabinet (over the tens displayed!).
When I complain about that facts no excuses even the thead to put me out of this museum by the public force !!!
You a have to understand what "sneak preview" for a museaum can means (and only into a small post outside the museum entrance!)

reviews.title: Well worth a visit!
reviews.text: An interesting museum with many artefacts reflecting Bryggen’s history. We opted for a tour. Glad we did. We learned so much about the area and its past. The tour included a walk around the area and access to the old city hall site which is restricted. Dane was our tour guide. He was exceptional. Welcoming, knowledgeable and interesting. All staff were great! Welcoming and knowledgeable. Although parts of the museum are under renovation it is still worth a visit. The sections available are well organised with lots of interesting artefacts. Highly recommend!

reviews.title: Great intelligent experience
reviews.text: Even though the museum is partially closed for renovation, it is well worth a visit. The tour (200kr) is excellent and covers both the museum and a walk around the wharf area with access to an area closed to the public - the foundations of the old city hall. 90 minutes. Dane, a history graduate, was a terrific, informative and amusing guide. We went back a bit later in the day to have a look at some of the artefacts and Dane generously came down and effectively gave us a bit of a private tour for the best part of an hour. Wonderful!

reviews.title: Interesting but not fantastic
reviews.text: Only did this museum because we had the Bergen Card. Otherwise entrance is 100Nkr. It’s interesting but not fantastic. Very quickly seen, as there isn’t much to see! Nice clean toilets.

reviews.title: A complete waste of money for an incomplete museum
reviews.text:
We paid NOK100 each to see this museum. We didn’t have a lot of time and asked if we would be able to see the museum in an hour, to which the reply was, “Yes”. It actually took us 18 minutes to see it all!  What we were not told was that the museum was being renovated and therefore only the basement was open.  So all of the exhibits were in the basement, as the rest of the floors were off limits. None of the exhibits was labelled and thus we had no idea what we were looking at. There was a typed brochure which was meant to explain what everything was, but it didn’t really help. For instance, there was a skeleton in the exhibition, labelled "skeleton" in the brochure - which was completely unhelpful. 

We have just noticed that the museum had been closed due to renovation between Sept 2018 and May 2019. I think it should still be closed. We were not warned that most of the museum was closed in advance of purchasing our ticket and feel rather cheated. The least they should have done was vastly reduce the entrance price so that it reflects what is actually available to see.  We were told it would be fully open in Sept 2019. So don't waste your time or money going before then.

reviews.title: Superb!
reviews.text:
We visited this museum as part of a walking tour of Bryggen and whilst we walked through the buildings and alleyways on the tour it was only through the museum that the place came alive.

The museum houses artefacts which demonstrate how the original traders lived and worked there and exposes the very basic conditions they endured.

Essential to visit whilst in Bergen but do it as part of a walking tour to gain the most benefit and understanding.

reviews.title: Visit the museums in Bergen- Bryggen!
reviews.text:
Visit the Byggen museum to understand how Bergen became such an important city in Norway. It was one of the main Hansa Ports in Europe from 1300 as it had access to fish and the dried cod from Lofoten. Guided tour in many languages walks you around the area to understand the Hansa period and development of Bergen. 

The Fish museum has a wonderful cafe and restaurant right on the water -a bus stop away or walk.

reviews.title: Expensive and incomplete
reviews.text: This museum should be excellent some day. When we visited they were behind schedule with new displays but had opened. We found not only incomplete access but a lack of labelling and yet they were charging full entrance for this experience. Shame on you! Reduce your entry costs until you have fully opened. Be honest.

reviews.title: Walking tour very informative
reviews.text: The walking tour began in the museum, and then we could return to the museum afterwards to explore more. Our tour guide was excellent, clearly  explaining about medieval  Bryggen and its many incarnations. The museum itself has a wonderful collection, but is not well explained. You have to interpret a lot for yourself. But it has a great collection of archaeological finds from Bryggen.

reviews.title: Walking tour and museum
reviews.text:
Walking tour didn’t take to long but really informative and both my wife and I enjoyed it. Walking around Bryggen and being told the history was better than just seeing it on your own. Museum was included in cost and again it wasn’t to long but gave you enough of an idea to know what life must have been like. 

So glad we got to do this and hope they continue to preserve the area.

reviews.title: Museum closed at the moment!
reviews.text: We were disappointed to discover that this museum is closed for renovation at the moment, and there doesn't seem to be any other place in Bergen showing any of their exhibits.

reviews.title: A tiny treaure
reviews.text: The Bryggens Museum is located at the end of, and slightly behind, the Bryggen (wharf). It chronicles the time when Bergen was part of the Hanseatic League. It is built around and over foundations and walls that were uncovered when excavations were undertaken for a new church. The upper floor has a small gallery of Norwegian art with a sampling from the last 500 years.

reviews.title: Very average
reviews.text: The museum generally focusses on the architectural history of Bergen but the exhibits are limited and there is not a great deal of detail behind it. The temporary exhibition of paintings was okay but all of the information plaques were in Norwegian. Not really worth the effort.

reviews.title: Small but fascinating
reviews.text: Interesting archaeological displays plus a display of Norwegian artists' works. There were lockers in which to store coats etc but you will need coins.

reviews.title: Another closed attraction in Bergen
reviews.text: Another walk in the rain & wind to a closed attraction. Apparently they anticipate reopening in 6 years. If we hadn't wasted our time going to check out closed attractions we could have actually took advantage of the Bergen card before 3 pm closing times.

reviews.title: Average Museum, Very Dated
reviews.text: The Bryggens Museum, one of many in Bergen, is fine for a brief visit. Much of the information and artifact cards are in Norwegian only, which is a problem for the non-Norwegian speaker. TV/Video screens weren't working,and many plaques were missing. This museum was built probably in the late 1970s, but hasn't really been updated. For a more unique look into the history of Bergen, there are other museums like the Hanseatic that do a better job showing the old city.

reviews.title: A Very Thoughtful Step Back Into History
reviews.text: Similar in many ways to the equally wonderful Tenement Museum in New York City, the Bryggens Museum is a must-see for anyone interested in life in Hanseatic Bergen.  That may sound like a pretty obscure/dry thing to be interested in, but it is not.  Take the guided tour (you've paid for it anyway, but it really is very helpful) for important insight into the time and culture of old Bryggens.

reviews.title: Tiny But Packed With Information!
reviews.text: Call it the anthropologist in me, but I enjoyed the fact that this museum was built over the ruins discovered during earlier anticipated renovations. The collection is quite small, but well presented. More English translations would be welcome. We also very much enjoyed our 1.5 hour Bryggens Museum walking tour on 9/2/18, with a high level overview of the history of this unique area. Recommended!

reviews.title: Nice museum, expected to be bigger
reviews.text: The basement tells about the Hanse and is very informative, with many artifacts. The upper floor shows Norwegian Art. Looking at the size of the building, I expected more exhibits. Tip: take the Bryggen tour which starts from here and also goes into the historic area.

reviews.title: rude staff
reviews.text: The girl at the reservation desk was a very dour individual who seemed rather put out to answer our questions.because of this we did not spend our money to see their museum.

reviews.title: Excellent history, very special exhibits
reviews.text: The history museum on the bottom level is excellent, tons of artifacts, lots to learn and see. There were 2 special exhibits on the top levels when we were there that I really enjoyed - an art exhibit that was a great follow up to the Oslo National museum, and an exhibit about Frithjof Saelen, who was a norwegian resistance fighter in WW2 and a cartoonist. I bought a copy of Snorri the Seal because I found it so interesting.

reviews.title: Skulls and Weapons from True Battles
reviews.text: Great Musuem!  A real insight to life over 1000 years ago, and battles.  Take several days and really visit everything in Bryggen (Old Bergen).  Fantastic history of  a country of brave and hearty people!

reviews.title: Helpful in Understanding Bergen History
reviews.text: The guided Bryggens Walking Tour was highly recommended by Rick Steves, so we booked in advance for 12:00 tour in July.  The guide was extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic.  We immediately followed that with the Bergen in the Middle Ages tour also through Bymuseet which we had booked in advance (not necessary).  We were the only 2 booked on the tour and we had the same excellent guide as the Bryggens Tour.  Doing 3 hrs total of walking tours was too much for me.  So many choices in Bergen, unless you are really into medieval history, I suggest the Bryggens tour as #1 with the Middle Ages tour as a Plan B if the weather is poor.

reviews.title: Excellent small museum in the Bryggen area
reviews.text: We did the Bryggen Museum walking tour which included three museums (this one, the Schoetstuen (meeting house) and the Hanseatic museum), and then went back and visited all three again.  Well displayed artefacts with a good English explanation in most cases - the guide highlighted everything as well.

reviews.title: Nice museum
reviews.text: More Hanseatic things and some Medieval things.  Excavation and a walking tour makes it worth it.  Then there is a lot to see.  Next to St Mary's church we almost missed it because we thought it was church related.  Used our wonderful Bergen card, thank you Bergen!

name: Farmers Market Bergen
ranking_subcategory: #41 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #41 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #41 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: Farmers market in Bergen centre, twice per month on Saturdays. At the market, you can purchase various local food directly from producers. The offering various per season but generally consists of cheese, ecological meats, fish, game, bread and pastries, honey, fruit and vegetables.

reviews.title: Wish we were hungry
reviews.text: We just walked around as we were too full from our breakfast in our hotel. What a shame as everything looked amazing. Hopefully we will be back and hungry next time.

reviews.title: Great spot for seafood lovers
reviews.text: Wow! Seafood of every description, eat there or takeaway. Competing stalls allow for comparison of prices. A must do visit in Bergen.

reviews.title: Foodies paradise
reviews.text: We were lucky enough to be here when farmers market was on. Oh my - i died and went to foodie heaven especially the cakes & slices! There was multiple laps up & down the hotel staircase in the evening! Reindeer burger was great too. Money well spent!

reviews.title: Wonderful outdoor market
reviews.text: Great outdoor market with friendly vendors to help with seafood purchases....can get a real taste of the local dishes. Also has restaurants and pubs nearby if you prefer to sit down for lunch or enjoy a drink to cool off.

name: Festplassen

photo.caption: Theater at the top of the park

ranking_subcategory: #47 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #47 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #47 of 110 things to do in Bergen

address_obj.street1: Festplassen entre Olav Kyres Gate e Christies Gate

address: Festplassen entre Olav Kyres Gate e Christies Gate, Bergen Norway

offer_list.title: City Sightseeing Bergen Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour

reviews.title: Possibly nicer in summer
reviews.text: It's an OK square with some nice views, but I wouldn't say it's a must to see. It possibly looks nicer during summer when there are flowers around.

reviews.title: Interesting area to stroll around
reviews.text:
This large paved area is located at the top of Byparken, the City Park and Lille Lungegardsvann lake in the heart of Bergen.

It is where the statue of Christian Michelsen is sited, a local and national politician. As Prime Minister, Michelsen directed the peaceful resolution of the union with Sweden in 1905 

It has many uses including the May 17th celebration( Norwegian Constitution Day), also fun fairs, amusement parks, feast days and festivals.

It is interesting place to stroll around.

name: Bergen Public Library
ranking_subcategory: #30 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #30 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #30 of 110 things to do in Bergen

reviews.title: The heart of Bergen if you love books or music, or even 3D printing
reviews.text: The library has books in Norwegian and English, plus so many other languages downstairs in the reading area. The music section loans instruments. The Verkstedet has a 3D printer. You can borrow digital books, too.

reviews.title: Old library
reviews.text: Bergen central train station and the library were built in one style. I diddn`t visit library. I just made photos from outside

name: St. Mary's Church
ranking_subcategory: #24 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #24 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #24 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: This early 12-century church is a wonderful example of Romanesque architecture.

offer_list.title: Walking tour: Medieval Spirit of Bergen

reviews.title: WORTHWHILE RENOVATIONS
reviews.text: Bergen’s oldest structure dates from the 12th c. You are struck by its solid stone columns. It has little decor, reflecting a medieval church. The triptych is beautiful, in leaf gold. Stay in the church long enough and you will feel the coolness due to the stone. The pulpit is striking, looking very solidly built. One annoying feature is an admission charge [75 krones] and a prohibition on photography. I can understand no flash photography but the combination will limit tourists for one reason or the other. You do get a pamphlet.

reviews.title: Small Pretty Church
reviews.text: You will need to pay to go inside. A small cemetery along side the church. The church dates to the 12th century but has burnt down several times. The latest renovation was completed in 2013. It is pretty inside.

reviews.title: Very quickly seen
reviews.text: Expensive. Only saw it because we had the Bergen Card, so it was free. Otherwise it costs 100Nkr! Quite a good history about the church, which was in german hands until the late 1800’s. No cameras allowed!

reviews.title: A small pretty church
reviews.text: Just at the end of Bryggen, was small, a fee to get in, about 75NOK. A small cemetary in the grounds too.

reviews.title: Important church but wants to have its cake and eat it
reviews.text: Historically this church is so important and it’s good to get in. However having taken money for entrance you need to make some compromises. The ban on photography is unreasonable in the circumstances. Ban flash. Ban selfies. But if you want the entrance fees you have turned yourself into an attraction for tourists.

reviews.title: Miserable staff
reviews.text: Staff not welcoming at all. We were rushed round. We were on an organised trip so entrance fee paid but not worth the £7 fee.

reviews.title: Lovely but no photos allowed
reviews.text: It was next to our hotel so we paid a quick visit. Happily it is free with the Bergen card or else you pay 75 NOK for admittance. I don't like that in an active church. It's not a museum, it's a church and should be free, but that is my opinion. Anyway go to see the triptych altar and the roccoco pulpit. Both will take your breath away.

reviews.title: A spectacular 12th century church
reviews.text: This richly adorned church is truly spectacular. We were fortunate to catch an a cappella concert - eight voices of superb quality, which sounded even more superb in the excellent acoustics of the ancient church. Highly recommend a visit to the church  - but check online for opening times because it is not open every day. Also recommend a concert if you can time your visit to coincide.

reviews.title: Beautiful church
reviews.text: The interior of the church is beautiful, with many statues and paintings. The painting of the beheading of John the Baptist is quite gory. The angels carved on the pulpit were amazing. The church recently underwent a restoration, so they do charge an admission fee. Sadly, you are not allowed to take any pictures inside the church.

reviews.title: Twin towers.
reviews.text: Very impressive outside and in, but I must confess to an aversion to paying to enter a church. We would be happy to contribute of our own volition.

reviews.title: Big disappointment
reviews.text: Despite the beautiful altar, pulpit and medieval art works the NK75 entrance fee is way over the top and the whole experience ruined by the photo police aggressively shouting at people to stop taking photos.

reviews.title: Enjoyed an English language worship service here.
reviews.text: This ancient church is a real gem. It hosts an International Anglican congregational for English language services.

reviews.title: Lovely service
reviews.text: We felt really at home and welcome at your Sunday service. Pity that tourists are allowed in around service time tho. Thank you 🙂

reviews.title: Not Grand but Kind of Cool
reviews.text: I admit that I have visited too many churches during my travels and am a little jaded. But I am glad I wandered into St. Mary's in Bergen. It is not grand or awe-inspiring. But it is very interesting. In the first place, the pulpit is quite interesting and unique in Norway. It certainly does not correspond to my concepts of Lutheren Prostantism. Secondly, some of the old paintings are still hanging and some are quite interesting. I am glad I went and actually spent time looking.

reviews.title: Fee for Entrance
reviews.text: Seemed very odd that they charged a fee to look inside a church and even if you did pay the entrance fee, photos were not allowed.  We opted not to go in and just walked around the lovely outside,

reviews.title: A must during your visit
reviews.text:
An interesting place to visit, may be an hour will do it. Very near Bryggen. Renovations very evident, the pulpit is one of the most decorative that I have ever come across. 
Free entry with the Bergen Card.

reviews.title: Oldest standing building in Bergen
reviews.text: Known once as the German church up until WW2 as it was frequented by the Hanseatic league, living for a period of 400 years in the Hanseatic wharf, known as Bryggen.

reviews.title: A beautiful old church
reviews.text: Generally, I like old churches - the architecture, the art, the stained glass.  This one did not disappoint. The stonework is remarkable in its beauty, as is the woodwork and artwork on the interior (the stations of the cross are particularly notable).  You need not spend a long time here, but it is certainly worthwhile to pop in for 15 minutes to admire the craftsmanship.

reviews.title: Interesting architecture
reviews.text: Our tour was able to walk around the exterior of the church and also viewed some artifacts in another building.  The interior itself was closed.  Nevertheless this was an interesting sight.

reviews.title: Shut due to water damage
reviews.text:
We could only admire the outside of this old church as it was closed due to water damage during our visit.
It was built between 1130-1170 and recently restored. 
There are guided tours in Norwegian at 3 pm and English at 3:30 pm Monday to Friday, tickets cost approx NOK 75.

reviews.title: Historic stone church in the bryggen
reviews.text:
I have been to dozens of,old stones churches in Norway.  If you are visiting Bergen, this is a good example of a historic old church that is still in use. Recently cleaned the outside, but the inside is un touched.

Definitely worth a stop by anyone visiting Bergen.

reviews.title: Pretty Medieval Church
reviews.text: This small church is not open every day. However, on one of my days in Bergen, it was open. It reflected Norwegian Architecture dating back to the 12th century. From what I learned, it may be the oldest building in Bergen. It is definitely worth the visit.

reviews.title: Old church
reviews.text: As our tourist guide said this is the oldest stone church in the city. You have to pay entrance fee 50NOK. Sometimes concerts are held there

reviews.title: Beautiful historical art work
reviews.text: There is an admission charge for visiting this church, but it is well worth it. There are incredible centuries-old paintings and carving on view. Photography is forbidden.

reviews.title: Lovely old Church
reviews.text: This Church is the oldest building in Bergen and has been lovingly restored.  It is a beautiful example of romanesque architecture.  My only complaint is the very limited schedule of open times in the off-season, but it was worth the visit.

reviews.title: Interesting church and graveyard in its courtyard
reviews.text: Too bad it was closed when we tried to visit. We read it was renovated but it will have to be our next trip to bergen to try to see it. No explanation why it was closed, probably as we entered October already, and October in Brgen means tourist season is over.

reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.text: A beautiful and historic church in a pretty neighbourhood. Easy to visit as it is near the Bryggen and other interesting sites.

reviews.title: View From Outside
reviews.text: This is a very old church right in the heart of Bergen. I would suggest viewing it from the outside.  The inside is nothing specatular and it costs 50 NOKK to get in and no photos allowed

reviews.title: Lovely little church
reviews.text: We came here last year but there was a wedding going on so we could not see inside. This year, no wedding! The Mariankirke is a 12th century church and has a 15th century carved altarpiece and a pulpit with statues of the virtues. We were much taken by 1675 painting comparing catholicism and Protestantism. It has to do with who intercedes between the penitent and god. There is a fee to get in but you can pay by credit card and i think a visit is worth. No photos allowed.

reviews.title: Lovely church
reviews.text: The church was very beautiful. We loved spending a little time here in prayer. They have some small items for sale and a pamphlet with the history of the church in it. The staff was very kind and informative as well.

reviews.title: Disappointed
reviews.text: Outside is lovely but it was not open even though all information said it would be. Frustrating for all

reviews.title: Don't Waste Your Time
reviews.text: Little to see, no information provided, and they charge admission. Save your time and trouble, and skip the inside of this church. Happily, our Bryggen Museum walking tour guide gave us a brief history of the church from the outside; that was perfect!

reviews.title: Peaceful historic gem - but no pictures
reviews.text: This old church is a nice, peaceful place in the town. Shows the importance that the city had in history. In these days where you have almost not been at a place without at selfie taken, it is a bit peculiar, that it is forbidden to take a photos. A ban on using flash should to be enough

reviews.title: Take time for this lovely little church1
reviews.text: It's tucked away behind a large museum and it's a real treasure.  Spend a few minutes enjoying the amazing art in a quiet setting.

reviews.title: Take the Guided Tour
reviews.text: We paid $75 NOK per person for a 25 minute guided tour in English.  Well worth the price.  We learned so much about the church's history, including the art and wood carvings.  The alter piece is amazing.  There is so much detail we would have missed without a guide explaining it to us.  Highly recommend.

reviews.title: For Church Lovers Only
reviews.text:
Unless you love churches and want to help support the upkeep, it’s not worth the entrance fee.   Interior pictures on the internet have the lights on so you can really see the beauty of the restoration.  They were not on during our visit so it was very dark.  Understandably as a conservation measure, no photos can be taken.  However, even the photo cards were not worth purchasing as they were dark.  Inside the rose and flower woodcarvings are intricate and ornate.  Also, the front door ironwork 
is beautiful.  So if you need to conserve your time, an outside visit is sufficient.

reviews.title: Locked and Raining
reviews.text: We enjoyed walking the grounds and trying to read the ancient gravestones even thought the church building was locked and the rain was falling (yuck).  I was hoping to find a list of the graves in my quest to find Norwegian ancestors.

reviews.title: Oldest Church In Bergen with Original Architecture
reviews.text: Like most days in Bergen it started to rain as we approached the church which I guess is very normal for a day in Bergen. The architecture is very old church like and has a cemetery on one side. There is a cost to enter and they do not allow picture taking inside. It's quaint, has nice carvings and paintings.

reviews.title: The most ancient building in Bergen
reviews.text:
Built in 1100, this church was used exclusively by the German merchants of the Hansa. Indeed inside the church there are many paintings depicting prominent and rich merchants. The pulpit itself was donated by Lubeck merchants and is a real masterpiece with 12 small sculptures representing the virtues.
The altars features gravestones from the Middle-Ages and a precious wooden and golden panel of virgin Mary and the Apostles.
The style is norman-romanesque and very old.
50 NOK is the fee entrance. It closes at 4 pm.

reviews.title: Beautiful church
reviews.text: We walked especially to visit St Mary’s church as a typical 12th century church with some grave stones in the front. It costs 50NOK to go in and they do not allow photographs to be taken inside.

reviews.title: Still in use.
reviews.text: So I love church yards and look forward to seeing other people's tombstones only these were not in English and some were less than a hundred years old.  The church itself is still in use and a gentleman eating his lunch told me he was baptized in it 62 years ago.  The Norwegians are so friendly that we talked for 45 minutes.  The church itself is old some of its furnishings are old and it is a Catholic church because of the close proximity of the Hanseatic league.  Nice carvings, nice pulpit, nice baptismal font.

reviews.title: Baroque pulpit in simple church
reviews.text: Amazing! This old church, that has a rather simple architecture keeps a baroque secret with its pulpit. Whereas the church is of an early gothic architecture the pulpit is of an enigmatic baroqueness. Who made it? Why are the texts in German, and why are there Asian influences in it? One could sit there for several minutes and just admire, walk to it, sit back an admire again...

reviews.title: Perfect time to arrive!
reviews.text:
I didn’t realize it at the time, but arriving at the church on a Sunday afternoon was perfect. A man was taking down the “no photo” sign and closing the church for the day, but gave us a few minutes to take some photos with no charge.
Dating from the early 12th century, it is the oldest building in Bergen. It is considered one of the most outstanding Romanesque churches in the country. The pulpit is a fine example of Baroque decorative art (see photos below).

name: Rosenkrantz Tower - Bymuseet i Bergen
ranking_subcategory: #25 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #25 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #25 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: One of the most important monuments of the Renaissance. Close to Hakon’s hall lies the Rosenkrantz Tower, which is considered to be the most important Renaissance era monument in Norway. Parts of the tower are from the 1270s, but it has been built upon several times, both for defensive purposes and as a demonstration of power over the wilful Hanseatic merchants. Through dim and narrow stairways you can climb all the way to the roof, where the view over the city, the harbour and the fortress is impressive even today. On Sundays and all through the summer season one can take part in tours (for an extra NOK 20) which include both Hakonshallen and the Rosenkrantz Tower. Daily 9 until 16 from mid may-mid september.
address: Bergenhus Festning Bergenhus Fortress, Bergen 5003 Norway

offer_list.title: Bergen Shore Excursion: Bergen Walking Tour
Walking tour: Medieval Spirit of Bergen

reviews.title: Outside under Renovation, but Inside Still Worth A Visit
reviews.text: If you have trouble climbing stairs or have small children, this is not the place for you as there many narrow winding staircases that need to be climbed. You are taken back to the Medieval and Renaissance periods of history of Bergen, when there were battles between nations for control of commerce. Inside the rooms, there are sheets explaining for what the rooms were used in various languages. Try to find the old "toilet" room as it is hidden around a corner. In the rooms, there are costumes or dress up things for children and adults to use to give it a more personal feel of what it was like in those days.

reviews.title: 16th Century tower
reviews.text: Actual tower had scaffolding and covered as renovation work is under way. You can go inside, pay to enter the tower.  King once lived at the site now you can explore the rooms and tunnels.

reviews.title: Fun inside
reviews.text: Costs 100Nkr entrance. Bergen card holders are free. A lot of fun for adults or  if you’re with kids. Under renovation 2019 so I would hope it will be a better attraction in the future. Lots of rooms and tunnels to explore. Easy use an hour here and good exercise too! Areas around here are military. Good views from the walls of the fortress. Toilets are free and reasonably clean.

reviews.title: Medieval
reviews.text: A very medieval building, prominent on the city skyline and worth a visit to see some history in this lovely city.

reviews.title: Worth the visit
reviews.text: We went on our own to the Rosenkrantz Tower. A guided tour would have been better, but we all the exhibits were in English, so we still had a good visit. The interior is much bigger than the name suggests; it is much more than just a tower.

reviews.title: Music Fest local
reviews.text: Could not tour too much of this as the Musical Festival was going on but it was a fascinating place and had been fairly well restored.

reviews.title: Ah Shakespeare
reviews.text: You walk to the water and then across a path to the tower.  You get to see the famous tower.  Okay for the Shakespeare fans.  Nearby museums are terrific.

reviews.title: Dungeons and skeletons - marvellous scariness
reviews.text: I visited the Rosenkranztower (Bergen) with a grandson of 8.  The first part of the tower was built in the 1200’s, but was completed in the 1500’s. There are royal bedrooms (and the royal loo!), but most wonderful for the 8year old: the spooky staircases and dungeons! Complete with a skeleton!

reviews.title: Time Travelers
reviews.text: Exploring this tower was one of the most interesting experiences.  You are walking the same halls and stair cases that have been used for hundreds of years - you need to stoop to get through most of the doorways and the halls are so narrow that most professional athletes would likely get stuck.  I loved almost every second of it.  The moments I did not like were only a couple of occasions when there were cutout-style images of people in a space - I found it very startling and jarred me out of my time-travel experience.  But it was easy to get back into it because the place just oozes history.  Love that there are items you can handle and try on in some of the rooms and written information (in a number of languages) in others.  I could have spent quite a bit of time in there, just soaking it up and imagining what the walls would say if they could talk.

reviews.title: scandinavia
reviews.text: we happened upon this place while walking to go to the resistance museum -- Elton John's concert was right next door.  you don't go in anywhere but you can tell it was imposing in it's day.  If you're from the midwest they have a Pasty shop inside.

reviews.title: Lots of stairs but very interesting.
reviews.text: There weren't any English information booklets available during our visit but there were still information sheets on the walls in each room. There were lots of steep narrow stairs to climb so this attraction is not suitable for anyone with mobility issues.

reviews.title: Under renovations, but grounds are worthwhile
reviews.text:
While the tower is under renovation, the surrounding fort and grounds are open and well worth a visit.
A little irregular underfoot in parts.
Views over the harbour are wonderful

reviews.title: Worth the Visit
reviews.text:
Visited the tower. The outside was undergoing renovations. Still it was worth the trip.
We got a guided tour so we could visit Haakons Hall.

Tour guide was very informative.

The tower is very old and has many winding spiral staircases.

It is quite the workout to climb to all the rooms. If you are very overweight or large, you will get stuck in the passageways as they are very narrow.

Also this tower is not recommended for people with trouble walking a lot of uneven stairs and passageways.

Some rooms were empty but then I like the architecture and character of old medieval buildings the most. 

Was worth the visit.

reviews.title: Interesting tower full of winding and spiral staircases
reviews.text: As others have noted, the tower is undergoing renovations so there is nothing to see on the outside save the plastic sheeting and scaffolding. The inside was open however and provided a interesting self-guided tour of multiple rooms on multiple levels (including the damp claustrophobic dungeon) connected by winding and/or spiral staircases. Many rooms were mostly empty but there were signs in many explaining what the rooms were used for. Rosenkrantz Tower is worth a visit but don’t expect much of a wow factor. We bought the combo ticket which also provided access to Håkons Hall.

reviews.title: Wait for the renovations to be over
reviews.text: I hate to write a mediocre review of an attraction due to renovations, but this was disappointing because of the scaffolding and how little there was to see. I recommend keeping this in mind if you visit during the renovations. Additionally, many of the rooms I saw had nothing in them. They need to update the signs (bigger, clearer fonts) inside the rooms, for the dim lighting conditions and older peoples' eyesight.

reviews.title: Important, interesting, but a bit rough
reviews.text:
The Rosenkrantz Tower was clearly an important structure through much of Bergen’s history and you can get a good understanding of its changing structure, use and importance via a tour.  It does not have the extensive displays of historic armor, weapons, furniture, furnishings and implements that you might find in some other European castles.  Some of the rooms are nearly bare spaces.  Nearly all of the windows were boarded up when we visited, making the rooms dark, if not claustrophobic.  However, extensive work is being done, so that may very well be temporary.  
The historical presentations that were provided were interesting, particularly the ones on a witch trial and a major battle during the Anglo-Dutch wars.  Stairways are steep, narrow and winding, so anyone with mobility issues should be aware of that.

reviews.title: Renovation work being carried out
reviews.text: Unfortunately with the renovation work being carried out it was not possible to go inside the tower which was covered in scaffolding,there is what appears to be a court yard that was open and also the grounds are both worth a visit

reviews.title: Ancient Tower
reviews.text: A very photogenic and iconic spot in the old town.  This tower is on the horizon and we saw it as we wandered around from our cruise ship.

reviews.title: Fun to see really old tower
reviews.text: I enjoy viewing really old castles and towers and such, and this was no exception.  There are also some great pictures to be had afterwards at the hilltops with colorful houses.

reviews.title: Currently covered with plastic
reviews.text: Staff were helpful and informative at the tower. There is an excellent model that showed the extent of the damage caused when a German ship exploded in the harbour just outside the tower in 1944. There were informative displays throuthouset but because of the renovation work you can’t access the roof.

reviews.title: Not open at the moment!
reviews.text: We were disappointed to find that this isn't open at the moment due to renovation work. Also, you can't see the exterior because of scaffolding.

reviews.title: Iconic Tower
reviews.text: A very attractive tower that makes part of this city's modest sky line, so you see it off in the distance.  Stop by and take a photo.

reviews.title: Fun Castle Tour with lots of dress up.
reviews.text: A nice bit of Norwegian History, really interesting to walk around the tower. Not a very clear order to do it all in but was enjoyable to stop off in whatever room you passed on the stairs. Lots of fun to dress up in lots of old outfits and with the armour and weapons!

reviews.title: Looked good from outside but was closed!!
reviews.text: When I visited this place in November, it was closed for some renovation work so couldn't go inside. However, we visited the other parts of the fortress which were very good and well kept.

reviews.title: Fascinating!
reviews.text: The tower was the only part of this site that was open when we visited due to repairs. Totally worth the visit and price of admission - a glimpse into medieval history of Bergen. It was fun to snake through the stairwells of the tower and reach the different levels/rooms for each well-documented part of the structure. The museum really “tells a story.”

reviews.title: A self-guided tour of history.
reviews.text: We really enjoyed our visit to Rosenkrantz Tower, in spite of the construction/maintenance going on outside during our visit.  We found this place fascinating and had a great time visiting the various rooms, finding our way up and down the stone spiral staircases, and playing around with the equipment and weapons left in some of the exhibit areas. We visited in early November 2018 while exterior maintenance was happening, so some windows were blocked, but it was also a rainy day, so this was a welcome respite from outdoor activities.

reviews.title: The feel of Old Bergen.....
reviews.text: This building was being restored when we visited, but you still received the feel of its history and its place in the history of Bergen/Norway. It is not handicap accessible and involves many steps...caution to those with mobility issues.

reviews.title: Interesting history
reviews.text: This takes at least 30 min to get through, probably longer in peak tourist times.  Well worth a stop if you like history.  It's an interesting maze of rooms and has plenty of information.

reviews.title: Until Renovations are over-skip this
reviews.text: The grounds around the Tower were very nice. The inside does not have much to offer and you can't get up to the roof for a view, due to reconstruction.

reviews.title: Interesting maze
reviews.text: Facade is under reconstruction but you can visit the tower. Narrow spiral stairs mean you have to bi fit and watch your head all the time. Arrows in the tower are not positioned precisely so sooner or later you will have no idea where you are and how to get out. However, exibits in the rooms are few and not so interesting.

reviews.title: Lots of stairs provides access to the tower
reviews.text: Part of Bergen's core history. The tower provides an inside into the medieval past. The cold heavy rain outside provided the right context for to visit to this stark stone building. Very informative.

reviews.title: a maze inside
reviews.text: The entire outside was being worked on mid-September 2018; because of this we could not go outside for the great view everyone talks about.  This place has a ton of rooms and it's like a maze inside - it's easy to get turned around and miss things.  We both found it interesting, not great.  We spent about 45 minutes inside.

reviews.title: Love those spiral staircases!
reviews.text: Under cover of scaffolding, we almost walked past it! Once inside (and allowing the school group ahead of us!) it was a fascinating place. Some of the staircases were a bit of a tight climb - they definitely must have been tiny people way back then! - but taken at a careful pace they were fine. Some of the rooms felt a bit lacklustre but that’s just me as I love a good ruin and don’t go much in for reconstructed stuff. Helpful, friendly staff - thank you!

reviews.title: Very interesting site
reviews.text: This site is effectively a museum these days offering an insight into the fortress' role across the centuries. Surely the most interesting is the stories of the English siege of the Dutch in the port of Bergen and the resulting battle that directly involved the fortress.

reviews.title: Under construction
reviews.text: Our young daughter enjoyed exploring the tower. We loved the history and enjoyed walking up each level of the tower.

reviews.title: Not for faint hearted
reviews.text: It is well worth a visit but beware there are lots of steep narrow spiral staircases. Interesting  info on witches

reviews.title: Currently being renovated
reviews.text: When I visited, there was scaffolding all around the tower, so could not really see it well. You can go inside and walk up through the rooms which are explained. However, there is not that much to see.

reviews.title: o.k.
reviews.text: o.k. if you have extra time in Bergen,otherwise I would skip it.Also the stairs are rather steep if you have mobility issues.

reviews.title: Unique unassuming medieval history
reviews.text: This would be fun for families with young kids.  Walk north past the Bryggen Waterfront (essentially, a shopping mall) to the stone tower, and you'll find a fun interesting historic site.   After walking through the gates, head to the small doorway on your left to get a ticket for the tower.     You'll be meandering the stairs on the outside of the tower, passing the various rooms  - each with their own story.   Some are empty with just a description of how the room was used, while others have sparse objects to see/touch that emphasize the storyline.    For example, it's fun to try on the armor and see how heavy it really is.  But the surprise and story ending is up at the top when discover a richly detailed room describing key events in the Rosenkrantz history.

reviews.title: A Family Favorite in Bergen
reviews.text: Our family with teens loved Rosenkranztz Tower. The history is fascinating and the twists and turns of the narrow spiral staircases added to its intrigue.  We spent about an hour winding through the rooms, learning about the castle's inhabitants.  Highly recommend.

reviews.title: Part of a cluster
reviews.text: Of Renaissance and Medieval buildings restored and maintained.  Nice armor display.  Great views to the city and out to the fjord.  Stairs, what more can I say Medieval stairs.

name: The Royal Residence (Gamlehaugen)
ranking_subcategory: #32 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #32 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #32 of 110 things to do in Bergen

offer_list.title: Biking Tour and Grieg Concert in Bergen

reviews.title: Very nice
reviews.text: I was there on my first day in Norway. And it was absolutely nice. It’s a very clean  place and there’s everything you need to start your Norway journey. The castle looks wonderful and the garden is very nice. I was there for about 1 and half hour walking through the garden and sit at the sea calming down after the long flight from Germany.  Right after I decided to walk to Troldhaugen. It’s about 4 km to go and it took about 1 hour. It’s a easy walk just the last few meters up to Troldhaugen are a little bit harder (comparing to the rest) If you’re having enough time I’ll recommend to do this walk. I saw so wonderful landscapes just by waking from one village to an other.

name: Bergenhus Festningsmuesum
ranking_subcategory: #16 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #16 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #16 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: The Military Museum in Bergen and the Western part of Norway. Free entrance and facilitated for disabled people. Exhibitions: The Resistance Movement in and around Bergen 1940-1945 Newspapers in Bergen / The Underground Press 1940-1945 The history of Bergenhus Fortress Women's Contribution to the Armed Forces Norwegian Forces abroad (peacekeeping operations etc.) Enigma

reviews.title: Excellent quality presentations about a sensitive subject & it's free
reviews.text: Fellow travelers recommended this 'Resistance museum' to us and we saved it for a rainy day. The curation is excellent and the English translation assistance is good. We usually avoid museums but are really pleased we sheltered here from the rain and viewed the exhibitions which cover much more than World War 2 which is still something of a sensitive topic in some countries but here was professionally explained complete with primary documents & items. I was especially interested in the exhibits on the Norwegian peace keeping role while my companion took lots of photos of the historic military uniform displays. Not only is entry free but there is also a free toilet & we could have stayed for a cup of tea but the rain had stopped so we moved on.

reviews.title: Excellent Museum for No Cost
reviews.text:
This museum is well worth the walk to the end of the Bryggen area.  It had the best displays and in-depth information both historically about Bergen and the wartime history from centuries back, including clothes.  The Resistance Museum is ne of the best we have seen to date.  The older students were there learning about their history and listening to lectures.  It is a very important part of the history of Bergen and Norway.  The written, audio and artifact history it provides is a trove of information of historical importance.

Well worth the walk and allow yourself up to two hours to read and explore everything.

reviews.title: Unless You Read Norwegian, Skip this One
reviews.text: There were some interesting artifacts, but you could not understand what they were without knowing Norwegian. What would it take to translate the captions?

reviews.title: An Interesting Museum
reviews.text: Of particular interest is the history of the Resistance movement in Norway during WW2.  I knew very little about Norwegian history in general and about its involvement in WW2 specifically.   It's a small museum, but took us about an hour to complete.

reviews.title: Charming free museum
reviews.text:
Excellent free museum detailing some of Norway's military history, especially under Nazi occupation in WWII. 

Welcoming and helpful staff who was able to provide a lot of extra information. All exhibits have multiple language translations and are well laid-out. 

Free tea and coffee to top it off!

reviews.title: Great small museum for history buffs
reviews.text:
My husband loves military history. I do not.  However, I like stories about people. This small museum, run in large part by volunteers, fit the bill perfectly for the two of us, as it tells the story of the Norwegian people and the resistance to German occupation.  The museum guides you through the story by following storyboards complete with artifacts. There are no reproductions here - just what survived the war.  
The volunteer was helpful and it was truly a joy to go through something that he was obviously quite proud of.
As museums go, I have a one to two hour maximum attention span. We got through in about an hour, and I read just about everything, and left satisfied that I had learned something.
Admission is free and it was a very worthwhile use of our time.

reviews.title: Love military history, love here
reviews.text: If you love military history you should leave time for this. Very well presented and available with notes only in four languages. Set over three floors there is also a small cafe. Not only covers the WW2 era and resistance but also shows Norway’s contribution to NATO over the recent decades.

reviews.title: Very informative
reviews.text: Free admission to this museum (free tea and coffee too!). Very interesting museum. For each section, there is a pamphlet of information. Pick one up as you enter each section for additional explanations and information. Warning: this museum may cause information overload! I headed over to Rosenkrantz Tower and Hakaan's Hall after doing this museum (they're in the fortress grounds).

reviews.title: in memory of the World War II resistance movement
reviews.text: This is an incredible museum, with exhibitions that include women's contributions to the Norwegian Armed Forces, the resistance movement in and around Bergen 1940-45, the underground press 1940-45, etc. I was particularly interested in the history of the resistance movement, which is presented through photographs, weapons, espionage equipment,sabotage material, film footage,and interviews. This exhibition, which opened in 2006, does honour to the many brave Norwegians who fought back in any way possible against the German occupation force. Don't miss this!

reviews.title: Not to be missed.....
reviews.text:
This museum to the WWII resistance movement is outstanding. It is focused on the underground units in the Bergen area...the Oslo Resistance Museum has a different focus and is also very good.
This display provides numerous examples of the dedication, ingenuity and risk taken by members of the resistance. It also describes the various political elements that made up the resistance. It is stunning to see pictures of Bergen from this time when it was occupied by the Nazi powers. After learning of the sacrifices made my numerous persons and the tortures received at the hands of the SS and Gestapo it was somewhat comforting to know that many of the Nazi perpetrators were executed just outside of this museum. 
Displays have Norwegian and English descriptions.

reviews.title: Excellent Museum if you are interested WWII
reviews.text: We missed the Resistance Museum in Oslo. This museum is self guided with excellent timeline of the invasion to liberation during WWII. Excellent displays and it is all free! You can spend 20 minutes or 2+ hours like we did.

reviews.title: Worth A Visit..
reviews.text: My husband and I visited the museum and were surprised how long we stayed. While there are a number of exhibits for different historical topics I really enjoyed the Norwegian resistance museum on the 1st floor. There are booklets available for each exhibit in various languages and these are worthwhile taking for more in depth information.

reviews.title: Another spot to see in Bergen Festing
reviews.text: This museum you can visit for free and once you are at the castle consider visiting it too. It is run by the Norwegian military, their officer will wait at the entrance (speaks excellent English and also engaged in conversation in French) and shows military history, including naval battle against English fleet (an interesting story how leaders of democracy were trying to loot somebody elses wealt, in agreement with Norwegian king but due to poor communication deal went wrong and turned into battle). Also you will learn about the resistence movement in Bergen in WWII and how 240-250 members of resistence were arrested by ocupation forces after a treason. Separate exhibition shows photos on numerous peace mission of Norwegian army in modern times, including in my country, Bosnia and Herzegovina, unfortunately ths exhibition has only Norwegian text. You are also kindly invited to have tea or coffe for free in their cafeteria which we gladly accepted and refreshed ourself after seeing the museum. You can also take a peak in one of the books from museum related topics from their library in cafeteria.

reviews.title: Great place with lovely people running it
reviews.text:
Came here because we had a few hours to kill, it was raining pretty hard outside, and the reviews said it was nice enough. Plus, it's free. We were greeted warmly and supplied with booklets containing extensive translations which covered pretty much all of the displays. We were also welcome to stay in the cafe as long as we liked with coffee and a selection of teas, all completely free.

The exhibits are very interesting and insightful. They contain everything from uniforms and weaponry to written first hand accounts an newspapers. I especially liked the display dedicated to the secret press.

Overall, definitely worth a visit if you're at all interested in the subject.

reviews.title: Worth a visit if you’re interested in military history.
reviews.text: Really good exhibit over 3 floors. Friendly and helpful staff and free of charge. Parking outside. Check for opening times before going if you’re off season. Has the history of the fortress, Bergen during WW2 and then the more recent activity of the Norwegian Armed Forces who still have staff based in the fortress.

reviews.title: If you are a WWII History Buff, then this is the Place for you!
reviews.text: There is a lot of Norwegian military history packed into this little museum with the most fascinating being a detailed, chronological  history of the Nazi occupation of Norway in WWII.  It is told with story-boards, photos, first-hand written accounts and military artifacts, including some weapons.  It tells the story of a nation surprised by the initial attack and then subjugated by the ruthless, brutal suppression of the Resistance.  Overall, the details of this struggle  are little known history outside of Norway.  My wife and I were very impressed with the information and how it was presented.  I pride myself on my knowledge of WWII but I learned a lot at this museum and it was fascinating.  If you are a WWII History Buff, this is a must place to go in Bergen.

reviews.title: Good specialist museum
reviews.text: Location in the center of Bergen - easy access. The museum shows well life in Bergen during the second world war. Interesting topic was the part which shows the resistance forces during the war. More info in English will be great.

reviews.title: Very  interesting
reviews.text: Shared the history over the last 300 years, especially resistance during the war and involvement since. Even offered free coffee after

reviews.title: Great info on Norwegian Military and WWII history
reviews.text: After visiting Haakon's Hall, we decided to enter this museum nearby as rainy day.  Start with very good top exhibit on Norwegian wars and military attire including info on the various fortresses built. The middle floor though took up most of our time as shows pictures of the principal characters in WWII Bergen and discusses their fates; fascinating.  The visit is free, and even has free coffee and place to leave coats and umbrellas.

reviews.title: Hidden gem
reviews.text: This museum is free and about the Second World War and the history of the fortress. The exhibits are not labelled in English but there are leaflets in English that explain them.

reviews.title: It's A Military Museum Starting off in 1100, But the 2nd WW Resistance is a Main Topic
reviews.text: When we first walked in we were greeted by a nice gentleman who was in the Norwegian military and was stationed in Washington and Maryland working with the USA. The museum is free as is coffee.tea and a few goodies which was very nice. The museum briefly exhibits the beginning of the Norwegian military, but focuses on Enigma, The history of Bergenhus Fortress, Women's contribution to the Norwegian armed forces, Newspapers in Bergen during the wartime, The underground press 1940-1945, Norwegian forces abroad,&mainly on The resistance movement in and around Bergen 1940-1945. It also showed how cruel the Nazi party was to the Norwegian resistance. It's important to point out the British and the USA forces might not have been able to win the war when the did with out the resistance. we all need to work together and pull on the same side of the rope. Found this all very fascinating. The rest of the fortress was closed due to a annual music festival. There is English books and most displays have English too.

name: Bybanen

photo.caption: Kjempegod og effektiv forbindelse mellom flyplass og sentrum!

ranking_subcategory: #40 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #40 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #40 of 110 things to do in Bergen

reviews.title: Seats a little to hard when taking the full trip.
reviews.text: As we are about to have a similar light railway where we live we had to try this one out when going to the airport. It was a good experience although the bus makes the tour more directly in only twenty minutes against 45. However, the trip is a bit of a sightseeing tour where you mix with the locals too.

reviews.title: So slow
reviews.text:
It take me longer time to travel with bybanen from Bergen center to the airport, than it takes me to fly from Sandefjord or Oslo to Bergen. This flight takes med 40 minutes, Bybanen use 1 hour!
BUT, if you don't have any rush it is very nice trip and cheap. It cost me more to drive from the airport to citycenter, park my car and then drive back later. Oneway ticket cost only 38,- NOK and the ticket is also valid on the local bus in this region. Ticket is valid for 1,5 hours.

reviews.title: Practical and efficient
reviews.text: The Bybanen is very practical when arriving at Bergen airport if your final destination is located close to one of the stops on the route. It’s quite new, and thereby clean and in good condition. Frequent departures is also a big plus.

reviews.title: Clearer instructions, please!
reviews.text:
First of all, we love public transportation. We have used it all over Europe and the US. It is always easy to understand, and the instructions are usually quite clear. Even in France (where they refuse to have alternative languages) we were able to muddle through the process. (We also speak Spanish and German, so that might help). So, we arrived here late at night, trains were running every 15 minutes, and the price was right (about $10 for the two of us). The ticket station even had an English option. Perfect!  But then we tried to use it. Quite confusing, especially when we just wanted to go to the end of line at downtown, a few minute walk to our hotel. Instructions started off in English, then suddenly went to Norwegian. We were lost, and could not find the NOK 38 option anywhere, as the advertised price shown next to the ticket terminal. We tried it a half a dozen times, with the same confusing results. Maybe we were tired, or pressed a wrong button, but we eventually gave up as a train came and went.  We walked across the road and hired a $86 taxi. Good payday for him, not so good for us. 
So, this review is a long-winded way of pleading for better instructions for the tired international tourists arriving into your beautiful city!

reviews.title: Tram
reviews.text: You can take this tram to the airport and buy a ticket from one of the machines at every stop. The cost is NOK 38 per adult, which is much less than the bus to the airport, not mentioning the taxis. Plus you can still enjoy the views on the way.

reviews.title: Best way from and to the airport
reviews.text: Running every 5 minutes during the day or 10 in the evening, this is reasonably priced alternative to buses and taxies (single ticket one way 37 NOK i.e. 3,70 EUR). You can buy ticket on the machines at every stop and pay by credit card. It will take some 40 minutes to get to city center. Every stop is announced with different jingle. Sopts right next to the railway station and before it, at the main bus station so it is highly useful

reviews.title: Perfect for the airport
reviews.text: Very reasonably priced compared to the airport bus and it does not take much longer.  In fact the day that I travelled there was quite a bit of congestion on the roads and as the tram is mostly on dedicated tracks it was perfectly on time.  Easy to buy tickets either with a card or as I did with coins as a away of using up some of them but do make sure that you validate the ticket.  I had to watch someone else as I got it wrong.  Regular and very well used service.  Stop about 4 minutes walk from my hotel too so ideal.

name: Haakon's Hall - Bymuseet i Bergen
ranking_subcategory: #33 of 110 things to do in Bergen
subcategory_ranking: #33 of 110 things to do in Bergen
ranking: #33 of 110 things to do in Bergen
description: A stone hall worthy of a king Hakonshallen is more than seven hundred and fifty years old, and was built by King Hakon Hakonsson between 1247 and 1261 as a royal residence and feasting hall. When the king’s son Magnus Hakonsson Lagabøte married the Danish Princess Ingeborg in 1261, 2000 guests were hosted in three buildings. "Kings held court in the stone hall", as the sagas say. Hakonshallen is open most days of the year, even in the winter. On Sundays and all through the summer season one can take part in tours which include both Hakonshallen and the Rosenkrantz Tower. From mid may-mid september open daily 10 until 16. From mid september - mid may (winter) open daily 12 until 15.

offer_list.title: Walking tour: Medieval Spirit of Bergen
Bergen: Excursion with a city view from the top

reviews.title: The setting and the exterior are very fine
reviews.text:
We didn't pay the entrance fee to see inside but from the outside this is an impressive building with a real sense of history. The setting is great, inside a walled park with a quadrangle of other more modern but still delightful buildings. 

Well worth finding but I suspect from other comments and the description given by the staff that it is not worth paying the entrance fee.

reviews.title: Not Much to See
reviews.text: Haakon’s Hall is a stone structure inside a fortress from medieval times (restored several times), but really, there’s not much to see.  It’s a large, empty hall.  It was once a royal residence and feasting hall, and is used today for ceremonies and concerts.  The most impressive features of the hall were the high timbered ceilings and arched windows.  The only decorations were tapestries on the wall and a royal table at one end of the hall.  It’s an okay place to visit, but I think there are more interesting places to see in Bergen.

reviews.title: Don't waste your money
reviews.text: I love seeing architecture of days gone by, but even $11 was too much for this "museum".  There is nothing in it except chairs and tables from the 1980s.  No history, no artifacts, just an empty hall.  It's a beautiful hall, but not worth the time or money.  Seeing the outside offers more than seeing the inside.

reviews.title: Not Much to See
reviews.text: There wasn't too much to see here in my opinion.  The hall was lovely and a lot bigger than I expected, but that was about it.

reviews.title: Saw the Edvard Grief Choir Perform Here
reviews.text: A beautiful old hall that is perfectly suited for a performance.  Great acoustics and a vintage setting for a concert.

reviews.title: Restored 13th century hall
reviews.text: The impressive walls remain from the 13th century structure. The building was heavily damaged during WWII when a munitions ship exploded in the harbor. The building was restored in the 1950’s with a new roof, floors and ceilings. It’s a worthwhile visit and awe inspiring to think these walls have stood for 700+ years. You take a self-guided tour. Interesting but not many real “wows”.  We bought the combo ticket that also allows access to Rosenkrantz Tower (which we found more interesting).

reviews.title: Beautiful building
reviews.text: Well worth the visit, the main hall is beautiful. Quite a few stairs to negotiate if you have mobility issues.

reviews.title: Interesting hall spoilt by 1950 renovqtins
reviews.text: The actual hall is magnificent and the ceiling particularly so. However, I did think the 1950 renovations were out of keeping with the medieval heritage. Staff were incredibly helpful and informative.

reviews.title: Interesting Building
reviews.text: This is one of Bergen's oldest buildings  that dates back to the 13th century. Expereincing the history of any city makes my travel expereince more meaningful. This is worth the visit.

reviews.title: Enlightening
reviews.text:
A definite visit, if you are here for a day or a week.
The guides were very helpful and the history is enlightening. Interesting to visit

reviews.title: Impressive old building which is more than just a hall
reviews.text: I had expected just a hall, but there's more to it than that, and the information provided helps you to understand what you are looking at.

reviews.title: A wonder from the 1100s
reviews.text: Bergen is Norway’s second biggest city and at one time was its capital. There are several historical attractions here but Haakons Hall was my favourite because it has medieval and modern history.It was built in the 1100s as a reception hall for those who sailed into Bergen’s port to meet the then king of Norway, Haakon. When the capital was moved, the building fell into disuse but remained standing. During WW2 it was the accidental casualty when Norwegian saboteurs blew up a Nazi ship in the harbour and in 1950s it was restored to its former glory.

reviews.title: under renovations
reviews.text: The building is steeped in history, but due to renovations there isn't a great deal to see other than an ornate banqueting hall. Authentic and easy to find ... but rather pricey for what you get.

reviews.title: Nothing but a just a big fancy banquet hall!!
reviews.text: I would suggest avoiding this because for the entry fees that you pay, you don't get to see much as most of the parts are closed for renovation.

reviews.title: Grand, Historic and easy to get too
reviews.text: This ancient building sits right on the edge of the harbour keeping watch for centuries.  It is authentic, aged and wonderful. It is easy to get to and surrounded by park like setting. Very much worth the time and effort.

reviews.title: An interesting look back to 900ad, but just an OK visit
reviews.text: Although much of this is under construction, the tour of a 900ad castle and its ruins were interesting. Its expensive though, and no discount considering much of it is closed and the self-guided tour was somewhat confusing and disoriented. I'd perhaps see how far along things are before visiting. At about 20$usd i remember for entrance, its not a lot of bang for your buck.

reviews.title: History buffs rejoice
